HEADLINE: Yeltsin Goes After a Russian Religion: Vodka

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 20

 BODY:
She may not look the part, but Tamara Chernyshkova recently became one of Russia's most wanted criminals. Feeble, aged and practically blind, she is nonetheless a foot soldier in this country's most profitable illegal enterprise.
Mrs. Chernyshkova peddles bootleg vodka. Stationed outside one of this city's most heavily used subway stops, the 63-year-old former schoolteacher sells up to 100 bottles of homemade liquor each day to a clientele that would gladly buy more. 
 "I have never gone home with extra bottles," she explained as she burrowed in an old green sack for a sample of her wares. "But now the cops are after us and the bribes are getting hard to pay. Yeltsin thinks he's going to solve Russia's problems by putting us out of business. Let him try."
Desperate to wipe out Russia's $3 billion debt to its own labor force, President Boris N. Yeltsin has decided to double taxes on vodka to the equivalent of $7 a liter, to restore the state monopoly on the production and sale of the liquor, and to rein in the counterfeiters and smugglers who now account for an astonishing 70 percent of Russia's gargantuan market.
Mr. Yeltsin loves a challenge, but this may be one of his biggest. Russians don't just drink vodka, they worship it. There is no better way to judge the chaos of Russia's unruly marketplace, the porousness of its borders, the failures of its tax system, or -- most important of all -- the bleak health of its citizens, than by looking at vodka consumption.
"This bacchanalia must stop," said Anatoly B. Chubais, Mr. Yeltsin's chief of staff, who is widely assumed to have been responsible for Mr. Yeltsin's decree. "It is a political decision. We have no other choice."
That may be true, but it is hard to imagine any task more futile for a Russian leader than coming between its people and their ubiquitous drink. On advice from Lenin (one of the few teetotaling Russian leaders), Stalin thought seriously for a while about limiting vodka sales. He quickly came to his senses. When the last leader of the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, made a major effort to curb drinking in 1985, he was ridiculed as Mr. Mineral Water. To most of the world, Dmitri Mendeleyev is known as the great chemist who devised the periodic table of elements. Here, he is at least as well-known -- and far more fondly -- as the Russian who first realized that 40 percent is the best proportion of alcohol for vodka.
"This country is insane from that drink," said Galina B. Tkachenko, who is in charge of the Health Ministry's uphill effort to teach people about the dangers of alcohol. "I don't even think it's worth trying to show people over 30 what vodka is doing to them. We are mostly just trying to stop the children before they start."
In 1995, according to Health Ministry statistics, an average of 4.1 gallons of spirits were consumed by each Russian citizen, a count that includes infants and those too ill to drink at all. No country drinks more hard liquor, and it shows. Reported cases of alcohol poisoning, long an epidemic that has cut horribly into productivity, health and harmony, rose by more than 25 percent in the last year, according to the Government.
Alcohol abuse is a direct cause of what demographers and politicians regard as potentially the greatest threat facing Russia: its sharp and continuing drop in life expectancy. According to the Center for Alcohol Policy, an advocacy group here, half of adult men and nearly a third of the women suffer some physical consequences of long-term drinking. The group estimates that half of all deaths in the nation can be attributed at least partly to alcohol.
Other health researchers decline to speculate, noting that alcohol abuse is only one reason -- dietary habits, smoking, living conditions, the environment, and stress are others -- that the Russian death rate is higher than in any other industrial country.
"We don't feel comfortable throwing around hard figures," said Dr. Tkachenko, "because these things are very hard to separate. But anyone with eyes can see that drinking has for many years ruined our health and ruined our economy."
The Yeltsin Administration seems to be focusing on the financial part of this equation. In Mr. Yeltsin's tough talk about cracking down on vodka makers, health was never mentioned. There has been no talk of cutting production, only of the Government getting its fair share of taxes.
Nothing has greater potential to supply a quick fix for Russia's tax mess. The measures suggested by Mr. Yeltsin would bring in at least $350 million a month.
No matter what the shape of Russia's economy, vodka here has always been a big part of it. In 1900, its sale accounted for 50 percent of revenues for the Czar's government. By 1988 the figure had fallen to 35 percent of the Soviet budget. But today, vodka generates less than 5 percent of revenues.
Like most other branches of Russian industry, vodka distilleries were unable to react to the pressures of a free market. Famous brand names like Stolichnaya and Smirnov could not compete and were quickly trapped in battles over their valuable names (Smirnov is fighting Smirnoff, an American make) as smugglers and bootleggers stepped in to meet the nation's insatiable demands.
With people like Mrs. Chernyshkova selling millions of bottles of vodka every day at kiosks, train stations and street corners, usually for less than $2 each, the warehouses where vodka is produced illegally are working overtime. Bootleggers get two or three deliveries a day, and get to keep about a dime for every bottle they sell. Five hundred bottles a week translates into $200 a month for the seller, twice as much as the average industrial wage.
"We are well aware that vodka can be a cash cow," said Levon S. Marutyan, director of the Dolgoprudny Integrated Works, one of 85 vodka distilleries officially sanctioned in the Moscow region. "But we are nearly bankrupt. We are trying to make a quality product with the right ingredients. We are willing to pay taxes of course. But how can we compete if thousands of people with stills and oak buckets can turn out something they call vodka, put it into a bottle and sell it on any street corner?"
He can't, as a quick visit to any of Moscow's outdoor markets will show. At Davydkovo, one such market, there are dozens of kiosks selling vodka by the crate. There is pepper vodka, honey vodka and vodka with every type of fruit mixed in. There is vodka in plastic cups, ram's horns and soccer balls. Most of all, there is just plain vodka by the truckload.
"I'm getting married," said a man from Voronezh, in southern Russia, as he dragged a pallet with 200 bottles he just bought for $250 across a snow-covered lot. "You can't beat the prices."
Much of the pure alcohol in Russia today is smuggled in from Belarus and Ukraine, where border crossings are not closely monitored. It is then diluted with water and bottled here. In Russia's western Kaliningrad enclave, a free trade zone, customs officials seized more than 25 tons of pure alcohol from Europe in December alone.
"This is a true crisis for Russia," said Anatoly K. Kravchenko, the chief of the state office on production and sale of spirits. It is Mr. Kravchenko's job to regulate the struggling industry. And as he sat one recent day with five types of vodka lined up in shot glasses for a visitor to sample, he admitted that this battle would be a tough one.
"This is our national product," he said, glumly. "Can you imagine Japan struggling to produce its own rice, or France its own wine? We are fighting for our identity."

HEADLINE: The Politics of Reconciliation

 BODY:
Inaugural addresses often evoke a sense of triumph and a vision of battles to come. For lovers of such sailing rhetoric, President Clinton's address yesterday was distinctly earthbound. But it was also notable for its ennobling appeal to conciliation and what he called "a new spirit of community for a new century." The overarching theme of the entire ceremony, in fact, was of racial healing, drawing from the celebration the same day of the Rev. Martin Luther King's birthday. The selection of speakers such as the Rev. Jesse Jackson at a morning prayer service and a series of inclusive religious and musical events during the day were especially appropriate for the swearing in of Mr. Clinton and another Southerner, Vice President Gore. Dr. King's message was that Southern politicians could one day become the healers rather than promoters of what Mr. Clinton called the "constant curse" of racism in American history.
Looking beyond race, Mr. Clinton appealed for an end to partisan squabbling in Congress. That was exactly the right sentiment at a time when, paradoxically, the nation's unusual run of economic prosperity has been accompanied by rising bitterness and resentment, cutting across racial, cultural and political lines. 
 But there was also an element of strategy in Mr. Clinton's plea, which came after a week in which he called for a resolution to House Speaker Newt Gingrich's ethics case, and awarded a Medal of Freedom to Senator Bob Dole. His actions challenged Mr. Gingrich and Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, to join his crusade against "petty bickering" or emerge as defenders of gridlock.
For government to work, of course, it needs to regain the people's trust. The President's only reference to the scandals of the last year came when he looked toward a time when "the people will always speak louder than the din of narrow interest." These were perfunctory words in view of the public hunger for cleaner politics.
To offset its more plodding passages, the speech contained a fine sense of history, as if the President were attempting to respond to some of the memorable phrases and moments of his predecessors. Sixteen years ago, for example, Ronald Reagan declared in his first Inaugural Address: "In this present crisis, government is not the solution to our problem; government is the problem." Mr. Clinton updated that moment with a nice populist flourish when he said: "Today we can declare: Government is not the problem, and government is not the solution. We, the American people, we are the solution." He was clearly savoring the consensus in the last election that government is something more than the enemy of Americans.
The President's appeals for racial harmony sprang in part from a central accomplishment of his first term. By tackling welfare and gun control and presiding over a decline in crime, he has eased the ugliness of race in American politics and restored the Democrats' authority on divisive issues. We continue to feel that the welfare law, if left as Mr. Clinton signed it, will hurt the poor. But if he keeps building on what he has done, he can carve a revitalized consensus in support of jobs and education for those on welfare.
Mr. Clinton waited until the end of his speech to mention his obligatory "bridge to the 21st century." More interesting was his invocation of other turns of the century in American history. The transition from the 18th to the 19th century brought a continent conquered and tamed. The transition to the 20th was more similar to what Americans face today. Rising economic inequality and ethnic diversity in the country led to the Progressive Era and the government activism that Mr. Clinton seeks to revive. History was a reminder, then, that for all the President's desire for harmony, it is government -- and in these next four years a mixture of Presidential determination and Congressional cooperation -- that will make his dream succeed or fail.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Boston Scientific in Deal To Buy Medical Supplier
Boston Scientific agreed to acquire Target Therapeutics, a maker of specialized catheters primarily used for treating the brain, in a stock swap valued at about $1.1 billion.
Boston Scientific has become the leading supplier of nearly all types of catheters, which are tubes used to gain access to internal organs and blood vessels. With the deal, it will become the leader in the one area of catheters that has eluded it. [Page D2.]
 
Profits Strong at Brokerage Firms
Paine Webber, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Alex. Brown, benefiting from the continuing bull market in stocks, reported earnings for the last three months of 1996 that exceeded analyst forecasts. [D9.]
 
Stocks Rise on Earnings Reports
Strong earnings reports sent stocks higher in a quiet holiday session. The Dow industrials gained 10.77 points to close at 6,843.87. [D10.]
 
New Nasdaq Trading Rules Start
Nasdaq began trading 50 stocks under new rules intended to give average investors better prices. There was limited evidence of benefits, but it was too early to reach conclusions. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
Medical-Cost Rise Is Expected
Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for three years, are inching ahead and may be poised for a sharp rise, especially for small businesses. [A1.]
 
Strikes End in South Korea
Workers returned to their jobs in South Korea after weeks of strikes, with business leaders saying the economy would suffer little lasting harm from the walkout. [A8.]
 
Olivetti to Sell Computer Unit
Olivetti said that it would sell its money-losing personal computer company to Piedmont International, a newly formed investment group, for $159 million to $190 million. [D4.]
 
Pharmacia & Upjohn Chief Resigns
The chief executive of Pharmacia & Upjohn will step down immediately, the company said, prompting a sharp drop in its stock. [D9.]
 
Lift Seen for Netscape Software
Netscape is expected to announce that KPMG Peat Marwick has selected the newest version of Netscape's business communications software as the standard for 17,000 workers in its United States offices. [D2.]
 
Ryder Cutting Jobs and Offices
Ryder System said it was cutting 2,100 jobs and closing 200 field offices and other facilities to try to improve its results. [D21.]
 
Tax Suspension Helps Sales Gain
Driven in part by a one-week suspension of the sales tax on clothing, sales surged over the weekend at New York City stores. [B1.]
 
Pepsi 'Generation' Reincarnated
Pepsi-Cola will return to promoting its flagship soft drink with a single, unified voice that will invoke the popular "Pepsi generation" line, but with a twist. The campaign will carry the theme "Generation next." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
A Logo for Broadway
In an effort to heighten awareness of Broadway theater, the League of American Theaters and Producers has commissioned a logo for shows' marketing and promotional materials. [C14.]
 
Neither Rich nor Famous
In an era of millionaire computer programmers, the inventor of Eudora electronic mail software, which is used by 18 million people, is not rich or famous. [A10.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1235 words

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: VOICES;
Priorities for the Nation: Education and Housing

 BODY:
The New York Times asked a variety of political and public figures the following question: "If you could get the Democratic President and the Republican Congress to set aside their differences and get one thing done, what would it be?"
Here are some of their answers: 

 
Robert A. Caro
Author of biographies of Lyndon B. Johnson and Robert Moses
The one thing is education. That looms over everything else. Lyndon Johnson said that "if there isn't anything in the Constitution on the subject of education, there ought to have been."
He, at least, made a Titanic effort to stamp education firmly onto the national agenda but for many reasons, Vietnam first among them, he did not achieve what he wanted. During the years since he left office, moreover, America has, decade by decade, failed dismally to educate its young people adequately for the modern world. There must be a determination by the President and Congress alike to raise both funding and standards.

The Rev. Edward A. Malloy
President of the University of Notre Dame
I would like to advocate the equivalent of a Marshall Plan for Washington, D.C., the capital city. I was born and raised in Washington. And although there have been some recent proposals, including an initiative from the White House, I think our country deserves a capital city that is well-run, attractive, and a model for the quality of urban life for the country.
If you've been to Paris and London and Rome, you know the capital cities of many European countries have special consideration and treatment, and become sort of icons for the representation of those countries. I think we have a reverse situation in our country.

Representative John Lewis
Georgia Democrat and a civil rights leader
More than anything else, in order to set the right tone and give the American people a greater sense of trust, faith and confidence in our political system, we must do something about campaign finance reform. By taking a great deal of money out of the political system, the elected officials in Washington, including those that run for President, the House and the Senate, I think we will spend more time taking care of the business of the people, rather than dialing for dollars.

John F. Smith Jr.
Chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation
What comes to my mind rather quickly would be to eliminate a lot of the government regulations that is nonvalue added to business and to the community at large, and hopefully we can do that. Democrats and Republicans should also work to eliminate the budget deficit.

Carol Steele
President of Friends of Cabrini Homes and housing project tenant
It would be to put more funds in public housing. They need to empower more residents to do resident management. Who knows more about what residents need than the residents themselves? If we can untangle the bureaucracy and make our own decisions and get (rid of) red tape for repairs, we can rehabilitate the homes better. We need more low-rise; they provide more of a home atmosphere. We need good security. With the welfare reform, people are going to need jobs to sustain themselves. The people in Washington need to be creative and come up with ideas for jobs.

Doris Kearns Goodwin
Wrote "No Ordinary Time: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt"
Most of all, we need fundamental and substantial campaign finance reform to reopen the political system to the ordinary citizen. As it stands now, money buys access to privilege and legislation.
I believe changing that system now should be the priority of the Congress and the President. All of the other issues which the nation needs to face, from the growing income disparity between rich and poor, from our racial divide, to our inadequate education and the devastation of our inner cities, cannot be dealt with without restructuring the political system so that it is not so dependent on and responsive to the privileged few.

Gov. Gary Locke
Elected in Washington as the first Chinese-American governor
I'd like them to work on increasing the economic security of working families so that they can meet their needs for better education, affordable health care and security and dignity for their elders. I see this as part of their economic and tax policies. Families want more education not just for their kids but for the parents, continuing education and job retraining. Families are very much concerned about the rising cost of health care and that a major illness could bankrupt them if they have no insurance.

Roberto C. Goizueta
Chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company
I was honored to address immigrants taking the oath of citizenship on Independence Day 1995. As a naturalized citizen myself, I encouraged them to work hard to prove the inherent superiority of a democratic society, the lasting stability of a democratic capitalistic system and to show the world that people can indeed be trusted with governing themselves.
President Clinton and the Congress have the opportunity on a world stage every day to prove the superiority of that democratic society and our capitalistic system. Abandon personal attack. Persuade your opponent, don't destroy him. Learn to listen and acknowledge. By doing so, you show the American people you have put the nation's interests ahead of your own personal interests and show by your own actions that self-government is the most effective form of government.

Dr. David Baltimore
Professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology
We need to start a massive program in infrastructure development, housing and transportation. It would require finding money that has not been made available for years, possibly by cutting the defense budget or using the lower estimate of inflation or raising taxes.
I firmly believe that the education of young people is the most important thing we can do to give them a place in the future economy and at the same time to insure the strength of the economy.
In communication, I'm thinking of things like shoring up the strength of the Internet so it doesn't get overloaded. We need to keep it publicly available rather than seeing it privatized.

Derek Bok
Teaches at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government
I would choose a campaign finance law with partial public funding, which would keep political parties and politicians from receiving private donations large enough to influence public policy. Although such a reform would not directly alleviate poverty, improve schools or preserve Social Security, it would help to address a remarkable number of weaknesses that hamper our ability to deal with such national problems.
Curbing the influence of private money in politics would lessen the disadvantages of the poor and other unorganized groups in defending their interests in Washington. Effective campaign finance rules would also ease some of the pressures that currently make legislative compromise so difficult and lead to ungainly laws that are hard to implement properly. Furthermore, such rules would reduce pressures to give undeserved tax breaks, subsidies, and other pork-barrel benefits which add to the government waste so distasteful to Americans. Finally, campaign finance reform would help relieve suspicion and cynicism toward government.

Gov. George W. Bush
Texas Republican
"A real balanced budget."

HEADLINE: Plutonium Had Been Removed from Vietnam

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The failed 1975 effort to retrieve a canister of plutonium from the Dalat nuclear reactor in the Central Highlands of Vietnam described in your Jan. 16 news article should have been unnecessary.
Years earlier, the nuclear material had been removed from South Vietnam, but was then returned, creating one of the most egregious misuses of the Atoms for Peace program. 
 About the time of the Tet offensive in 1968, I took my concerns about the Dalat reactor to the White House, where Hans Heymann, a Rand Corporation colleague on loan from the think tank, had been recruited to work on Vietnam problems. He set in motion a White House request to the Pentagon that it remove the nuclear fuel from Dalat.
That was done. The two Rand "culprits," myself included, then felt the full fury of the Atomic Energy Commission, which declared that removing the fuel was a damaging symbolic act, undermining the United States commitment to Vietnam.
The more important symbolism would have been a strong dedication to strict international controls over nuclear materials. But seeing otherwise, the commission directed that the nuclear fuel be returned to Vietnam in the midst of escalation of the war.
And so the radioactive materials sat at Dalat until the final Vietcong assault in 1975. Vietnamese officials say some of the plutonium is still there (news item, Jan. 19).
This episode raises questions as to whether Energy Department efforts to bring to light the hidden secrets of the nuclear era may still not reflect the complete stories and the lessons that might be drawn from them.
 
ARNOLD KRAMISH
Reston, Va., Jan. 19, 1997
 
The writer was chief analyst for nuclear proliferation at the Atomic Energy Commission, 1947-51.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
NATO or Tomato?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Sometimes the news is in the noise and sometimes the news is in the silence. If you want to understand what's wrong with NATO expansion -- the new Clinton Administration's first major foreign-policy challenge -- then you should listen to the silence, the silence of Europeans on this subject. Don't get me wrong, the West Europeans support NATO expansion, but it's nothing they ever seem to talk much about or debate. They treat it as something America will take care of, something America will finesse with the Russians and something America will pay for.
And that's the news. The West European states are the ones supposedly most threatened by a resurgent Russia, which is right next door. They are the ones supposedly most in need of the East Europeans' joining NATO to create a buffer with Russia. And yet the members of the European Union seem about as interested in NATO expansion as they are in the Super Bowl. Why? Because the West Europeans think the real threat to them is not Russia, but Eastern Europe. 
 Yes, the Poles, Hungarians, Czechs and others clamoring to join NATO are the ones who really scare the E.U. Because the E.U. members know that Russia is no threat to them now. What threatens them right now are all those new East European free-market democracies, whose factories and farmers want to export to Western Europe at prices that will undercut the West Europeans and whose workers all want to flock to Western Europe for jobs, which would drive down wages. Russian missiles and Russian tanks are a nebulous and distant danger to Western Europe. But Polish hams and Polish workers are a clear and present danger.
So NATO expansion is the bone E.U. members throw the East Europeans instead of letting them into the European common market, which is what the East Europeans really want and need. That's what would really bolster their democracies. For the West Europeans NATO expansion is the ideal way to block the East Europeans from becoming members of the E.U. -- without feeling guilty about it. As Prof. Michael Mandelbaum of Johns Hopkins deftly noted: "We are going to extend the NATO nuclear umbrella to the Eastern Europeans, so that the Western Europeans won't have to buy their tomatoes." It's like America telling Mexico it can join NATO but not Nafta.
The E.U. assumes the U.S. will just go along with this sham. But the E.U. should take note of some alarm bells that have just been rung here. The first came from Secretary of Defense William Perry, who began a farewell interview by remarking to me that the Russians are still not on board at all for NATO expansion.
"I believe it's going to be very difficult," said Mr. Perry. "The Russians, at all levels, are opposed to NATO enlargement. At all levels they are still nervous, suspicious and fearful of NATO." Mr. Perry said he still believed in NATO expansion and that the Russians must persuade their public that this poses no threat to them. But he also argued it was imperative that NATO forge a NATO-Russia charter that will provide a framework for involving Russia in some NATO decision-making and therefore calm Moscow's concerns. A NATO team was in Moscow Monday to explore such a charter.
But even if it succeeds, the Europeans should heed a second alarm from Senator Joseph Biden, now the ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who says: "I have serious reservations about NATO expansion."
Mr. Biden explained that he did not object to NATO enlargement in principle; but he is not yet convinced it can be done without undermining U.S. arms-control treaties with Russia or the course of reform there, and even if it can, whether the benefits to the U.S. will be worth the price. He also wonders whether NATO actually is the best way to bolster democracy in East Europe. "If we are really going to alienate the Russians," he asks, "what are we going to get for it?"
None of this has been debated by the U.S. public or Congress, said Mr. Biden, and until it is, anyone who assumes Congress is on board for this is making a big mistake. As he put it: "Right now, if I stand up and start talking with my constituents about the price, if I tell them 'We are about to extend our nuclear umbrella to Slovakia,' I wonder how many people in Dagsboro, Del., are going to say, 'Hey, that's a great idea.' "

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Eases Against the Yen On Mixed Signals From Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened slightly against the yen yesterday on remarks by a Japanese official about the yen's value, but ended higher against some other key currencies.
A cut in Italian interest rates, fresh evidence of economic weakness in Germany and a generally upbeat assessment of the American economy by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, helped underpin the dollar. 
 The American currency has been rallying fairly steadily for a few weeks and is trading near 46-month highs against the yen and two-and-a- half-year highs against the German mark and the Swiss franc. Continuing weakness in Japan and in much of Europe has also lent strength against those nations' currencies.
"The dollar is clearly in demand," said John Hazelton, chief currency trader at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York. "We've certainly been going one way for a long time. There's no reason to think it won't continue, though it will stop and start as people take some profits."
Yesterday, the dollar touched an intraday high of 118.28 yen in Asian trading, and settled in New York at 117.94 yen, down from 118.06 on Monday. The dollar fetched 1.6286 marks, up from 1.6264. But the British pound rose to $1.6628, from $1.6622.
Early in the day, Japan's Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said at a news conference that he thought the yen was too weak, pushing down the dollar for a time. It began to recover when the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, William J. McDonough, who had just conferred with Mr. Mitsuzuka in Tokyo, said a strong dollar was in the United States' interest.
The dollar derived some strength against the mark from a report by the Ifo Institute for economic research in Munich that business confidence in western Germany fell in December for the second month.
The report provided further evidence that Germany's recovery was faltering, suggesting in turn that the Bundesbank might lower interest rates, perhaps as early as tomorrow.
The dollar was also helped by a three-quarters of a point cut in the Italian discount rate, to 6.75 percent, amid subdued inflation. The move was seen as part of a trend toward lower European interest rates.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Character Issue R.I.P.

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
As Bill Clinton sailed into his second term so tranquilly that his Inaugural Address all but invited the nation to join him in a cozy nap, he made Houdini look like an amateur. Despite Whitewater, Travelgate, Filegate, Paula Jones and campaign-finance shenanigans with a shady cast large enough to populate a new Coppola epic, he took the oath of office not in manacles but with an approval rating rivaling Ronald Reagan's.
How does the President escape hit after hit on what can now be referred to nostalgically as "the character issue"? As with speculative explanations of Houdini's illusions, the answer keeps changing. 
 During the campaign, when polls showed that Mr. Clinton was popular despite his character shortcomings, conventional wisdom had it that the American public was so cynical, so selfishly preoccupied with its own burgeoning economic prosperity, that it had no character itself and didn't care about ethics and morals.
Once the election was over, Mr. Clinton's defeated opponents offered a new explanation: The President had triumphed because his scandals were hidden from the public by the liberally biased mainstream media, which dismissed Paula Jones and underplayed Whitewater to get its pet re-elected. Even if this theory were true, however, it hardly can be said to apply now, after the Jones case has ensnared the Supreme Court. Yet not even Ms. Jones's prominence in late-night TV monologues or on Newsweek's cover has derailed Mr. Clinton's approval ratings.
A new explanation is thus needed, and this week it has come from David Brock, the right-wing journalistic assassin best known for branding Anita Hill as "a bit nutty, and a bit slutty." Writing in The Weekly Standard, Mr. Brock signs on to a theory that some of us have been postulating for three years: scandal overkill by Mr. Clinton's most rabid opponents. "The case against the character and ethics of President Clinton," he writes, has been "undermined and trivialized" by "indiscriminate and sometimes patently absurd allegations that delegitimize and discredit more serious charges."
Mr. Brock names the names of betrayers of the anti-Clinton cause. Hilton Kramer of The New York Post is ridiculed for promoting the "wild claim" that Mr. Clinton's refusal to release his medical records had a connection to what Paula Jones called his "distinguishing characteristic." ("Was this what the conservative case against Clinton had boiled down to -- talk about the President's private parts?" asks Mr. Brock contemptuously.) Also indicted are Reed Irvine's Accuracy in Media, for spreading "outlandish claims about the circumstances of Vincent Foster's death," and the Wall Street Journal editorial page, for promoting Gary Aldrich's rumor-stuffed book "Unlimited Access."
It's hard to dispute Mr. Brock's case that the "exaggeration, overstatement and outright dissimulation about the Clintons," complete with Byzantine conspiratorial subplots involving drug-running schemes and unsolved murders in deepest Arkansas, have backfired. The Clinton-haters' most lurid hyperbole may have tainted genuine stories to the point where the public lumps them all together as shrill partisan sniping and tunes them out. Where Mr. Brock is less forthcoming is in downplaying the size of his own role in creating the very syndrome he now decries: he's the founding father of private-parts political journalism. It was his wildly prurient piece for The American Spectator about Troopergate, which even took Mrs. Clinton to task for allegedly using state troopers "to fetch feminine napkins," that helped undermine the Paula Jones story the first time around. For him now to lecture others about abject scandalmongering is akin to a drug lord imploring junkies to "just say no."
But in Washington, opportunism can be its own reward. In only a few months Mr. Brock has morphed from scourge of the Clintons to Hillary Clinton defender (in a bizarre book published last fall) to moderate critic of the same right-wing journalists who invented him. What's next -- a Sunday morning talk show? You know Bill Clinton has triumphed over his tormentors when the most savage of them has repackaged himself with an audacity that is positively Clintonesque.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Ballplayer Who Opened the Door

 BODY:
The 1969 letter from the outfielder Curt Flood to Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn was plain but powerful. "Dear Mr. Kuhn," it began. "After twelve years in the major leagues, I do not feel that I am a piece of property to be bought and sold irrespective of my wishes. I believe that any system that produces that result violates my basic rights as a citizen."
What Flood was complaining about was a form of economic servitude shaped by organized baseball's reserve clause, which kept players tied to the same team forever unless they were traded or sold. The system prevented players from marketing their talents to the highest bidder. 
 Flood was traded to the Philadelphia Phillies in 1969 after a distinguished career with the St. Louis Cardinals. He refused to report and asked Kuhn for permission to bargain with other clubs. The commissioner turned him down, so Flood filed a lawsuit charging that baseball was a monopoly and that its reserve clause violated the antitrust law.
Although Flood lost his case in the Supreme Court in 1972, he had put the issue into play. In 1975 an arbitrator ruled that a player was bound only for the length of his contract, and granted free agency to two pitchers, Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally. When that ruling was upheld in Federal court, the owners abandoned the fight.
Flood never made a dime from his courage. He left baseball for a year and his skills eroded. But by the time he died on Monday, at age 59, he had earned the gratitude of an entire generation of players who have profited hugely from the freedoms that he made possible.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Boeing eliminates a program, and its investors are happy.

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher 

 BODY:
SHARES in the Boeing Company rose sharply yesterday after the company decided not to proceed with a multibillion-dollar plan to develop two larger, longer-range versions of its 747 jetliner.
The decision, which Boeing announced on Monday night, appears to concede the high end of the airline market to Boeing's archrival, the Airbus Industrie consortium of Europe. Airbus yesterday reconfirmed its intent to proceed with a new 500-seat super jumbo jet. 
 But analysts said they doubted that Boeing was really conceding anything. If Boeing found no ready market for a super jumbo, then Airbus will not be able to sell its still-larger proposed aircraft in sufficient numbers to justify the cost of its development, they said. Should a market develop, Boeing could always restart the "stretch 747" program in less time than Airbus can develop an entirely new airplane.
In the meantime, Boeing will reap considerable cost savings. Estimates of the research and development cost for the stretch 747 ran from $4 billion to $7 billion. Scrapping the program should translate to added per-share earnings of $1.50 between 1997 and 2000, said Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst with NatWest Securities. Boeing shares, which rose $7.375, to $113.875, yesterday, could reach $125 within three to six months and $150 within 12 to 18 months, he said, reaffirming an aggressive "buy" rating on the stock.
With the program's demise, "you lose the biggest remaining uncertainty regarding this stock," Mr. Heymann said. "You make this money available to enhance shareholder value in other ways."
Boeing has said that it will proceed with development of the 767-400 ERX, a larger, longer-range version of its midsize jet, and with more variants of the 777, a new wide-body that is sized between the 767 and the 747. The company is also developing a "digitized" version of the 747, which will incorporate the avionics display developed by Honeywell Inc. for the 777 cockpit. A Boeing spokesman said that these programs would make use of the personnel and manufacturing capacity gained through the proposed acquisition of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
Mr. Heymann said that Boeing's 250- to 400-seat models better served today's market than a new super jumbo would. Increasingly, airlines are fragmenting their service, with more direct routes between smaller cities in the United States and abroad, rather than connecting services through hubs like London and Tokyo. These flights do not require the capacity of a 747 and are more economically served with a smaller airplane, he said.
On some level, the announcements out of Boeing and Airbus amount to a game of chicken. By announcing plans for a bigger 747 before it had any customers locked up, Boeing pushed Airbus to announce a larger plane, too. Now, by dropping its effort, just as Airbus has announced plans to reorganize as a single company from its current status as a consortium of several European concerns, Boeing may gain breathing room.
"Airbus is preoccupied with its restructuring and is talking a 2003 delivery" for the proposed new jet, said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with BT Securities. Because Singapore Airlines and British Airways, two major potential customers, said they would not decide to buy such jets without seeing both competing designs, it makes no sense for Boeing to commit to a design now, he said. "Two years from now they may be able to see more clearly," he said.
Though today's fragmented route structure argues for more midsize jets than jumbos, the market could still evolve for a larger plane, Mr. Demisch said. And though investors were cheered by the near-term cost savings from killing the program, Boeing has yet to say what it will do with that cash, Mr. Demisch said.
The elimination of the stretch 747 "does leave a window open for Airbus. Clearly one reason Boeing had hoped to get this airplane off the ground was to lock up the high end of the market for another 20 years," Mr. Demisch said. "There is going to be a real dog fight for the large-airplane market some time in the next decade," he said.

LENGTH: 831 words

HEADLINE: Scholars Attack Public School TV Program

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
In separate research, professors from Vassar and Johns Hopkins sharply attack Channel One, the 12-minute television program seen daily by an estimated eight million public school students in the United States, as an advertising vehicle loaded with superficial, biased and sometimes hurtful programming.
"It's real function is not journalistic but commercial," Mark Crispin Miller, a professor of media studies at Johns Hopkins University, said in a paper entitled "How to Be Stupid: The Teachings of Channel One." 
 "It is meant primarily to get us ready for the ads," he writes. "It must keep itself from saying anything too powerful or even interesting, must never cut too deep or raise any really troubling questions, because it cannot ever be permitted to detract in any way from the commercials."
Working independently, Professor Miller and a Vassar College sociologist, William Hoynes, did two studies coordinated by the Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting, a liberal media watchdog group based in New York City. They analyzed videotapes of 36 shows distributed in 1995 and 1996. These programs, they said, contained a total of 91 news stories and 177 on-camera sources.
In response to the studies, a company spokeswoman, Claudia Peters, said the findings were irrelevant, given the program's popularity.
"Channel One," she said, "has been evaluated and reviewed by educators in 12,000 schools nationwide and renewed at a rate of 99 percent. A recent study by the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan found that 93 percent of all teachers would recommend Channel One to other schools and teachers."
Noting that some members of the Public Broadcasting System carry some Channel One programming, she said, "The fact that Channel One news coverage of Rwaanda, Bosnia and Tibet is available on PBS stations nationwide speaks for itself." Ms. Peters also noted that Channel One has received more than 100 education and journalism awards, including the George Foster Peabody Award in broadcasting.
Ever since 1990, when Whittle Communications introduced Channel One into middle and high schools, the daily programs, which include two minutes of advertising, have aroused controversy over the role of commercial television in the classroom. Only one state, New York, bans Channel One from its public schools.
Channel One, which was purchased in 1994 for $250 million by K-III Communications, provides its program to more than 12,000 schools in the United States. The audience is believed to include more than 40 percent of the nation's teen-agers.
While critics accuse Channel One of exploiting students for profit, supporters maintain that the advertising is a small price to pay for bringing a lively discussion of current events into the schools.
The study on the content of Channel One's news programming finds that only 20 percent of its air time is spent on coverage of "recent political, economic, social and cultural stories." The other 80 percent is advertising, sports, weather and natural disasters.
Professor Hoynes, the Vassar sociologist, said in his report that even what passes for news on Channel One -- oversimplified political stories, the promotion of Channel One personalities and frivolous contests -- must not be taken at face value.
"It is dubious whether such news provides educational or civic benefits to either students or educators at schools that receive Channel One," his report said. "Instead of taking the news quality of Channel One for granted, this research suggests that we need to systematically study Channel One programming to determine the nature of this news."
Professor Miller said the program is objectionable also because its commercials teach children "that you can and should surrender to your craving right away."
Such criticism of Channel One was challenged by Jeffrey Cole, director of the U.C.L.A. Center for Communication Policy.
"The Channel One news programming is quite sound," he said. "They have higher standards for advertising in that they won't take ads for beer, liquor and X-rated movies. The news they give you is a whole lot better than what you get on most local television news programs."
Especially controversial is the fact that nearly all the students in subscribing schools cannot avoid watching the programs. And unlike textbooks, the programs have not been previously reviewed by the faculty.
In exchange for providing the program, 19-inch television sets for each classroom, two VCR's, wiring and a satellite link, the Channel One contract requires each school to show programs every school day.
Longtime critics of Channel One, like the Center for Commercial-Free Public Education, were quick to embrace the reports. The group's executive director, Marianne Manilov, said of Channel One: "They will tell you that the students don't have to watch, but in practice they can't opt out. Channel One is promoted as an educational tool, but I would question its value."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Is Upbeat On Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave an upbeat assessment of the economy today, saying that after nearly six years of uninterrupted growth it had retained "considerable vigor, with few signs of the imbalances and inflationary tensions that have disrupted past expansions."
But living up to his reputation as ever-vigilant for trouble ahead, Mr. Greenspan said that a long period in which relatively small wage increases had helped to hold down inflation "may already be running its course." 
 His comments helped start a rally in the financial markets, which saw his statements as evidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at its next meeting on Feb. 4. After falling more than 40 points early in the day before Mr. Greenspan spoke, the Dow Jones industrial average rebounded and finished the day up 40.03 points to close at 6,883.90, another record.
Mr. Greenspan also appeared to be dropping a broad hint that the central bank saw a strong possibility of larger wage increases starting to fuel rising prices later in the year, and that the Federal Reserve was determined to squelch that.
In wide-ranging testimony before the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan also made these points:
*He said his comments in a speech last month about "irrational exuberance" in the financial markets, which set off a brief but sharp decline in stock prices, were not a "shot from the hip," but were intended to raise an important question about how to factor rapidly rising asset prices into the economic outlook. He also characterized the run-up in stock prices last year as "breathtaking," a remark that apparently had no effect on market psychology today.
*He reiterated his support for eliminating the Federal deficit, but opposed the balanced budget amendment currently before Congress, saying technical constraints on economic policy should not be placed within the Constitution. Republicans are pushing for a vote within a month or two on the amendment, which the Clinton Administration is lobbying heavily to defeat.
*He said the researchers at the Federal Reserve agreed with the conclusions of a Congressionally appointed panel that the Consumer Price Index overstates increases in the cost of living by around one percentage point. Although he warned that fixing the index would not be a fiscal cure-all, his statement gave new ammunition to proponents of reducing the cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other benefit programs as a way to reduce Federal spending and make it easier to balance the budget.
*He said he was skeptical that there was a fixed unemployment rate below which inflation would inevitably rise, and said that the Federal Reserve should not try to manage inflation by fine-tuning the unemployment rate.
The Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee has left monetary policy unchanged for nearly a year, since it reduced the two short-term interest rates it controls, the Federal funds target rate and the discount rate, to 5 percent from 5.25 percent, last Jan. 31.
Since then the Fed has stood by as growth accelerated and then moderated, leaving unemployment below 5.5 percent for most of last year but not generating the increases in inflation that traditional economics models predicted.
Average hourly earnings last year increased 3.8 percent, the sharpest rise since 1990. But increases in overall compensation were held down by a reduction in the growth of health care costs as companies move employees to managed care programs. And while the Consumer Price Index rose 3.3 percent last year, compared with 2.5 percent in 1995, the figure most closely watched by economists -- the "core" index, which factors out volatile food and energy prices -- declined to 2.6 percent last year from 3 percent in 1995.
Mr. Greenspan devoted much of his formal testimony today to exploring how old assumptions about the interplay among growth, unemployment and inflation had been opened to question by the restrained increases in wages and prices over the last year.
He said that job insecurity appeared to play some role, since workers were more concerned about keeping their jobs and retaining access to on-the-job training programs than about getting a raise. At the same time, he said, companies have been reluctant to raise prices on their products and services, fearing that competitors, anxious to capture market share, will not follow suit. Moreover, he said, companies can afford to hold the line on prices because their profits and rates of return on capital remain strong.
But Mr. Greenspan said the trade-off that workers had been making -- subdued wage demands in return for job security -- was "transitional" and would ultimately come to an end, especially if unemployment remained so low that companies must bid up wages to attract workers.
"The unknown is how long the transition will last," Mr. Greenspan said. "Indeed, the recent pickup in some measures of wages suggests that the transition may already be running its course. If so, the important question from a monetary policy point of view is whether prospective labor market conditions will be consistent with the maintenance of satisfactory price performance."
Asked by Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa, to explain his comments last month about whether stock and other asset prices were flying too high, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that he was aware that his comments could roil the markets, but said that he was only trying to discuss the relationship among asset prices, the economy and monetary policy in a general way.
"We thought long and in detail that any such statement could very well have immediate market effects," Mr. Greenspan said, suggesting how carefully he weighs every word he utters in public. "Our judgment, however, is that if we are endeavoring to explain, as I was in that speech, the full structure of policy-making as the Federal Open Market Committee implements it, then it would be important to make certain that everybody knows what we look at."
To considerable laughter, Mr. Greenspan said the speech succeeded in the sense that "everyone noticed what I was saying," but that it also failed in that people "didn't read as much of the context in which that was being stated as I would have preferred."
On the Consumer Price Index, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed had studied the issue from two perspectives. First, he said, Fed researchers had examined the array of macro-economic statistics and determined that they did not add up to a consistent picture, suggesting that at least one important gauge of economic performance was faulty. The most likely culprit, he said, is the price index.
The Fed has also studied the price index itself and came to much the same conclusion as the panel headed by Michael J. Boskin, an economist at Stanford University, which reported to Congress last month that the index overstated inflation by around 1.1 percentage points.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, helped lift markets yesterday when he testified before a Senate committee. (Reuters) (pg. D9)
 
Chart: "Greenspan As Market Mover"
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is listened to closely whenever he speaks, often moves stock and bonds prices, even if investors misinterpret his message.
 
YESTERDAY -- Mr. Greenspan said that American investors had "experienced an enormous further accretion of net worth as the stock market continued to climb at a breathtaking rate." The remark was a reminder of his use of "irrational exuberance" in December. But this time, the Dow Jones industrial average rose, climbing 40.03 points to 6,883.90, while the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.78 percent, from 6.83 on Friday.
 
DEC. 5 and 6 -- In a speech on Dec. 5, Mr. Greenspan asked ". . . how do we know when irrational exuberance has unduly escalated asset values, which then become subject to unexpectedand prolonged contractions as they have in Japan over the past decade?"
The impact came Dec. 6 as many analysts concluded that the remark could be a prelude to a rise in interest rates. Markets in Asia and Europe plunged. The Dow fell 55 points and was down as much as 144 points. The yield on the 30-year bond rose sharply at first but ended up just slightly, at 6.51 percent.
Reflecting on his use of the phrase "irrational exuberance," Mr. Greenspan told a Senate panel yesterday that "It was not a shot from the hip. . . . We thought long and in detail that any such statement could very well have immediate market effects."
 
JULY 18 -- Mr. Greenspan said ". . . there are a number of reasons to expect demand to moderate and economic activity to settle back toward a more sustainable pace in the months ahead." Stock market investors took this as a signal that short-term interest rates would not be raised soon. The Dow jumped 87.30 points, or 1.62 percent.
But bond investors saw a signal that the Fed might raise interest rates when Mr. Greenspan said that "the Federal Reserve has had to become especially vigilant to incipient inflation pressures." The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.92 percent, from 7.02 percent.
 
FEB. 20 and 21 -- On Feb. 20, Mr. Greenspan said "a number of fundamentals point to an economy basically on track for sustained growth, so any weakness is likely to be temporary." This was seen as a rejection of further cuts in short-term interest rates. The Dow fell nearly 45 points, while the yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.40 percent, from 6.24 percent.
But when Mr. Greenspan restated his testimony before on Feb. 21, the market interpretation was reversed: the Dow jumped 57.44 points and yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.37 percent. (pg. D9)

HEADLINE: On Campus;
Reich Takes Brandeis Post Over a Return to Harvard

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 21

 BODY:
Robert B. Reich, the outgoing Labor Secretary, will not return to Harvard, where he spent most of his career, but will instead join the faculty of Brandeis University next fall as a professor of social and economic policy, Brandeis announced today.
Mr. Reich will establish a Center on Jobs, the Economy and Society at the Heller Graduate School for Advanced Studies in Social Welfare at Brandeis, continuing the work that has filled his career, first at Harvard University and later in the Cabinet. 
 "I have dedicated my life to ensuring that the economy works for everyone," Mr. Reich said. "A central tenet of my writings and the policies I put into place as Labor Secretary is that our ability to thrive as a nation depends on the capacities of our people who work productively together -- both as participants in an economy and as members of a society."
In his four years in Washington, Mr. Reich fought for pension plan protections and a higher minimum wage, earning a reputation as an outspoken liberal voice in the Cabinet. The university hopes that he will attract other public officials and academics to the center to work on the problem of economic inequality, which Mr. Reich calls a dangerously growing trend.
Before joining President Clinton's team in 1992, Mr. Reich lectured for 12 years at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. Asked today why he was not returning to Harvard, he said at a news conference: "I'm of the belief that you don't go back to what you did before. I maintain the highest regard for the institution, but it's time to do something else. This is a marvelous opportunity."
Mr. Reich, 50, resigned shortly after Mr. Clinton's re-election, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family. He has two sons, aged 12 and 15, with his wife, Clare Dalton, an associate dean at Northeastern University Law School in Boston.
 JULIE FLAHERTY

HEADLINE: Democrats' Shift on Gifts May Affect Coffers Less Than Image

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Democratic Party's decision to reject donations from American subsidiaries of foreign companies could prove to be unworkable in the global economy of the late 1990's.
And if the party really does limit contributions to $100,000 a year from any one donor, it might find itself at a serious financial disadvantage. But the party can probably stretch the voluntary rules it established today so that the limit has little effect. 
 Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, the new general chairman of the party, said at a news conference today that the limits on contributions were "a serious step that's going to cost us."
But nonpartisan authorities on campaign finance practices described the Democrats' announcement today as more public relations gloss than substantive reform. Kent Cooper, the executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a watchdog group, called the party's restrictions on contributions "methadone treatment for the money-in-politics drug."
"It's a good first step," Mr. Cooper said, "but it doesn't cure the addiction."
First, consider the party's decision to reject contributions from subsidiaries of foreign companies. Under the law, such donations are legal as long as they are directed by American employees and the money does not come from the foreign parent. (Candidates cannot take corporate donations, but parties can.)
In the last campaign, American subsidiaries of foreign concerns gave millions of dollars to the political parties. Republicans received more, but the Democrats still got a pile. The largest such donor to the Democrats was the American branch of the Seagram Company, the Canadian liquor conglomerate, which gave at least $1.2 million. The company also gave more than $650,000 to the Republican party.
Restricting donations from these subsidiaries might be popular, especially at a time when the Democratic party is under fire for taking questionable contributions from foreigners. The problem is that it is often difficult to decide just what is an American company at a time when American corporations are increasingly buying stakes in operations overseas and European and Asian companies have extensive interests in this country.
Take, for example, Honda America, a unit of the Honda Motor Company of Japan. It has 12,000 employees in Ohio, makes cars from parts fabricated at American tool-and-die shops and sells the cars mainly to American customers through American dealers. Is this an American company or a Japanese company?
And when the M.C.I. Communications Corporation, the second largest long-distance telephone carrier in the United States, becomes part of British Telecommunications, does that mean it can no longer participate in American politics?
American companies give their shareholders' money to political parties for one main reason: They think it will expand their influence on the decisions of the American Government, and they are doubtless right.
So say a Democratic President or a Democratic Congress is working on opening up the telephone market in Singapore to American companies. Does the restriction imposed by the Democrats mean that AT&T is free to give money to get a foot in the door, but M.C.I. is not?
As of today, that seems to be the case. "If the ultimate owner of an entity is a foreign company, then we would not take that contribution period," said Steven Grossman, the party's chief operating officer.
Governor Romer conceded that the application might be unfair to companies like M.C.I. "This is a crude instrument," he said, "but it's the best we have."
Now consider the Democrats' announcement that they will take no more than $100,000 a year from any single source. This too has a popular ring after an election campaign in which dozens of companies, unions and trade associations gave more than a million dollars each.
Mr. Romer said that if the rule had been in effect in 1996, it would have cost the party $6.5 million.
But here's the rub. The $100,000 limit (and, for that matter, the restriction on donations from subsidiaries of foreign companies) applies only to the Democratic National Committee. It does not apply to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee or the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, which raise money for candidates for the House and Senate. Nor does it apply to the state party operations.
No one expects the Democrats to commit suicide. So if the new funding restrictions pose too much of a disadvantage, party officials will surely channel contributions to the state parties or the House and Senate operations.
"This doesn't clean up the system," said Ann McBride, president of Common Cause, another watchdog group. "It gives the illusion of solving the problem, but it's still going to allow a lot of big money into the party."

HEADLINE: Justices Void Federal Law Restricting Indian Estates

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Federal law that prohibits members of Indian tribes who own very small pieces of land within a reservation from passing the property on to their heirs.
Under the 1984 law, the property reverts at the owner's death to the tribe, which becomes in effect the only legal heir. The owner's estate receives no payment. In an 8-to-1 opinion by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the Court said the law violated the Fifth Amendment, which bars the Government from taking private property without compensation. 
 Congress passed the law, the Indian Land Consolidation Act, to address a longstanding and increasingly serious land ownership problem on the reservations. Tracts of 40 to 320 acres that had been allotted to Indian families a century ago have, through inheritance, acquired so many owners that individual stakes are now as small as a few square feet or even inches. Some tracts have hundreds of owners. The purpose of the law was to consolidate these fractional shares under tribal ownership so that the land could be put to an economically efficient use.
The law was challenged in 1993 by the children of William Youpee, a member of the Sioux and Assiniboine Tribes who died with a will that left to his children his fractional shares in 34 parcels on three reservations in Montana and North and South Dakota. The shares were small and had a total value of under $2,000. An administrative law judge of the Department of the Interior found that the land met the definition of property that must revert to the tribe.
The children sued the Interior Department on the ground that the law amounted to an unconstitutional taking. They won in both the Federal District Court in Montana and the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, which called the law "an extraordinary and impermissible regulation of Indian lands."
In upholding the Ninth Circuit's ruling in her opinion today, Babbitt v. Youpee, No. 95-1595, Justice Ginsburg relied heavily on a 1987 Supreme Court opinion that declared unconstitutional an earlier version of the Indian Land Consolidation Act. Congress responded to that decision by amending the law, but Justice Ginsburg said the changes were too minimal to make a difference.
The sole dissenter today was Justice John Paul Stevens, who said the law was justified by the Government's "valid interest in removing legal impediments to the productive development of real estate."
Under the law, a property interest reverts to the tribe if it represents 2 percent or less of the original tract and is "incapable" of generating at least $100 in any of the five years following the owner's death. If it did not generate at least $100 in any of the five years preceding the death, the legal presumption is that the test has been met.
In a brief filed on behalf of the Youpee children, a group of tribal landowners said the economic test was inadequate to measure the value of property that could be used for hunting, recreation or religious ceremonies.
Separately today, the Court asked the Clinton Administration for its views in a prominent affirmative action case that followed the dismissal of a white public high school teacher in Piscataway, N.J. The Court has not yet decided whether to hear the case.
The Piscataway school board, faced in 1989 with having to shrink the business education department in which the two most junior faculty members had been hired on the same day, chose to keep the black teacher and dismiss the white one.
The Justice Department, under the Administration of President George Bush, sued the school board on behalf of the white teacher, Sharon Taxman, who was rehired in 1992. The Federal District Court in Newark, ruling that the dismissal violated the Federal law against racial discrimination in the workplace, awarded Mrs. Taxman $134,000 in back pay.
By the time the case was on appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, the Clinton Administration was in office and switched sides to support the school board. The appeals court refused to accept the Administration's brief and upheld the district court's ruling in a sweeping decision that rejected the argument that achieving or maintaining diversity could ever be a valid reason for basing an employment decision on race.
The decision to switch sides was criticized within the Clinton Administration itself, including by Walter Dellinger, then an Assistant Attorney General and now the acting Solicitor General. But the Administration did not take a position in October when the school board filed its Supreme Court appeal, Piscataway Board of Education v. Taxman, No. 96-679. Now the Administration cannot avoid declaring itself once again.

HEADLINE: Stocks Surge On Remarks By Greenspan

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices surged higher yesterday, continuing their torrid January pace, on stronger-than-expected earnings reports and what many investors believed were "conciliatory" remarks about the stock market from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 40.03 points, to close at 6,883.90 in heavy trading, notching its 10th record this year. 
 Although stock prices dropped about 40 points in early trading, the Dow bounced back in the early afternoon, nearly hitting the 6,900 mark after word spread that Mr. Greenspan had told the Senate Budget Committee that the economy remained strong and that there were few immediate signs of inflation.
Analysts cheered the remarks by Mr. Greenspan, who last December had hinted at a stock market that may have been infected by "irrational exuberance." Yesterday, Mr. Greenspan played down that remark and spoke instead of Americans benefiting from the market's "breathtaking" climb.
"Basically, the cautionary fears about Greenspan's remarks gave way to a sigh of relief," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "It looks like Mr. Greenspan is not going to take the punch bowl away from the bull market."
A steady stream of better-than-expected earnings reports also bolstered the market.
Although Wells Fargo's net income was down because of acquisition costs, its operating profit rose; shares of the bank holding company advanced 9, to 288 3/4.
Chrysler and Citicorp reported higher-than-expected earnings, lifting both stocks. Chrysler gained 1 1/2, to 36, and Citicorp advanced 2 7/8, to 112 1/8.
I.B.M., Boeing and Philip Morris accounted for more than 38 points of the Dow's 40-point gain yesterday, with Boeing alone, which jumped 7 3/8, to 113 7/8, accounting for 23.5 points. The aerospace company's shares shot up after it announced that it had scrapped plans to spend $7 billion on a more sophisticated version of the 747.
Shares of I.B.M. rose as high as 170 1/8, before ending at 168, a gain of 1 on expectations that the company would report strong earnings after the close of the market. The company's earnings were in line or slightly below expectations.
Philip Morris gained 2 3/8, to 119 5/8.
The Dow's big loser was Caterpillar, which fell 2 1/8, to 76 3/8, after the company reported that 1997 earnings would probably not be much higher than those of 1996. Caterpillar did, however, report better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings yesterday.
Broader market indexes once again outpaced the blue-chip barometer. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 6.02 points, to 782.72, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 12.69 points, to 1,376.97.
Analysts said the broad market advances had been powered by a confluence of events: a strong dollar, strong fourth-quarter earnings reports, large seasonal inflows into mutual funds and news of Mr. Greenspan's "conciliatory" remarks.
"You put that together and that's a powerful mix for equities; it's a very potent cocktail," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company. "I think the market wants to go higher. That's been the tenor of the last few weeks."
Mr. Pradilla said investors continue to bet on blue-chip stocks and technology "bellwethers," such as Microsoft and Intel, which are lifting the entire sector.
For the second consecutive day, Microsoft was the most actively traded issue, gaining 4 1/4, to 95. Shares of Microsoft have risen nearly $13 in the last two weeks, partly on last Friday's higher-than-expected earnings report.
Intel rose 2 13/16, to 148 1/16. McAfee Associates, the software developer, rose 6, to 56 1/4.
Oil, airline and financial services stocks also fared well. Shares of Salomon rose 2 5/8, to 51 3/4, after the company said its net income increased to $1.98 a share, beating analysts' estimates. Shares of Merrill Lynch gained 2 1/4, to 86 5/8.
Analysts said that market momentum was surprisingly strong, and that the Dow, which is up nearly 7 percent so far this year, could soon reach 7,000. "The big story is momentum," Mr. Metz of Oppenheimer said. "That's what people are playing."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Reports Its Second-Best Year Ever

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Brisk sales of Jeeps, pickup trucks and mini-vans allowed the Chrysler Corporation to announce unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter results today that closed out the company's second-best year ever.
Chrysler earned $807 million, or $1.12 a share, in the fourth quarter, down 22 percent from the comparable period a year earlier but well above most Wall Street analysts' predictions. The company's earnings were damped by $279 million in special charges that wiped from its books some high-interest debt, pension costs, a charge from a subsidiary it sold and early retirement plan costs. Excluding those actions, net earnings would have hit $1.09 billion, or $1.51 a share, Chrysler's highest quarterly results ever. 
 Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, said that he was optimistic about 1997. "We've had three strong years and as we look ahead, we don't see anything besides clear sailing," he said. Nevertheless, he said the company had taken precautions against unforeseen trouble. "We are prepared if the market turns down for any reason," Mr. Eaton said.
Because Chrysler has always foundered in hard times, many are waiting to see whether it can survive the next round. Mr. Eaton repeated that Chrysler believed it had saved enough cash for the next rainy day to avoid cuts in its product development plans or restraints on its efforts to continue to increase its auto business.
"We're getting more and more confident that we can go through the next downturn, largely getting through it on operating earnings, and that would allow us to use a significant portion of our cash reserves for growth opportunities," Mr. Eaton said.
Chrysler has long said that its automotive operations need about $7.5 billion in cash reserves -- which now total $6.95 billion -- to help weather its next recession without cutting back on its car and truck development plans.
For the year, Chrysler earned $3.53 billion, or $4.77 a share, up from $2.03 billion, or $2.65 a share, in 1995. Indeed, excluding special charges, earnings for the year were Chrysler's highest ever. Revenue grew 15 percent, to $61.4 billion, from $53.2 billion in 1995.
Chrysler stock rose $1.50, to close at $36, after the results were announced. Other auto stocks also rallied, with General Motors Corporation shares rising $1.25, to $62, and Ford Motor Company stock rising 50 cents, to $33.625.
Chrysler -- whose best year was 1994 when it earned $3.71 billion -- was the first of the Big Three to report its fourth-quarter earnings. G.M. is expected to announce its results next Tuesday, with Ford's due the following day. The consensus among analysts is that G.M. will earn 49 cents a share and that Ford will earn $1.02 a share, according to First Call Corporation, a Boston firm that tracks analysts' estimates. The figures exclude one-time charges.
Wall Street analysts said Chrysler's results were strong all around. "This company is extremely well positioned," said Stephen J. Girsky, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley. "The stars are starting to align for them," he said, pointing to Chrysler's improved profitability.
In 1995, Chrysler earned worldwide profits of $1,235 for every car or truck it sold. In 1996, it earned $1,925 a vehicle. And in the last quarter, it earned $2,115 for each vehicle, far higher than other auto makers.
But some analysts cautioned that despite Chrysler's strong performance last year -- it ended the year with 15.9 percent of the United States market, up 1.6 percentage points -- it will have to work hard to maintain the gains.
"If you want to look at the company in a vacuum you'd probably see nothing but higher sales and better times," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an auto analyst at Bear, Stearns. Chrysler's success came in part because "they capitalized on G.M.'s misfortune," he added.
This year, G.M. is unlikely to face the prolonged strikes that slowed production last year, and has more than a dozen new models replacing several tired designs. That should stiffen the competition, Mr. Lobaccaro said.
Nearly 80,000 union workers at Chrysler will share in the company's good fortune. On average, hourly workers will receive a bonus of $7,900 for 1996, up from $3,200 last year but below the 1994 record of $8,000.
Shareholders also benefited as Chrysler continued its stock buyback spree. Chrysler said it still planned to buy back $2 billion in stock this year, having already bought back 14 percent of its outstanding common stock since early 1995.
Chrysler's fourth-quarter results included an after-tax loss of $191 million incurred as the company retired $550 million in high-interest debt. Chrysler expects to issue about $550 million in lower-interest debt.
