HEADLINE: Giuliani Says State Budget On School Aid Is Skimpy

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today gingerly contested Gov. George E. Pataki's claim that his proposed budget would narrow the disparity between state spending on New York City's schools and others across the state.
At a legislative hearing, the Mayor said that under the proposed budget, the disparity would actually increase. He said Mr. Pataki's proposal would increase school aid statewide by too little to keep pace with inflation and with increased enrollment in New York City. 
 Appearing at a joint session of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, the Mayor first took note of Mr. Pataki's plan to move closer to parity in school aid over five years, saying, "I commend the Governor for moving in that direction."
New York City has more than 37 percent of the state's public school students, but it receives less than 35 percent of state school aid.
The Mayor did not overtly appeal for more aid. But he said that under the Governor's budget, "We'll actually move in the wrong direction in the first year, possibly the second year of that proposal."
He added that even after five years, "We're still getting considerably less" than the city's full share.
In a mayoral election year, Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, is caught between his need to be seen valiantly defending the city's interests in Albany, and his need to keep the peace with Mr. Pataki, a fellow Republican, and the Legislature. And he must watch his political flank on education spending. His Democratic rivals have been making nearly the same criticism against him that by implication he made against the Governor today: that the Mayor's education budget has not kept up with rising enrollment and expenses.
Mr. Giuliani's remarks were milder than those he made last year, when he complained about the school finance disparity, also saying Mr. Pataki had not done enough to cut the city's Medicaid costs. Mr. Giuliani spoke of Medicaid only when prompted by legislators, saying he would reserve judgment on the Governor's proposals for cuts in Medicaid spending until later in the process.
Of Mr. Giuliani's remarks, Mr. Pataki said, "I would think that probably every community in the state will be asking for more money for their schools, and have a good case for it."
As he announced his 1997-98 budget last week, Mr. Pataki proposed a five-year effort to help the city catch up with the rest of the state. When transportation and construction assistance are left out, as the Governor says they should be, Mr. Pataki's budget narrows the gap slightly next year. But with those categories included, the disparity grows slightly.
Mr. Giuliani did not ask for more school aid, but said the city's schools would need $300 million to $500 million more in support next year just to keep pace with inflation and enrollment. Mr. Pataki's budget calls for $309 million more in aid to schools statewide, a 3 percent increase.
In his annual budget-season pilgrimage to Albany, Mr. Giuliani met with Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Rensselaer County Republican, and appeared with the Governor to sign a watershed agreement.
His complaint, though muted, was the same one Mayors have made for years: that the state shortchanges the city. He also argued that Mr. Pataki's property tax relief plan is unfair, giving New York City residents less than 10 percent of the benefit because it leaves out renters and co-op owners.
He also said that the city, which has reduced welfare rolls, should share in the Federal money the state will receive for reducing the number of recipients.
Mr. Giuliani called on state lawmakers to make permanent the experiment in eliminating the sales tax on clothing items under $500.
The Mayor urged legislators not to heed Senator Bruno's call to end rent regulation. He predicted that, in the end, the Legislature would do no more than tinker with the rent laws.
To that, Mr. Bruno said, "The Mayor is not always right in everything he says or does."

HEADLINE: Studies Show Need to Track and Prevent Hospital Drug Reactions

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Adverse reactions to drugs and mistakes in prescribing them commonly cause illness and sometimes death among hospital patients in this country, three new studies have shown.
Up to half of the problems were avoidable, said the authors of the studies, to be published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association. The studies differed in the way they were conducted but added to existing evidence of these dangers. 
 One problem is an allergic reaction that cannot be predicted or prevented -- which can occur the first time an individual takes a drug. Another reaction can occur if a patient has a known drug allergy that doctors, nurses and pharmacists fail to note before the medication is administered. A reaction can also occur when a patient is given a combination of drugs, even when each drug presents no problems individually.
Some hospitals have begun to develop computerized systems to identify adverse drug reactions and take other steps to prevent them. Nevertheless, more rigorous tracking is needed because hospitals, professional organizations and government, which pay much of the cost of medical care in this country, have focused too little attention on the problem, the authors wrote.
The rates of adverse drug events varied widely in earlier studies, in part because of the way hospitals and those doing studies identify the rates. One study found that about 30 percent of hospital patients had adverse drug events and that 3 percent to 28 percent of hospital admissions were related to such events.
Studies also have suggested that adverse drug reactions may account for as many as 140,000, or nearly 6 percent, of the 2.3 million deaths that occur each year in the United States. Currently, hospitals are believed to be detecting only an estimated 5 percent of such reactions.
But researchers need more documentation of adverse drug events before widespread enthusiasm about prevention can develop, said Dr. David C. Classen's team at LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City, which conducted one of the studies.
Although not all adverse drug events result from errors, the study of the problem is part of a small but growing focus of broader research on errors in medicine. Such research suggests that hospital errors could be caught systematically through management techniques and computer systems analogous to those used in industry to control the quality of manufactured products.
Using a sophisticated computerized surveillance system, Dr. Classen's team found that unwanted drug reactions affected 2.43 percent of 91,574 patients admitted to the LDS Hospital from Jan. 1, 1990 to Jan. 1, 1994. On average, the adverse events nearly doubled the patients' risk of death and lengthened their stay by nearly two days -- at an added cost of $2,013. Even a mild reaction like itching can be costly, because of treatment for the reaction and tests for other possible causes. In 1992, direct costs to the hospital were $1.1 million, excluding costs of liability or injuries to patients.
If other hospitals have rates similar to that of LDS Hospital, then an estimated 770,000 patients in this country have adverse drug reactions each year, at a cost of $1.56 billion. Earlier studies estimated the costs to be as much as $79 billion a year.
The study also documented some false economies. To save $5,000 a year, LDS Hospital pharmacy officials switched brands of vancomycin, an antibiotic. However, the hospital's drug monitoring system found that the new brand produced 25 more adverse events, for reasons that were not explained, and cost the hospital $50,000. Without the monitoring system, Dr. Classen's team reported, hospital officials would not have known their decision was penny-wise but pound-foolish.
A second study involved 4,108 patients admitted to medical and surgical units at Brigham and Women's Hospital and Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston during a six-month period in 1993. A team led by Dr. David W. Bates identified 190 adverse drug events, of which 60 were preventable. The team found a surprisingly large difference in the average length of stay between patients who suffered preventable and nonpreventable adverse drug events. The preventable events led to an average added stay of 4.6 days and cost of $5,857 compared with 2.2 additional days costing $3,244 for the nonpreventable ones.
The authors urged caution in extrapolating from their findings, but said that if their conclusions were confirmed, the total cost to the nation would be $4 billion a year.
In the third study, a team headed by Dr. Timothy S. Lesar, a pharmacist at the Albany Medical Center, analyzed every third adverse drug event that hospital pharmacists detected and averted from July 1, 1994, through June 30, 1995. The team detected 2,103 errors thought to have potentially dangerous, at a rate of 3.99 per 1,000 orders for medications. Dr. Lesar's team wrote that the most commonly identified factors were "inadequate knowledge, availability, or appreciation of important patient information and drug factors."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Making the Most of an Opportunity

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Felix Burgos's profile in The New York Times during the Neediest Cases Fund campaign in December 1993 was a portrait of a man laboring to keep his self-respect. Out of work for more than a year, he relied on public assistance for a meager existence. He had side-stepped eviction from his Brooklyn apartment by working as an unofficial superintendent for his elderly landlords. "I had maybe $1.30 to my name," he recalled the other day. "I was back in my December rent."
In exchange for his welfare benefits, Mr. Burgos, 51, worked as an unpaid computer operator at Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, a job arranged through the Work Experience Program, the city's workfare program. It was that small fact, near the end of the article in the Saturday newspaper, that caught the interest of Richard Martin, the president of Medical Malpractice Insurance Association on William Street in lower Manhattan. 
 Mr. Martin was looking to hire someone for a job entering insurance policy data into his company's computer system. He called Catholic Charities at 8:30 Monday morning to invite Mr. Burgos to an interview.
Mr. Martin is known for his spur-of-the-moment generosity. He once hired musicians he heard playing in a subway station for his company's Christmas party.
In Mr. Burgos's case, Mr. Martin said, "We happened to have an opening in that area that dealt with computer usage and filing and records retention and we were interviewing people at the time. We just decided to take a look at him. We were very impressed with the interview and hired him on that basis. He is an excellent employee. We're very happy to have him."
Mr. Burgos had no experience with insurance work. For a decade he had worked as a major-domo, cleaning houses, running errands and managing personal schedules for up to a dozen clients at a time. He took two years of business courses at the Fashion Institute of Technology and later worked for a company that made fabric sample books. "When it came to insurance," he said, "all I knew was home insurance and life insurance."
It was the closing of the fabric company that left him unemployed. At Catholic Charities, the computer work suited his meticulous personality (his friends call him Felix Unger), but the agency could not afford to hire him. Instead Catholic Charities, one of seven social-service agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, helped him with minor expenses and with his job search by printing his resume and paying for new shoes and clothes.
Fifteen minutes after his interview, Mr. Burgos was offered a job as record retention coordinator at Medical Malpractice Insurance Association. He accepted, but there were no guarantees. His supervisor, Joseph Alvear, said, "As much as I like the thought of giving somebody the opportunity, I didn't want dead weight. We gave the guy the opportunity, and the guy worked out."
Mr. Burgos started his new job on Dec. 20, the Monday after his interview. "When I arrived on Wednesday morning, the director of personnel hands me an invitation to their Christmas party and a check for a week's salary," he said. "In a week's time, your life just changes. Six, seven days before you have nothing in your pocket. Seven days later you are having a Christmas party on the 41st floor of a building where there is white glove service and a five-piece string playing Christmas songs. I'm looking down from the 41st floor and pinching myself. Is this happening? Is this real?"
For his co-workers, Mr. Burgos's success has been a sobering inspiration. "It goes to show sometimes you just need to give somebody a chance," Mr. Alvear said. "There might be a lot of worthwhile individuals out there who just don't get the opportunity."
In each of the last three years, Mr. Burgos has contributed to the Neediest Cases Fund. This year he sent $100. "I find myself to be truly blessed and very lucky," he said. "I was hoping that if someone were to read this, maybe they would have a job to help someone else. To help one person at a time is good enough."

HEADLINE: A Classic Boston Brawl Pits Mayor Against New Stadium

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Beefy guys, working on beers, gobbling popcorn and potato chips, pals of Tommy Menino, huddled around a television set not much bigger than an altar two Sundays ago, cheering the New England Patriots to victory over the upstart Jacksonville Jaguars.
"YESSSSSS," they screamed, jumping to their feet and punching the air, as defensive back Otis Smith scooped up a fumble in the fourth quarter and ran 47 yards for a touchdown that guaranteed the home team a trip to New Orleans for the Super Bowl on Sunday. 
 Their battle cry was echoed across state and region and is still reverberating in this sports-mad city. "Jambalaya," they call the giddy mood that has swept over Boston.
But, among this one set of fans, price tags still dangling from new Patriots' caps, there was a curious ambivalence.
"Two more weeks of this," groaned Tommy Menino, who is the Mayor of Boston, putting his head in his hands.
Thomas M. Menino is being hammered unmercifully these days for stubbornly trying to block a proposed new football stadium for the Patriots. He has been denounced by the local press, the powerful downtown business community, the Governor and, above all, a legion of fans euphoric that their team -- once so bad that spectators would put paper bags over their heads as a sign of embarrassment -- is now a winner.
A mayor against a major league stadium? When a winning franchise confers big-time legitimacy on places like Jacksonville, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C.? And in Boston, where the Red Sox, the Celtics and the Bruins are folk religions? In an election year, how could this be?
As the Patriot's owner, Robert K. Kraft, sought to use the brief Jambalaya fever running up to the Super Bowl as leverage to secure the 69,000-seat stadium, political operatives on both sides of the issue outlined a classic brawl in a city where an election is called a "fight," and the loser gets "croaked." In play, they said, were not only the future of the last piece of prime undeveloped waterfront in the city -- a dreary industrial wasteland that is clearly destined to become Boston's next glittering district -- but also the enormous amounts of money at stake in major league sports. And there are towering egos, political rivalries and the suspicions of the tough, tight-knit South Boston neighborhood where Mr. Kraft wants to build.
"It's unbelievable -- any place else you would worry who would be hurt racing to the microphone to take credit first," said one of the operatives working to get the stadium built.
"In Boston, there are only three things: sports, politics -- and revenge. This has all three plus money," he added, pleading for anonymity because of the passions the stadium issue has engendered.
In truth, the struggle is less about football than real estate development, which in Boston is also a contact sport.
And, in an era when the Patriots' 24-year-old quarterback, Drew Bledsoe, has a contract for $42 million over seven years, financing the stadium is about more than selling tickets to eight home games. The project rests on renting public land cheap in an area soon to be flooded with Men in Dark Suits because of development already under way, backed by tens of millions of dollars of improvements by government. These men and their corporate employers, it is reasoned, will want to spend huge amounts of money to belong to the fancy year-round sky-box club attached to the stadium. It is this club, to a large extent, that will support the plan.
Mayor Menino insists that a badly needed new convention center should be the priority for the site.
The Mayor also backs up the fierce objections from South Boston -- in many ways the heartland of the city's traditional politics -- that if the stadium is built, the nearby narrow streets of their densely populated neighborhood will be clogged with thousands of cars. Many Patriot fans are so famously boorish that Monday Night Football would not televise their games for fourteen years, and these fears were hardly assuaged when more than 7,000 fans seeking tickets for the Jaguars game got into an alcohol-fueled melee outside the team's present stadium in Foxborough, throwing punches at each other and bottles at the police.
"It just doesn't work," Mayor Menino said of the stadium proposal in an interview. "It's bad urban planning. The neighborhood is against it; the people in South Boston are adamant. There are other alternative sites; this is one of the most valuable parcels of land in the city. It's not just a stadium issue, the whole thing is being confused."
Mr. Kraft, a cardboard box mogul, says he was traumatized as a youth in 1953 when the baseball Braves moved away, and bought the Patriots three years ago to keep them from going to St. Louis or somewhere else.
He has powerful allies. Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican, is determined to make sure the team does not leave the state. And Chad Gifford, the head of the BankBoston Corporation, has a major stake in financing development. He is a key member of "The Vault," an inner circle of bankers and other powers who shape much of the city's economic life, so-called because local lore has it they first met secretly in the vault of a member's bank.
"This is the new Boston, a whole new vista," a person working behind the scenes for the stadium said, displaying maps showing the planned development along the waterfront. "The new frontier, a great, healthy world-class city returning to its seafaring roots, chic, trendy. It's all about to happen, it's undeniably exciting. There's big dollars. Menino doesn't have vision and the neighborhood is parochial."
The infighting is so sharp that when the lights went out for eleven minutes at the rattletrap Foxboro Stadium just as the Patriots were to kick a field goal, people at Mayor Menino's game party hooted and jeered, voicing dark suspicions of a plot to show the need for a new field.
"Whaddeedo, Kraft, throw water on a transformer?" a woman snorted.
For the record, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Electric Company, Karen Berarbino, said the problem was a blown fuse on a pole outside the stadium. Mr. Kraft smilingly denied any sabotage, but was quick to take advantage.
"It was unfortunate, but maybe it makes a point," he told local sportswriters, to chuckles. "But we didn't plan it."
Meanwhile, the owner has been flirting with politicians in Providence, R.I., which the National Football League designated as the host city for the Patriots-Jaguars game, and with the Pequot Indians, who have so much money from their Foxwoods casino in Ledyard, Conn., that they could pay for building a stadium nearby. This has increased the pressure on officials here, and there have been profanity-laced telephone exchanges between the Governor and the quick-tempered Mayor.
Mayor Menino declared in his annual State of the City Message that he would not "rush into a deal by sacrificing good urban planning or the people of our neighborhoods." Governor Weld countered with a State of the State Message in which Patriot football metaphors were piled on like linebackers on a quarterback. He wound up by trumpeting, "Jambalaya -- Go Pats."
The Governor, Mayor and owner managed to get together to hold a pep rally for the Patriots this Sunday, where an estimated 15,000 people gathered in City Hall plaza on the coldest day of the year, with a wind-chill factor of minus 10, to cheer the players, wave pompoms and cheese graters -- and drown out the Mayor in a resounding chorus of boos.
"Stadium, stadium," they chanted as the Mayor maintained a frozen smile.
At the moment, it appears that the stadium proponents have the advantage because the 27-acre site is owned by Massport, the state port authority, whose officials are appointed by the Governor, and is thus beyond the Mayor's control. Governor Weld has the procedures in place to have a $500,000-a-year lease approved for Mr. Kraft. The lease would run for 65 years with two optional 16-year extensions and a possible rent increase after 10 years.
Opponents of the stadium have vowed to fight the Governor in the courts and in the State Legislature and the city is reviewing environmental regulations in hopes of tying up the project.
Although Mr. Kraft has insisted in meetings with South Boston leaders that the stadium would only be used for Patriot home football games, the lease terms would allow other events, including rock concerts.
City officials contend that this is a sweetheart deal, estimating that the land should rent for more than three times that much and that the whole area will drastically increase in value soon. This is because the new high-rise towers of the nearby financial district are spreading to the area near the now-desolate site proposed for the stadium, with a new Federal court house, luxury hotel and World Trade Center expansion already in the works. The changes are supported by what the city estimates are about $60-million in government-financed improvements, including toxic waste cleanup and a subway extension.
Mr. Kraft is banking on this business development for a market to sell some 6,000 special mid-field seats at $6,000 a year, with a minimum 10-year purchase necessary, which will give membership in the private, year-round club, with a restaurant, bar and meeting rooms. The stadium will also have an N.F.L. pavilion as a permanent tourist attraction.
The club memberships would provide Mr. Craft with $360 million. He has said that he expects to spend more than $200 million to build the stadium.
"It's certainly an interesting method of financing," one of the Mayor's men said, not without admiration, after producing a series of figures designed to show the project was a land grab at public expense.
Indeed, when Mr. Kraft rented space in the basement of Mr. Gifford's BankBoston for a mockup to encourage potential backers, what he built was not a model of the stadium itself, but of the club. It is a fine thing, testosterone as architecture, all wood-paneled walls, leather chairs, a marble bar, helmets and footballs resting on shelves.
Word leaking out last month about the plan sparked fury in South Boston, the insular, largely Irish neighborhood that feared it would be inundated on game days.
"This could be the last straw for people to pack up and leave," said Jimmy Kelly, the City Council president who first became prominent as an opponent of court-ordered busing for school integration in the neighborhood two decades ago.
"We are an automobile society and they will be taking their cars, tens of thousands of them through the heart of South Boston, and parking all over the neighborhood," he said. "And all the tailgating parties and painting their faces and socializing with their beers and cocktails. That's fine where there's elbow room. But not in somebody's neighborhood."
As a Bostonian, Mr. Kelly, one of the guests at the Mayor's party, became indignant at the suggestion that he was not a sports fan.
"The 1952 Red Sox, I could tell you the starting lineup, all their averages," he said. "But in the 50's they stayed with the team. They don't have the same kind of loyalty today. A lot of people have Patriot fever now and they're thinking with their hearts. But there's no loyalty anymore, they play for the highest bidder and after all the hoopla and the painting faces they could be gone. Its a sad thing its come to this."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BEGINS SPENDING TO SAVE CITY'S RESERVOIRS

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
New York City today began spending $660 million on a five-year program to cut the flow of pollution into its upstate reservoirs and avoid the need for a $4 billion filtration plant.
Under an agreement worked out among the city, New York State, Federal environmental officials and a coalition of small watershed communities, a typical New York City water bill of $400 a year will increase regularly until by the year 2002, it will be $435 a year, not counting other unrelated increases. The watershed-agreement increases will buy thousands of acres of land around the reservoirs, upgrade more than 100 aging sewage treatment plants, and support economic development projects in the Catskills. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed a foot-thick agreement today, ending 21 months of negotiations and decades of water-related litigation and bad blood between the city and its neighbors to the north.
The first city checks -- $13 million in "good neighbor" funds for villages and towns around the reservoirs -- are already written and ready to go, said Joel A. Miele Sr., the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner. Within 90 days, the Governor's office said, an additional $38 million will go to Westchester County and $30 million to Putnam County.
Mr. Miele said more than 13,000 acres had already been offered to the city by upstate property owners. With the Mayor's signature today, he said, appraisers and other city water officials could now begin buying parcels that fit the city's priorities.
Mr. Giuliani was joined in a ceremony at the Capitol by Gov. George E. Pataki, Federal environmental officials and local officials from communities around the Catskills and Hudson Valley. Mr. Pataki said the agreement effectively balanced the needs of the communities in the hills and valleys that produce the city's water with those of the millions of people who drink the water.
"It's going to save the city literally billions of dollars," the Governor said. "But it's going to allow a quarter of a million people who live in the watershed communities to have certainty as to what can be developed and how it can be developed."
Besides starting the flow of money, the signing sets in place the first new set of regulations for preventing pollution around the city's 19 upstate reservoirs since 1953. For four decades, the watershed towns have been operating under rules that still governed such things as "two-seat privies," said Michael C. Finnegan, the Governor's counsel and the principal architect of the talks leading to the upstate-downstate deal. But the new rules deal with a range of modern-day threats to clean water: everything from proliferating weekend homes and their septic fields to the possibilities of casinos in the Catkills.
The agreement effectively puts off until at least 2002 a threatened order by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to keep the city's water clean with a filtration plant, which would have been the largest such plant in the world, filtering more than a billion gallons of water a day from reservoirs west of the Hudson River.
"Had the Governor not exercised leadership here," Mr. Giuliani said, "had the city not cooperated with watershed communities, the city would have faced catastrophic costs."
Commissioner Miele said that if regular monitoring over the next 20 years shows the program is working, the city could be granted a permanent waiver of any order to filter the water.
Yesterday, Jeanne M. Fox, the regional administrator of the E.P.A., said she was optimistic that the agreement would protect the water supply, which serves nine million people in the city and surrounding communities. "Protecting public health comes first, and we think this agreement -- if it's complied with -- can work," Ms. Fox said.
Mayor Giuliani said, "This is a wonderful example of the Federal Government working with us rather than imposing mandates."
Some private environmental groups and state legislators said they were concerned about loopholes. An important gap in the deal is the lack of limits on construction of sewage treatment plants, said Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group. Added treatment capacity will only encourage more sprawl -- and more pollution, he said.
Nonetheless, other environmental groups enthusiastically praised the deal, saying some flexibility was essential to forging a compromise.
"There are 500 pages of specific things to do," said Chris Meyer, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a private organization that has been a frequent antagonist of the Mayor and the Governor on other environmental issues.

Map/Diagram: "IN THE WORKS: Keeping the Water Clean Enough to Drink"
 New York City agreed yesterday to spend $660 million over five years to safeguard its upstate watershed from pollution. Ninety percent of the city's drinking water comes from reservoirs in the Catskills, fed by rivers and streams threatened by sewage and runoff from the region's towns and farms. Inset shows how yesterday's agreement seeks to control the main sources of pollution.
 
SEWAGE PLANTS -- Improvements to 105 plants that discharge partly treated sewage in the watersheds.
 
FARMS -- Incentives to control runoff from fertilizer and livestock wastes.
 
DEVELOPMENT -- New York City will buy land to block new buildings and roads.
 
SEPTIC SYSTEMS -- New rules limiting construction close to streams.
 
Map shows watershed of New York City and diagram illustrates ways the City will seek to control pollution. (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OFFERS MEDICARE SAVINGS

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
One day after his inauguration, President Clinton made a conciliatory gesture to Congressional Republicans today by announcing that his budget proposal would contain more savings in Medicare than he was willing to consider last year.
At a White House appearance before a strategy session with his economic advisers, Mr. Clinton said his budget for the 1998 fiscal year would propose trimming the growth in Medicare spending by $138 billion over six years. 
 "The only way we can actually balance the budget is if we seize this moment to work together," he said. "And I'm going to do my best to reach out to the Republicans." He added, "I want to meet them halfway on this and on many issues. And I hope they'll meet me halfway."
Prominent Republicans, in fact, said the President had met them halfway, and they gave him high praise. When budget talks between Congress and the President collapsed last January, Republicans were seeking to rein in Medicare spending by $158 billion over six years, and Mr. Clinton had proposed $116 billion in reductions. While it was not clear today whether the President was using precisely the same economic forecasts in his latest proposal, he did appear to be trying to strike a mid-point.
Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, has been one of the most politicized issues dividing Republicans and Democrats as they have sparred over budget proposals over the past two years. Mr. Clinton and the Democrats campaigned hard against the Republicans on the issue in the 1996 campaign, running against the House Republicans' bid in 1995 to make $270 billion in savings over seven years in the program.
Democrats often went so far as to suggest that the Republicans wanted to dismantle Medicare altogether -- charges that the Republicans bitterly repudiated as scare tactics.
But today the tables were turned as influential Republicans praised the President's gesture while Democratic leaders of Congress remained conspicuously closed-mouthed.
"I am very encouraged by President Clinton's decision today to meet Republicans halfway on the Medicare savings level," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who chairs the House Ways and Means Committee. "This is a very positive and very significant development." Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who chairs the House Budget Committee, said, "This frankly brightens the prospects for being able to get a budget agreement."
Democrats, however, were circumspect. "We have not seen the details of it and I think until we know more about it we have to reserve judgment," said Laura Nichols, the spokeswoman for Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader. Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, also had no immediate comment.
Most of the savings in Mr. Clinton's proposal would come from health care providers, with hospitals losing $45 billion in payments over the six years, while health maintenance organizations would lose about $46 billion.
Administration officials said that their ability to propose more savings than they had previously endorsed would be made possible in part through a reduction in Medicare payment rates to H.M.O.'s. The H.M.O.'s are paid 95 percent of what the Government pays for beneficiaries in the standard Medicare program. The Administration would reduce that figure to 90 percent beginning in the year 2000.
Another $18 billion in savings over six years would come from Medicare recipients through the premium charged for Medicare services. Under law, the monthly premium paid by Medicare recipients is expected to drop after 1998 to below 25 percent of the cost of Part B of Medicare, which pays for doctors' services. In Mr. Clinton's proposal however, the percentage would hold relatively steady at 25 percent.
A recipient now pays a monthly premium of $43.80, which is about 26 percent of the Part B program's costs. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that in the year 2002, if current law remains in effect, the premium would be $51.50 a month and would pay for 20.8 percent of those costs. Using these assumptions, Mr. Clinton's proposal would result in a monthly premium of $61.90 in 2002, about 25 percent of the costs.
Bruce C. Vladeck, the adminstrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare, defended the increase at a briefing by noting that the Republicans' various Medicare plans had all included even higher premium increases.
On another question affecting Medicare premiums, Mr. Clinton's aides declined to rule out the possibility that the President might agree in negotiations with the Republicans to go further and make premiums contingent on a Medicare recipient's income.
"There are a number of policies that relate to premiums that could very well be acceptable to us in the right context and there are some other approaches that aren't," said Franklin Raines, the director of the Office of Management and Budget.
While Mr. Clinton would no longer be in office six years from now, any Medicare agreement he strikes with the Congress could produce long-term annual savings. Unlike most other Government spending, which is set annually in individual bills, changes in the Medicare program would be put into the permanent law and would have long-lasting effects, unless the changes were modified in the future.
The Administration has estimated that without any changes in the Medicare program, the trust fund that pays hospital bills will run out of money in the year 2001.
"In the long term, in the big picture we really do have to get a balanced budget done this year," said Gene Sperling, the director of the National Economic Council, "and we do have to address the Medicare trust fund this year."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Just Another Hot Night In Chicago

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
SAME old same old. Bulls-Knicks. Champions versus challengers. Practitioners of elegance versus promoters of ugly.
"Two styles," Phil Jackson declared in an unprepared statement that sounded just enough like another round of his never-ending war with whoever calls himself coach of the Knicks. "One of passing and cutting and shooting, and one of clutching and grabbing and holding." 
 Same old same old. Global icons versus East Coast enigmas. Michael Jordan versus Patrick Ewing. The ultimate Money Player versus a mere depositor of hefty checks.
Scottie Pippen versus Whoever You Think Is the Second-Best Knick.
Last night, that would have been Larry Johnson. Then Allan Houston for a few rousing moments in the fourth quarter. But Jordan had on his classic Knicks game face, and his jumper was falling. He scored 51 points. He screamed a few choice words at Jeff Van Gundy after the Knicks' coach claimed that Jordan offers young players phony friendship to gain a competitive edge, as if he needs one. The Knicks rallied from 17 points behind in the fourth quarter but came up short again, 88-87.
"I don't believe anything's really changed with this rivalry," Jackson said.
Same old same old. Bulls win. Knicks lose. With dignity, of course.
It took almost half the season for the Knicks to come face to face with their longtime playoff tormentors here, more than enough time for Zen Master Jackson to reveal his team's special motivation for thwarting the Knicks' ambitious urban-renewal program implemented last summer in an effort to restore Chicago to the status of Second City.
Jackson's message to his players: the Knicks are still a representation of everything that has gone wrong with professional basketball and it is therefore their duty to preserve the purity of the game, if not (lest we forget that Dennis Rodman once was and hopefully will be again a member of their team) the integrity of the sport.
"It's like Phil was telling us, 'Be ready for another rugby match,' because that's who they are," the reserve guard and 3-point-shooting specialist Steve Kerr said.
Told that the Knicks, despite the expensive additions designed to transfuse badly needed fluidity and fundamental skills into their offense, have nonetheless too often looked ugly this season, Kerr interrupted.
"It doesn't look ugly; it is ugly," he said. "They're sort of at the heart of the N.B.A. controversy -- the physical play, the low scores and people starting to say that they don't like our game anymore. It started with Detroit and then with Riley in New York and, unfortunately, it's spread to Cleveland and Atlanta."
No one quite expected the Knicks, with Ewing still their hub, to become a completely different body of work, but for the $157 million committed to Johnson, Houston and Chris Childs, a facelift should not have been out of the question. They hired Johnson and Houston to rewrite the equation, upscale the offense, free the Knicks from the physical strain of having to win by handcuffing the opposition, or worse. But when the Knicks desperately needed to score last night in the last six minutes of a game that was available for them to steal, they couldn't. They went about five minutes without a field goal. Ewing missed wild shots. Johnson disappeared. Houston finished 5 for 18.
It's a long way to the playoffs, but it is no hysterical contention that Johnson has thus far been the second coming of Charles Smith, while Houston has played like, well, Dallas. So timid has he been defensively that Van Gundy started Childs on Jordan in an obvious effort to spare Houston some pain. Childs exchanged rather unfriendly words with Jordan in the second quarter. Good move. Next time, forget the coach's advice, try a warm embrace. Jordan proceeded to torch all three of the rich new Knicks who took turns guarding him.
 The Knicks didn't quit. They never do. They clawed their way back with a 17-2 run. Then Jordan put them away. Then Pippen claimed that they were better off with Anthony Mason than with Johnson and that John Starks is "much better" than Houston. Then Jackson gave them credit for what he always does.
"Clutching, grabbing, holding," Jackson said. "The Knicks are very good at that."
As long as Jordan's been around, that's never been good enough.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strong Truck Sales Help Chrysler Post Robust Profit
Brisk sales of Jeeps, pickup trucks and mini-vans allowed Chrysler to announce unexpectedly strong results for the fourth quarter, closing out the company's second-most-profitable year ever.
Chrysler earned $807 million in the quarter, down 22 percent from a year earlier but well above most analysts' predictions. For the year, Chrysler earned $3.53 billion. [Page D2.]
 
Irish Bank in Pennsylvania Deal
Allied Irish Banks, which operates here as First Maryland Bancorp, agreed to acquire Dauphin Deposit, a Pennsylvania bank company, for $1.36 billion. [D2.]
 
Chase and Citicorp Profits Up a Bit
Chase Manhattan and Citicorp reported small increases in their profits for the fourth quarter. Chase's earnings were held down by the costs of the merger with Chemical Banking, while Citicorp's were curtailed by a decline in credit-card profits. [D2.]
 
Boeing Drops Plan for Bigger Jets
Boeing stock rose sharply after the company decided not to proceed with a plan to develop larger versions of its 747 jet. The move appears to concede the high end of the market to Airbus Industrie, though analysts said they doubted that Boeing was giving up much. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Stocks Continue to Gain
Stock prices surged, with the Dow industrials rising 40.03 points, to close at 6,883.90. [D10.]
 
Japanese stocks closed strongly today. The Nikkei index was up 655.72 points, or 3.78 percent.[D10.]
 
A Strong Year for Salomon
Salomon bounced back from a difficult 1995, as net income nearly doubled in 1996, driven by trading and investment banking. [D2.]
 
Results Surge for Exxon and Shell
Exxon and Shell reported big jumps in quarterly results as a result of sharply higher prices for crude oil and natural gas. [D2.]
 
Specialty Services Help Bells
Four regional telephone companies -- Pacific Telesis, SBC Communications, Nynex and Bell Atlantic -- reported generally healthy earnings, bolstered by profits from caller ID, call waiting and other specialty services. [D4.]
 
New Bonds Begin Trading
Inflation-indexed bonds began trading at surprisingly high prices and low yields as the Treasury Department announced plans for its first auction ever of such securities. [D17.]
 
An Olive Branch in South Korea
In a concession aimed at ending nearly a month of labor unrest, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea said that he was willing to allow the National Assembly to amend a new labor law, and he hinted at recognition of a union group that the measure outlaws. [A8.]
 
Intel Loosens Its Tie
Intel is planning a campaign that is infused with the kind of offbeat humor rarely found in computer advertising. One commercial features the actor Jason Alexander, who plays the whiny George on the NBC sitcom "Seinfeld." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
New Metro Business Coverage
Today, The New York Times is introducing Metro Business, in the Metro Section. Appearing Tuesday through Friday, it will include news and features on local business, from real estate to retailing. [B6.]
 
Microsoft has come from the West Coast to New York's Silicon Alley, seeking to buy original programming, but the seduction has not always been smooth as the software giant's suburban-office-park culture clashes with that of the downtown loft dwellers. [B1.]

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Captain's Place as a Yankee Great Is Secure

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
In "On the Waterfront," Marlon Brando as the boxer Terry Molloy says, "I coulda been a contender." In the Bronx today Don Mattingly could say, "I could have been a Hall of Famer."
Mattingly will be at Yankee Stadium to announce his retirement, a year after he took a leave of absence from baseball. The leave now becomes permanent and wise. 
 A completely healthy Mattingly could still be playing first base for the Yankees, could still be the productive and dangerous hitter he was early in his career. A healthy Mattingly could already have amassed statistics that would have catapulted him to Cooperstown.
But a chronic back problem, one that apparently could not be fixed with surgery, undermined Mattingly, robbed him of his power, his production and his place in the Hall of Fame. Some of his zealous fans will nevertheless argue for that honor, but Mattingly will have to be satisfied with knowing he had some great seasons for the Yankees and he was the No. 1 player in New York for more than a decade.
There was none better than the Mattingly, who was the scourge of American League pitchers from 1984 through 1989. Returning from an educational winter of baseball in Puerto Rico after his first major league season in 1983, the quiet left-hander surprised the Yankees with his new-found power to right field.
He had spent the winter working on pulling the ball and hitting for home-run power, and he graduated summa cum laude. Home runs, doubles, hits of all kinds flowed the next several seasons. He drove in runs, he scored them and he became the most feared hitter in the league.
He hit so well that his defensive play at first base became secondary, but it was first rate, too, also best in the league. At the same time, the two best defensive first basemen played in New York, but as much as Keith Hernandez meant to the Mets, he did not supersede Mattingly.
If Mattingly had any shortcoming in those years, it was his reluctance to use his status to improve economic life for other players. When he was preparing to go to salary arbitration in 1987, after a season in which he batted .352, hit 31 home runs, drove in 113 runs and led the league in hits (238) and doubles (53), Mattingly could have asked for any salary and won.
But for perhaps the only time in his professional life, Mattingly backed away, let himself be cowed by George Steinbrenner. The owner told his star player that if he attained too high a salary in arbitration, he would trade him. It was clearly a bluff -- if Steinbrenner had traded Mattingly, fans would have placed him on the first train out of the Bronx -- but Mattingly fell for it.
Instead of breaking the $2 million arbitration barrier, he sought and won $1,975,000. Too bad Steinbrenner could not have exercised the control over Mattingly's body that he had over his mind. Mattingly never voluntarily let anyone know that he was suffering with a bad back, but eventually his production began slipping and then plummeting. It atrophied along with his back.
A doctor who once examined Mattingly and saw all the test results said years before Mattingly took his leave of absence that he had no business continuing to play, indeed he didn't know how Mattingly did continue to play.
In his final six seasons, Mattingly hit a total of 58 home runs, averaged 64 runs batted in a season and batted .300 only once. In the career Yankees records, he is among the top eight of just about every important offensive category, hobnobbing with Ruth and Gehrig and DiMaggio and Mantle and Berra. But their achievements took them to Cooperstown, and his will not. Mattingly, however, has already won a spot in the Yankees fans' Hall of Hearts. He made an impression there that will not soon wither.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Don Mattingly, who will officially retire today at Yankee Stadium, in one of his last games as a Yankee. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Looking for a Space in the Crowd;
Foreign Car Makers Seek Low End of Sport Utility Niche

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Clutching a white plastic shopping bag full of car brochures, Carolyn Spicer, a 52-year-old credit union manager, stood at the North American International Auto Show here and carefully studied the light-gray, Jeep-like Honda CR-V on the platform. After looking at it from the front and the side, she guessed it would sell for $25,000 when it goes on sale next month.
So she was surprised to learn that the sticker price would be just $19,300 for a well-equipped model. "If they keep that price," she said, "it's going to really go." 
 That's exactly the reaction Honda has been hoping for, and precisely the one Detroit fears. After years of limited success, foreign auto makers are staging an all-out assault on America's sizzling market for sport utility vehicles, the crown jewels of Detroit's Big Three. With imports like the CR-V accounting for most of the new offerings, and with the dollar close to a four-year high against the Japanese yen and climbing against the German mark, foreign auto makers appear poised for big sales gains.
In the next four years, at least 17 Japanese and European companies plan to introduce new four-wheel-drive sport utility models into a market now dominated by Chrysler's Jeeps, Ford's Explorers and Expeditions and G.M.'s giant Suburbans, Tahoes and Yukons. This surge is a clear threat to American auto makers, all of which lose money on their cars while making their profits on sport utility vehicles and, to some extent, mini-vans and pickups.
"Without a doubt, the Japanese are going to be very aggressive" in the sport utility market, said Alexander Trotman, chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company. For Detroit-based companies, he said, "the weakness of the yen just makes the task a lot harder."
Not that auto executives or analysts actually expect sales of American-brand sport utility vehicles to fall. Drivers' appetite for these truck-like vehicles is still growing, and most new foreign models are considerably smaller and less powerful than Detroit's brawny road hogs.
But by focusing on more affordable alternatives -- American models often run as much as $30,000 or more -- foreign auto makers may be stealing a march on Detroit. The Chrysler Corporation, Ford and the General Motors Corporation have dominated this market for years because many sport utility vehicles began as little more than pickups with covered beds. With little expertise in truck-building, and with an initial skepticism that the craze would last, foreign auto makers dithered for years, only introducing a few models and not advertising them very heavily.
Now Japanese auto makers are pouring into the market with sport utility vehicles built on the chassis of small and midsized cars. G.M., Ford and Chrysler are all developing similar vehicles -- Chrysler is even looking at a sport utility version of its Neon subcompact -- but still have a couple of years' work to do. The few existing American models that cost less than $20,000, like the Jeep Wrangler and the Geo Tracker, are still quite truck-like.
Executives at the Honda Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation, which are making the most ambitious pushes with the new Honda CR-V and the highly successful Toyota RAV4, introduced last year, say each views the other as its main competitor. Both companies say they are particularly eager to offer sport utility models to their millions of remarkably loyal car owners, who might otherwise be tempted by American offerings.
But foreign auto makers also have their eye on people who used to buy upscale foreign sedans and now drive large American sport utilities instead. "The defectors that went to Explorers and these other vehicles are going to come back, because we're going to give them an alternative," said Richard A. Colliver, senior vice president of Honda's auto operations in the United States.
Most new foreign models will also be built abroad, which could add a couple of billion dollars a year to the American trade deficit with Japan in particular and could feed trade tensions. Foreign auto makers want to make sure they can capture a large chunk of the market before investing in new factories here to build sport utility vehicles.
The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, for example, plans to import 30,000 to 35,000 Montero Sports this year, a new model that went on sale in December for $17,620 to $31,110. "You need a minimum of 100,000 vehicles a year" to justify the assembly of a model in the United States, said N. Kevin Ormes, Mitsubishi's group vice president for sales and marketing. "Until you can get that kind of volume, you can't justify the costs."
But the biggest question is how large a share foreign auto makers will capture of this huge and growing market. Sport utility vehicles claimed 14.2 percent of the United States auto market last year, more than twice the 6.7 percent in 1990, and are also catching on in Japan, Latin America and the Middle East.
A statistical analysis by Ward's Autoinfobank and DRI/McGraw-Hill, two data research groups, predicts that as foreign models pour in, the heady growth of the American market will moderate this year.
The new analysis also forecasts that the Asian auto makers will capture 21.6 percent of the sport utility market, or 477,000, this year, up from 19.2 percent last year, or 411,550. European auto makers are predicted to double their share in the next four years, to 2.6 percent in 2000.
These vehicles are fabulously profitable. Ever since G.M. recovered its initial development costs years ago, it makes as much as $10,000 in pretax profit from each mammoth Suburban. Japanese profits are likely to be less because, by and large, they are selling smaller, less expensive vehicles in a more competitive market.
The strong American dollar, which has rebounded nearly 48 percent from its trough against the yen and nearly 27 percent from its trough against the mark both in April 1995, is giving foreign auto makers an extra lift. The dollar's turnaround has produced a sharp reversal in the fortunes of Japanese auto makers' subsidiaries in the United States, which now find it much more cost-effective to import vehicles and parts from Japan.
"It took the negative and turned it into a positive," said Richard L. Chitty, vice president for small cars at Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc.
Some American auto executives remain optimistic in the face of the latest competition. They point out, for instance, that most of the new Japanese models -- like the Honda CR-V and the Toyota RAV4 -- have four-cylinder engines. Most American sport utility vehicles have more powerful V6 or V8 engines, leading Detroit executives to dismiss foreign offerings as not big or rugged enough to satisfy buyers who dream of barreling down dirt roads in the Rockies.
Robert Lutz, Chrysler's vice chairman, said that the Honda CR-V was likely to steal sales mainly from the Honda Accord and other foreign cars, not his company's Jeeps. "Honda will sell a ton of those things, I'm convinced," said Mr. Lutz, a former Marine pilot, pausing to stir cream into his coffee with a black Swiss Army knife and then lick the blade. But the result of more foreign offerings, he said, will be more import buyers driving sport utility vehicles instead of cars.
The sentiment among some shoppers at the auto show here suggested that Mr. Lutz was right. Jeff Knudsen, a 43-year-old security company supervisor from Redford, Mich., who drives a Plymouth Acclaim but longs for a full-size Chevrolet pickup, took a look at the CR-V and scorned it as too small for the long road trips he takes.
"I like it, but it's not big enough for what I like to do," said Mr. Knudsen, his hands stuffed in the pockets of his shiny blue baseball jacket.
But the CR-V remains roomier than a midsize sedan. And as few as 3 percent of sport utility vehicle owners use them to tackle the rutted dirt roads that are a staple of television ads. So Japanese auto makers contend that their lighter, less powerful vehicles are perfectly adequate.
The Honda CR-V "is as off-road capable as I think anyone will want to drive it," said Thomas G. Elliott, executive vice president for automotive operations at the American Honda Motor Company Inc. "We don't expect people to go out and climb rocks with it," he added at Honda's American headquarters in Torrance, Calif.
The smaller engines of many imported sport utility vehicles also make them more fuel-efficient than the gas-guzzling American alternatives. If gasoline prices rise or if the Clinton Administration follows through on hints that it may raise fuel-efficiency standards for these vehicles, foreign producers could collect a bonanza.
Yet for reasons that are not entirely clear to market researchers, buyers of sport utility vehicles tend to be far more brand-loyal than car buyers are. So the relatively small market share of Japanese auto makers in these segments means they cannot count on a lot of previous customers returning to buy the next model.
The weakness of the Japanese economy in the early 1990's has also made Japanese auto makers reluctant to gamble huge sums on entirely new designs. So they have come up with sport versions of cars, like the Subaru Legacy Outback, which is really a station wagon with modest changes like a higher suspension, a stepped-up roof, and a reinforced chassis.
"We're really 10 or 15 years late coming to that market so we had to come with something different," said George T. Muller, the president of Subaru of America Inc., a unit of Fuji Heavy Industries based in Cherry Hill, N.J. In August, Subaru plans to introduce the Subaru Forester, which looks more like a traditional sport utility vehicle but is built on a chassis similar to the Outback's.
Japanese auto makers have had the most success selling sport utility vehicles like the Nissan Pathfinder to urban residents on the East and West Coasts. They have had less success selling them to Midwesterners and people who use the vehicles for their intended purposes, such as hunting and fishing trips and traveling to remote areas.
That may not change soon, said Jerry Hirshberg, the president of Nissan's North American design operations. "Pathfinder is not a car we designed with a gun rack in mind," he said.

HEADLINE: Times Expanding Nationwide Distribution

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
The New York Times will begin a series of major changes next month to make the daily more widely available around the country and to offer readers an improved paper with later-breaking news.
The changes illustrate the growing importance of The Times's circulation nationwide, but they will also be evident to readers in the metropolitan New York area who will receive papers with more up-to-date information because of new, later newsroom deadlines. 
 These are among the changes:
*On Feb. 18, The Times will introduce what amounts to another geographic edition, in addition to its local and national editions. It will begin printing at plants outside Boston and Washington for 110,000 Times buyers from Maine to Richmond who now get the New York edition. The new four-section edition will offer later-breaking news and sports results, a separate arts section and local weather and television listings. And the paper will be home-delivered to more distant suburbs in both the Boston and Washington areas.
*Reaching for readers in areas outside the Northeast, The Times has so far contracted with 33 daily newspapers around the country to deliver its national edition along with their own papers. A similar deal with a national magazine distributor will carry The Times to more than 25,000 retail outlets across the country within a year, up from 17,000 now, strengthening a weak link in the distribution of a paper that is often hard to find outside airports and hotels.
*Starting in September, after a $350 million printing plant at College Point, Queens, has begun to operate, The Times will expand its current four-section New York regional edition to six sections most weekdays. The expanded New York edition will have color photography and color advertising seven days a week, starting with sports and gradually working out to the rest of the paper, including the front page, by this time next year.
*Beginning early next year and continuing through 2000, the New York regional edition is expected to add new weekly theme sections -- health and technology are early possibilities -- to expand the paper's appeal to readers and specialty advertisers.
Although the plans have been largely shaped by a desire to offer readers later news and an improved paper, they fit into The Times's increased emphasis on building both nationwide circulation and the national advertising that runs in all editions. Seeking to counter declines in circulation and advertising, The Times sees opportunities both inside and outside metropolitan New York as local papers scale back national and foreign news as well as stock tables, Times executives said.
National advertising currently accounts for 44 percent of the total column inches in all editions, and, because of its premium price, 53 percent of ad revenues, with local and classified advertising providing the rest. By contrast, at The Los Angeles Times, the country's second-biggest seven-a-day-a-week paper after The Times, national advertising amounted to 15 percent of the total column inches in all editions last year.
"We were seeing particularly strong growth in national advertising," said Janet L. Robinson, president and general manager of The Times. "That made us examine where we were going after advertising and where we were going after circulation."
National advertising is not only more profitable than classified or local advertising, it also spreads the sources of revenue across the country, better insulating the paper from local economic slumps, Ms. Robinson said. Advertising revenue pays for two-thirds of the cost of production.
The Times has also sought to build on the encouraging circulation growth of its national edition. Since 1980, 95 percent of The Times's daily circulation gain has come from the national edition, which now has a weekday circulation of 279,000 and a Sunday circulation of 389,000. Subscribers outside the New York metropolitan area have also demonstrated less resistance to increases in the newspaper's price.
For the last few years, executives of The Times have explained their business model with a short, self-confident phrase: "Premium quality, premium price." The Times would deliver top-quality news and features, they explained, and in exchange readers would be willing to pay a high price and advertisers would pay high rates. Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times, said in an interview that the coming changes will "keep the promise" implicit in the "premium quality, premium price" idea.
The new editions printed in Boston and Washington will go to East Coast readers who live north of Hartford and south of Philadelphia. For those readers, the big change will be later-breaking news and expanded sports results. Currently, papers for these readers are trucked from the New York area, and the newspaper's press time must be early enough -- 9 P.M., currently -- to allow timely delivery.
Tying publication of the early edition to the movement of trucks instead of the events of the day makes little sense, said Joseph Lelyveld, executive editor of The Times. "We are just not serving our readers as well as we should be with our early edition," he said.
After renegotiating contracts with its production and delivery unions to allow printing in Boston and Washington, The Times will be able to deliver from locations much closer to its readers. That means press times will be pushed back to 10:45 P.M. for papers going outside Boston and Washington, and midnight for papers delivered within those metropolitan areas. The midnight press time will make the paper more competitive with the deadlines of many papers.
The 762,000 buyers of the New York regional edition will also get later news and sports. Press times for that edition will be 11:15 when the overhaul begins in September and 11:30 starting next January. Some readers, primarily in outlying areas of the New York metropolitan area, now get papers produced as early as 9 P.M.
The new edition will allow The Times for the first time to extend home delivery beyond Boston and Washington and their close-in suburbs, into towns like Nashua and Manchester in New Hampshire and perhaps as far south as Richmond, Norfolk and Charlottesville in Virginia. The Times insists, and Wall Street analysts generally agree, that the added presence in New England will not hurt sales of The Boston Globe, which is owned by The Times, because the two publications do not compete on local news.
Using other newspapers to make home deliveries and Magazines Distribution Inc. to stock The Times on retail shelves is far cheaper than having the paper do those tasks itself. The Times's home delivery agreement with The Chicago Tribune, for example, will permit home deliveries beyond the close-in suburbs of Chicago, adding such markets as Joliet, Aurora and Elgin in Illinois and Hammond, Ind.
Ms. Robinson predicts that along with early distribution of a nationwide Sunday Preview edition, which began last May, these initiatives will add 7,000 to 10,000 in daily circulation and 10,000 to 15,000 to the Sunday paper by the end of this year alone. By the end of the century, she said, The Times will have grown by 29,000 on weekdays and 103,000 on Sunday.
The Times's circulation and advertising have fallen from their peaks. Weekday sales have declined by more than 100,000 since 1993, to about 1.1 million, while the Sunday paper has lost about 80,000 in sales, falling to 1.7 million. And total advertising linage has fallen to 3.8 million inches last year from a peak of 6.1 million in 1987.
Aggressive price increases for advertisers and readers in recent years account for, and offset, part of the decline, Times managers maintain. But no newspaper with national ambitions can sustain continuous circulation slippage, analysts contend.
James Dougherty, an advertising and publishing analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, is among those on Wall Street who worry that the circulation and advertising problems many newspapers are experiencing are not easily solvable.
"The things the Times management is doing are absolutely sensible," Mr. Dougherty said. "The paper has a large constituency outside the New York area, and the easier it is for people to get the paper, the better off it will be. However, they don't solve the big issue, which is that you have a lot of people who aren't reading papers anymore, and a lot of advertisers who just are not buying into newspapers."
Steven N. Barlow, senior media analyst with Smith Barney, is more optimistic on The Times's outlook, crediting relatively mundane events. Lower newsprint prices, aggressive staff reductions and other cost-cutting at The Times are the basis for his prediction that the company's earnings will grow to $2.15 a share this year from his estimate of $1.80 last year, and that the stock price, currently at $40.625, will reach about $45 by next year. The stock price stood at $29 a year ago.
The new edition for the Northeast and the Washington area along with the College Point plant "are like a $1 billion face lift for the Old Gray Lady," said Mr. Barlow, who now rates The New York Times Company a strong buy. "That is going to make investors start paying attention."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Big Industrial Nations Signal Confidence in Strong Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surpassed 119 yen for the first time in nearly four years yesterday and rallied against other currencies on signs that the richest industrialized nations want the United States currency to strengthen.
The dollar also benefited from an optimistic appraisal of the American economy on Tuesday by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. It was aided as well by a growing suspicion that the Bank of Japan, the Japanese central bank, would not intervene to protect the yen and fresh evidence of economic weakness in Japan and Germany. 
 It was one of the broadest one-day gains in the dollar since the currency began appreciating sharply against the mark and yen late last year. The latest rally has pushed the dollar up nearly 3 percent against the yen and nearly 7 percent against the mark in the first three weeks of 1997.
"Basically we've had some substantial dollar moves today," Jesse Torres, vice president and chief dealer at the New York branch of Bank Austria, said. "People realize that the dollar continues to be a good investment."
The dollar hit an intraday high of 119.20 yen, the strongest since February 1993, before settling late in New York at 119.03 yen, up from 117.94 on Tuesday. The dollar also traded as high as 1.6454 marks, the strongest since June 1994, before settling in New York at 1.6427, up from 1.6286 on Tuesday. The pound fell sharply on the dollar's strength to $1.6300, from $1.6628 on Tuesday. It was the weakest level in nearly three months.
Traders said the main force driving the dollar came from remarks by Japanese and French officials suggesting that the Group of Seven industrialized nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- all want the dollar to continue to rise.
Backing off his statement of concern about the yen's weakness on Tuesday, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mutsuzuka of Japan said the major industrialized nations support the encouragement of a strong dollar.
The mark's weakness partly reflected new indications of a faltering German economy in data from the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, which convenes its policy making council today amid speculation that it might lower interest rates.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Rises to 5-Month High And Gold Tumbles Further

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Coffee prices jumped to a five-month high on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York yesterday amid concern that a Colombian dock workers' strike and a disappointing Brazilian crop would reduce exports from the world's two top producers.
On other markets, gold dropped to its lowest price since September 1993 and soybeans fell. 
 A strike at Colombia's key Pacific port of Buenaventura entered its ninth day, delaying shipment of at least 210,000 132-pound bags, the Colombia Coffee Growers Federation said.
At the same time, concern is mounting that Brazil's coffee crop will fall well short of Department of Agriculture projections of 27 million bags. Brazilian officials said on Monday that the nation's harvest, normally one-fourth of global supplies, could be as low as 18 million bags.
Coffee for March delivery rose 5.65 cents, to $1.353 a pound, on the highest price for an active contract since Aug. 26.
Gold dropped as the dollar surged against major currencies, raising the cost to foreign investors.
The dollar climbed to a 47-month high against then yen and a two-and-a- half-year high against the Deutsche mark, powered by expectations that the major industrial nations would not act to halt its rise.
Gold prices, suffering from forecasts for muted inflation and the prospect of central bank sales, are down 4.7 percent so far this year as investors look for more attractive returns elsewhere.
"Gold has suffered all around the world from asset relocation," said Bridget Fraser, a vice president of commodity-based derivatives at Bankers Trust in New York. "The traditional gold holders are looking for alternative investments -- the outlook for gold isn't great. Prices are going lower."
Gold for February delivery fell $2.10, to $351.70 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange's Comex division, its lowest closing price since Sept. 17, 1993.
Soybean futures fell amid expectations that recent rains in South America could cause a bumper harvest.
Soybeans for March delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade fell to $7.405 a bushel, down 6.25 cents.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says New York Outdid Suburbs in '96 Job Growth

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
One of the tenets of economics in America is that suburbs create more jobs than cities. Last year, New York City broke that pattern. For the first time since 1980, the city outshone its entire suburban encirclement of office parks and edge cities in making new jobs.
Of the 70,000 net new private jobs added in the 27-county region tracked by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, 37,000 were in the five boroughs of New York City -- a slim majority, but a majority nonetheless. Over most of the last 17 years, the city has never come even close to that. Through the boom years for job creation from 1979 to 1988, for example, New York accounted for only about one quarter of the one million new jobs created in the region. 
 The changing balance between the growth rates of city and suburbs is partly because suburban job creation has slowed. "The city is driving the growth," said John L. Wieting, the New York regional commissioner for the statistics bureau. "That's a break in the historic pattern."
Mr. Wieting and other economists said that one year's worth of numbers, while providing a mirror to the growth that New Yorkers have already witnessed in places like Times Square and downtown Brooklyn, do not necessarily suggest the arrival of a long-term trend. Nor do they point to a dazzling economic boom.
New York City's private job base rose only 1.3 percent in the 12 months ending Nov. 30, better than in 1995 but less than in 1994 or 1993, which were both strong years of economic recovery from the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's. Growth in the suburban job base in 1996 slowed even more, rising only 0.8 percent. Both lagged far behind the national growth rate of 2.4 percent in the period, according to Federal figures.
What the New York numbers do suggest -- especially in some major areas like retailing and manufacturing, where the city has long been the weakest link in the regional economic chain -- is a shift, at least for now, in the local balance of power. More people were working in New York in October in the retail trade category, for example -- nearly 571,000 jobs, up 3,000 in 1996 -- than in any comparable October since 1990, according to figures from the New York State Department of Labor.
Equally profound is that the city did better, or at least less badly, than the surrounding counties in holding onto manufacturing jobs. The city lost manufacturing jobs, as it has nearly every year since the early 1970's. But in the suburbs, where corporate downsizing and restructuring continued to be a major force at places like AT&T, New Jersey's largest private employer, the hemorrhage was worse. Of the 19,000 manufacturing jobs that disappeared, only 5,000 were in the city.
Job growth in areas like motion picture production, on the other hand, which contributed 6,600 new jobs, indicate larger national and international changes in which the city stands to benefit uniquely.
An increasing number of internationally produced film projects, in particular, have found New York to be a convenient halfway point between Hollywood and Europe for both financing and production, according to Harold Vogel, an entertainment industry analyst at Cowan & Company. A strengthened Canadian dollar also helped, he said, by making Toronto -- one of New York's main competitors for urban movie sets -- more expensive.
There were also indications of internal changes in the city's economy.
The securities industry, buoyed by the bull market for stocks, fueled much of the city's job creation. But that growth was mostly in the businesses that serve the needs of Wall Street, like printers, legal services and accountants, which added 12,500 jobs -- making up the single largest component of the job creation.
In what may be a portent of a restructuring industry, job growth in traditional high-paying jobs like brokers increased less than in previous booming stock years, partly because of labor-saving technology, according to an analysis by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Another major wrinkle in the city's trajectory is that it continues to be the center of shrinking public employment, as state, Federal and local governments -- especially New York City's government -- reduce their work forces. The city lost more than 9,000 public jobs in the city in 1996, according to state and Federal figures.
If that public employment deficit is subtracted from the net growth in private jobs, the city's total growth shrinks to 28,000 jobs, while the rest of the region -- less affected by government job cuts -- still has a growth of 30,000 jobs.
Another regional wrinkle indicated in the job creation numbers is that some parts of the region outside New York are doing better than others. Long Island, in particular, emerged in 1996 as a center of suburban job growth, according to Rae D. Rosen, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Ms. Rosen said that Long Island shares some of the same strengths as New York, with fewer of the city's weaknesses.
"Long Island doesn't have the drag of government layoffs, and it's adding more retail employment," she said.
