HEADLINE: Madeleine Albright's Agenda

 BODY:
Riding the magic carpet of yesterday's unanimous Senate confirmation vote, Madeleine Albright becomes Secretary of State today. She can be an eloquent champion of freedom around the world. How skillfully she blends that calling with the pragmatic politics of American diplomacy will define her stewardship at the State Department.
Restoring America's traditional interest in democracy and the rule of law to the heart of Washington's foreign-policy agenda would be a service to the nation and the world. As America's chief diplomat and principal voice on international issues, Ms. Albright must carry out President Clinton's decisions. But she also has an extraordinary opportunity to shape the debate. She should use it to restore a better balance to policies that have become excessively driven by commercial considerations. 
 America's national interests sometimes call for putting commercial or security concerns ahead of human rights issues. It makes sense, for example, to negotiate with Stalinist North Korea on nuclear weapons issues, to expand trade with a less than fully democratic Mexico and to maintain economic exchanges and diplomatic dialogue with a China that torments democrats and dissidents and bullies its smaller neighbors.
But such diplomatic realism does not require Washington to mute its distaste for provocative and repressive policies, as it has most conspicuously done in the case of China. Overlooking such behavior weakens American credibility abroad and feeds cynicism at home. The American people expect their foreign policy to reflect American ideals.
Madeleine Albright is ideally equipped to speak out forcefully on freedom's behalf. Her background as a refugee from both Nazism and Communism has taught her the differences between democracy and dictatorship and made her sensitive to the need to reinforce market and electoral reforms with independent civic institutions. Her strong scholarly grasp of foreign policy has now been seasoned by four years of experience at the United Nations.
She takes office at a propitious moment for new initiatives on democracy and human rights. President Clinton has grown more comfortable and experienced with foreign policy. The notable successes already achieved on trade, Bosnia, relations with Russia, Middle East peace and choosing a new United Nations Secretary General will free Ms. Albright from some of the burdens of crisis management that preoccupied Warren Christopher.
It can be a remarkable match of personal qualities and political opportunity. Ms. Albright should make the most of it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Shrinking Science Budget

 BODY:
The National Academy of Sciences reports that Federal spending on basic research and new technologies in 1997 will barely rise above 1996 levels, despite years of steady decline. Even worse, the five-year deficit reduction plan, as embraced by Congress and President Clinton, will knock 35 percent out of the country's science programs by the year 2002. The trend is ominous because research pays big dividends, accounting for perhaps half the growth in living standards and raising output by 30 cents or more on each invested dollar.
The National Academy estimates that Washington spends about $40 billion on activities that add to scientific knowledge. Biomedical research, primarily at the National Institutes of Health, gets about 30 percent of the science budget. The National Science Foundation, which funnels money into university research, accounts for only about 5 percent. Programs outside the Institutes of Health have fallen by about 10 percent since 1994. 
 If Congress and the President insist on balancing the budget by 2002 while giving away $100 billion in tax cuts, they may have to trim the total spending on all discretionary programs by 30 to 40 percent. But some programs, like border patrols and public health, will be left alone. That will force Congress to take even more from programs like science, where there is no short-term payoff.
Mr. Clinton promised in 1992 that he would promote economic growth through public investments. The budget plan for 1998 that he will deliver to Congress early next month may propose only small reductions. But after 2000, he and Congress will find themselves on a destructive course.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL;
White Wants Pulpit Between Hash Marks

BYLINE: By Timothy W. Smith 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
They call Packers defensive end Reggie White the minister of defense. It's a clever play on the fact that White is an ordained minister and an associate pastor at the Inner City Church in Knoxville, Tenn., and one of the most menacing pass rushers in the National Football League.
White is a reverent man. He believes that God paved the way for the Packers to get into the Super Bowl so that he could have a platform to advance his ministry. 
 But that platform might not extend beyond the final whistle of the game against the Patriots on Sunday.
If the Packers win the Super Bowl, White may want to use the post-game moments to say a prayer in front of the stadium crowd and, possibly, on live television. Some people in the N.F.L., however, are concerned about this and have discussed it in meetings, according to a person familiar with the situation.
To the league, the post-game platform at the Super Bowl is reserved for presentation ceremonies and live televised interviews of players and coaches.
Players often kneel in prayer on the field during and after a game. But should White be able to express his religious views to a worldwide audience simply because his team was victorious in a football game? Does religion have a place in the N.F.L., sharing space on stage with the league's signature event?
Greg Aiello, a league spokesman, said the N.F.L. had not discussed the situation in any staff meetings and that no request had been made for any formal post-game prayer ceremony.
This is not an issue with any real villains, but it is a delicate situation. If White could espouse religious views, why not someone else with a political agenda? The league can't take away White's First Amendment rights to free speech, but it can deny him a free microphone.
Christianity and spirituality are pervasive in society and in the N.F.L., and they have had a strong presence around the Packers during this Super Bowl week. White's spirituality is a strong influence in the Packers' locker room. He often prays with teammates like receiver Don Beebe and tight end Keith Jackson and has many other believers on the team.
This belief is strong, too. Desmond Howard, the Packers' ace punt-return specialist, said he was troubled by a severe hip injury in training camp. Being a free agent who had bounced around with a couple of teams before joining the Packers, Howard was worried that he would not heal fast enough to make an impact before the final cuts. A former first-round pick by the Redskins, Howard was running out of chances.
"I consulted with Reggie," Howard said. "We prayed together. He prayed for my hip to heal. It got better. I was able to play in the first preseason game and I returned a punt 77 yards."
Jackson said players believe so strongly in White's ministry, which Jackson described as "teaching a man to fish," that several players donated money from an N.F.L. Players Association dues rebate to White's ministry. It totaled about $170,000.
Jackson said the players have a greater awareness of their responsibilities to the outside world.
"It starts with Reggie and guys like me and Don Beebe," Jackson said. "We're willing to take a role-model stance, reach out to kids and say, 'Hey, this is not what you're supposed to be doing.' We're an unselfish team and we echo that message to little league and high school football teams. We accept the role of a role model."
Quarterback Brett Favre, one of the Packers' most irreverant players, doesn't feel he has to rein himself in when he is around White. They do, however, have a very good relationship.
"Whether or not you believe what Reggie believes or not, you have to respect him," Favre said. "He doesn't do anything for himself. Everything he does is for other people. He's a good person and he means well."
White is trying to rebuild his Knoxville church, which was destroyed by arson a year ago.
White has said that through his ministry, he offers low-interest business loans. He said he had been trying to contact Magic Johnson about an idea to build 24-hour basketball gymnasiums next to the movie theaters Johnson is building in inner-city neighborhoods around the country. White said they have a proposal from the city of Indianapolis to build a 24-hour gym.
"To me, when you help people out of their situations you don't have to preach much to them," White said. "In order to meet people's spiritual needs, we have to meet some of their economic needs. That's what we've been working on."
White believes the country will be a better place if people become more spiritually enlightened.
For White, who has said that God has made the football field his pulpit, religion and football are as natural as a three-point stance.
"A lot of people ask me questions about football and religion," he said. "But the thing is that there are people's lives at stake. I don't see the problem. Most of you guys, when we get down in the end zone and pray or get together and pray on the field, you have a real problem when it comes to that.
"But there are people who write me letters, whose lives have changed, who have read my book, who are better fathers, better husbands, better men and women for it. That's what it's all about. That's why I don't understand when you guys have a problem with it when people's lives are being changed."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Selling Missiles It Once Banned

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Just a few years after they ended their nuclear arms race, the United States and Russia are locked in a fierce competition for arms sales to Southeast Asia, with both countries offering potential purchasers some of the world's most sophisticated missiles as incentives.
From Thailand to Malayasia, countries shopping for advanced fighter aircraft are demanding -- and receiving -- the chance to buy deadly accurate, air-to-air missiles that allow a jet pilot to shoot down an enemy plane he can not even see -- indeed, one that might be as far as 30 miles away. 
 When Thailand first asked for the missiles, known as Amraams -- an acronym for their formal name of advanced medium range air-to-air missile -- Clinton Administration officials rejected the request. The officials feared that the sale could cause regional instability and trigger an arms race.
Bangkok immediately said that if the United States blocked the sale of the missiles, it would not buy American-made F-18 jets, a pending deal worth nearly $600 million. The Thais made it clear they were considering the Russian MIG-29, which can carry a similar missile.
Washington eventually capitulated, even though American and Thai officials say Bangkok did not really want to buy a plane from Russia.
The Amraam's journey from a weapon that Washington zealously protected to one that is now available to a range of countries illustrates what happens once arms restrictions are relaxed even a little, American officials and arms control advocates said in interviews.
"Once we've said 'yes' to one, it is hard to say 'no' to the next," said an official in Washington.
American officials said this week that the decision to provide the missile to the Thai Air Force opens the door for other countries in the Association of South East Asian nations to make similar requests, although each would still face a case-by-case review.
The sale of Amraams to Thailand is also a telling illustration of the workings of the global arms bazaar. These days, American officials say, it is business, not ideology, that is driving sales.
During the Cold War, the Pentagon advocated restrictive policies on arms sales, particularly of sophisticated weapons that might fall into enemy hands. Now, the military services push the arms trade as a way of helping defense contractors suffering from cutbacks.
The aim, American officials said, is to drum up sufficient business to keep the defense manufacturers profitable and ready to serve the American military.
The Amraam was one of the most effective weapons for the American-led alliance that routed Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.
Navy admirals, whose pilots fly the F-18, were among the earliest advocates of clinching the sale to the Thai Air Force by including Amraams in the deal.
Just a few years ago, the United States would permit the sale of Amraams only to NATO allies.
Then, in 1995, the United Arab Emirates went shopping for 80 combat jets, a deal worth between $6 billion and $8 billion, which the oil-rich country could afford, though there were questions about whether it had enough qualified pilots.
The Emirates demanded various types of sophisticated gear for their planes, and at the top of the list was the Amraam, American officials said.
After an intense debate, and over opposition from the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the Clinton Administration agreed. With that, Lockheed's F-16 has now emerged as the likely winner of the contract, edging out the French Mirage.
After the sale to the United Arab Emirates, Thailand demanded the same missiles. "We caved to them as well," said a State Department official in Washington. "It shows how the threshold gets passed."
Now, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, which have been turned down in the past on requests for Amraams, are expected to come knocking again. And this time it will be hard to say no, American officials said this week.
Because of Amraam's "extremely good" potential to hit aircraft out of visual range, any air force that has it enjoys a clear advantage over the enemy, according to Jane's Defense Weekly, a publication that assesses military weapons systems.
In seeking to buy Amraams, the Thais are not preparing for an imminent war, Western military analysts said. Rather, they are modernizing their air force in line with Bangkok's status as a growing economic and political power.
"Even in the absence of a specific threat, the Thais are correct in their strategic thinking," a senior Western military officer said about Bangkok's purchase of Amraams.
The F-18, the French-built Mirage and Russia's MIG-29 all would have fulfilled Thailand's needs, he and other military analysts said.
The MIG-29 is an extremely good combat plane, and is less expensive than either the French or American jets. But its "Achilles heel," as one Western military officer put, is that maintenance and service are not at the same level. And many countries, including Thailand, are still reluctant to buy from Russia.
The Malaysians bought MIG's three years ago, in large part because the Russians agreed to offset part of the price with the purchase of Malaysian palm oil.
Similarly, in Thailand, McDonnell Douglas, manufacturer of the F-18, agreed to buy some Thai products -- from rubber to frozen chickens -- in order to sweeten the deal.
"It was a high stakes game," said a senior Western military official in the region. "Had we called their bluff, it's anyone's guess what might have happened."
With so much money at stake, Washington was not willing to take the risk. A senior American diplomat added, "We couldn't tolerate a treaty ally buying a Russian jet."
The Thais won't get the missile technology right away, not until someone else in the neighborhood gets comparable technology. But that is a question of when, not if, American officials said. Malaysia already has MIG-29's, and it has promises from Russia for eventual sale of the sophisticated missiles.

HEADLINE: A Top Canadian Visits Cuba, Nettling Washington

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Jan. 22

 BODY:
In a brief visit that clearly signaled the sharp divisions between the United States and Canada over how to deal with Cuba, Canada's Foreign Minister dined with President Fidel Castro and other Cuban officials on Tuesday before signing joint declarations today on human rights and foreign investment.
In Washington, the State Department criticized the overnight visit by the Foreign Minister, Lloyd Axworthy, the highest-ranking Canadian to set foot in Cuba in more than 20 years. 
 "It doesn't make sense to reward a dictator in our hemisphere who is completely behind the times," said the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, even before Mr. Axworthy had arrived in Havana on Tuesday. "You reward him by sending your Foreign Minister down there, by having visits as usual, by trading. We think that's wrong."
Today, however, the State Department tempered its response, with Mr. Burns expressing "the highest personal respect for Minister Axworthy." He reserved critical remarks for Cuba, voicing skepticism that its Government was prepared to take "systematic and meaningful steps that would lead to a transition to democratic rule."
Mr. Axworthy, who has been a vocal critic of American policy toward Cuba and the Clinton Administration's attempt last year to toughen its longstanding economic embargo, called the trip the culmination of a yearlong series of meetings between senior Canadian and Cuban officials. He said it probably signals even closer relations between the two countries, as Canada tries to play a greater role in the hemisphere.
"Cuba comes up on our radar scope as a much higher priority than before," Mr. Axworthy said in an interview on Tuesday. "Canadians are discovering a whole new world south of our southern neighbor."
The substance of the visit consisted of a mildly worded joint statement issued today before Mr. Axworthy's departure saying that Canada would help Cuba do more to respect human rights, but containing no mechanism to force the Cuban Government to do so. The countries agreed to cooperate on human rights by preparing seminars and exchanging human rights experts. The statement also pledged greater protection for foreign investments.
But those declarations were secondary to the imagery of the visit, which came just hours after the end of festivities for President Clinton's second inaugural.
Mr. Axworthy spent much of the time meeting with Cuba's Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina. Mr. Robaina was clearly elated to be host to the most senior Canadian official to be received in Havana since Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau in 1976, a visit that was as much an annoyance to the United States as this trip is now.
"Your country does not share the policy of isolation and blockade," Mr. Robaina said to Mr. Axworthy at the start of the brief working session that preceded the state dinner. "And our country is grateful for that."
Mr. Castro warmly welcomed Mr. Axworthy to the ornate Palace of the Revolution for a formal dinner Tuesday evening of lobster cocktail and baby lamb chops, topped off by Cohiba Esplendidos, expensive Cuban cigars.
Mr. Castro also had lunch with the Canadian officials this afternoon. Reporters were banned from both meetings, but as the Cuban leader was leaving the Canadian Ambassador's residence he said that the visit had produced "better understanding of each other and lots of good conversation."
"We talked of many things, many things, but among friends," Mr. Castro said in pointed reference to the unwillingness of the United States to deal directly with Cuba. "Among friends you can talk about everything."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Axworthy had been taken by Cuban officials to an oil-drilling operation in the beach resort of Varadero that had been taken over recently by a Canadian company, Sherritt International. A huge American-made Caterpillar motor sat there, along with several mud pumps that were clearly marked as having been made in the United States, all in Cuba in violation of the economic blockade.
Cuba's Vice President, Carlos Lage, seemed to best capsulize the importance of the visit when he said that the presence of the American equipment at a Canadian project in Cuba showed how ineffective the United States blockade had been.
"Canada is showing that it is possible to be a friend of the United States and of Cuba too," Mr. Lage said.
Canada and the United States have been at odds over Cuba since the first days of the Cuban revolution 38 years ago. Washington has tried to isolate Cuba and Mr. Castro diplomatically, while imposing increasingly economic blockades.
Mr. Clinton had shown signs of being willing to negotiate more directly with Cuba until two Cuban MIG's shot down a pair of unarmed civilian planes flown by anti-Castro dissidents from Miami in February 1996. Under pressure from Cuban-Americans, the President then shifted direction and signed the Helms-Burton Act, which seeks to punish foreign business executives, including Canadians, who do business with Cuba.
For its part, Canada never severed its diplomatic and commercial ties with the island, arguing that close contact, rather than isolation, would help move Cuba toward democracy.
Canada enjoys a substantial and growing trade with Cuba, with Canadian businesses investing in hotels, restaurants and other businesses that have been closed to companies from the United States.
Last year, trade between Canada and Cuba exceeded $430 million and was growing by more than 10 percent a year. Canada sends down machinery, wheat and other products and buys lobsters, sugar and nickel from Cuba.
Canadians are also among the largest groups of tourists to Cuba, with 156,000 visiting last year, a 10 percent increase over 1995.
In addition, Canada provides financial support to several non-governmental organizations in Cuba, including the Centro Felix Varela, which lobbies for sustainable development and homosexual rights, among other issues, but not broader political change.
"If what the U.S. Congress wants is to see changes take place in Cuba -- and we support those changes, but go about it in a different way -- I can't see what they have to complain about," Mr. Axworthy said.
But Marc Thiessen, a spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and a sponsor of Helms-Burton, said: "The whole thing is a ruse. If Mr. Axworthy thinks that coming away with a piece of paper signed by Castro is going to make one bit of difference, then I have a bridge I can sell him."
The Helms-Burton Act has created a rift between the United States and its closest allies while prompting Cuban retaliation. Earlier this month, Cuba passed tough new measures that would punish any Americans who filed a suit under the Helms-Burton Act by excluding them from any future compensation for expropriated property.
On Jan. 3, Mr. Clinton delayed for a second six-month period the part of the act that would have allowed Cuban-Americans to file such suits against foreign businesses that have taken over property once owned by American companies in Cuba.
Canada has adopted measures to block the impact of the law. It also has threatened to bring a complaint against the United States because the Helms-Burton Act violates the North American Free Trade Agreement, which guarantees free passage of businessmen in the United States, Canada and Mexico, the three countries that signed the agreement.
Officials of Sherritt International have been denied entry to the United States because the company runs a huge nickel-smelting operation in Cuba that was owned by the American company Freeport-McMoRan of New Orleans before the 1959 revolution.
Mr. Axworthy said no decision had yet been made to go forward with the complaint.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Fidel Castro receiving Canada's Foreign Minister, Lloyd Axworthy, at a formal dinner in the Palace of the Revolution in Havana. (Canadian Press)

HEADLINE: Albright Picks 2 Diplomats For Top Posts

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Madeleine K. Albright, who was confirmed today by the Senate as Secretary of State by a vote of 99 to 0, has chosen two highly experienced government hands for top jobs in the State Department.
Thomas R. Pickering, 65, the senior professional diplomat in the Foreign Service -- named Ambassador a half-dozen times, most recently serving in Moscow -- will return after a short retirement to become Under Secretary for Political Affairs, the third-ranking job in the State Department, Clinton Administration officials said. He will replace Peter Tarnoff. 
 Stuart E. Eizenstat, 54, a Georgian who ran domestic policy for President Carter and serves as Under Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, will become Under Secretary for Economic Affairs in the State Department. He succeeds Joan E. Spero.
Ms. Albright, 59 and born in Prague, is expected to be sworn in by President Clinton on Thursday, the first woman to be Secretary of State. By choosing people of such stature for the two appointments, she is understood to be sending a signal to other government departments that she intends that the State Department play the leading foreign-policy role on issues like Mexico, China and Japan, which have had strong economic components.
The Senate vote "signals a new era of bipartisan foreign policy, and I can't wait to get started," Ms. Albright told reporters at the American Mission to the United Nations in New York, where she has been serving as American delegate.
With Mr. Pickering, who has had perhaps the most successful career of any professional diplomat of his generation, Ms. Albright is sending an encouraging message to the Foreign Service officers who are the backbone of the State Department.
Ms. Albright's predecessor, Warren Christopher, was sometimes criticized for letting the Treasury and Commerce Departments, in particular, take the dominant position in policy formulation toward Asia and Latin America.
Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, a close friend of Mr. Clinton's and a prime architect of the Administration's policy toward the former Soviet Union and NATO, will remain in his post for the present. Mr. Talbott, who has been managing the parallel task of NATO expansion and negotiating a document governing NATO's strategic relationship with Russia, is expected to stay at least through July, when the alliance will announce its new members at a Madrid summit conference.
Mr. Pickering stepped down in November as Ambassador to Russia after more than 30 years with the State Department. He was first named an Ambassador in 1974, when he served in Jordan, and has also been Ambassador to Nigeria, El Salvador, Israel and the United Nations.
Mr. Pickering returned to Washington to become director of the Eurasia Foundation, a small, nonprofit organization that works with the post-Soviet states. He is said to have agonized over leaving the foundation so quickly, but both Ms. Albright and Mr. Clinton asked him to take the new job, which he had sought before his retirement.
Mr. Eizenstat, who has also served as American envoy to the European Union, has recently been managing a difficult task: trying to persuade the European Union, Canada, Mexico and other crucial American allies to join Washington in isolating Fidel Castro's Cuba, as called for in the Helms-Burton law, which the President signed last year.
While the European Union still objects to Washington's effort to place sanctions on European companies and business executives for otherwise legal trading ties to Cuba, Mr. Eizenstat has succeeded in getting the Europeans to take a more vocal public stance against Cuban human-rights abuses, enabling Mr. Clinton to renew a waiver of the most contentious part of the law. That section would allow American citizens to bring suit in American courts against foreign companies that operate in property expropriated from Americans, without compensation, when Mr. Castro took power nearly 40 years ago.
In other important positions, Stanley Roth, who had served as the Asia director in Mr. Clinton's National Security Council before joining the U.S. Institute of Peace, a federally financed research institute, is expected to be named Assistant Secretary for East Asia, replacing Winston Lord.
Ms. Albright's chief of staff will be Elaine K. Shocas, a former Federal prosecutor and counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee, who served her in the same job at the United Nations. Her spokesman there, James P. Rubin, 36, a former aide to Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, will become Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs.

HEADLINE: Saul B. Marantz, 85, Pioneer In Hi-Fi Audio Components

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE B. JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Saul B. Marantz, a pioneer in the development of high-fidelity audio components, died last Thursday at Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, N.J. He was 85 and lived in Bridgewater, N.J.
A man of many parts -- photographer, classical guitarist, graphics designer, collector of Chinese and Japanese art -- Mr. Marantz was fascinated by electronics from his boyhood days in Brooklyn. His passion for music led to his first attempts at building audio components. 
 In the 1950's and 60's, the Marantz name became synonymous with audio products that were pleasing to look at, easy to use, durable and sonically first rate. Working with audio engineers like Sidney Smith and Richard Sequerra, Mr. Marantz created a series of vacuum-tube components that became touchstones for the fledgling hi-fi industry. Several of those products, like the Model 9 amplifier and the Model 10B tuner, have become still-working classics that today command as much as $20,000.
With the advent of transistor technology in the early 1960's, Mr. Marantz and his colleagues soon brought forth another benchmark product, the Model 18 receiver. It was an early, high-quality example of what a receiver, which combines the preamplifier, power amplifier and tuner in one box, could be.
To younger audio designers, the Marantz name symbolized clarity of vision and integrity of purpose. When a modern-day audio expert, Mark Levinson, had completed the design of one of his first now-famous components, in 1974, he took it to Mr. Marantz for an appraisal.
"What impressed me about Marantz design was its elegant simplicity, its economy and symmetry," recalled Mr. Levinson, now the president of Cello Music and Film Systems, a high-end electronics company. "In a sense, Marantz was building classics. The equipment was so thoroughly engineered that, once a product was finished, few changes ever were necessary."
After service in the Army during World War II, Mr. Marantz and his wife, Jean Dickey Marantz, settled in Kew Gardens, Queens. One day in 1945, he decided to rip the radio out of his 1940 Mercury, where he rarely listened to it, and put it to more practical use in his house. But that transplant required building additional electronics to make the radio work indoors. Such was the hook that snared Mr. Marantz for life.
Further efforts to refine sound reproduction in his living room led Mr. Marantz to a breakthrough. Piecing together parts and tips he picked up on his frequent visits to a Harvey Radio store in Manhattan, he built a high-quality preamplifier he called the "Consolette."
Word of this musical-sounding new device began to spread across the emerging hi-fi scene, and Mr. Marantz suddenly found himself an entrepreneur, though on a back-room scale. Then into his business walked Mr. Smith, an engineer captivated by Mr. Marantz's sense of the possibilities of sound reproduction. Their creative partnership took the Marantz Company to world prominence.
The two men's shared perfectionism proved to be the original company's downfall. In a recent interview, Mr. Marantz acknowledged that the cost of developing perhaps the most celebrated of all Marantz products, the Model 10B tuner, in which both Mr. Smith and Mr. Sequerra played significant roles, fatally overextended the company's resources.
In 1964, Marantz was sold to Superscope Inc. and has since passed through several hands. The present owner, Philips Electronics N.V., last year reintroduced nearly exact likenesses of the original products under the name of Marantz Classics.
After the sale to Superscope, Mr. Marantz stayed as president until 1968 and then retired -- briefly. In 1972, he co-founded the Dahlquist Company, a maker of high-quality loudspeakers, serving as president until his second retirement in 1978. Last year, he helped to form two new audio businesses, the New Lineage Corporation and Eye Q loudspeakers.
Mr. Marantz was a member of several professional organizations, including the Audio Engineering Society. He served as vice president and member of the board of the Institute of High Fidelity.
He is survived by a daughter, June M. Chamberlain of Bound Brook, N.J.; a brother, Charles E. Marantz of Costa Mesa, Calif.; a sister, Edith M. Marksohn of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Survey Sees 'Moderate' Economic Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Inflation remained subdued despite continued "moderate" growth of the economy, the Federal Reserve's periodic survey of business conditions in all geographic areas showed today.
The findings, which were presaged on Tuesday by comments of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, were a further indication that the central bank was likely to keep interest rates unchanged at its policy meeting in early February. 
 "District reports provided scattered evidence of increasing wage pressures, particularly for skilled workers, but in general did not indicate significant price pressures other than for energy items," the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco said, summarizing the report's findings, which included responses through the second week of January.
The survey, known as the beige book, is a compilation of anecdotes and research from regional Fed banks that is put together to help top Fed officials set policy.
Employers in the Chicago and Richmond districts appeared to have the most trouble filling jobs and were being forced to raise pay accordingly.
In the New York district, which includes the entire state plus northern New Jersey and a small piece of Connecticut, the overall economy "has a slightly firmer tone" than in the preceding survey, on Dec. 4.Holiday retail sales in the district were among the best in the nation.
Among districts that quantified holiday retail sales, New York posted growth of 4 to 8 percent compared with 1995 levels, while sales in Philadelphia rose 5 percent, sales in St. Louis 7 percent and in Minneapolis zero to 2 percent, the Fed survey reported. It also cited a separate poll of small retailers across New York State that showed a gain, before inflation, of 4 to 6 percent for same-store sales, "with the strongest reports coming from Manhattan."
Women's and children's apparel and jewelry were the strongest categories, confirming other appraisals, while electronics and other big-ticket durable items were generally weak.
The survey also cited the New York district, along with Chicago, as having a "firming" of residential real estate prices.
Real estate prices advanced 2 to 5 percent in the fourth quarter, according to real estate agents in New York and New Jersey, and the tight New York City-area apartment market seems to have prompted a pickup in construction of buildings.
The pace of permits issued for new apartments more than doubled that of any of the preceding five years, with the bulk of the increase coming in the second half of 1996, the Fed's survey said. Commercial construction was also stronger in the New York district.
In a separate Government report today, the Commerce Department said builders broke ground on single-family homes and apartment buildings at an annual pace of 1,329,000 in December, a decline of 12.2 percent from November.
Although this decline was about triple the consensus estimate, analysts cautioned that the seasonal adjustment process was especially unreliable during the winter months. For all of 1996, starts climbed 8.8 percent, to 1,473,700, the highest total in eight years.
The survey by the Fed of its 12 districts, conducted as part of its preparation for a meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee on Feb. 4 and Feb. 5, said, "Economic growth in December and early January was moderate in most parts of the country."
The survey also showed that factory activity expanded or held steady in most areas of the country. Producers of steel and other metals as well as machine tools, construction materials and capital equipment registered the biggest gains.
Wage pressure was most visible in the bidding for skilled factory, administrative and technical workers, especially computer technicians, the Fed reported. "Signs of increasing wage pressures" were reported inChicago, and Richmond characterized these as "more evident." The Boston, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Atlanta, St. Louis and San Francisco districts also noted worker shortages.
The job market in Spartanburg, S.C., is so tight, the Richmond Fed said, that offers of higher pay for temporary employees were starting to draw workers from low-paying permanent jobs.
The Fed mistakenly posted today's survey on the Internet nearly two hours before its new official release time of 2 P.M. Bob Moore, a Fed aide, said, "We broke our own embargo" but added that officials did not yet know whether the error was related to the fact that until now the beige book was published at noon.
Economic announcements such as this one often move the stock and bond markets, so the releases are carefully timed to prevent some traders from getting unfair advantages from advance knowledge of the data. Mr. Moore said the Fed had received no complaints from traders about the early release of the beige book report.
The Commerce Department's report also showed that the slump in new house and apartment construction was most striking in the West, where starts tumbled 29.2 percent. The Midwest and South declined 7.9 percent and 7.2 percent, respectively, while the Northeast edged down negligibly but from a pace far below that of any other region.
Permits for new homes moved lower by less than 1 percent, to an annual pace of 1,410,000, the Commerce Department's report also showed.
Shipment of mobile homes, for which figures lag a month, eased 4.1 percent in November to a rate of 354,000.

HEADLINE: Unlikely Meeting of Minds: Lebed Meets The Donald

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
During his swing through the corridors of America's business world this week, Aleksandr I. Lebed, the retired general who aspires to be the next President of Russia, hobnobbed with executives at Du Pont in Delaware and sipped tea with Wall Street investors at the Harvard Club in Manhattan.
And then he dropped in on the man who aspires to be the king of New York capitalism. 
 Mr. Lebed, meet Donald Trump.
For almost an hour yesterday, the two men conferred at Trump Tower in a meeting that was declared off-limits to the press. What could be in the works? A five-star hotel and casino smack-dab in Red Square?
Mr. Trump said he did indeed discuss his intentions to build "something major" in Moscow, maybe a hotel, maybe an apartment building. And Mr. Lebed said he was all for it, with one caveat.
"The highest skyscraper in the world cannot be built next to the Kremlin," Mr. Lebed joked. "We cannot allow anyone spitting from the roof of the skyscraper on the Kremlin."
But for all his jokes and witticisms, Mr. Lebed, 46, described his mission as a very serious one. For while the ailing Boris N. Yeltsin remains President of Russia, the campaign to replace him is already under way, at home and abroad. And Mr. Lebed's visit to the United States has been widely viewed as an attempt to win the support of American business executives and to portray himself as the one man who can lead Russia and pave the way for investment and democratic reform there.
"He has come around to the idea that in an attempt to run for the presidency, it's better to have the West in your corner," said Steven Solnick, coordinator of Russian Studies at the Harriman Institute at Columbia University. "He may perceive that Yeltsin benefited greatly from support from the Americans in the last campaign. Bill Clinton made a trip to Moscow during the campaign. And the International Monetary Fund extended loans that enabled the Government to make credible promises to pay wages."
Mr. Lebed received none of that support during his bid for the presidency last year. The retired general, who won the hearts of many ordinary Russians with his critique of the country's hasty embrace of the free market, worried many American politicians and investors with his sometimes autocratic demeanor and crude populist outbursts.
And while his popularity gave him a strong third-place showing at the polls and, briefly, a job as national security chief in the Yeltsin administration, it did not automatically translate into trust from the West.
Mr. Lebed, who was dismissed as security chief in October, took the opportunity provided by an invitation to President Clinton's Inauguration on Monday to visit the United States for the second time in a little more than a month.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, offered the invitation at the behest of an unnamed businessman from his state. And Mr. Lebed used the trip, from Washington to Delaware and on to New York before heading back to Russia yesterday evening, to reassure Americans that as President he would welcome foreign investment and continue the democratic process.
"I want to build a free, democratic Russia," said Mr. Lebed on Tuesday afternoon in his remarks to the United Nations Correspondents Association in New York.
"The only thing I kill now are wars," he added, describing his role in brokering peace accords in Chechnya and Moldova.
He repeatedly stressed similar themes, saying that the Russian Army should not interfere in politics, that obstacles to foreign investment should be removed and that he would not interfere with NATO expansion into Eastern Europe. "Russia should take it calmly," he said. "There should be no hysteria."
But Mr. Lebed also insisted that Russia's brand of democracy would not be transplanted whole from Western soil. Press freedom, he said, would not extend to the publishing of personal affronts to national leaders. And free enterprise would not necessarily include the privatization of the energy, telecommunications and transportation industries.
He left a strong impression on his audience. A bear of a man, with a craggy face and piercing blue eyes, he sat in a wood-paneled dining room at the Harvard Club yesterday in a charcoal-gray suit, his big, restless hands alternately tapping the table and pounding it for emphasis.
But even for those who met him, he remained something of an enigma, especially since he was careful to avoid offering specific details about how he might manage economic and political change. In one meeting, he declared that he would appoint a panel of experts aged 30 to 45 to realign Russia's economic policies, suggesting that anyone older had been psychologically ruined by the Soviet experience.
"While he seems to be aware of the difficulties that investors face," said Jack V. Wirts, the executive vice president of the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization in New York, "I don't think he enunciated any different directions that his government might take."
Still, many of the business people seemed encouraged. A spokeswoman for John A. Krol, president and chief executive of Du Pont, and Jerry A. Blumberg, Du Pont's executive vice president, said their hour-long conference with Mr. Lebed in Delaware on Tuesday morning offered a valuable window into the investment climate in Russia.
"Russia is a key growth market for Du Pont," said Kathy Forte, a spokeswoman for the company.
And Mr. Trump, who gave the retired general a crystal apple as a parting gift, said Mr. Lebed had "a lot of wonderful ideas," though he declined to discuss them.
"He invited me to Russia and I accepted," Mr. Trump said. "I thought he was terrific."
For his part, Mr. Lebed seemed slightly overwhelmed by New York City's technology and architecture. During his visit to Trump Tower, Mr. Trump's steel-and-glass palace on Fifth Avenue, he marveled at the computers on the desks and the automatic lock on the doors. "Very impressive," he said.
And he found the city's skyscrapers a bit unnerving.
"It's hard to get used to the huge towering structures," he said.
Still, Mr. Lebed said the visit had served its purpose.
"I extended the circle of my friends," he said, describing the objectives achieved during his trip. "We made clearer the routes and framework for future cooperation. I've received new guarantees that if I meet certain conditions as President, investments will go to Russia. If the conditions are civilized, the investments will be civilized."

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Welfare Chief to Head Social Services in Michigan

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Marva L. Hammons, the head of the sprawling agency that distributes welfare benefits to nearly a million people in New York City, is resigning to become head of social services in Michigan.
The departure of Ms. Hammons, one of the few high-ranking black officials in the Giuliani administration, was not unexpected because she had been consistently shut out of most important decisions involving social services and her agency, the Human Resources Administration. Ms. Hammons was rarely seen at major announcements at City Hall and was not at yesterday's news conference when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced her departure and named her replacement, Lilliam Barrios-Paoli. 
 Ms. Barrios-Paoli is a trusted Giuliani aide who now heads the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. Ms. Barrios-Paoli has a reputation as an able administrator who held a number of management positions in the administrations of Mr. Giuliani and Mayor Edward I. Koch, including a seven-year stint at H.R.A.
Advocates for welfare recipients have sharply criticized Ms. Hammons, saying she did little to lead an agency that has long been considered the city's most unmanageable and cumbersome bureaucracy.
But in reality, Mr. Giuliani and his top aides have directly overseen many of the agency's new initiatives themselves, including the city's workfare program, which has put more than 122,000 people to work cleaning streets and parks in return for their benefits, and the fingerprint-imaging program to weed out welfare fraud.
The Mayor congratulated Ms. Hammons on her new appointment yesterday and said, "I want to thank her for the significant contributions she made to restructuring H.R.A."
He reserved higher praise for Ms. Barrios-Paoli, saying, "Her proven capabilities as a leader, manager and an administrator and her commitment to city government will be a tremendous asset to the Human Resources Administration."
Ms. Hammons declined to comment yesterday but issued a statement saying she looked forward to her new job and adding, "I have very much enjoyed working at H.R.A. and have benefited greatly from the support I received from Mayor Giuliani and the staff of the agency."
While Ms. Hammons had receded into the shadows in the Giuliani administration, John Truscott, a spokesman for Michigan's Governor, John Engler, said, "She'll have a very high profile in Michigan because she has the full backing of the Governor."
Governor Engler has been in the forefront of welfare reform at a national level, and has cut the welfare rolls in his own state by more than 140,000, a 46 percent decrease.
In her new job, Ms. Hammons will run an agency that administers cash assistance to about 167,000 people, only a fraction of those handled by New York's Human Resources Administration. She also will be taking a pay cut, from $133,000 to $100,000 a year.
Ms. Hammons took over H.R.A. in 1994, after managing services for Denver's 15,000 welfare recipients.
During her tenure in New York, the city's social service agency lost more than 7,500 employees. Much of the staff reduction occurred when the Mayor stripped away the department's responsibility over child welfare last year and created a new agency to manage the city's foster-care and child-protection programs after the highly publicized beating death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo.
The caseload also declined significantly in her tenure. Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that welfare rolls had been reduced by 220,000 in the last three years, leaving a caseload of about 940,000. Advocates for the poor said that while some of that decline could be attributed to an improved economy, the Mayor's harsh policies accounted for the rest of the drop.
"Really bad things happened under her watch, but it's not clear that she had much to do with any of it," said Liz Krueger, of the Community Food Resource Center, an agency that works with welfare recipients.
Nonprofit organizations that have worked with Ms. Barrios-Paoli in the 10 months she has run the housing preservation agency praised her willingness to work with them but said the department needed someone with more housing expertise. The Mayor has not yet appointed a successor at the housing agency.

HEADLINE: Enterprise's Unconventional Path;
Rental Car Giant Successfully Shuns Industry Shakeout

BYLINE: By GIANNA JACOBSON 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22

 BODY:
For 40 years, Enterprise Rent-a-Car Inc. has gone against all the conventional industry wisdom. Not only has it ceded the bread-and-butter airport business to Hertz, Avis and other national competitors, but it has also done without celebrity-driven advertisements and catchy slogans.
Yet while the Hertz Corporation and the others got the higher profiles, the St. Louis-based Enterprise has become the industry's giant. 
 Sticking close to the niche it developed -- providing rentals for customers whose cars are being repaired or who need an extra car -- Enterprise is No. 1 in fleet size and locations. And though it trails Hertz in revenues ($3.1 billion versus $3.8 billion in 1996), its estimated $500 million in pretax earnings probably make it No. 1 in profits, too. (Hertz, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, does not disclose earnings.)
"Enterprise's track record is astonishing," said Jon LeSage, editor of Auto Rental News, a trade publication based in Redondo Beach, Calif. "They have very quietly and humbly built an empire."
Now, as the $16.5 billion industry reorganizes in the wake of a six-month spate of acquisition deals, the question is whether Enterprise and its owners, the founding Taylor family, can keep that empire, and all those profits, largely to themselves.
Auto manufacturers, stuck with hefty write-offs or paltry profits from their rental car subsidiaries, are beating a hasty retreat from the overcrowded business, which no longer is needed, as it was during the recession, as a captive market for new cars. In the last six months, four of the biggest rental car companies have changed hands, or are about to. Two others are for sale, and Hertz itself may be heading for the block as well.
The changing of the guard ushers in two wily financial chieftains -- H. Wayne Huizenga, the founder of Blockbuster Video, and Henry Silverman, head of HFS Inc., the world's largest franchiser of hotels and real estate offices -- who promise to bring a new aggressiveness to the business. Mr. Huizenga's Republic Industries owns Alamo Rent-a-Car and is in the process of buying National Car Rental; HFS owns Avis Rent a Car.
Characteristically, the Taylors say they will continue to go against the grain, keeping Enterprise in the family and out of the airports. And, they say, they are more than capable of fending off the inevitable assault on their profitable terrain.
"I am watching this frenzy with fascination, but I am sitting on the sidelines," said Andrew Taylor, Enterprise's chief executive and son of the company's founder and chairman, Jack Taylor. "Everybody wants to throw us in the same pot with the other rental car companies, but our businesses are different. We have no plans to be in the airports. We're sticking to our niche."
And why not? Enterprise dominates the replacement niche, also known as the home-city rental business, with more than 70 percent of the market, according to a report prepared by Jordan Hymowitz, an industry analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.
"Not only is Enterprise profitable, but it is in the fastest-growing and least competitive rental car niche," the report said. "An industry adage states there are two types of rental car companies: those that lose money and Enterprise."
But if Andrew Taylor is not going after the "Airport Seven," as he calls them, he concedes that they are beginning to invade his turf.
"They're coming after us," he said, "no question."
Already, Hertz is revamping its replacement division, dubbed H.I.R.E. (for Hertz Insurance Replacement Entity), and Alamo is considering a similar division.
"Whenever you have one player in a market segment, there is room for competitors," said Joseph Russo, a Hertz spokesman.
Andrew Taylor responded with typical competitive fervor: "Our delivery network is tough to compete against. Our ability to move people and resources around the organization is pretty awesome. It will be interesting to see who gets that growth in market share."
Indeed, Enterprise is a maverick in a lot of ways that have paid off and will be hard to match. Simply by locating its 3,100 branches away from airports, it reduces overhead significantly by cutting out high concession fees. It saves more by handling its own reservations, avoiding 10 percent travel agent commissions and a separate 3 percent fee that other rental car companies pay to use a shared reservation system. And it employs a highly sophisticated computer network to track the whereabouts and service history of each of its 315,100 cars, keeping inventory lean and cars on the road an average of six months longer than Hertz and Avis do. At the same time, the company is known for its extra level of service: it often delivers cars to customers' homes or takes customers to the cars.
The new market picture will become clearer in the next year, as the industry adjusts to all the ownership changes. HFS touched off the flurry of deals last July, when it bought Avis from its employees and the General Motors Corporation for $800 million. In the last few weeks alone, these deals or related events have transpired:
*Team Rental Group Inc. said it was acquiring the Budget Rent a Car Company from Ford for $350 million. Team Rental is the largest Budget franchisee.
*Republic Industries announced its intention to buy National from G.M. for $600 million, on the heels of its purchase of Alamo from Michael Egan, a rental car executive who owned 94 percent of Alamo, for $625 million.
*The Chrysler Corporation put its Dollar Rent-a-Car and Thrifty Car Rental divisions on the block.
*Ford said it was exploring possibilities for Hertz, including an initial public offering and a spinoff.
"I've never seen anything like this frenzy of activity around the rental car business," said Neil Abrams, a Purchase, N.Y., auto rental industry consultant. "What is remarkable about Enterprise is that it is the only major player in the industry that has had no changes in ownership or top management in the past four years."
The rental car companies that had been owned by the car makers relied heavily on manufacturer subsidies for what little profitability they had.
With the recent deals, financial managers have taken over the show. Mr. Huizenga will use National and Alamo as a "used car factory" of sorts, according to the Montgomery Securities report. Both will supply cars for Republic's budding Auto Nation USA chain, which sells late-model used cars.
Mr. Silverman of HFS also hopes to benefit from having complementary businesses. With such well-known chains as Century 21, Coldwell Banker, Days Inn, ERA, Howard Johnson, Ramada (U.S.), Super 8 and Travelodge, HFS operates a vast reservation system with endless opportunities to promote Avis rentals.
The increased emphasis on profitability is unlikely, however, to result in consumers paying more for rentals, experts say, because the industry is too fee-competitive. "We are not optimistic about seeing even modest price increases in the near future," Mr. Hymowitz, the analyst, wrote.
As the dust settles, Andrew Taylor remains bullish about Enterprise's prospects, estimating revenues will jump to $6 billion by 2001.
The company will grow, he said, by opening more branches across the United States and especially abroad. With 150 branches in Canada and Britain, Enterprise is preparing to venture into Western Europe next, beginning in Germany.
Enterprise also wants to amass local and regional players in the replacement rental market. Last year, it bought Standard Rent-a-Car, a Sacramento, Calif., company, and Agency Rent-a-Car, a replacement division of Avis spun off by HFS. Enterprise closed Agency's branches shortly after the purchase.
As ambitious as Enterprise's plans are, Andrew Taylor is quick to point out, "We don't have to grow." At least not in light of the estimates that place its profits at the $500 million level, according to Mr. LeSage of Auto Rental News.
Enterprise's secret profitability weapon, Mr. LeSage said, is management of fleet costs, which account for nearly half of operating expenses.
While the business and leisure rental car companies have relied on manufacturer subsidies and buybacks, "nobody is better than Enterprise at negotiating prices to buy and sell cars," Mr. LeSage said. Enterprise sells its cars at 30 retail lots it owns around the country, in a fashion nearly identical to Mr. Huizenga's much-heralded chain.
Though Enterprise has grown most quickly in the last 15 years, it has long benefited from innovative strategies. Jack Taylor, a World War II fighter pilot aboard the U.S.S. Enterprise (hence the company name), left his job as a Cadillac salesman in 1957 to effectively invent the concept of auto leasing with his first venture, Executive Leasing.
As leasing began taking off nationwide in the 1970's, the father-son team started to push their replacement-rental business -- which they had formed in 1963, with 17 cars -- as a service to leasing customers.
"We could see this niche and we figured there was something here," said Andrew Taylor, 49, who took over as chief executive in 1991. "There was an evolution of people's reliance on having transportation all of the time, and we were fortunate to ride that wave."
Executive Leasing remains a division of Enterprise, though it accounts for less than 5 percent of the company's gross revenues.
A highly decentralized network of company-owned branches -- "a confederation of small businesses," in Andrew Taylor's description -- fuels Enterprise's growth on the strength of referral relationships with auto dealers, insurance agents and adjusters and body shops. Competition among the branches is notorious, with managers encouraged by the home office to place bets with each other on staff performance. (The losers might pay for dinner or work extra hours at the winning branch.)
But as Enterprise grows, Andrew Taylor says, it is getting harder to find enough employees with the competitive mind-set he seeks and the affability necessary to work with the public for long hours.
This year alone, Enterprise is preparing to hire 10,000 college graduates for its management training program, making it one of the nation's largest hirers. Enterprise now has 31,000 employees.
About 25 percent of the new hires will leave before six months. Those who stay do everything from washing cars and picking up customers to handling paperwork. Almost everybody in the company, from Andrew Taylor down, goes through the program. As Mr. Taylor likes to say, "We've all had our ties sucked into the vacuum."
Richard Allen, the Enterprise vice president who leads the recruiting effort, recognizes the enormousness of the job. "We need more people than most companies to facilitate our ongoing growth," he said. "We need to be more aggressive than most in who we hire."
As the industry begins a new era, aggressive will be the watchword at Enterprise for more than just hiring.
"This is a business of details, not brilliance," Andrew Taylor said. "Our customers don't care if we have the best computer system. They want someone to look them in the eye and ask, 'How can I help you?' "

HEADLINE: Hometown Recalls Paul Tsongas as Hero Who Inspired Renewal and Pride

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 21

 BODY:
To most people beyond this city, Paul Tsongas was the man with the odd voice who made a quixotic run for the Presidency in 1992. No one really believed that Paul Tsongas was going to be President.
To Lowell, he was the favorite first son whose extraordinary relationship with this once dying mill town transformed it, and the people who live here. The local newspaper, The Sun, made Mr. Tsongas's legacy clear in Sunday's front-page obituary: "He leaves his family and the city he resurrected." 
 Because of Mr. Tsongas's vision, Lowell, a city of 103,000 people about 25 miles northwest of Boston, has a national historic park that draws thousands of tourists each year, a minor league baseball team, a new stadium on the way, a Sheraton hotel, 14 new schools, thousands of jobs and, as important as all the bricks and dollars, renewed civic pride.
"He made it cool to be from Lowell," said James Cook, one of the former Senator's legions of hometown friends and director of the Lowell Plan and the Lowell Development Finance Corporation, a nonprofit economic development group started by Mr. Tsongas. "Twenty-two years ago, you used to say you lived north of Boston. Now you say you're from Lowell, and proud of it."
Mr. Tsongas, a Democrat who died of pneumonia on Saturday at the age of 55 after a long battle with cancer, went to Washington as a United States representative in 1975, and was elected to the Senate in 1978. He stunned nearly everybody in 1984 when he decided to retire after one term because of his cancer. But he never left Lowell or, in a way, his first job in politics as a Lowell City Councilor.
Two weeks before his death, from his hospital bed in Boston, so weak that nurses had to dial the phone for him, he was calling around town to make sure there were enough City Council votes to keep the planned baseball stadium downtown, Mr. Cook said. (The Council voted, 9 to 0, in favor of the downtown site.)
Mr. Tsongas never passed up an opportunity to promote his hometown, not even in death. In an extraordinary public relations stroke, he arranged for a public wake to be held at his Victorian house, in the stately neighborhood where the mill owners once lived, so the mourners would have a chance to see Lowell.
Thousands of people -- including the waitresses who served him coffee, the Mayor, Edward Caulfield, and the people from all over the state who never met him but wanted to pay their respects -- have filed past his coffin and through his beloved city this week.
"He was the pillar of the Lowell community," said 71-year-old Arthur C. Anton, the owner of Anton's Cleaners and a friend of Mr. Tsongas's father, who also owned a dry cleaning business, as he left the Tsongas house this evening. "He had an ability to get people to respond to his vision, his dreams. We're so proud of him for what he has done for us, and what he left us."
With his back bent against the biting cold, Mr. Anton stood on the sidewalk, talking about the Lowell National Historical Park, which was signed into Federal law in 1978, thanks to Mr. Tsongas's efforts.
"We would never have the park if it weren't for Paul," Mr. Anton said. "You know how many tourists we get now because of it? They all come to see how the mills began, the quilt museum, the mill girls."
Mr. Tsongas's funeral, to be held on Thursday, is another opportunity to show off a revitalized Lowell. The funeral cortege is scheduled to go from the Transfiguration Church past Cawley Stadium, where the baseball team, the Spinners, will play until the promised new stadium is built; past the Paul E. Tsongas Arena now under construction, and the newly renovated Lowell High School, and onto the Lowell Cemetery, high on a ridge overlooking the Merrimack River, where Mr. Tsongas will be buried near his Greek immigrant parents, Efthemios George and Katina Tsongas.
It is also in deference to Mr. Tsongas's wishes that all week his friends and colleagues have been talking up the city even as they have been grieving for the man.
"He'd be kicking us right now if we weren't doing our jobs promoting the city," Mr. Cook said. "He had arranged that we would all talk to the media when and if it happened. It was the same thing when he was running for President. He joked that it was his marketing campaign for the city of Lowell."
Mr. Tsongas's obsession with Lowell could be exasperating to those who wanted him to be President.
"There we were on the Presidential campaign plane, and he would be talking to somebody about some zoning regulation in Lowell," said Edward F. Jesser, a Boston political consultant, who was Mr. Tsongas's media adviser during the former Senator's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination five years ago.
From the campaign trail, from Washington, from his hospital bed, Mr. Tsongas stayed in touch with Richard Howe, the elder statesman of the Lowell City Council. "He was always a Lowellian," said Mr. Howe, who has served on the Council since 1965.
When Mr. Tsongas was elected to the Council in 1969, Lowell, an industrial city of Greek, Portugese and French Canadian immigrants, had double-digit unemployment. Nearly half a century after the mills had moved South, the city's downtown business district was blighted by abandoned and dilapidated buildings.
"Between 1950 and 1970, Lowell just hit rock bottom," Mr. Howe said. "For youngsters graduating from high school, the only goal was to get out of Lowell. Our goal was to change the mood and the atmosphere and the direction government was going."
Over time, Mr. Howe and a group of others, led by Mr. Tsongas, made Lowell a place where people wanted to stay. As a Congressman, Mr. Tsongas was able to secure millions of dollars in state and Federal funds for improvement projects for Lowell.
He did menial labor, too. One of the rituals of life in Lowell was seeing Mr. Tsongas at work in Kittredge Park, the green space that he had helped restore.
"I would drive down the street, and there would be this former Presidential candidate sweeping the leaves out of the gutter," said the Rev. David Malone, the pastor of the Eliot Church, whose hundreds of Cambodian parishioners reflect the changing demographics of Lowell. "It's one of the most powerful images in my 55 years as an American citizen. He'd be there with his broom and a dustpan."
Three weeks ago, Mr. Cook said, Mr. Tsongas called him from the hospital to ask him to bring him three photographs -- one of the arena under construction, another of the new supermarket being built in the Acre neighborhood, and one of Kittredge Park.
Mr. Cook had the pictures taken, and brought them to the hospital. "We set them up on his windowsill," he said.
"He loved this city as much as anyone I ever met," Mr. Cook added. "Every team needs a coach or a cheerleader. He was both for Lowell."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The death of a man who loved Lowell, Paul Tsongas, has brought sympathy from all corners of that Massachusetts city. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Wall Street Helps the Many Who Had a Bad Year

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Lifted by donations from the employees of seven Wall Street firms, total contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund shot upward yesterday, crossing the $4 million mark on a pace expected to result in the fund's second-best finish ever.
But at a time when social service providers say they are bracing for changes in the welfare laws that will mean less public money and services for the poor, and though the economy remains strong, the fund trails far behind the record-setting appeal at the height of a recession five years ago. 
 Yesterday, the fund's 85th annual appeal, which runs through Feb. 28, had collected $4,001,272.25, about $300,000 more than last year at the same time. But that is still about $425,000 behind the pace of the 80th annual appeal, which went on to finish with a record $5,083,520.81 in 1992.
Leaders of the social service agencies supported by the Neediest Cases Fund said the mixed success of this year's appeal left them with conflicting emotions, troubled by a sense of increased cynicism among Americans about charitable giving, yet grateful that many had recognized the deeper need and given more.
"The irony of the whole situation is that the level of human misery is increasing geometrically and there is a compassion fatigue out there," said Stephen D. Solender, chief executive of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven charities benefited by the fund.
Among the contributors who have helped the fund outperform last year were 346 employees from seven Wall Street firms, who contributed more than $90,000. Once the firms submit corporate matching gifts, the donations will total about $125,000, up from about $88,000 last year.
James Valentine, 31, who tracks the railroad and trucking industries as an equity researcher for Salomon Brothers, and his wife, Emma, 28, gave $20,000, the largest of the Wall Street contributions, because they were concerned about children.
"I think it was a good year for me, a good year for Salomon," he said, "and I think that the donation will make a much bigger impact on the children it's going to serve than it would have on my wife and me. I think in New York more than in many other places in the U.S. there are many children in need. Given the compensation levels on Wall Street, we figured it was the least we could do."
The Wall Street effort to support New York's neediest is spearheaded by first- and second-year analysts, typically the youngest workers in an investment bank. It is organized by Salomon Brothers, which coordinates the donations from other firms. "I think the key selling point is the money is going directly to the people who need it most," said Christian B. Hensley, 22, a coordinator.
Malcolm Kostuchenko, 24,, another coordinator, said: "We have a list of the charities. The New York Times covers the overhead and we have documented stories about how it works. People feel very comfortable going ahead and giving."
This week's contribution, the first of two, included gifts from employees at Salomon Brothers, Paine Webber; Morgan Stanley; Merrill Lynch; Goldman, Sachs; Bear, Stearns and Dillon, Read. The second Wall Street gift is expected at the end of February near the close of the appeal, and is to include contributions from additional firms.
To meet the ever-growing social service needs of New York's poor, particularly immigrants and refugees, Mr. Solender and other social service providers said, the call must go out for a wider response from a greater part of the city's citizenry.
"You could see real hell in this city," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society of New York, another agency supported by the fund. "The confluence of all these negative policies is beyond my ability to comprehend. This message hasn't permeated the public consciousness yet."
Permeating the public consciousness was precisely the goal of Adolph S. Ochs, the former publisher of The Times, when he started the Neediest Cases Fund in 1912. Moved by a chance encounter with an immigrant pauper on a winter night, Mr. Ochs reasoned that if New Yorkers only knew how some of their neighbors lived, they would be anxious to help.
He assigned a reporter to delve into the files of some of the city's largest and oldest social service organizations. The stories first appeared in the newspaper's magazine section under the headline: "Santa Claus, Please Take Notice! Here Are New York's 100 Neediest Cases."
The Wall Street workers were not the only ones to notice the greater need this year. "I too am raising my gift for this year," Glen Winters of East Setauket, L.I., wrote in a note accompanying her $125 donation. "What the new welfare laws will mean to many wounded recipients, I hate to think."
Ms. Winters, 72, a retired Federal employee who helped start Suffolk County's Head Start program 30 years ago, said she gave to the fund for the first time last year. "I always wanted to," she said, "and I decided why do I keep putting this off? I just think we are going to have a lot of problems."

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Police Union Officials Indicted
Federal authorities charged in an indictment that top officials of the union that represented the transit police took kickbacks and engaged in several other schemes before the force merged with the city Police Department. The announcement was seized on by Mayor Giuliani, who noted that among those indicted is a negotiator for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. That union rejected the city's contract offer, a development Mr. Giuliani said was linked to legal problems involving P.B.A. officials and negotiators. [Page A1.] 

In what may be the singular paradox of the Giuliani era, his administration's relationship with the P.B.A. may be more bitter than that of his predecessor. News Analysis. [B6.]
 
City Seeks Hospital Partner
Seeking to wrest more control from the private medical centers that staff its public hospitals, New York City officials said they would seek a new partner for the city's largest medical-care contract -- a $100 million deal to run the Queens and Elmhurst Hospital Centers. [B1.]
 
D'Amato Behind Bill's Passage
Of all the politicians involved in arranging the agreement to pass legislation providing women longer hospital stays after mastectomies, the lawmaker most responsible was Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. The measure's passage provided yet another example of how Mr. D'Amato uses his influence over the state's political leaders to push issues important to him through the Legislature. [B1.]
 
Girl Hurt in School Fall
Trying to hide from a dean who was looking for her and other students who had cut class, a 13-year-old girl was injured when she fell two floors down an air shaft at an intermediate school in Queens, police officers and school officials said. [B3.]
 
Mayor Wins on Airport Rent
Mayor Giuliani won a victory in his long-running battle with the Port Authority over back rent at the city's two airports when the Federal Aviation Administration partially reversed a decision it had made. [B3.]
 
$20 Million Gift to Cornell
David A. Duffield, a Cornell University alumnus who amassed a fortune in the development of computer software, is giving his alma mater $20 million toward the construction of laboratories and classrooms to train the next generation of scientists and engineers. [B4.]
 
Head of Welfare Agency Quits
Marva L. Hammons, the head of the sprawling agency that distributes welfare benefits to nearly a million people in New York City, is resigning to become head of social services in Michigan. [B5.]
 
Police Commander Suspended
The commanding officer of the Police Department's licensing division was suspended without pay after he was accused of doing favors for friends, the police said. [B6.]
 
Court-Martial Testimony
Testimony in the court-martial of a male cadet charged with raping a female classmate focused on the questions of precisely how drunk the 20-year-old woman was and, by implication, whether she had the ability to consent to a sexual act. [B9.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
Plan to Solve Segregation
A panel established by Gov. John G. Rowland to address segregation in the state's schools said that the state should require school districts to accept students from anywhere in Connecticut and should pay more for school construction projects that bring black and Hispanic students into mostly white districts. [B6.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Passion for Giving Revealed
Over the last 15 years a self-made entrepreneur from New Jersey has given away more than $600 million to hospitals, universities and other beneficiaries -- but has done it in such secrecy that most recipients never learned who their benefactor was. The donor is Charles F. Feeney, who made his fortune with a string of duty-free airport shops. While large anonymous donations to charity are not unheard of, the scope and style of Mr. Feeney's giving, and his passion for total secrecy, are unique. [A1.]
 
Charles F. Feeney said he never forgot his humble beginnings. [B4.]
 
Mall Still a Lure for Shoppers
While others took advantage of the tax-free week in New York, there were those who still made the trip to the Newport Center Mall in Jersey City to do their shopping. Perhaps for those in the mall habit, the lack of a tax on clothing just can't compete with the comfort of a climate-controlled Main Street. Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves. [B1.]
 
METRO BUSINESS
 
Finding Niche in 99 Stores
Seizing on the "one-price" mania that burst onto the retailing scene in the early 1990's and creating a new employment niche, three extended Pakistani families have opened 34 of the so-called 99 stores, most in New York City, a few in New Jersey, in the past five years. [B1.]
 
City Outpaces Suburbs on Jobs
One of the tenets of economics in America is that suburbs create more jobs than cities. Last year, New York City broke that pattern. For the first time since 1980, the city outshone its entire suburban encirclement of office parks and edge cities in making new jobs. [B8.]
 
Success Lurks in Whitman Plan
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to allow motorists to buy no-frills no-fault insurance that reduces their premiums was widely seen as classic pocketbook politics. But the seal of approval for "auto choice" insurance reform from the adroit Republican could prove the breakthrough that bipartisan proponents have been waiting for. Economic Scene in Business Day. [D2.]
