HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

I.B.M. Drags Down Dow, But Nasdaq Hits Record
I.B.M. stock fell sharply, dragging down the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 33.87 points to close at 6,850.03.
But the Nasdaq reached another closing high as Microsoft and Intel rose. I.B.M., Intel and Microsoft have all reported strong fourth-quarter earnings, and all have warned investors that their rates of growth may slow. But investors see a brighter future for Intel and Microsoft than for I.B.M. [Page D10.]
 
Compaq Earnings Up, Lifting Stock
Compaq's earnings exceeded Wall Street estimates, and the company's stock rose sharply. Compaq attributed the earnings gain to greater sales in the more profitable parts of the company's product line and to internal changes that have resulted in lower costs and increased profit margins. [D3.]
 
Jury Decides Against ABC
A jury ruled against ABC and two employees, awarding the Food Lion supermarket chain more than $5.5 million in punitive damages in a case that focused on the propriety of gathering TV news with hidden cameras and undercover reporting. [A1.]
 
A Strong Quarter for Bear Stearns
Quarterly earnings at Bear Stearns rose 68 percent, surpassing analysts' forecasts, as they have at other investment banks. Dean Witter reported strong profits, too. [D3.]
 
USAir Profit Down 55%
USAir said that earnings fell 55 percent in the fourth quarter as it continued to struggle with rising costs. [D3.]
 
Perelman: Ruling Is No Problem
Ronald O. Perelman, who is seeking to maintain control of Marvel Entertainment, suffered a setback when a judge rejected parts of a borrowing agreement that Marvel had negotiated. But a spokesman for Mr. Perelman said the ruling was not a problem because the judge had indicated that she would approve alternate language in the agreement that would amount to the same thing. [D2.]
 
Pharmacia Stock: A Bargain?
Most securities analysts were unhappy with Pharmacia & Upjohn even before the surprise resignation this week of John L. Zabriskie, the chief executive. But a few contrarians saw a brighter side. The share price was already one of the cheapest in the pharmaceutical sector, and after Mr. Zabriskie quit it got even cheaper. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Bank Employees Release President
Employees protesting a Government plan to cut jobs at Credit Foncier de France released the bank's president and other executives after six days. But labor organizers pledged to continue occupying the Paris headquarters until the Government scrapped plans to eliminate the jobs. [D8.]
 
Consumer Accounts in Shifts
Account activity has been accelerating in the last week in consumer product advertising. One big change involved a division of Johnson & Johnson, which moved the account of the Nicotrol anti-smoking patch, with billings estimated at $41 million, to the Health Care Connection unit of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York from DDB Needham New York. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Pizzeria Uno has acknowledged that ads for "low-fat" pizzas were misleading and has promised the F.T.C. not to make such claims again. [A21.]
 
New York City Job Growth Gains
Last year, for the first time since 1980, New York City created more jobs than its suburbs, breaking one of the trends of recent economic development in America. [B8.]
 
A Big Donor's Anonymous Giving
Charles F. Feeney, the founder of the DFS Group chain of duty-free shops, which was recently sold to LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, has secretly donated more than $600 million to hospitals, universities and other beneficiaries over the last 15 years. [A1.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
China Now Leads In Crude Steel Production

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
China replaced Japan in 1996 as the world's leading crude steel producer, a Japanese industry group said yesterday. China's output last year rose 5.2 percent, to 110.4 million tons, ahead of Japan's output of 98.8 million tons, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said. The group attributed China's increased output to that country's economic expansion. 
 Japan's 1996 production fell 2.8 percent from the record high of 101.7 million tons in 1995, which resulted in part from the rebuilding after the January 1995 earthquake in Kobe. The United States continued to occupy third place, with a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 95.9 million tons, the group said.

HEADLINE: In Business;
A Boom in Tourism

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Tourism is booming in New York City. According to the latest estimates, 30.3 million people visited the city last year, pouring $13 billion into the local economy. So why is the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau rolling out a major campaign to lure tourists with discounts at 250 hotels, restaurants, stores and cultural institutions? Two words: The cold.
"We have now entered the slowest time of the year for the 25,000 tourism-related businesses and their 130,000 employees," said Stephen J. Morello, the bureau's president. "It's not because we have less to offer but because the weather makes us less competitive. We can't sit back and let the city sell itself." 
 Indeed, after the New Year, the hotel occupancy rate dips to somewhere between 65 percent and 70 percent, compared with last year's average occupancy rate of 81 percent.
Fifteen hotels, from the Days to the Ritz-Carlton New York, are participating in the campaign called "New York for a Song," by offering discounts of up to 40 percent. Hotel guests will receive a "fun pass" -- a subway Metrocard with one free fare and a discount at participating restaurants, stores, theaters and museums. The campaign is scheduled to run through the end of March.
 LISA W. FODERARO

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1625 words

HEADLINE: He Gave Away $600 Million, and No One Knew

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
Over the last 15 years, a businessman from New Jersey has given away more than $600 million to universities, medical centers and other beneficiaries -- but has done it in such secrecy that most recipients never learned who their benefactor was.
The donor, Charles F. Feeney, who made his fortune with a string of duty-free airport shops, covered his tracks so well that business magazines for years have estimated his net worth in the billions, not realizing that he had transferred most of his assets to his two charitable foundations and is actually worth less than $5 million. 
 After years of secrecy, Mr. Feeney, who is 65, agreed this week to discuss his gifts because the duty-free stores were sold this month to the company that makes Moet & Chandon Champagne, and a lawsuit over the sale would have revealed his anonymous donations.
Mr. Feeney -- who has both Irish and American citizenship and has also made many gifts to Irish groups, including personal donations to Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing -- was matter-of-fact in describing why he had given away his fortune. "I simply decided I had enough money," he said. "It doesn't drive my life. I'm a what-you-see-is-what-you-get kind of guy."
Harvey P. Dale, a New York University tax law professor and president of Mr. Feeney's Atlantic Foundation, who has helped Mr. Feeney orchestrate his gifts since 1982, said: "He doesn't own a house. He doesn't own a car. He flies economy. And I think his watch cost about $15."
While large anonymous donations to charity are not unheard of, the scope and style of Mr. Feeney's giving, and his passion for secrecy, appeared to be unique, according to independent experts on philanthropy. "I've never heard of anything like this," said Thomas A. Troyer, a senior partner in the law firm of Caplin & Drysdale in Washington, who specializes in philanthropic law.
From the Mount Sinai School of Medicine to Portland State University, none of the American recipients of Mr. Feeney's largesse knew who their benefactor was. Grants were paid by cashier's check to conceal the source. In fact, the beneficiaries never realized that they owed their thanks to a single giver -- they were told that the money came from several generous "clients" who wished to remain anonymous.
Few of the recipients had ever even met Mr. Dale or Joel L. Fleishman, the president of Atlantic Philanthropic Services, which gave away the money on behalf of Mr. Feeney's foundations, the Atlantic Foundation and the Atlantic Trust.
Dr. Robert Butler, chairman of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, said he met Mr. Feeney in 1990 while making a proposal to an advisory board that reviewed grant proposals.
"I had no idea that he was the main supporter of what I call the Anonymous Foundation," Dr. Butler said, adding that the grant was made, starting the International Longevity Center at the New York Academy of Medicine. "Anonymous giving, giving that is not dependent on ego, is just really rare."
Mr. Feeney said that by giving anonymously, he could go about his life unhampered by pitches for donations. "There are people who want, and rightly deserve, recognition for giving, but in our case it wasn't important," he said.
It was Mr. Dale who helped Mr. Feeney set up his foundations, which like his Duty-Free Shoppes chain are based in Bermuda, avoiding the disclosure requirements of private foundations in the United States. Mr. Feeney also declined to take a deduction on his personal income taxes for the money he gave to the foundations, in order to preserve the secrecy. And Atlantic Philanthropic Services, the New York-based entity that screens applicants and writes the checks, is a for-profit company, also avoiding disclosure rules.
Mr. Feeney gave his entire 38.75 percent interest in the duty-free chain, known as DFS Group, to the two foundations in 1984 (even his partner, Robert W. Miller, was not told). Now, the foundations have received the proceeds from the sale of the controlling interest in the chain to LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton of France. The chain has sales of more than $3 billion annually, mostly in liquors and luxury goods, more than the combined sales of Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus.
The sale proceeds, along with other business assets Mr. Feeney has turned over to the foundations, have left the charity with $3.5 billion, even after the $610 million that has already been distributed to charities. It would rank as the nation's fourth-largest grant-making foundation if it were based in the United States, yet the two groups operate with tiny staffs, just 20 professionals in the United States and overseas.
The foundation's largest single grant was $30 million, according to Mr. Dale, who refused to identify the recipient on grounds that the information might discourage other donors from supporting it. "One reason for keeping gifts anonymous is to avoid what we call this 'crowding out' effect," Mr. Dale said.
Recipients were effusive in their praise for their anonymous donor's style of giving and what it had enabled them to do. "This is operational support, the most valuable kind of assistance," said William Nelsen, president of the Citizens' Scholarship Foundation of America, in St. Peter, Minn., which has received support since 1984.
Mr. Nelson said that the group, which mobilizes community groups to raise money for college student aid, was able to significantly expand its "Dollars for Scholars" program to reach 770 chapters throughout the country, thanks in large part to Atlantic money, which he said was more than a million dollars.
"As an organization, we've more than quadrupled in size since getting support from this anonymous donor," Mr. Nelsen said.
At the College Board, which administers scholastic assessment tests for college-bound high school seniors, the mystery donor was always referred to by the name "anonymous," said Dr. Donald Stewart, president of the College Board.
"Anonymous was most interested in results," Dr. Stewart said. The anonymous donor supported "long-term research to establish whether we are right, which is crucial for the project's credibility and in assessing whether all schools should adopt the same approach," he said.
Several recipients said that once they were invited to apply for funds their plans were closely examined. "Ed McMahon did not knock on my door," said Chuck Supple, president of Public Allies, which places young people in internships with nonprofit organizations. "These guys really kick the tires."
Judith Ramaley, president of Portland State University, in Oregon, called her first foundation grant last year her "catalyst," less than one million dollars that enabled the school to publicize its innovative new curriculum and links to the community, which have now drawn national attention and the support of other foundations. "They were the trail mix at that key moment on our very steep hiking path," she said.
One-fourth of Mr. Feeney's contributions have been made abroad, half of that in Ireland. The foundation also supports projects in South Africa, the former Soviet bloc, Eastern Europe, Israel and Jordan. There was less secrecy surrounding Mr. Feeney's activities in Ireland. Several Irish university presidents and other beneficiaries said they had met Mr. Feeney several times.
Mr. Feeney also said he had given substantial personal donations -- not from the Atlantic foundations -- in the last two years to the Washington office of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, which in 1994 entered into a cease-fire with the British that was broken last February. Public records show that Mr. Feeney has contributed some $280,000 -- making him the group's single largest American donor.
While Mr. Feeney acknowledged that some would criticize his support for a group linked to the I.R.A, he said his gifts to Sinn Fein had been monitored to insure that they supported only nonviolent activities. He continued supporting the Washington office despite the cease-fire's collapse, he said, "because I'm hopeful that it will be renewed."
The Atlantic Foundation's board of directors includes several prominent personalities in the philanthropic and educational establishment -- among them, Elizabeth McCormack, a senior adviser on charitable giving to members of the Rockefeller family and vice chairwoman of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation; Frank H. T. Rhodes, president emeritus of Cornell University, Michael I. Sovern, president of the Shubert Foundation and president emeritus of Columbia University, and Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., an attorney and chairman of the Natural Resources Defense Council.
None of them had previously disclosed their connection with the Atlantic groups publicly, nor did they discuss Mr. Feeney's giving with peers or even their families, they said in interviews this week. "This organization has operated on a need-to-know basis," Mr. Fleishman said.
Most recipients said their only contact was with program officers of Atlantic Philanthropic Services.
Mr. Rhodes, the foundation board member and former president of Cornell, said that the foundation was careful not to use money to tell recipients what to do or how to do it. "The danger with foundations is that sometimes the staff and board come to feel that they own the money," Mr. Rhodes said, "and they micromanage. We have a motto: noses in, fingers out."
Mr. Dale said of the relationship to grant recipients: "We are voyeurs. We let good people do good things. We oversee, but we don't interfere."
And despite his decision finally to disclose his donations, Mr. Feeney is still trying to keep a low profile. He declined this week to be photographed.

HEADLINE: Save Social Security, Save Our Families

BYLINE: By Gary L. Bauer; Gary L. Bauer is president of the Family Research Council.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For more than 20 years, I have worked to defend average American families, which time and again get the short end of the stick. I fear they will be the chief victims again as Washington considers three plans to "reform" Social Security, all based on putting payroll taxes or private contributions into the stock market.
Social Security, as designed in the 1930's, provides special compensations for couples who devote themselves to rearing children during their active years. A woman who never takes a job receives at least 50 percent of her retired husband's benefits. If her husband dies, she receives 100 percent of his benefits. There are also survivor benefits for children who are orphaned or who have a lost a bread-winning parent. 
 Any privatization plan that makes benefits dependent on lifetime contributions by a payroll worker would leave these women and children out in the cold. Is this the message we want to send to parents making huge sacrifices in time and money to raise our next generation of workers?
Moreover, any plan to replace the modified pay-as-you-go system we have now with a contributory system would involve a long transition during which workers would have to continue to pay taxes for their parents' retirement while contributing dollars for their own. The only way to do this, assuming that current recipients would not be cut off abruptly, would be through colossal tax increases or enormous growth in Federal deficits.
To pay for this transition, the privatization plan favored by five of the 13 members of the Social Security Advisory Council would require a 20 percent increase in the present payroll tax for workers and employers, effective for the next 70 years. The only reason that the increase is not far bigger is that this plan would also ask the Government to borrow an additional $7.2 trillion over the decades ahead, to be paid off by 2070.
Another plan offered by the advisory council would finance privatization completely through even higher payroll taxes. If so, according to Sylvester Schieber, a council member, payroll tax rates would increase to 19.3 percent (from the current 15.3 percent), a whopping 26 percent increase.
 The rush to overhaul Social Security has been fueled by questionable economic assumptions. The idea of having workers put their retirement dollars into the stock market rather than into government bonds, as is the case today, has tremendous appeal during a record bull market: The Dow Jones industrial average has multiplied eight times in 15 years.
Yet the advisory council based its plans on the assumption that the market will continue to grow in the decades ahead at a rate equal to or greater than the current pace. So for the privatization plans to work, the Dow would have to be in the neighborhood of 52,000 by 2012. Is this realistic? I haven't found very many economic historians who think so.
 Still, no matter what the market does, why do we think the nation will be better off by forcing workers to put their money into stock rather than, say, spending it on rearing children? The late Theodore Schultz, a Nobel Prize-winning economist, concluded from his landmark study of postwar economic recovery that human capital is roughly twice as important as monetary capital in generating economic growth. It is people who matter, not things, in generating the wealth of a nation.
It is possible to reform Social Security and to avoid the huge deficits projected to occur when baby boomers retire without placing an undue burden on today's families. As a first step, the retirement age, which is scheduled to be raised to 67 in the next century, should instead be raised periodically to reflect changes in life expectancy. Payroll taxes, instead of being sharply increased, should be cut by 20 percent for workers and employers, with employees who benefit from the tax cut receiving a commensurate reduction in their future benefits.
Such changes would help rein in entitlement growth while giving working families flexibility to make their own decisions in raising the next generation of the world's most productive workers.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An Op-Ed article on Thursday about proposals to change Social Security referred incorrectly to Theodore W. Schultz, who won the 1979 Nobel Prize in economics. He is not dead. Mr. Schultz, who is 94, lives in Evanston, Ill.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Happier Motoring: Choices in Buying Insurance

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
The proposal from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey last week to allow motorists to buy no-frills, no-fault auto insurance that could pare premiums by as much as one-fourth was a strong endorsement for a fledgling idea that has been unable to take flight nationally. The idea is known as auto choice, and the seal of approval from an adroit Republican who has her sights on bigger things, may finally be the step that lifts it off the ground.
"Once people understand auto choice means lower premiums and better coverage, it's a no-brainer," argues Peter Kinzler, director of the Coalition for Auto Insurance Reform, an ad hoc group of consumer activists that operates without funds from the insurance industry. 
 From the perspective of reformers, the Whitman endorsement could not come at a more opportune time. Next week Mr. Kinzler's group, along with the University of Wisconsin's Auto Compensation Project, is sponsoring a conference in Washington to highlight the virtues of auto choice and to publicize the introduction of legislation by Senators Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat from Connecticut; Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, and Mitch McConnell, Republican from Kentucky.
One reason auto insurance is so expensive is that it costs a fortune to determine liability in court. Plaintiffs' lawyers typically take one-third to one-half of any compensation. Moreover, the ability to sue for payoffs far exceeding injury victims' medical bills and lost wages encourages fraud. In 1995 Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, estimated that fraud added $200 to the average household's insurance cost.
No-fault insurance, requiring insurers to cover their own clients' economic losses regardless of fault and permitting suits only when injuries are severe, was supposed to contain this colossal waste. But trial lawyers have maintained the upper hand by keeping it relatively easy to get to court in most states.
Stricter no-fault laws that barred all suits against offending drivers whose behavior is short of criminal would do the trick. But this approach is a nonstarter, in no small part because of opposition from Ralph Nader, who sees no-fault as an unacceptable interference with every American's right to a day in court. That's where auto choice fits in.
The invention of Jeffrey O'Connell, a law professor at the University of Virginia, and Michael J. Horowitz, a fellow at the Hudson Institute in Washington, auto choice is just what it sounds like. Those who value the right to sue for pain and suffering could still buy insurance to do that. Those who do not could save money by limiting their insurance to no-fault protection covering medical bills and lost wages.
When two drivers who chose the no-fault protection were involved in an accident, each would look to his own insurer for compensation. When two drivers who bought pain and suffering insurance collided, responsibility -- and compensation -- would be settled through the legal system.
It gets a bit more complicated if a fully covered "pain and suffering" driver collided with a no-fault driver. Here, the fully covered driver would not be able to sue the other for pain and suffering. Rather, he would look to his own insurer for compensation. This may sound odd but it is just the way coverage against "uninsured motorists" works today.
If everyone chose the no-fault route, the savings would be enormous. A study by the Rand Corporation, updated to 1996, puts the figure at $40 billion nationwide, or $220 a vehicle.
Auto choice, which was quietly endorsed by President George Bush in 1992 and Bob Dole in 1996, may be broadening its political base with the support of moderate Democrats like Senators Lieberman and Moynihan. What's more, there are signs that Nader-inspired opposition from consumer groups is crumbling: Stephen Brobeck, the executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, has signed on.
But lawyers, who reap tens of billions of dollars annually from auto injury suits, have plenty of money to feed the campaign contribution machine. And at least for the moment, there is no compelling incentive for legislators to bite the hands that feed them. That's why the New Jersey initiative -- where 35 cents of the total premium dollar now goes into compensation for pain and suffering and lawyers' fees -- looms so large.
The New Jersey plan offers motorists four choices. At one end is a policy close to business-as-usual, with "unfettered access" to the courts. At the other is $250,000 in true no-fault protection, which would cut premiums by 20 to 25 percent.
In between are hybrids that Governor Whitman apparently figured would help deflate opponents' argument that access to court was a matter of principle. One option would allow motorists to buy limited coverage for pain and suffering from their own insurers, reducing premiums by about 8 percent. The other would establish a new, very tough injury threshold for access to court.
Auto choice remains a political long shot. Insurance companies, which might be expected to be powerful natural allies, are in fact, largely indifferent because they see little additional profit, anticipating that competition would force them to lower their premiums in proportion to their costs.
But when seasoned politicians like Governor Whitman take a shot at mobilizing the discontent of motorists who have insurance premiums that can easily exceed $2,000 a year, the assumption that trial lawyers can buy their way out of trouble may not hold forever. "Who could say no," the Governor asks, "to a bill that simply gives consumers a choice?"

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Jan. 23, about legislative proposals to allow motorists to buy no-frills, no-fault auto insurance, misstated the position of the Consumer Federation of America on one such auto choice proposal before Congress. The federation does not support it.

HEADLINE: New York Shoppers, Unleashed

BYLINE: By Frank DeCaro; Frank DeCaro, the author of "A Boy Named Phyllis: A Suburban Memoir," writes about style.

 BODY:
It wasn't the lime green cashmere sweater that found its way home from Brooks Brothers, or the navy blue fedora. It wasn't that new Lanvin necktie from Saks, the Calvin Klein underwear from Bloomie's or the light blue Banana Republic sport shirt.
No, what summed up this week's shopping frenzy -- the delirium of rack pawing fueled by a one-week repeal of the New York sales tax on clothing -- was watching the actor Dolph Lundgren buy footwear in the middle of the afternoon. Even Norse gods can't resist saving a little money after lunch. 
 "It's like Christmas in here," the sales clerk said. And at Barneys, where the man who survived "Rocky IV" was shoe shopping, and at stores all over Manhattan, it was. Except that people were buying presents for themselves this week.
The sales tax abatement, touted by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani as a miracle salve for the city's economy despite skepticism from economists, has allowed consumers to give in to their most selfish shopping instincts. It has granted New Yorkers permission to guiltlessly say gimme. After a disappointing holiday retail season, stores are thrilled. Even Gov. George Pataki saved $12.49 last Saturday.
Though the experiment is expected to cost the city $7 million in lost revenue -- and the state an estimated $10 million to $20 million -- the Governor and legislative leaders now seem to favor Mayor Giuliani's goal of abolishing the sales tax on clothes priced under $500.
The hope is a permanent tax break will stem the flow of shoppers to New Jersey, where clothing isn't taxed and there's no difficult math to do in the dressing room.
What perfect timing. From fashion magazine layouts to liquor ads, the message is to indulge. Conspicuous consumption is back, they say. Forget the Nike slogan "Just do it," with the rigor it implies. Just buy it.
Who can resist the temptation? Certainly not bargain hunters, and we are a city of those. While our savings this week is only 8.25 percent and limited to "necessity" clothing -- like lime green cashmere sweaters -- it is an inducement the best shoppers can't fight, even though January is supposed to be the slow season. After all, fall and winter merchandise is on sale, and the tax break makes these clothes even more irresistible. But what if this were a time when prices weren't so drastically reduced? Full-price clothes would still be a hard sell.
On the one hand, in this fashion retailing mecca, the best merchandise is presented in the poshest way; the snootier the sales clerk, the more desirable the goods. Stores are our country clubs, each with its own clique. But the city has also been malled, chain stores replacing special retailers. It's becoming Paramus without the free parking.
Mayor Giuliani would have us believe that with no sales tax we can indulge our basest fashion needs, revitalize the city's economy and compete with New Jersey, all at the same time. That would be swell, though it's unlikely.
Even without a tax break, New York City is still the only place where shopping remains a performance art. Malls may have food courts, but we have Dolph Lundgren.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Steven Guarnaccia)

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Moment of Realization: Home Has Disappeared

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
In every life there comes a moment of realization that what we assumed would always be there is actually vanishing. Our parents die, the houses we grew up in are sold, neighborhood landmarks disappear and sooner or later what we used to call home just isn't there anymore.
Jeanne Jordan and Steven Ascher's absorbing documentary film, "Troublesome Creek: A Midwestern," presents itself as a case study of the decline of a small-farming way of life in the American heartland. But the movie, which Ms. Jordan narrates in a deceptively chipper, faintly sardonic style, is really the story of her own coming to terms with the ultimate disappearance of home. 
 The film, which won the award for best documentary at last year's Sundance Film Festival, is really an extended home movie starring Ms. Jordan's likable parents, Russel and Mary Jane Jordan, members of a hardy breed of farmers in northwestern Iowa who have worked the land for generations. Ms. Jordan is one of six children of the couple, who, like so many other agricultural families in the 1980's, found themselves getting ever more deeply in debt to increasingly hard-nosed financial institutions.
After much anguished consultation, the Jordans decided that the most economically feasible solution was to auction off their farm equipment, animals and other possessions to pay the debt, and give the land to their oldest son, Jim, to work, while they moved into town. That way, the land would remain in the family.
The film presents the bushy-browed Russel (who was once runner-up in an Abraham Lincoln look-alike contest and who suffers from Parkinson's disease) and Mary Jane as laconic salt-of-the-earth types who face up to their situation with a tight-lipped dignity, although not without tears. Mary Jane, a onetime Iowa state 4-H president, is especially bereft over the sale of her Ethan Allen furniture.
The Jordans' story, which the narrator humorously dubs "a midwestern," is interspersed with scenes from classic westerns like "Red River" and "High Noon." Straining a metaphor, the movie compares the auction of the family's belongings on a snowy winter morning to a climactic Hollywood gunfight. But for all the buildup, not much suspense is generated over the auction price of a combine and a herd of cows.
In the film's eeriest scene, Ms. Jordan and her parents revisit an earlier family home, now uninhabited, in the once-cozy Iowa community of Rolfe, which now appears to be a well-kept ghost town. There's the spic-and-span facade of Ms. Jordan's high school, which, she says, was recently closed for lack of enrollment. Everything seems to be snugly in place except for the people, who have gone somewhere else.
Without becoming analytical, the movie, which opens today at the Angelika Film Center, describes the economic cycles of farm life and offers some rough statistics on the decline of American agriculture. (Since the 1960's, the number of farms has dwindled to fewer than two million, from six million).
But what gives the film its elegiac resonance has little to do with the farm crisis or with western movie myths. The images of the land, with its windmill and its cattle, and of the Jordan clan figuratively drawing their wagons into a circle in hard times exert a nostalgic tug for a Norman Rockwell dream of which this family, in better days, seemed to have found a piece.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By William Grimes 

 BODY:

Off Broadway, Too, Goes on the Move
Two can play the real estate game. For several years now, the Broadway shuffle on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues has hogged the theater news. But Off Broadway is showing signs of real estate restlessness.
This week, Second Stage ended a six-year search for larger quarters, taking out a lease on the top two floors of the former Manufacturers Hanover Bank on the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 43d Street. The 1927 Art Deco building will undergo a $4 million conversion into a 299-seat theater, which is scheduled to open in the fall of 1998. 
 Second Stage will keep its 108-seat theater at Broadway and 75th Street. "Artistically we were a little stymied," said Carole Rothman, the artistic director of Second Stage. "We can't do musicals, and playwrights these days tend to write very cinematically, with plays that have 26 scenes, and we have no room for scenery."
The limited seating has also put a cap on earned revenue, as the theater's next production illustrates. It's a new play by Lanford Wilson, "Sympathetic Magic," which Ms. Rothman described as "a comedy about chaos and order." Mr. Wilson can draw audiences of 800 a night. "At Second Stage, only 800 people a week can see it," Ms. Rothman said.
Just around the corner, on the north side of 43d Street just west of Eighth Avenue, the Manhattan Theater Club, which has its office on 16th Street, plans to convert two floors of an office building into an administrative office for itself and four rehearsal studios. Some studios will be rented out, helping to relieve a shortage of rehearsal space in midtown. The complex is scheduled to open in June.
There's more. Eric Krebs, who owns the John Houseman and Douglas Fairbanks Theaters, is expanding westward on 42d Street. This week he began construction of a 280-seat theater in the Riverbank West apartment building between 10th and 11th Avenues. The theater, scheduled to be completed in late April, will have table-and-chair seating for revues and raked seating for plays.
Last but not least, J. C. Compton, formerly an actress and the wife of Harold Clurman, is creating a theater complex in the old Century Association headquarters, a 19th-century townhouse across from the Vineyard Theater on East 15th Street.
The Century Center, as the new complex is named, will have a 299-seat theater and smaller room for seminars, readings and classes. "Minor Demons," a new play by Bruce Graham whose producers include Blake Edwards and Tony Adams, begins performances on March 4.

 
 
Serious About Silliness
 If you're going to be banana No. 2, it doesn't hurt to have Bill Irwin as banana No. 1. So Christopher Evan Welch, making his New York debut at the Laura Pels Theater in "Scapin," has no complaints, unlike his character, Sylvestre, whom he describes as "the nervous friend."
Scapin is a schemer and an optimist. Sylvestre is a realist, which is to say, a pessimist, not overly bright, but smart enough to know that when servants try something clever, a beating from the master lies in store.
"He has to be dragged into things," said Mr. Welch, who specializes in economical gestures and tiny but constant changes of expression. "In the commedia dell'arte, the characters would have worn actual masks. Today we wear the masks of our neuroses. It's clear that Sylvestre has problems that go way beyond this play."
Mr. Welch grew up near Dallas and during high school began competing in local acting tournaments, winning top honors in the "humorous interpretation" category his first time out. After studying theater at the University of Dallas and the University of Washington, he walked right into the lead role in Tony Kushner's adaptation of "The Illusion" at the ACT Theater in Seattle. He has worked steadily ever since, mostly at the Seattle Repertory Theater, where Mr. Irwin directed him in an evening of sketches and in an early version of "Scapin."
When "Scapin" concludes its run, Mr. Welch will make his Broadway debut in mid-April on the Roundabout's Stage Right in "London Assurance," a 19th-century comedy.
In the meantime, Mr. Welch is devoting serious attention to absolute silliness. "Bill and I talk every day about shaping a beat," he said. "We change the laughs all the time. In fact, we dropped two lines the other day. The badda-bing stuff requires constant retuning."

 
 
Director as Character in a Play
 The Elia Kazan problem just won't go away. Mr. Kazan, one of the century's most influential film directors, was recently rebuffed by Hollywood when the American Film Institute and the Los Angeles Film Critics Association denied him lifetime achievement awards. Forty-five years after he cooperated with the House Un-American Activities Committee, he remains a troubling figure, the focal point of hot debate about the relationship between ethics and art.
In New York, theater audiences will have a chance to revisit the same arguments in a new play, "Names," which begins performances at the American Jewish Theater on March 1.
Written by a first-time playwright, Mark Kemble, "Names" gathers the charter members of the Group Theater in a room in the Algonquin Hotel in the early 1950's. Outside, an angry anti-Communist mob is picketing. Inside, John Garfield, Harold Clurman, Luther Adler, Stella Adler, Clifford Odets and Lee Strasberg pace, worry and argue. Enter Mr. Kazan.
Audience members may come ready to hiss, but Mr. Kemble gives Mr. Kazan a fighting chance. "I'm mixed about Kazan," he said. "The argument is about two rights, which is much more interesting than a wrong and a right, because then you're just beating someone up."
Mr. Kemble came to his subject by a peculiar route. While sitting in a Greenwich Village cafe in the early 80's, he was approached by a casting agent for the film "Frances" who thought he looked like Garfield. He flew out to Los Angeles, landed the small role and became obsessed with the actor, the blacklist and the Group Theater. "Names" is the result, a play about politics, friendship and the disintegration of an artistic collective. "In a way," Mr. Kemble said, "it's really about the breakup of a family."

 
 
Actor of the Week
 The Sam Shepard-Signature Theater machine rolls on with three one-act plays, "The Sad Lament of Pecos Bill on the Eve of Killing His Wife," "Killer's Head" and "Action." Keep a close eye on the middle one, a 20-minute monologue that will be delivered by a different actor each week of the run. Signature has signed up Jamie Sheridan, Bill Pullman, Treat Williams, Stephen Lang, Arliss Howard and John Diehl for the rotation. Performances begin on Jan. 28 at the Joseph Papp/Susan Stein Shiva Theater.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Retreats With Stocks, Ending Mixed in Profit Taking

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar hit a nearly four-year high against the yen and touched another two-and-a-half-year high against the mark yesterday before retreating to end mixed on profit taking and faded hopes for lower German interest rates.
A late selloff in the American stock market also helped undermine the dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average, which surpassed 6,900 during trading yesterday afternoon for the first time, tumbled nearly 100 points in the final hour of trading. 
 Despite the dollar's mixed showing, traders said the currency remained in heavy demand. They predicted that it would test the 120-yen level and keep rising against the mark.
"This new-found bullishness by the market is extremely strong and well entrenched," said Stephen Flanagan, senior foreign-exchange trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "It's going to take some heavy selling to change market sentiment about the dollar."
The dollar traded as high as 119.69 yen in intraday dealings, the strongest since February 1993, before settling in New York at 119.47 yen, up from 119.03 on Wednesday.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.6455 marks, the highest since June 1994, before dropping to 1.6366 in New York, from 1.6427 Wednesday.
The pound, which tumbled Wednesday to the lowest level since October, weakened further in a broad retreat caused partly by fears that the governing Conservative Party might have to call elections in March instead of May.
In New York the pound cost $1.6292, down from $1.6300.
The yen also suffered from Japanese data that showed the country's trade surplus narrowed far more than expected in December, suggesting the currency had room to fall further. A weak currency tends to bolster exports and weaken imports.
The mark derived strength against the dollar partly from profit taking from the dollar's surge on Wednesday. In addition, the Bundesbank's decision to leave interest rates unchanged at its regular meeting countered some speculation that the German central bank might reduce rates to stimulate the country's economy. Lower rates diminish a currency's value.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Strong Clothing Sales Spur Rise In 4th-Quarter Earnings at Sears

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that earnings surged 25 percent in the fourth quarter, led by strong sales of clothing and other goods and an increase in credit card revenue.
Sears's earnings gain came even as many other retailers reported a disappointing holiday season, which is expected to push fourth-quarter profits lower. 
 "Sears is among the leaders in sales growth," said Terry McEvoy, an analyst with Janney Montgomery Scott Inc.
Sales rose 11 percent, to $12.04 billion from $10.87 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year -- a closely watched indicator of a retailer's sales strength -- rose 5.4 percent.
Sears, the nation's second-biggest retailer after Wal-Mart Stores, earned $567 million, or $1.42 a share, up from $455 million, or $1.13 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The results surpassed the average estimate of $1.37 from 23 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc.
Shares of Sears fell $2 today, to $49.125, amid a broad decline in stocks.
It was the fourth consecutive quarter that the retailer exceeded expectations and that earnings rose by 25 percent or more.
Sears, which operates about 800 department stores, said it had same-store sales increases of higher than 10 percent in all clothing categories in December, as well as in computers, electronics, tools and hardware.
The company, based in Hoffman Estates, a suburb of Chicago, said same-store sales in its 2,500 specialty stores also rose more than 10 percent. Those stores sell auto parts, tires and furniture.
Sears credit card revenue rose 18 percent as a result of strong sales and higher rates. Its provision for unpaid accounts rose by $133 million, to $328 million, largely because of an increase in personal bankruptcies.
The revenue from credit cards made up about 28 percent of net income, said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report. He said investors could find that worrisome if interest rates rose or personal bankruptcies increased further, which would reduce the company's benefit from credit cards.
"The question Wall Street asks is will they be able to control that and run it as profitably as they are right now," Mr. Barnard said.
The company's gross margin widened to 27.9 percent of sales from 26.9 percent, as Sears sold more higher-margin goods, such as apparel.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Fall Late in Day After Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell yesterday but stayed in a narrow trading range as the market absorbed a fresh supply of debt.
The 30-year bond fell 15/32 , to a price of 9514/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direct, rose to 6.86 percent, from 6.82 percent on Wednesday. Bonds had rallied during the day but turned lower in the last hour of trading, as did the stock market. 
 Yesterday, the Treasury sold $12.5 billion of new five-year notes at a yield of 6.325 percent, up from 6.125 percent last month and the highest yield in more than three months.
John Canavan, government debt analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, said he thought yesterday's five-year note auction went fairly well, with better-than-average retail interest.
"Combined with the two-year note auction the day before, which got a decent reception," Mr. Canavan said, "today's five-year note auction did not appear to be a problem and brought the market through this week's supply without any difficulty, as far as the auctions are concerned."
He added that there was no real reason for the market to be down yesterday, though supply did appear to be a prime suspect since there were others in the market to borrow.
The Province of Quebec sold $750 million of 10-year notes to international investors at a price to yield 7.118 percent, or about 58 basis points more than a comparable United States Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In when-issued trading, the Treasury's new inflation-indexed securities being sold next Wednesday were offered at a price to yield 3.42 percent, up 11 basis points from the previous day.
According to Credit Suisse First Boston, one of the three book managers along with Goldman, Sachs and Merrill Lynch, American investors made up about 40 percent of the buyers for the global bond issue.
The initial weekly unemployment report gave investors some respite, as the number of people filing for unemployment rose more than expected, to 355,000 for the week ended Jan. 18.
The report served to ease concern about a tight labor market, but traders said they did not believe the market would move into a new trading range before the release of the Employment Cost Index on Tuesday. The surprising September drop in the index's year-over-year growth to 2.8 percent precipitated the market's rally late last year.
The weekly jobless claims number suggested that employment reports were more likely to moderate than to strengthen, said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors. He added that some investors were looking ahead to reports next week on wages and economic growth in the fourth quarter.
Higher-than-expected readings could give the Fed more reason to raise interest rates to contain inflation. Fear of higher interest rates, combined with expectations of more debt sales by other borrowers, could induce further selling.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Gingrich's Revenge

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
One thing above all led to the undoing of the Republican revolution that Newt Gingrich and his colleagues launched after their election victory in 1994. That was Mr. Gingrich's decision to shut down the Government at the end of 1995 as a way of waging the policy conflict with President Clinton.
The shutdown outraged the public. Americans, it turned out, did not agree with the radical Republican aim of disemboweling the Federal Government. 
 We are now in serious danger of repeating on a far grander scale the folly of immobilizing the Government. That would be a likely consequence of the proposal at the top of the Republican Congressional agenda: a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget.
One provision of the proposed amendment, not much noticed so far, would require a three-fifths vote in both houses of Congress to raise the limit on the U.S. debt. Sponsors of the amendment say this feature would be an automatic way to block deficit financing. But just think how it would likely work in practice.
As it is, the debt ceiling has produced crisis after crisis. Getting a simple majority vote for an increase in the ceiling has often proved difficult, putting the Government at risk of being unable to pay its bills. It will be far more difficult -- often impossible -- to win three-fifths of the votes in both houses.
Moreover, debt-ceiling crises tend to occur quickly, when budget forecasts have slipped. There is an unexpected slowdown in the economy, so tax revenues are below estimates. Or a financial crisis like that over savings and loans increases expenditure.
Suppose the President has presented a balanced budget, as the amendment would demand, but then events unbalance income and spending. There is no way to raise taxes or cut spending quickly enough to avoid the need for temporary borrowing, so the President asks Congress to increase the debt limit.
Forty-one senators, one more than two-fifths, could block the increase. Different members of that bloc would have different prices for relenting: build my dam, shift money from Medicaid to Star Wars, whatever. It takes no great analytical skill to appreciate how extraordinarily hard it would be to work through such a crisis.
Failure is likely, at least temporarily. And that would mean one of two things: shutting down parts of the Government or having the United States go into default.
That scenario is not far-fetched. It is the logical outcome of the balanced-budget amendment. And it would have consequences far graver than the overreaching by Newt Gingrich that closed much of the Government in 1995.
For the United States Government to default on its obligations, or even to approach a serious possibility of default, would be devastating to financial markets in this country and everywhere. If it happened once, confidence would be weakened even if we emerged from the first crisis. Everyone would understand that the system -- the new system created by the amendment -- virtually insures more crises in future.
Foreseeable consequences of that kind have led a broad spectrum of financial and economic thinkers to oppose the amendment. Alan Greenspan stated his opposition this week. Robert Eisner, past president of the American Economic Association, spoke for 38 economists, including 9 Nobel laureates, in a critical article in The Wall Street Journal. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal think tank in Washington, has issued formidable analyses.
The possibility of a crisis over the debt ceiling is only one provision of many in the proposed amendment that alarm those and other critics. The amendment would effectively end majority rule in Congress, giving minorities new blocking powers and assuring stalemate again and again.
The Republican leaders who are pushing the amendment must be aware of those dangers. They have to be going ahead, then, either because they are in the iron grip of ideology or because they see a chance for partisan point-scoring. Neither reason justifies endangering the system that has enabled this country to survive and prosper over 200 years.

HEADLINE: Russia's Frail President

 BODY:
Boris Yeltsin's weakened health has understandably preoccupied Russian politics for months, but a new surge of calls for his resignation as President is premature. Mr. Yeltsin may eventually prove unable to give his country strong and enduring leadership. But unless he suffers a sudden decline, it will be several months before a sound judgment about his fitness can be made.
That is not to belittle the precariousness of his condition. Weakened by heart problems and slowly recovering from bypass surgery and pneumonia, President Yeltsin is a frail figure today. Despite a brief return to work and a flurry of decrees, he clearly cannot run the Russian Government in his current state. But recovery from bypass surgery ordinarily requires several months of rest, and the added complication of pneumonia has slowed his convalescence from his November operation. He has not helped himself by rushing back to the Kremlin. 
 Mr. Yeltsin's rivals and opponents are eager to push him aside, propelled in part by mounting economic problems and opinion polls showing growing impatience with the Government. The Russian economy contracted by 6 percent last year, and the gap is rapidly growing between those who have done well under capitalism and those who have struggled or fallen into poverty. Crime and corruption remain staggering problems.
Russia's Communist-dominated Parliament approved a non-binding resolution this week to sack Mr. Yeltsin. Aleksandr Lebed, the former general who finished a strong third in the first round of presidential balloting last spring, is impatient to get on with a new election he is confident he can win. In a visit to New York this week, he warned of coming chaos in Russia if problems like uncollected taxes and unpaid workers are not addressed.
Mr. Lebed's bulldozer approach to politics is both refreshing and unnerving. There may be a limit to the frustrations Russians will endure, although they have shown remarkable stoicism over the decades, but predicting instability only invites unrest. A political upheaval is not in Russia's interest.
Moscow's political leaders should not be so quick to talk of discarding a president. Mr. Yeltsin won election by a wide margin in a fair vote. The interests of democracy require that he be given a reasonable time to recover before Russia is asked to face the issue of his fitness to serve and the unpredictable consequences of a resignation.
Mr. Yeltsin has an able team of aides who can manage the Government while he tries to regain his strength. If by spring it becomes clear that his recovery is faltering, he should not dodge the difficult issue of resignation or talk himself into the mistaken belief that he is indispensable. Under the Russian Constitution, new elections would be held within three months of a resignation.
The United States, for its part, must continue to do business with the Yeltsin Government. Vice President Al Gore plans to meet next month with Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, and President Clinton is tentatively scheduled to play host to Mr. Yeltsin in March. But Washington should recognize that Mr. Yeltsin may not be able to handle a full agenda of issues or deliver on promises he makes.
Russia cannot wait indefinitely for its President to heal. But pushing him out the door now would do more to undermine democracy than a few more months of uncertainty about his health.

HEADLINE: Cleaning Up Commerce

 BODY:
William Daley, President Clinton's nominee for Commerce Secretary, promised at his confirmation hearing to take politics out of the most politicized department in the Government. It was a necessary pledge that may not go far enough.
The Clinton Administration was not the first to escort powerful corporation executives into presidential palaces and government offices around the globe in pursuit of export sales. But his first Commerce Secretary, Ronald Brown, perfected the practice, critics charge, mostly on behalf of big contributors to the Democrats. The Commerce Department is also where John Huang worked as a political appointee on trade before leaving to raise money for the Clinton campaign -- fueling suspicions that the Administration swapped access to officials in exchange for political donations. 
 Mr. Daley's comments were designed to deflect criticism by those who accused the Administration of turning Commerce into an adjunct office of the Democratic National Committee. He promised, if confirmed, to wipe out about 40 percent of the department's politically appointed jobs. He also promised to suspend trade missions for a month while he creates guidelines for giving all corporate executives -- not just those who donate to Democrats -- an equal shot at accompanying department officials abroad. The task will not be easy. Commerce can justify promoting products that pack a large economic wallop. But how to put that abstract principle to work in a politically charged environment is far from clear.
Mr. Daley should not stop with depoliticizing trade missions. This may be the time for rethinking more broadly the historic role of Commerce in promoting American business abroad. Mr. Daley can surely defend using political muscle to sway foreign governments that are choosing between American products and imports from another country. Such political decisions abroad warrant political interference, especially since other governments are not shy about backing the commercial interests of their exporters. The sale of Boeing aircraft to Saudi Arabia fits this model. It also makes sense for Commerce to spend some money, primarily on behalf of small companies, providing generalized information to American exporters about foreign opportunities and similar information to foreign importers about American exports.
But Mr. Daley will need to look skeptically at the practice of using Government influence to help particular American companies win contracts from private companies overseas. He might also review the department's export-promotion schemes that use taxpayers' dollars to subsidize advertising and sales of American products abroad.
Mr. Daley declared that the Commerce Department ought not to favor Democrats over Republicans. He also needs to check that the department is not favoring businesses over taxpayers.

HEADLINE: Worst Freeze In Years Ruins Florida Crops

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 23

 BODY:
A freeze last weekend, the worst here in seven years, caused $93 million in damage to winter vegetable and tropical fruit crops in Dade County, officials said today, and losses for all crops could total $250 million statewide. The damage could lead to sharply higher prices across the nation.
The Florida Agriculture Commissioner, Bob Crawford, said the higher estimate included losses of citrus crops, sugar cane and other agricultural products that have yet to be assessed. He has asked Gov. Lawton Chiles to declare agricultural disasters in 18 counties. 
 Among those counties, though, three in South Florida, including Dade, were the hardest hit by the freeze on Saturday night and Sunday.
Nearly 16,000 acres and 70 percent of all crops in Dade County were destroyed. Pole beans and okra suffered 100 percent losses while 85 percent of the green bean, yellow squash and zucchini crops were lost. Sixty percent of the banana and mango crops were also lost.
Half of all winter fruits and vegetables sold nationwide originate in Florida. In some areas in the state, vegetable prices have already increased 50 percent to 70 percent.
"Green beans have doubled in price since last Friday," Mr. Crawford said, "and bell peppers are also going up dramatically."
Although vegetable crops were hardest hit, citrus growers are also worried. It is not yet clear how the state's citrus crops will be affected, since roughly 40 percent of state's oranges have already been harvested, said Bob Terry, an administrator with the Florida Agriculture Statistics Service.
"We did have some ice reported in fruit," Mr. Terry said, "but that doesn't necessarily translate into lost fruit. It's very difficult to tell what has been lost."
The Florida Citrus Commission has recommended that there be heavier inspection at citrus packing houses for the next 10 days to determine the severity of the damage to the fruit.
"This way the fresh market will be assured of receiving Florida citrus that has not been damaged," said Philip Lesser, director of economic and market research at the Florida Department of Citrus.
One reason for the severity of the losses, officials said, was that farmers did not get adequate warning of the weather, which would have enabled them to take precautions. Because of budget cuts, the National Weather Service stopped forecasting temperatures for agricultural areas as of last April, forcing farmers to rely on local forecasts of populated areas, which tend to be warmer, on average, by five degrees or more. Even a difference of a few degrees can be crucial to crops.
"This was the first year we
haven't had a weather forecast coming from the Government," specifically for farming areas, Mr. Crawford said. "It really left farmers in the lurch not knowing this freeze is coming."
In addition, the weather service had predicted temperatures around 40 degrees for last weekend, well above freezing, but temperatures in fact dipped below freezing, in some areas to 19 degrees.
Precautions farmers can take if they know severe cold is coming include spraying crops with water heated to 72 degrees so a protective coating of ice forms to prevent freezing, and saturating the ground with warm water.

HEADLINE: China's Leader For Hong Kong Backs Repeal Of Rights Laws

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Friday, Jan. 24

 BODY:
In the face of international and local criticism over China's intention to roll back laws protecting a range of civil rights in Hong Kong, the man who will rule the territory under Chinese sovereignty has declared his support for repeal of the laws.
Local legislators, lawyers and the territory's rambunctious press expressed alarm over the recommendation by a Beijing-appointed body that a series of recently adopted laws, including core provisions of Hong Kong's bill of rights, should not stand when Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule on July 1. 
 But it was not until Thursday that Tung Chee-hwa, a former shipping tycoon chosen by Beijing to be Chief Executive of Hong Kong when Britain hands over the colony, declared his support for China's intentions, which include reinstating colonial legislation restricting protests and requiring official approval to set up political organizations.
"The key question here for the community to debate is what is more important to the community -- social order, inconvenience caused to the public at large or individual rights," Mr. Tung said at a dinner organized by two leading newspapers, Sing Tao and The Hong Kong Standard. "I believe it is important to get the right balance between individual rights and social order for the good of the entire community."
Mr. Tung has repeatedly stressed the need to subjugate individual rights, whether expressed in the form of protest or through democratic institutions, to "the good of the public at large."
China's move to return to authoritarian colonial legislation that had been repealed by Hong Kong's elected legislature in recent years has drawn vigorous protests from London and Washington. On Wednesday the Chinese Ambassador to Britain, Jiang Enzhu, was summoned to the Foreign Office to be told of London's unhappiness over Beijing's intentions.
In Washington the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said that the Administration was "deeply concerned over any attempts to weaken civil liberties and basic freedoms in Hong Kong."
Martin C. M. Lee, the chairman of the Democratic Party, Hong Kong's largest party, said today that he was dismayed by Mr. Tung's capitulation to Beijing's injunctions.
"I express regret that Mr. Tung doesn't seem to understand that what he's been talking about are entirely human rights matters, and they are also legal matters," Mr. Lee said in a telephone interview. "It has everything to do with human rights."
Many of the laws China plans to revoke were passed after 1984, when Britain and China signed an agreement to return Hong Kong to China and London promised not to significantly change the colony's laws or electoral system. Since then, however, the British authorities have moved to a fully elected legislature and have adopted numerous guarantees of civil and democratic rights.
Many local newspapers attacked Beijing's intentions.
"This is an obvious attempt to emasculate Hong Kong people's freedom to demonstrate and collect petitions," Sing Tao said. "Hong Kong people should keep on protesting against the reinstatement of the ordinances concerned."The Hong Kong Economic Times, which often supports Beijing, said, "Before amending or abolishing Hong Kong law, the Preparatory Committee legal panel should first consider the desires and needs of Hong Kong people." The panel is the Beijing-appointed body that made the proposals.
But Mr. Tung is having none of it.
"The issue is not about the freedom of expression and freedom of assembly," Mr. Tung said. "The issue is not about human rights. If people want to demonstrate or lie in the middle of the road, in my view, they're welcome. They should be allowed to do so. But they must do so without causing inconvenience and harm to the community at large and they must do so within the law.
"This is not a human rights issue," he insisted. "Some people in this community like you to believe this is a step backward on democracy and a step backward on human rights. This is not true."

HEADLINE: Rug Pulled From Stocks In Last Hour

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market dropped sharply in a sudden late-afternoon selloff yesterday, ruining what looked to be another record performance. The fall came on the busiest day of trading in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.
The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 94.28 points, or 1.38 percent, all of it in the last hour of trading, to close at 6,755.75 Before the selloff, the Dow was up 56 points and fell as much as 150 points from there. It was the first time this year that the Dow declined two consecutive days. 
 "The market was just overdue," said Alfred Goldman, market analyst at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. The Dow had risen 500 points this year, he said, "and we haven't even paused to catch our breath," adding, "Today, we took a peak at 6,900 and then the market ran out of steam."
The sudden market decline, the worst since a 101-point fall in the Dow on Dec. 31, came after two years of sparkling stock market returns and at a time when even bullish analysts forecast only moderate gains in 1997.
Analysts, who in general had trouble finding reasons for the sudden turn, said it appeared that selling on the futures market -- where big bets on the outlook for stocks are often made -- set off the plunge.
In addition, a string of large, computer-aided sell programs helped sink the Dow, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm based in Greenwich, Conn.
Other analysts cited a slump in the bond market, which pushed interest rates higher in the afternoon just ahead of the fall in the stock market. Even as the Dow and the other major market indexes moved almost daily to highs this year, analysts have been worried about the jump in interest rates.
"Clearly we have had pressure building because we have had interest rates moving up and the stock market has been ignoring it," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company.
Analysts are worried about interest rates because when they rise they make stocks less attractive. The yield on the 30-year bond, which rose to 6.86 percent, from 6.82 percent Wednesday, has risen from 6.35 percent on Nov. 29, its recent low. Some market strategists are predicting a fall in the market this year caused by rising interest rates as the economy begins to grow faster.
But others simply said the market needed a timeout after rising nearly 7 percent this month as of yesterday's intraday high. Many said the drop was healthy and still left the Dow up 4.8 percent on the year.
"It was time for this," said Charles Pradilla, a market strategist at Cowen & Company. "Bonds sold off and the market was extremely overextended. You don't expect the market to keep going to new highs with lackluster interest rates."
Elaine Garzarelli, an independent market analyst who was formerly a leading strategist for Lehman Brothers, was reported during the day to have turned bullish on the market. After prices turned down in the afternoon, some analysts suggested that her reversal might have contributed to the drop, noting that she had turned bearish last July 18 -- as it happened, the day stock prices bottomed after a summer decline and then began another record run. Her office would not comment.
But while the selloff was sudden, some analysts said that yesterday's reversal was nothing to worry about.
"It's just a timeout, not a top-out," Mr. Goldman at A. G. Edwards said. "The fundamental and technical underpinnings are still positive. It's still a bull market and its going higher."
Although such technology stocks as Microsoft and Intel made strong gains early in the day as the Nasdaq continued to outpace the Dow, the fortunes of these and other computer and technology companies were reversed late in the day. Microsoft lost 2 5/8, to 94 3/4, and Intel lost 3/8, to 151 3/4.
Better-than-expected earnings reports from United Technologies and McDonald's also helped lift the Dow early. United Technologies rose 3 1/8, to 69 5/8, and McDonald's was up 1 1/4, to 46 1/2. I.B.M. also rallied early in the day after sharp losses on Wednesday that pulled the Dow down. But later it turned down, with a loss of 6 1/4, to 151 3/4. In the last two days, shares of I.B.M. have lost nearly 10 percent.
The Dow hit its high for the day of 6,906 around 2 P.M. Then as it began to decline, the fall was accelerated by the first of three computer-aided sell programs at 2:30. The last computer selling went from 3:37 to 3:57, dropping the Dow by 88 points, according to Birinyi Associates.
"The market was overbought," said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "It's been on a vertical rise all year. A key reversal on the downside brought in all the nervous people."
David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said, "I am at a loss to say why the market dropped, but I have been at a loss to say why it was going up every day."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 685.1 million shares, surpassing the previous high of 680.9 million last July 16. Of the top 10 volume days on the exchange, five took place this year.

HEADLINE: Administration Won't Merge Programs Promoting Exports

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration decided today that the three Government agencies that play a major role in financing American exports abroad should not be merged, concluding that while the current system was fragmented and awkward, the political costs of reorganization were too high.
The decision came at a White House meeting of the National Economic Council, which coordinates major economic decisions for President Clinton much as the National Security Council reviews foreign policy decisions. While the decision before the council was a narrow one, it signaled that the Administration was in no hurry to heed calls from business leaders and a number of current and former Government officials that the system of programs to promote and finance exports needed a major overhaul. 
 The Office of Management and Budget has recommended merging the Export-Import Bank of the United States, which provides low-cost financing for American exporters; the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which provides political-risk insurance to companies trading or investing overseas; and the Trade and Development Agency, which develops feasibility studies of overseas markets for exports and investment in emerging markets. All three need to be reauthorized by Congress this year.
In private, even many of the advocates of those programs concede that they are badly organized, largely because they were created one at a time by Congress, often with intersecting or conflicting charters. For example, the investment corporation is barred from operating in China, under legislation passed after the bloody suppression of protesters in Tiananmen Square in 1989. But the other agencies are free to operate there. But supporters do not see a better way, yet.
"If we were starting from scratch, we certainly wouldn't organize it this way," one senior Administration official deeply involved in the debate said after today's meeting. "But the energy and time that would be consumed by reorganizing was judged not to be worth the benefits."
The reauthorization seems almost certain to reopen a long-simmering argument between the Administration and the Republican majority in Congress over whether these agencies sustain jobs in the United States -- as the Administration argues -- or whether they are a form of "corporate welfare." Next week a coalition of forces led by Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who heads the Budget Committee, plans to release a list of Government programs for industry that it wants to eliminate or vastly cut back.
The list seems likely to include subsidies provided by the Agriculture Department to help food exporters, and the Rural Utility Service, which subsidizes electric power in rural areas. Mr. Kasich's group also wants to reduce the contribution from the United States to the International Monetary Fund, at a time when Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is insisting that that contribution must be bolstered.
The Overseas Private Investment Corporation has long been on Mr. Kasich's hit-list. Last year he nearly succeeded in eliminating its budget.
Ruth Harkin, who heads the agency and is the wife of Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, defended the Administration's position.
"This is about two different philosophies of what the Government should be doing," she said. "We believe that what is critical here is how to maintain and create American jobs through exports."
Almost every one of the nations with which the United States competes -- including members of the European Union and Japan -- also help exporters by offering financing or insurance. As a result, advocates of those programs here say that to eliminate them would be tantamount to unilateral disarmament, giving America's economic competitors a major advantage.
