HEADLINE: F.B.I. Agent Runs a Brooklyn Club to Snare a Mafia Outfit

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
From the outside, the Portofino Soccer Club in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn was just another nondescript social club. But inside, the authorities say, it was the rendezvous for a select gathering of men who arranged million-dollar business deals for products like dresses from Donna Karan and Liz Claiborne, exercise machines, computers, video-cassette recorders, television sets, cigarettes and featherbeds.
Sitting on the dilapidated white couches of the club, the men, many of them Mafia members or associates, sipped their coffee and quietly disposed of $6 million worth of stolen merchandise in the last two years. But unbeknown to them, the Portofino was the centerpiece of a sting operation that ended yesterday in the racketeering indictments of 47 men, including Nicholas Corozzo, the reputed new boss of the Gambino crime family. 
 Federal Bureau of Investigation officials, who said they captured all the deal-making on videotape, said the sting operation offers a window on an underground economic network that moves millions of dollars of hijacked goods into seemingly legitimate stores.
"The great majority of business people know that when they get cut-rate prices for dresses, computers and big items, that it is hot goods," said James K. Kallstrom, the F.B.I. official in charge of the New York office. "The smaller items, like perfume and watches, are part of the underground economy, people selling it on street corners."
Zachary W. Carter, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York State, whose office will prosecute the defendants, said the case should serve as "a wake-up call, because it shows how pervasive organized crime remains in the theft of interstate commerce."
F.B.I. officials said that an agent posing as an accomplished fence infiltrated the Gambino organization and was authorized by mobsters to open the social club.
It was only the second time, officials said, that an F.B.I. agent had penetrated the inner sanctum of a Mafia faction. The only previously known infiltration occurred from 1976 to 1981, when Joseph Pistone, an agent pretending to be a jewel thief, wormed his way into the operations of the Bonanno crime family.
Mr. Kallstrom declined to identify the agent who ran the club, except to say that he had been with the F.B.I. for more than 20 years. "To make your bones with a mobster, an undercover agent has to be a fabulous actor and think quick," he said.
"Making your bones" is an expression for performing deeds, usually illegal, that allow a criminal to be accepted into a Mafia family or mob-sanctioned place. Mr. Kallstrom emphasized that the agent and a cooperating witness who helped him had not committed any illegal acts.
Investigators say thieves and hijackers use many systems for fencing their loot, depending on the marketability of the stolen products and the relationships they have established with fences. Some fences deal only in specific items, like jewelry, liquor or women's clothes, because they have created illicit channels for selling such merchandise to established wholesalers or merchants.
Other fences are known for accepting almost all kinds of merchandise. If these fences are unable to peddle goods illicitly, they sell them to street hawkers.
Thieves usually get 10 percent of the wholesale value of the stolen goods, with fences getting another 10 to 20 percent, investigators say.
Law enforcement officials maintain that focusing on hijackers and major fencing operations is their most effective tactic in deterring crimes and disrupting the flow of stolen goods. They say it is impractical to investigate the thousands of merchants who might be on the receiving end of stolen property.
"Eventually," Mr. Kallstrom said, "the hijacked merchandise gets into the legitimate market, even though there are illegitimate gains for some business people who are as corrupt as the guys who hijacked the load."
Stephen M. Carbone, the head of the F.B.I.'s Hijacking Squad in the New York area, said that the investigation, known by the code name Second Gear, began four years ago, in an effort to disrupt Gambino hijacking operations. In addition to the New York area, the hijackings or thefts of trucks and their cargoes occurred in New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Virginia, officials said.
Investigators said that the cooperating witness, who also was not identified, had links to hijackers and Gambino associates. He introduced the undercover agent to mobsters as a figure who could fence substantial amounts of stolen goods.
After a year of ingratiating himself with the gangsters, the agent and the cooperating witness were granted permission by a Gambino faction known as the Canarsie crew, headed by Mr. Corozzo, to open the Portofino Club in a red brick building at 3516 Flatlands Avenue, near East 36th Street. The agent and the cooperating witness then leased a warehouse at 5803 Avenue J, near East 58th Street in Canarsie.
Mr. Kallstrom said that although the F.B.I. used concealed cameras to tape the discussions in the Portofino, none of the hijackings were planned there. The thieves came to the club to make deals for the disposal of the property. The thieves then delivered the property to a warehouse, where the deliveries were taped.
The stolen goods were later traced to their rightful owners, and Mr. Kallstrom said all the recovered property would be returned.
Investigators said that the clubhouse conversations implicated Mr. Corozzo; his top Mafia aide, Leonard DiMaria, and six other members and associates of his crew in a host of crimes, including loan sharking, extortion and illegal bookmaking. Yesterday's racketeering indictment was the second in a month for the 56-year-old Mr. Corozzo, who investigators say recently assumed control of the Gambino family, one of the nation's most powerful Mafia groups.
Mr. Corozzo, law enforcement officials say, replaced John Gotti, who is serving a life term in prison. Mr. Corozzo, who was arrested in December in Miami on separate Federal racketeering charges, is being held without bail in Florida.
Asked if Mr. Corozzo's indictments might cause realignments in the Gambino family and aid Mr. Gotti's son, John Jr., who investigators say has ambitions to become the Gambino boss, Mr. Kallstrom replied, "He might be happy about this."

HEADLINE: Was It His Career, or Theirs?;
A Corporate Wife Holds Out for a 50-50 Split of Assets

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
He works at full throttle. She raises the children and creates the elegant home. She plays hostess at business dinner parties, orchestrates charity events, relocates on command, accompanies him on trips and listens to his office woes. She is the corporate wife, and her career, she believes, is managing her husband's career.
But how much is her contribution worth? A divorce case in Connecticut involving a General Electric executive worth as much as $100 million puts a fresh spin on that question -- and, in the process, is rattling the corporate elite. Its resolution, many people say, will be a verdict on the institution of marriage itself and on the value of the supportive duties traditionally known as "women's work." 
 The plaintiff, Lorna J. Wendt, turned down a $10 million settlement from her husband of 31 years, Gary C. Wendt, the chief executive of GE Capital. Invoking economic theory, she is arguing that her performance as a corporate wife was an investment, entitling her to half the family fortune.
"Gary wanted to buy out my partnership, and I didn't want to be bought out," she said, using language she learned in her role. "It's like a hostile takeover -- he offered me a very small percentage, and I said that's not the price of the buyout."
The case breaks new ground because in divorce, too, the rich are different. While a 50-50 settlement is common practice for ordinary people -- indeed, the law in 11 community property states -- American courts elsewhere generally balk at awarding the wife half when an estate is worth more than $10 million or $15 million. The wife is awarded what she needs to live in the style to which the pair had become accustomed.
There is little wonder why the executive set is following the Wendt case closely: As executive pay and stock option awards have ballooned in recent years, a growing number of top managers -- particularly those in high technology, on Wall Street, and in the media/entertainment world -- have substantial assets at risk.
Most divorce cases, whether the couple are wealthy or not, are settled out of court. So Mrs. Wendt's persistence is unusual. But Mr. Wendt will not quit, either. "She was not responsible for my success," he said. "This is about who created and preserved the assets. "
Since reports of the Wendt case first arose last month, it has sparked heated conversations at dinner parties, in bars, on commuter trains and in corporate corridors all over the country. Mrs. Wendt, who is 53, said she was getting calls and letters of encouragement from many women. Mr. Wendt, who is 54, can also brandish a batch of support letters from both men and women.
"The important public policy issue here is: What is the nature of the marital partnership," said Martha A. Fineman, a Columbia University law professor who testified for Mrs. Wendt. "Is it an equal partnership or is a housewife a junior partner?"
A decision against Mrs. Wendt, Ms. Fineman said, "would say that our historically typical contributions to marriage are not valued, and that women are not full partners unless we are equal wage earners." The message, women say, would be clear: Why stay home?
Wendt v. Wendt, unfolding in State Superior Court in Stamford before Judge Kevin Tierney, is scheduled to be back in session on Tuesday, with his ruling expected by early spring.
Any judgment in the case that diminishes the wife would be coming at an odd time. For the last few years, politicians and pundits have preached family values, putting renewed emphasis on the importance of child-rearing and other traditional female roles. Last fall, the movie "First Wives Club" -- in which three women triumph over ex-husbands who trade them in for younger models -- hit a nerve among women who believe that for all their advances toward equality they remain losers in the gender wars.
Still, interviews with more than three dozen people, most of whom travel in circles like the Wendts', show that their dispute is hardly an open-and-shut case. Not all the women side with Mrs. Wendt, and not all men concur with her husband.
Many -- women and men alike -- buy Mr. Wendt's argument that his singular financial genius as head of GE Capital, which contributes more of General Electric's profits than any other division, created the wealth, not joint efforts with his wife.
But not one of the men who thought Mrs. Wendt deserved half would speak for the record. And several prominent men who have gone through or are getting a divorce -- including Henry R. Kravis, the buyout specialist, John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, and Robert Pittman, chief executive of AOL Networks -- declined through their spokesmen to comment at all.
Other people resist the notion that the wife has a lesser role, insisting that marriage is an equal partnership, for better or for worse.
"If her work is her husband's career, of course she should get half," said Toni K. Goodale, whose Manhattan-based firm counsels nonprofit organizations. "Some women have devoted their lives to furthering their husband's career -- just go up to Greenwich and you'll see them."
Ellen Schwartzman, whose ex-husband, Stephen, is a well-known investment banker, agreed. "I'm not saying that all women deserve half," she said. "There are women who don't even know what their husbands do. But where the career was a joint effort, the wife is entitled to half."
Sentiments are equally strong at the other end of the spectrum. "I know what it takes to develop a business and to run a business, and I think that has a value over and above the supportive relationship," argued Harriet Weintraub, a partner in Loving & Weintraub, a marketing and communications firm in Manhattan.
Her view was in sync with a top Chicago real estate agent who feared losing business if she allowed her name to be used. "I see an awful lot of women having a very nice time," she said. "What they do doesn't seem very extraordinary."
Many people have mixed feelings. "I think a woman who worked hard is entitled to a fair split, but I don't know if it is 50-50," said John Gutfreund, the twice-married former chairman of Salomon Inc., the Wall Street firm. "But what she needs to live on is not the way to resolve this."
And others dispute the notion that an estate's size should be a consideration. "It's like being a little bit pregnant -- if it's right at $2 million, it's right at $200 million," said one twice-divorced female financial adviser who insisted on anonymity. "How can we take half away from a guy who works on the assembly line and not from a guy who is worth so much more?"
But some courts do. Most states -- like Connecticut -- instruct judges to divide the spoils in an "equitable distribution." Many start with the presumption of an equal split, but then consider how long the two were married, what each needs to live on and who contributed what to the pot, among other things.
"I know of no cases where a wife has gotten 50 percent of the assets when they are of such substantial nature," said Robert Epstein, Mr. Wendt's lawyer. "If you believe that what she did was equal to his contribution, then you believe in the tooth fairy. We don't deny that she acted like a corporate wife, but we say that contribution was de minimus."
That such a debate is taking place reflects the surprising endurance of what seems an anachronism. After more than 35 years of the women's movement, corporate wives may be scarcer now but they are hardly an endangered species.
"There is enormous pressure in top jobs, and C.E.O.'s don't want to reveal their vulnerabilities to their boards or to their second-level managers," said Gerard R. Roche, a top executive recruiter. "They're really alone, and it's awfully good to come home to a real partner.
"The most successful executives lead totally integrated lives. They have corporate breakfasts, corporate vacations, corporate weddings. The total integration is seamless, and the wife can be very important."
Ms. Goodale bears witness to that. "The corporate wives I know can't have lives of their own," she said. "They are entertaining for him, going on trips with him, making friends with the wives of his associates. They're his sales department and his entertainment department."
The Wendts fit much of that description, according to their depositions and testimony so far. High school sweethearts in tiny Rio, Wis., they married in 1965, after college but before either had visions of striking it rich -- and long before the age of prenuptial agreements.
First stop: Harvard Business School, where Mr. Wendt earned an M.B.A., while Mrs. Wendt worked as a public school music teacher. He then worked in real estate in Texas, Georgia and Florida before moving in 1975 to GE Capital, where he became chief executive 11 years later.
All along, according to court documents, Mrs. Wendt ran the home, raised their two daughters and supported his career, mostly by entertaining.
"Here we have a case where two people have invested in a single career," said Myra Strober, an economist at Stanford University who testified on behalf of Mrs. Wendt. "The investments were different in kind, but these two people made equal sacrifices and therefore should get equal rewards."
Ms. Strober invoked the human capital theory of Gary Becker, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, who believes that investments in humans, like those in machines or buildings, pay a return over their lives. Mrs. Wendt, Ms. Strober argued, contributed to Mr. Wendt's career throughout their marriage and is entitled to her share of the assets -- even the stock options, deferred compensation and pension benefits -- accrued during the marriage.
Many economists, including Mr. Becker, agree that the activities of a corporate wife have a value. "The fact that the wife makes a significant contribution to his earnings is absolutely right," Mr. Becker said. "The hard part is to know what share it should be."
For a start, the Wendts do not agree on how much there is to divvy up. Mrs. Wendt's experts say the tally is about $100 million. But Mr. Wendt, in a telephone interview, said "the amount is about $25 million," an assertion that his expert witnesses will support. In that light, he contended, his settlement offer is generous.
The offer, according to Mr. Epstein, includes $4 million in real estate, $5 million in cash and $250,000 a year in alimony for life. "Such a settlement puts Mrs. Wendt in the 'Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous' category," Mr. Epstein said.
But Mrs. Wendt countered: "This is not about need. I can get along on $10 million, but why should he get $90 million? I entered into this marriage as a partner. I don't know when he decided that it was not a partnership."
All of which puts Judge Tierney in the hot seat, with many people watching his decision -- not least Dennis D. Dammerman, G.E.'s chief financial officer, and his wife, Patricia, who are in the early stages of a split as well.
But Mr. Epstein is confident. Referring to Mrs. Wendt's expert witnesses, he said, "There is nothing in our law yet that talks about a partnership or equal distribution. Some women want that, and I won't comment on whether that's the wave of the future. But I told Ms. Fineman that she should make her case to the legislature."

HEADLINE: New Bricks, Same Old Walls For Europe's Poor Nations

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Svetlana Raykova should represent the hope for the future of this shattered country. As generations of her family have done before her, she would like to marry and settle down here.
But years of Communist misrule have left the economy in ruins. Hundreds of thousands have fled. For the past two weeks, protesters have filled the streets. And Ms. Raykova now has doubts. From time to time, she thinks of leaving. 
 "I like my country and its traditions," said Ms. Raykova, 23, a language student at Sofia University, as she sat in her parents' cramped apartment, where she helps make ends meet by giving English lessons. "But the Government and the economic situation often make it impossible to see why I should stay."
Susan Langi, on the other hand, likes what she sees of her future in Hungary. A law student with fluent English and friends in the United States whom she met during visits there, Ms. Langi, 27, has a multitude of career opportunities at home and abroad. But because Budapest has blossomed, she has decided that she will stay and go into banking.
With fading memories of the jubilation at the collapse of Communism seven years ago, there is a new divide -- some call it the latter-day iron curtain -- between have and have-not nations of Central and Eastern Europe. Only in the former does the joy remain.
Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, more prosperous and stable, are cruising toward Western Europe, while much poorer Bulgaria, Romania and Albania languish in the doldrums. For the former, entrance into NATO and the European Union is a matter of when, not if. For the latter, a legacy of Communist rule and a reluctance to undertake market reforms have left faltering economies awash in corruption.
Czechs, Poles and Hungarians are sanguine about their countries' membership in the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, the prestigious club of industrialized nations.
But for citizens of Bulgaria, Romania and Albania, even those lucky enough to have reliable incomes find themselves barred from visiting Western Europe because their countries are on the European Union's "negative visa" list, along with Zambia and Afghanistan.
A New York University historian, Tony Judt, writing about this new European division in his recent book "A Grand Illusion? An Essay on Europe," predicted that the European Union, motivated in part by sentiment, would probably extend its "protective arm" around the old centers of the Hapsburg empire: Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and perhaps Slovenia.
Influenced by Western ideas and religion, and by the experience of pre-World War II capitalism, these countries have been the better students of reform. They have been protected from their worst nationalist instincts, their leaders assert, by the lure of Europe and the promise made in the early 1990's that they could join NATO if they met certain economic and democratic standards.
These countries alone will scrape into the fold of Europe, Mr. Judt said. Thus, there will develop "a sort of depressed Euro-suburb beyond which 'Byzantine Europe' would be made to fend for itself, too close to Russia and Russian interests for it to be prudent for the West to make an aggressive show of absorption and engagement."
The disparity between the halves is reflected in American aid policy.
In June, the United States Agency for International Development will pull out of the Czech Republic, its mission completed and its presence in the more mature economy and democratic political scene no longer needed, said Thomas Dine, the agency's director for the region. The agency plans to leave Poland and Hungary next year but remain in the poorer parts of Eastern Europe.
"The have-nots are almost dysfunctional," said Mr. Dine, who recently returned from cutting the ribbon for an American-financed sewage plant in southern Bulgaria. "It is there in the southern tier that we can make a difference. We have a northern-tier strategy and a southern-tier strategy -- one to gradually pull out and the other to stay and help them set up the institutions they need."
The 1996 economic data show the division clearly. Foreign investment and rising buying power have transformed the larger cities of Hungary, the Czech Republic and Poland into places with many of the accouterments of the West: fast-food restaurants, self-service gas stations, Benetton stores and apartment complexes outfitted with satellite dishes.
More than $15 billion in foreign investment has poured into Hungary since 1990. In neighboring Romania, which has more than twice the people, only $2 billion has come in, and in Bulgaria, a paltry $700 million.
The average monthly wage in Poland is now well over $300, and people have access to adequate and cheap medical care. In chaotic Bulgaria, the average wage fell to $30 this month, and many hospitals lack even such basics as X-ray film. Inflation in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic declined last year; in Bulgaria and Romania it soared.
Many people in the West "thought all the countries in Eastern Europe started out equal in 1989," said Natalia Kaneva, 32, the director of a restaurant and property management company in Sofia. "But we didn't. We were all different. Sofia was nothing before World War II. The Czech Republic was one of the most industrialized countries in Europe. Budapest was a major capital."
Ms. Kaneva said she had stayed because she had fought bureaucracy, extortion and failing banks to help build a surviving business. She blames both the Socialist Government, made up of former Communists, and the previous Government of so-called anti-Communists for bringing Bulgaria to its knees.
"They're all the same," she said with disgust after delivering hot tea and sandwiches as an encouragement to anti-Government protesters.
Many of her friends, she said, are among the 300,000 to 500,000 people who have left Bulgaria in the last six years. The latest escape trick, she said, is to buy a ticket to a Caribbean country that does not require a visa -- like the Dominican Republic -- and then ask for asylum at a stopover in Western Europe.
But Western Europe, straining under its own unemployment, does not welcome visitors from Bulgaria, Romania or Albania, who they fear will turn into illegal immigrants. Nor does the United States.
In contrast, Czechs who apply at the American Embassy in Prague in the morning receive a visa that afternoon; later this year visa requirements for Czechs entering the United States are expected to be abolished, which will give them the same status as Western Europeans.
Albania was isolated for more than 40 years by the Stalinist Government of Enver Hoxha. Few saw it competing with the likes of Poland, where, for example, land was not collectivized, or with Hungary, where small businesses cropped up in the still-Communist 1980's. But even so, many Albanians have found it painful to learn that throwing off the yoke of Communism does not mean automatic entrance into Europe.
Donald Bala, a law student, had wanted to take his bride on a honeymoon across the Adriatic Sea to Italy last summer. Mr. Bala had more than enough money but was denied a two-week visa. "We're completely locked in," he lamented.
At times, Mr. Bala said, he looks with envy at the drug couriers who tool around Tirana, Albania's capital, in expensive cars bought in Switzerland with their illegal proceeds. With no raw materials and archaic equipment, Albania's few industries -- bicycles, steel, glass, cement -- have shut down. Many families keep going on illicit drug money, remittances from abroad and the interest from local pyramid schemes.
Several thousand protested in Tirana last Sunday after three of the smaller pyramid schemes collapsed and did not pay depositors their interest. The police beat a number of protesters, and the opposition promised to stage more rallies.
Romania's political and economic prospects have improved since November, when the former Communists were ousted. The new President, Emil Constantinescu, is campaigning to start membership negotiations with NATO this summer, at the same time as Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic.
But although the the French Government is taking the pleas seriously, Romania is unlikely to prevail, a Washington official said. "It would be a sure way to sink the chances of the other three countries who will be invited in," he added.

HEADLINE: Pilar Barbosa, 99, Puerto Rican Political Mentor, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Pilar Barbosa de Rosario, a revered Puerto Rican historian and political authority who served as teacher, mentor and mother confessor to generations of Puerto Rican politicians, scholars and intellectuals, died on Wednesday at a hospital near her home in San Juan. She was 99 and widely regarded as the conscience of the ruling New Progressive Party.
In a career in which, in 1921, she became the first woman to teach at the University of Puerto Rico and later established the departments of history and social studies there, Dr. Barbosa became such an authority on Puerto Rican political history, from the movement for autonomy from Spain in the late 19th century to the drive for statehood in the 20th, that she was named the commonwealth's official historian in 1993. 
 It was a further reflection of her standing that after her death Gov. Pedro Rossello decreed a three-day period of mourning and that half a dozen members of the Legislature formed an honor guard at her coffin during a wake on Wednesday night.
The only reason a state funeral was not planned was that Dr. Barbosa had asked for private ceremonies, and as virtually any political figure in Puerto Rico would attest, Dr. Barbosa's wishes had long been treated as commands.
Indeed, long after she retired in 1967, Dr. Barbosa remained an influential figure in Puerto Rican politics -- a gregarious and vivacious woman with such a magnetic personality and wide-ranging knowledge of political history and current events that students, politicians and government officials trooped to her door for her counsel and her company.
"It was an intellectual watering hole," said Gonzalo Cordova, a friend who began teaching history at the university the year she retired. "You didn't come to drink, but for the conversation."
To Kenneth McClintock, a 40-year-old member of the Puerto Rican Senate, her wealth of political and historical knowledge was understandable. "As she was growing up," he said, "history was made at her dining room table."
Her father, Jose Celso Barbosa, was the founder of the Puerto Rican statehood movement and the precursor of the New Progressive Party, which has continued to embrace his ideals -- as modified over the years, to be sure, by his daughter, who insisted that the party of statehood also commit itself to social justice.
This, too, was a tribute to the legacy of her father. He was a black man who was so outraged at being denied higher education by the Spanish that after graduating first in his class at the University of Michigan medical school in 1882 -- and even then allowed to practice in Puerto Rico only after the intervention of the American consul in San Juan -- that he became a leader of the autonomy movement.
Having found a measure of racial and civil justice in 19th-century America after the United States displaced the Spanish in 1898, he espoused statehood as the best way to guarantee similar rights in Puerto Rico.
As one of his 12 children, Dr. Barbosa, whose mother died when she was a toddler, inherited her father's intelligence and his ideals. When she began teaching at the University of Puerto Rico in 1921 she was still an undergraduate herself, and the university was little more than a teacher's college.
After graduating in 1924, she moved on to Clark University in Worcester, Mass., receiving a master's in 1925 and a doctorate the next year.
Over the next decades Dr. Barbosa researched and wrote numerous books, pamphlets and papers on Puerto Rican political history, some based on her father's papers.
Partly, perhaps, because she and her husband, Jose Ezequiel Rosario, an economics professor who died in 1963, had no children, Dr. Barbosa began receiving her students for informal consultations on Saturday afternoons.
The sessions, which began in the days she lived in a farmhouse on the outskirts of San Juan, were continued after she retired and moved to a condominium in the city's Santurce section, but with a difference.
Because she no longer had a teaching load to keep her busy during the week, her proteges took to calling on her any day of the week.
By the time many of them had risen to high positions in the government, Dr. Barbosa, who also maintained friendly relationships with members of other parties, had acquired so much influence that she operated almost as a political boss -- a boss who seemed so blind to her own power that she may not have realized that an off-hand criticism delivered in a private conversation would soon be altering party policy.
Dr. Barbosa is survived by a brother, Rafael Barbosa, of Carolina, P.R.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Texas Instruments Stock Rises on Plan to Sell Unit
Texas Instruments shares rose 11 percent on a bad day for many stocks. The company reported a quarterly loss but announced a deal to sell its money-losing notebook computer business to Acer of Taiwan.
Having already agreed to sell its military electronics division, the company was quick to note that its core chip-making business was bouncing back after a weak period. [Page D3.]

Kohlberg Kravis Plans Acquisition
In its first takeover since amassing a new $5.8 billion fund, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said it had agreed to buy control of Amphenol, a maker of electronic cables and connectors, for roughly $1.2 billion in cash. The deal represents a bet by the investment firm that cable TV companies will resume large purchases of coaxial cable, Amphenol's most important product. [D2.] 

Xerox to Sell 2 Businesses
Xerox said it would sell two units, one to General Electric and one to Andersen Consulting. Xerox also reported better-than-expected earnings, and its stock rose. [D6.]
 
Boeing and McDonnell Fall Shy
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, which Boeing plans to acquire, reported strong earnings, but they fell slightly short of Wall Street estimates, and both stocks slipped. [D2.]

Little Softness in Sears's Quarter
Strong sales of clothing and other goods and an increase in credit card revenue helped Sears's quarterly earnings rise 25 percent. The gain came even as many other retailers reported disappointing holiday sales. [D5.]
 
Delta's Profit Up; Southwest's Falls
Delta Air Lines said that its earnings increased 79 percent in the most recent quarter, but Southwest Airlines said its profits fell because of a rise in jet fuel prices. [D13.]
 
Second Base for Sony, in New York
Sony, already one of the most American of Japanese companies, said it planned to make New York City into a second headquarters to better supervise its sometimes troubled operations in the United States and to track American media and technology trends. [D5.]
 
Bond Yields Rise, but Only a Bit
Despite the big drop in stocks, bonds traded within a narrow range as the market absorbed a fresh debt supply. The yield on the 30-year Treasury rose to 6.86 percent from 6.82. [D13.]
 
Tokyo Stock Troubles Stir Doubt
Japan remains one of the richest countries, but the recent stock-market convulsions have fed the growing sentiment that the country has lost some of its economic dynamism. [A1.]
 
Swiss to Set Up Holocaust Fund
The Swiss Government, leading banks and businesses agreed to establish a memorial fund for Holocaust victims, after months of pressure from American Jewish groups. [A3.]
 
Florida Crops Damaged by Cold
A freeze last weekend caused heavy damage to winter vegetable and tropical fruit crops in Dade County, Fla., officials said. The damage could lead to steep price increases across the nation. [A20.]
 
Christie's in Talks on New Space
Christie's, the expanding auction house, is negotiating a consolidation of its warehouses, offices and auction houses in a new home at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan. [A1.]
 
Hut 1, Hut 2, Sell!
The New England Patriots are underdogs in the Super Bowl, according to the bookmakers and commentators. But they are favored by the stock market, based on observed -- and irrelevant -- historical correlations between market performance and Super Bowl results. If that forecast comes true, the market could be in for trouble. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]

With the Super Bowl matching two teams that have a relative paucity of star power, viewers will have to wait for the ads to see celebrities. And there will be plenty -- ads and celebrities, that is. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Court Says 2 Pataki Aides Can Be Forced to Testify

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 23

 BODY:
A New York State appellate court ruled today that the Democratic-controlled Assembly can compel two advisers to Gov. George E. Pataki to testify about the activities of two private corporations that raised more than $2.6 million for the Governor's inauguration and transition in 1995.
The ruling appears to clear the way for the Assembly to hold public hearings into the inaugural and transition funds with the two advisers, Charles A. Gargano and Lawrence Kalkstein, as major witnesses. The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, was not available today to say whether he planned to go forward with such hearings. 
 The Assembly had tried last year to force Mr. Gargano and Mr. Kalkstein to testify before three Assembly committees investigating whether the Governor had improperly used the two funds for political purposes. But lawyers for the two men succeeded in persuading Justice Joseph Harris of State Supreme Court to block those subpoenas. Today's decision partly overturns that lower court ruling.
But even as the Assembly Democrats were lauding the decision, lawyers for Mr. Gargano and Mr. Kalkstein were also proclaiming victory. They said that the Appellate Division had upheld their contention that the two men need not answer questions that might infringe on their First Amendment rights to freedom of speech and association.
The lawyers have contended throughout this case that the Assembly Democrats were trying to use their investigation to embarrass the Republican Governor and to intimidate his supporters. They said today that if hearings are held, they will order Mr. Gargano and Mr. Kalkstein not to answer any questions that seem political in nature -- which, they strongly suggested, would probably be all of them.
"What is the real purpose of this hearing?" said H. Neal Conolly, one of the lawyers. "It's to have a show so people can be paraded in front of reporters and they can ask questions that are to their advantage. It's a political show."
Mr. Gargano, who is now Commissioner of the State Department of Economic Development, was Mr. Pataki's chief campaign fund-raiser in 1994 and helped raise money for the inaugural and transition funds.
Mr. Kalkstein, an accountant, has been a consultant to Mr. Pataki's campaign committees for several years and was an officer of both corporations, N.Y. Inaugural '95, and N.Y. Transition '95.
The two corporations were formed in late 1994 to finance the Governor's lavish inauguration and transition. But after promising to abide by strict limits on contributions and to publicize the names of contributors, Mr. Pataki's aides failed to do either.
Only after the Assembly subpoenaed their records did the two corporations release information showing who contributed and how the money was spent.

HEADLINE: New York Police, Seeking Raises, Assail Mayor They Once Backed

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
In a choreographed expression of scorn for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, police officers by the scores marched outside every station house in the city yesterday afternoon in orderly though occasionally raucous protests against the Mayor's final proposal to improve their pay.
Clasping placards suggesting that the lives they risk for the city were undervalued, and at times chanting derisive slogans against the Mayor, whom they had once championed, the officers vowed to continue periodic picketing until they gained an acceptable resolution of their contract impasse. 
 Puffing steadily on a cigarette outside the Fifth Precinct station house in Chinatown, Officer Shawn Russell summed up the emotions of many of his fellow officers when he spoke in bitter language of the betrayal and humiliation he feels at the hands of the man he had venerated.
"I cannot understand why, after the job that we have done, he would insult us like this," he said of the Mayor's final contract offer to the police union. Once an unalloyed supporter of the Mayor and his law enforcement agenda, Officer Russell said, "I think Giuliani has a better chance of winning Lotto than of police officers backing him again."
Mayor Giuliani continued to defend his economic posture yesterday. "This is a very, very generous offer," he said. "You could question whether the city really has the room for this, but we did it because we wanted to show police officers that we do appreciate the tremendous work that they have done."
He accused the union leadership of nourishing false expectations for its membership. "What they've done is try to make it appear as if we could do things that are impossible to do," he said.
The officers' anger came to a crescendo over the last few days. On Tuesday, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which represents the city's 38,000 police officers, rejected the city's last contract offer, which calls for no pay raises in the first two years, then increases totaling 16 percent over the next three years. On Wednesday, Federal authorities charged top officials of the Transit Police Benevolent Association with taking bribes from lawyers it shared with the larger police union before the two unions merged in 1995.
James L. Lysaght, one of the lawyers charged in the indictment, is described as the principal shaper of the P.B.A.'s strategy in the current contract talks. Mayor Giuliani at once declared that the alleged crimes were a primary reason for the stalled negotiations.
Mr. Lysaght and the three other people charged in the indictment pleaded not guilty yesterday at their arraignment in United States District Court.
In the taut showdown between the police force and City Hall, underscored by the late-afternoon demonstrations, Officer Russell and many of his colleagues made it evident that they saw a multifaceted issue in simple terms.
He brushed aside the fact that the Mayor's offer was more generous than those accepted by other city unions. Police officers, he said, deserve better still. Don't talk to him about what teachers make: teachers dodge chalk and he dodges bullets.
He readily dismissed the fact that corruption charges had been filed against some of those bargaining for him as beside the point. To him, the point was a mathematical one: he was not paid enough.
He spoke of a fellow officer, one of the most admired in the precinct, who reluctantly left last month to join a force in Nassau County for a raise of $18,000 a year.
Throughout the city, officers on the beat yesterday spoke of a blanketing mood of gloom and bitter anger, one profound enough that some even suggested it was affecting the vigor with which they pursued criminals. Officer after officer said they felt that they had done what the Mayor asked of them in reducing crime, and then some, and now the Mayor had failed to reward officers adequately where they wanted it most -- in their paychecks.
In a demonstration of their discontent, half-hourlong protests were staged around 4 P.M. outside all 75 station houses to denounce the Mayor's actions. Clad in street clothes, officers marched while displaying signs proclaiming, "We are the lowest paid Cops in the state" and "How much is a Cop's life worth?"
For the most part, the protests were fairly restrained, yet they attracted thousands of officers.
Chanting "Zero percent can't pay the rent," "Rudy must go" and "Rudy's a liar, set him on fire," about 75 officers marched before the 71st Precinct in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in one of the more boisterous protests. Passing motorists honked in support, and even prisoners in a Correction Department bus offered upraised thumbs and banged on the barred windows to support those who had arrested them.
Some 75 officers protested outside the 103d Precinct in Jamaica, Queens, where Officer Vinny Esposito introduced himself as, "Police Officer Underpaid."
Another 70 officers joined the protest outside the 30th Precinct in upper Manhattan, accompanied by 30 transit officers. Officer Joe Strong, a union delegate, teetered astride the legs of two police barricades and declared, "We will show the Mayor. We will not be defeated." Later, he said, "Mayor Giuliani, we give you heroes, you give us zeroes."
Officers yesterday were hesitant to point any fingers at the union. Most scoffed that the irregularities transpired at the transit union, not theirs. Others preferred to await more conclusive developments. "They can indict a salami," one officer in downtown Brooklyn said. "Let them prove the charges."
Raymond Byrne, a detective at the 48th Precinct in the Bronx, shrugged off the news: "Like any other union, it's human nature. You're always going to have people who are corrupt, who take advantage and steal."
A number of officers seized on the indictments as another reason to heap scorn on the Mayor. "The day before we're going to picket, he grabs the headlines with the indictments," said Officer J. P. Perez of the 84th Precinct in downtown Brooklyn. "I think the timing was deliberate."
It was the sullen mood in the station houses and patrol cars that dominated the talk of the officers. "It's gotten to where we say, 'Why risk your life if you're not getting anything out of it,' " said Aaron Jackson, a 30-year-old officer in the Seventh Precinct on the Lower East Side. "It's definitely affecting people in their jobs. Why go out and make arrests and be a cop if you can't make a living? Cops are only making arrests if they have to."
While other officers echoed Officer Jackson's appraisal, many others insisted that their job performance had not yet been dulled in any way by their sour mood.
Like many police officers, Officer Perez linked his anger to his economic anxiety. He is a single parent of three children who earns about $46,000 a year, appreciably below the pay of suburban officers. "I can tell you my kids have not eaten steak in three years," he said. "If this contract is passed, I'd have to sell my house." He said he lived in Nassau County but would not be specific.
Officers at the 71st Precinct in Crown Heights were circulating a flier that said, "N.Y.C. Needs Competitive Pay Raises." Beneath the lettering was a picture of an officer shaking hands with a man on the street and inquiring about his profession. The man replies, "I redeem old soda bottles. I was going to become a cop, but I couldn't afford the pay cut."
Officers were especially bitter over the fact that the drop in crime they have produced will serve as the centerpiece of the Mayor's re-election bid. "He sits at a desk over in City Hall taking full credit for what the police officers have done," said Officer Perez. "I've been 17 years on the force and never once did I see Mayor Giuliani in the back of my patrol car making an arrest."
Officer Ronald Fagan of the 84th Precinct said he and his wife had been reluctant to start a family because of his pay. "I can't imagine what would happen if my wife had to stop working," he said.
The simmering anger against a Mayor who was championed by the police rank and file when he was elected has left relations between the police and the Mayor as acrimonious, if not more so, than they were between the officers and the Mayor's predecessor, David N. Dinkins.
A few officers went so far as to declare that their anger against Mayor Giuliani was worse than it had been for Mr. Dinkins. In one police union office, a sign on the wall read, "Re-elect David Dinkins."
The police had any number of spats with Mr. Dinkins. They reached their boiling point in July 1992, when Mr. Dinkins rushed to console the family of Jose (Kiko) Garcia, a drug suspect shot to death by a police officer during a scuffle in Washington Heights. Even as Mr. Dinkins repeatedly insisted that his motive was to quiet the outbreak of violence triggered by the shooting, not to take sides, the police never forgave him.
Many police officers yesterday brought up the Garcia episode as the moment when their self-esteem hit bottom. They spoke of how they had steadily regained pride in what they do, as they have been embraced by Mayor Giuliani and have seen crime sink sharply. But at a time when they have begun to feel so good, they said that they were again dispirited by the contract impasse.
"We're feeling like we've won the world championship at the same time that we've gotten knocked out," Officer Russell said.

HEADLINE: Switzerland and Banks Agree to a Fund for Holocaust Victims

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BERN, Jan. 23

 BODY:
After months of pressure from American Jewish groups, the Swiss Government, leading banks and businesses agreed today to establish a memorial fund for Holocaust victims in what a senior official called "the humanitarian traditions of Switzerland."
The Government left open the question of whether it would contribute to the fund and officials said many key issues remain open to negotiation. It remained unclear who would contribute, who would be eligible for payments and on what legal basis the fund would operate. 
 Switzerland, which was neutral during World War II, has until now resisted the idea of helping in the creation of a compensation fund, saying such a step could be taken as an admission of guilt for wartime misdeeds. They have insisted that a historical inquiry precede any talk of payments.
Swiss officials portrayed the decision, announced in a statement after tonight's meeting of the cabinet, as a breakthrough.
"This is a major step," said Thomas Borer, a Swiss diplomat who leads a Government task force created to deal with the controversy over wartime gold transactions between Swiss banks and Nazi Germany and its handling of dormant bank accounts set up by Jews who subsequently perished in the Holocaust.
American Jewish groups who have been pressing Switzerland to set up a fund to help families of Holocaust victims said the Swiss Government's policy shift "appears to suggest that they are moving rapidly towards the establishment of a Holocaust fund."
Elan Steinberg, a spokesman for the World Jewish Congress in New York, which has taken the lead in pressing Switzerland to create such a fund, said, however, that the organization remained cautious. Mr. Steinberg said that after a year of negotiation and confrontation with Swiss officials "not one franc of restitution has been paid."
The change in Swiss policy seemed to indicate that the authorities here had come round to sharing the view of some of the country's main banks that a political gesture was required to defuse a stubborn crisis that could damage the Swiss banking industry and the economy as a whole.
Yesterday, however, Rainer Gut, head of Credit Suisse, the country's second largest bank, urged the rapid creation of what he termed a "well-endowed" fund in excess of $70 million, to be financed in equal parts by commerical banks, the Swiss National Bank and the Government.
Today's Government statement said the authorities "welcomed the readiness of some banking circles to take a rapid step in this direction."
The Swiss Government made a previous offer to negotiate a fund on Jan. 7, but, at that time, said it was prepared only for the fund to be drawn from dormant accounts discovered in Swiss banks after World War II, an idea that was rejected immediately by many Jewish organizations. Switzerland says some $29 million has been found in dormant acocunts, but maintains that only a small proportion of the money was deposited by Holocaust victims.
At issue are three aspects of Switzerland's relationship with Nazi Germany for which Jewish groups are seeking restitution. One is a well-documented trade in gold that enabled Nazi Germany to finance part of its war effort with gold it looted from conquered lands. Last December, the Swiss National Bank acknowledged making a profit of around 20 million Swiss francs, or about $5 million at wartime exchange rates, on those deals. Some accounts put the profit levels higher.
A second issue that has arisen recently is Switzerland's treatment of Jewish refugees, some 30,000 of whom were turned back at the Swiss frontier as they sought to flee Nazi Germany. Swiss historians say the wartime Swiss government refused to pay for the upkeep of the Jewish refugees, obliging American and Swiss Jews to spend some 55 million francs, or nearly $14 million, to support them.
The third issue is the fate of the bank accounts, insurance policies and other wealth deposited in Switzerland by German Jews who subsequently perished in the Holocaust.
In response to pressure from American Jewish groups and politicians, the Swiss authorities have agreed to two inquiries. One, under the chairmanship of Paul Volcker, former head of the United States Federal Reserve, is a joint Swiss-Jewish inquiry into the dormant accounts. The other is a panel of Swiss and non-Swiss historians charged with investigating the whole gamut of Switzerland's dealings with Nazi Germany.
Mr. Borer, the leader of the Swiss inquiry, met in Zurich today with representatives of commercial banks, the National Bank, insurance companies and other business interests shortly after the Government issued its statement in Bern.
At a news conference, Mr. Borer said the the significance of today's developments lay in the fact that, while the Government had previously "never expressed itself on a fund," it was now ready to "take the lead" in setting one up.
Mr. Borer said a "broad outline" of the fund would be ready "in a few weeks," but he declined to speculate about its likely size..
A key issue remains who will contribute. In its statement in Bern today, the Swiss coalition Government said that "a decision on the appropriate participation of the Government in the financing of a fund will be made when the hard, historical facts are presented."

HEADLINE: Spring, That Tease, Drops By, but Only for a Day

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Winter still has eight weeks to go, but spring slipped in early yesterday to remind people of its virtues, and for a few hours, its rites were evident everywhere in the region.
With the temperature hitting 54 degrees at Kennedy International Airport, William Smythe, a carpenter, eased his 24-foot cabin cruiser into the choppy but ice-free waters of Oyster Bay to test the depth finder his wife had bought him for Christmas. And Martin Schwartz, a retired druggist, tried nudging a golf ball across a thawing patch of brown grass. 
 "I just wanted to work on my putting," he said. "The ground is a little soggy, but who cares? It's sunny. It's warm. It's a perfect day for golf."
The roller-coaster ride is far from over. Temperatures dropped into the night, reaching 28 degrees at midnight, and chilly weather is expected today. Warmer weather will return on Saturday, with some rain.
But with yesterday's balmy weather, people took advantage of the mercurial character of this winter season, walking more slowly, jogging and cycling, pausing for sunshine, wearing windbreakers and denim jackets or no jackets at all. When they stopped to talk, New Yorkers asked each other if they could remember a season when temperatures fluctuated so wildly between the polar chill of the weekend and yesterday's almost sultry warmth. Many also wondered how we went from 75.6 inches of snow in Central Park last season to 5 inches so far in this one.
During lunch hour in Manhattan's Bryant Park, hundreds of office workers occupied the benches and many shed their winter coats and woolen caps. One of them, Rosemarie Censullo, said: "I love it because I'm not a cold-weather person to begin with. This is the first time I've been in the park since it went below 30 degrees. I guess that's been at least weeks."
Still, with the memory of last weekend's subzero temperatures, Ms. Censullo clung to her winter dining regimen, enjoying a bowl of steaming chicken chili.
One dissident from the general air of approval was a man walking his dog near the beach in Westport, Conn. "I hate going from it being like the Antarctic to being like Miami Beach so quickly," he said. "It's a good way to get good and sick."
To those curious about weather fluctuations that took the New York area from 0 to 54 degrees in the Porsche-like acceleration of five days, Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at Penn State University, blamed it on a shift in the storm track.
"Weather behaves differently from year to year," he said.
Last year, the predominant storm track passed to the south and east of New York, leaving New York at the mercy of the colder northern winds circulating within the track, Mr. Gadomski said. This year, the dominant track has been to the north, bringing warmer southern winds to New York. But since winds circulate in a counterclockwise direction, New York has occasionally been getting a whiff of the chilly air of Canada, and that accounts for last weekend's shivery temperatures.
In terms of snowfall, this season is less an aberration than last. New York, Mr. Gadomski said, has often had virtually snowless winters, the last one in 1992, when only nine-tenths of an inch had fallen by Jan. 23.
The warm winter has been salutary for many sectors of the region's economy, particularly construction. Although construction activity can fall 20 to 25 percent in punishing winters, this season there has been no decrease, said Edward J. Malloy, president of the Building Construction Trades Council, the umbrella group for the city's 100,000 unionized construction workers.
Some farmers said they were largely unconcerned about the fluctuations in temperature.
"The weather at this time of year really doesn't affect us too much," said Robert H. Gammon of Woodside Farm, a fruit farm in Jamesport, L.I. "It takes an awfully long time for the sap to flow. If this warm weather persisted for a month, it might be something to worry about."
The lack of snow this year has not hurt the winter's pre-eminent sport, skiing, all that much. In the era of man-made snow, the important factor is temperature, not snowfall, and early January provided enough freezing days at resorts like Bellayre Mountain Ski Center in Highmount, N.Y., to spread nearly all trails with man-made snow.
Dick Clark, superintendent of Belleayre Mountain, said that business was off about 10 percent from last year's level, but that figure pleased him, given the steep decline in skiers during the Christmas season when above-freezing temperatures rendered snowmakers useless.
"A warm day like today doesn't set us back," he said. "Man-made snow is a lot more durable than natural snow."
What was best about yesterday's unseasonable warm spell was simply the promise it brought that spring may be around the corner. Outside Theodore Roosevelt Elementary School in Oyster Bay, L.I., Margaret Ryder and her shaggy dog watched children racing around the playground, laughing and shrieking.
"I walk my dog here every day and it's great to see the kids back out on the playground," said Ms. Ryder, who is a computer analyst. "It's been too cold and too quiet, and I've missed all that wonderful noise only kids can make."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Passes 120-Yen Mark, Then Drops in Broad Pullback

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar vaulted over the 120-yen barrier for the first time in nearly four years yesterday but then dropped, hurt by fear that Japan's central bank was selling dollars to defend the yen.
The dollar retreated against other major currencies on profit taking from the dollar's sharp rise over the last week and on news of higher inflation in Germany, which further dimmed hopes of lower German interest rates. 
 It was the first broad pullback in the dollar in more than a week. But traders said the currency was still likely to go higher on the basis of a stronger United States economy compared with weakness in Japan and much of Europe, the same forces driving the dollar up for the last several months.
"There are still plenty of buyers for the dollar," said John McCarthy, foreign-exchange manager at ING Capital Markets Inc. in New York. "I don't think anything's changed."
The dollar traded as high as 120.13 yen in intraday dealings, the strongest since mid-February 1993 and the sixth consecutive day that the dollar has hit a nearly four-year high. But its subsequent drop left the dollar at 119 yen in New York, down from 119.47 yen on Thursday.
The dollar also fell to 1.6284 marks, from 1.6366. The pound cost $1.6308, up from $1.6292.
Even with the pullback, the dollar still ended the week 2.7 percent higher against the yen and 5.6 percent higher against the mark.
Traders initially bid up the dollar against the yen in Asian trading after a senior Japanese economic official said the yen's weakness was not aggravating Japan's inflation rate. Shinpei Nukaya, a Vice Minister of the Economic Planning Agency, told reporters there was "no big demerit seen" from the yen's drop.
But when the dollar hit 120 yen, speculation swept the market that the Bank of Japan was selling dollars. Still, there was no firm indication that the Bank of Japan was in the market, and its officials declined to comment.
The dollar's retreat against the mark partly reflected news that inflation in three of western Germany's four biggest states accelerated unexpectedly last month, further dimming hopes for an interest-rate reduction in Germany.

HEADLINE: Treasury Securities Prices Are Sharply Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, as investors sold on concern that coming reports on the economy and wages would show faster growth and greater inflationary pressures.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 10/32 , to 955/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.88 percent, from 6.86 percent on Thursday. A week ago, the yield was 6.83 percent. Fears that new signs of strength in the economy would lead the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates, combined with concerns about the market's ability to absorb a flood of new debt issues, have kept investors uneasy. 
 "The past week in the market has been like trying to jog uphill with 200-pound weights tied to your waist," said Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of the government bond trading at Cowen & Company. With no new data yesterday, many buyers moved to the sidelines.
Mr. Gamba said that market participants were particularly concerned about the Labor Department's employment cost index report for the fourth quarter, which is due on Tuesday. The estimates are for a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent to 1 percent, which would rekindle investor fears of a rate increase, Mr. Gamba said, "probably sooner than later, since everyone already knows it's coming."
If the barrage of new government, corporate and municipal issues "does not continue to plague the market, than the barrage of economic data next week surely will," he said.
In corporate trading, Citicorp sold $450 million of 30-year capital securities yesterday through Citicorp Capital II at a price to yield 8.015 percent, or about 107 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- more than a Treasury bond due in 2026. They are rated A-1 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's.
Capital securities are debtlike trust preferred stock that do not add to the company's debt load and that issuers can also defer the cash distribution for up to five years.
In when-issued trading, the Treasury's new inflation-indexed notes being sold on Wednesday were offered at a price to yield 3.49 percent.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
There are two widespread impressions about the growth and decline of religious groups in this country, and both of them -- at least in their unqualified form -- are wrong.
One is the notion that groups adjusting quickly to contemporary ideas, groups that "modernize" or "update," are likely to thrive. 
 The other view is just the opposite: Groups that resist the spirit of the day, remaining faithful to the strict demands of that old-time religion, increase and prosper.
What both theories ignore is that flourishing religious groups are always marked by some mixture of cultural adaptation and cultural resistance.
The first theory is often taken for granted among people who know almost nothing about the current religious landscape. The second is popular among those who know something but perhaps not enough.
That something is the steady, in some cases spectacular, expansion of conservative church groups like the Southern Baptists, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints or the pentecostal Assemblies of God -- paralleled by the decline of more or less liberal denominations like the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A), the United Methodists and the United Church of Christ.
It may seem counterintuitive that churches demanding more should grow more, but analysts have come up with plausible explanations of why, psychologically, this should be so. Liberal religious scholars have attributed such growth to a human urge to flee from the chaos and ambiguity of recent social change. More popular recently have been explanations modeled on economics that see conservative religion as a paradoxical but rational preference despite its apparent "high cost."
According to those explanations, religious groups that insist on strict adherence in belief and conduct drive away the lukewarm -- in economic terms, the "free riders" who use the church mainly for weddings, funerals and seasonal uplift. Consequently, those willing to sacrifice get in return the positive experiences of filled pews, enthusiastic worship and the collective affirmation of otherworldly rewards as well as dependable this-worldly support.
As happens so often, such theories have been exaggerated and simplified. The religious equivalent of "no pain, no gain" gets translated into "the more pain, the more gain" -- an elementary error, as any coach or doctor could attest. When it comes to conservatism, in religion as in economics, there is apparently a point of diminishing returns -- the point where religious demands become so costly that people are driven away.
Last November, Benton Johnson, a sociologist of religion at the University of Oregon, recalled some of these complexities in an address to the Society for the Scientific Study of Religion and the Religious Research Association.
He based his remarks on studies he had made of theological and political polarization among the Oregon Protestant clergy from the early 1960's to the late 1980's, as well as on research done by others.
Professor Johnson noted the extent to which conservatives, just like liberals, have modified their public stances to accommodate changing culture, although without budging an inch on their basic theological views.
Whatever became of conservative strictures against card-playing, dancing, gambling, drinking and shopping on Sunday, for example?
In 1962, 92 percent of Oregon's Southern Baptist ministers reported preaching against dancing; by 1987, the figure was 13 percent. In 1962, over 80 percent of the state's Baptist pastors had preached against drinking; in 1987, the number had decreased to 24 percent among Conservative Baptists and 8 percent among American Baptists.
And though there are rudimentary conservative efforts to stiffen laws against gambling and divorce, these ministers prefer to occasionally preach against these evils without mobilizing against them politically.
"Despite the posture of militancy and holding the line on doctrinal issues, a process of quiet accommodation has been going on within many old evangelical denominations," Professor Johnson said. "As the culture changes, the conditions for church stability and church growth change."
Those conditions appear to include "a medium degree of tension with the surrounding culture," he said, but only a medium degree. When a changing culture poses new threats to established positions, "it would be demoralizing to oppose none of these threats; it would be too costly to oppose all of them." What gets overlooked, he said, are changes that have already embedded themselves within the membership of these conservative religious groups.
Divorce, for instance. Although in 1987 none of the Baptist pastors had been divorced since entering the ministry, a high percentage -- three-fourths of the Southern Baptist pastors, for example -- reported divorces in their immediate families. A development like that, Professor Johnson believes, has tempered conservatives' views on divorce.
When a church historian, Martin E. Marty, reported Professor Johnson's conclusions in the Jan. 15 issue of The Christian Century, he called such modification of religious principles "negotiating with modernity."
You can view this "negotiating with modernity" as hypocrisy or evidence of creeping compromise. Or you can take it as the moderation that comes with experience. You can argue that growing conservative religious groups have negotiated with modernity better than shrinking liberal ones. But, one way or another, everyone does it.

HEADLINE: Fedex Reinstates Pickups On Dark Streets of Gary

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., Jan. 24

 BODY:
Federal Express executives have decided that the darkened streets of Gary may not be so menacing, after all.
Severely stung by criticism after it decided on Jan. 16 to eliminate after-dark pickups in the city, Fedex, the largest overnight delivery company, has reversed course. After a boisterous meeting on Wednesday with Mayor Scott King, in which Mr. King threatened to organize a nationwide boycott of the company, the company agreed to return full service. 
 "I can't tell you what they did in the first place, how they came to this boneheaded idea to cut service," Mr. King said. "They embarrassed our city for no good reason, and we were not going to sit back and take it. There was never one bit of supporting evidence that they offered to substantiate their claims that it is not safe for their drivers to work in Gary."
A spokesman for Fedex, Greg Rossiter, said a regional manager made a temporary decision to limit collections from the 10 curbside pickup boxes in the city after the manager had received reports from drivers concerned for their safety.
One driver reportedly said he had seen a handgun being fired into the air. Another driver reported that he feared he was about to be robbed when another vehicle cut off his truck. Other drivers said they had been sent to deliver or pick up packages from abandoned buildings.
None of the incidents were reported to the police. Mr. Rossiter said the company left it to the drivers to notify the police.
Chief John Roby of the Police Department said the police had no reports involving mail or delivery workers filed since 1994.
"That in itself says a lot," Chief Roby said. "These people don't carry cash. They are not easy targets. We have never been contacted by them for any reason."
Mr. Rossiter said Fedex stood by the decision to schedule the final pickups at 4 P.M. instead of 6 P.M., adding that the drivers, most of whom live in or near Gary, had voiced legitimate concerns about their safety and that Fedex policy let managers change service schedules.
Mr. Rossiter said the company had assurances from Chief Roby "that we would be able to call upon the police if there are any future concerns about driver safety."
Chief Roby scoffed at that and said Fedex, like other businesses here, had always had the support of the police and would continue to receive "the same help we have always been ready to provide."
Mr. Rossiter would not say in what other regions Fedex had cut service.
Officials from two other companies, Airborne Express and United Parcel, said their companies never curtailed service for safety reasons, except in cases of mass civil unrest.
U.P.S. drivers who feel unsafe are reassigned to other routes, and a new driver and escort, often an off-duty or a retired police officer, take over that route, said a spokesman, Mark Dickens.
A spokesman for Airborne, Tom Branigan, would not discuss security details, but said Airborne immediately adopted preventive measures in areas that the company viewed as unsafe.
After reviewing the cutback, Fedex offered pickup service until 5 P.M. Mr. King quickly stopped the city from using Fedex and garnered support for a proposed boycott from the Greater Gary Chamber of Commerce and industrial leaders in northwestern Indiana.
"This was not an idle threat," said Thomas McDermott, president of the Northwest Indiana Forum, which includes United States Steel, Inland Steel, LTV and Amoco. "With a few phone calls and faxes we were prepared to put them in a very awkward position."
Discussions with members of the United States Conference of Mayors increased the leverage. The executive director of the conference, J. Thomas Cochran, said members were outraged over the cuts here, coming on the heels of news that Pizza Hut had refused delivery to a high school in Kansas City, Mo., because of safety concerns.
"We are of the opinion that was very unfair, for someone to wake up one morning and redline one particular area where people are paying for services," Mr. Cochran said. "The one thing mayors won't stand for is someone dictating where and when they will and won't service an area. It may start in Gary, and then spread like a cancer to places like New Orleans, Newark, anywhere there is a perception of things not being as they are in the suburbs."
For two years, this steel-mill city 30 minutes from downtown Chicago has had the dubious distinction of having the highest per capita murder rate, 107 murders last year, or 92 per 100,000 of the population, down from a total of 132 in 1995. It is home to 119,125 people, 80 percent of whom are black.
Despite the opening of two riverboat casinos last year, which added more than 2,000 jobs, Gary still has the highest unemployment rate in the state. Its boarded-up downtown is testament to the jobs and businesses that disappeared in the 80's with the collapse of the steel industry.
Mr. King is the first white mayor since 1968, and he has staked his political future on turning around Gary.
"The last thing we needed at this time was a black eye coming out of nowhere," the Mayor said in an interview today. "Hopefully we have all learned a bit from this experience."

HEADLINE: Albright Vows to Seek Support In U.S. for Clinton Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
At her first news conference on her first full day as Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright promised today to stay the course of President Clinton's foreign policy but to sell it better to Congress and the American people.
Speaking of her first trip as Secretary of State, Ms. Albright said she had "already taken it." It was to Capitol Hill, she said, and it will be followed by many more. 
 "The President is serious and I am serious about working with Congress on a bipartisan basis," she said.
She also said she would schedule more events around the country to explain the goals and budgetary needs of American foreign policy.
"We have a strong case to make," she said. "But we cannot expect that case to make itself."
She said her first trip abroad would be to allies in Europe and Asia, a deliberate effort to accent what she called "our most important task -- sustaining momentum toward the creation of a Europe that is united, stable and democratic, and an Asian-Pacific community that cooperates increasingly, based on shared economic interests and a common commitment to peace."
Ms. Albright made no clear departures from the goals of Mr. Clinton's first term.
She said again that "the overall relationship with China" was "multifaceted," with areas of cooperation as well as of sharp difference, like human rights, and "it cannot be held hostage to any one issue." But she added that "we have made it clear" to the Chinese "that what happens in Hong Kong is very important to the overall relationship."
A comprehensive peace in the Middle East is among her highest priorities, but she suggested that she would reserve her own travel and intervention there for later. Her staff is mindful that her predecessor, Warren Christopher, was criticized for spending too much time there.
Ms. Albright said flatly that political contributions had not affected the Administration's foreign policy.
Asked about the Canadian Foreign Minister's trip this week to Cuba, Ms. Albright said relations with Canada were "the best possible," but she excoriated President Fidel Castro.

LENGTH: 391 words

HEADLINE: The Cuban Tango

 BODY:
The trip to Cuba this week by Canada's Foreign Minister, Lloyd Axworthy, was meant to send a strong message of protest to Washington about the overreaching Helms-Burton law. That misguided effort to punish foreign companies that invest in Cuba has already led to Canadian executives' being barred from United States soil, and, if fully enforced, could inundate Canadian businesses with scores of costly lawsuits. Unfortunately, Mr. Axworthy failed to deliver an equally strong protest against the human rights abuses of his Cuban hosts.
Canada is now Cuba's largest foreign investor, and Mr. Axworthy is Ottawa's highest-level visitor to Havana in more than 20 years. Americans cannot reasonably object to his making such a visit. Diplomats from democracies, including American Secretaries of State, visit dictatorships all the time. But such an important visitor should have insisted on the need to release political prisoners and expand individual liberties in this hemisphere's most repressive dictatorship. 
 Mr. Axworthy reports that he did raise human rights issues in his private meetings with Cuban leaders. Canada also provides funds to independent Cuban groups that campaign for environmentally sensitive development and gay rights. But on the most pressing issue, encouraging democratic change, Canada is doing less than it should. Ottawa ought to follow the example of the European Union, which recently decided to link any strengthening of its economic ties with Cuba to an expansion of the human and political rights of the Cuban people.
Fidel Castro's dictatorial rule and market-stifling economic policies have stunted Cuba for so long that it has become hard to imagine significant change. But Mr. Castro's advancing years and the economic crisis provoked by the end of Soviet subsidies make transition inevitable. It is in the interest of the United States, Canada and Cuba that change, when it comes, be peaceful and democratic.
By locking itself into a failed policy of rigid economic isolation, Washington deprives itself of the influence it should have as Cuba's most important neighbor and the home to the world's largest overseas Cuban community. Canada makes the opposite mistake. By not using its economic influence to press for political change, it forfeits its opportunity to exert a positive influence.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
