HEADLINE: New Jersey Treasurer Plans To Sell State Disability Fund

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Whitman administration announced plans today to sell the State Disability Benefit Fund, which distributes about $325 million annually to New Jersey workers who are temporarily disabled as a result of sickness or injury unrelated to their jobs.
The State Treasurer, Brian W. Clymer, said the sale would not have a noticeable impact, at least right away, on the more than 2.4 million employees and employers who contribute about $370 million through payroll deductions each year to the fund. Benefits are provided for up to 26 weeks to help make up for wages lost by the temporarily disabled, such as working women who have just given birth. The maximum weekly benefit is $339. 
 Mr. Clymer estimated that the fund could be sold for $200 million, allowing the Whitman administration to use the proceeds as a one-shot revenue source to help balance the $16 billion state budget that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is scheduled to propose next week.
This is the second time Mr. Clymer has turned to the State Disability Benefit Fund for budget savings. Last year, Mr. Clymer took $250 million from the fund's surplus to help balance the state budget. He said he did not know whether a surplus now exists in the fund and whether that would be part of the sale.
Democratic lawmakers attacked the proposal, accusing the Whitman administration of balancing the budget on the backs of working people. "Four out of five workers are covered by the temporary disability benefits that Governor Whitman intends to sell," State Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr. of Camden County said. "Since the state's temporary disability insurance has been an efficient program with low overhead, its sale clearly has more to do with the Governor's need to find revenue than common sense."
Mr. Clymer announced the proposed sale during a news conference about the state's revenue projections for the new budget. He projected moderate economic growth, and a $264 million increase in state tax revenue in the coming year. New Jersey, like New York, is benefiting from the boom on Wall Street, with personal income tax receipts estimated at $200 million more than anticipated for this fiscal year.
New Jersey and New York are among five states that administer temporary disability benefit plans. The fund was created in 1948, at a time when private insurance companies did not offer such benefits. But now, Mr. Clymer said, there are more than 4,000 approved insurance plans offering similar benefits, enabling the state to turn the fund over to a private insurer.
"It is not something that we need to be in the business of," Mr. Clymer said. "It is not something that we do efficiently. This is a competitive market. We should not be competing with the private market."
Private employers, who are required by state law to provide temporary disability insurance benefits to their employees, already have the option to purchase benefits from private insurers. But almost 80 percent of the companies that do business in New Jersey choose to participate in the state plan, state officials said.
While Mr. Clymer said increased competition in the insurance industry would benefit both employers and workers, it was unclear whether participants in the disability fund would be able to take advantage of such competition immediately.
Mr. Clymer declined to provide details about the proposed sale, but he did acknowledge that the state would sell the fund's customer base. Taxes that are now paid by employers and employees would be converted into premiums. It is unclear whether current participants in the plan would have the option to leave the plan after the sale, which Mr. Clymer said he hoped would be completed by June. But benefit levels andcurrent tax rates would remain unchanged, he said.
Taxes on employers range from one-tenth of 1 percent to three-quarters of 1 percent, and the employee tax is a flat one-half of 1 percent; each tax is applied against the first $17,600 of wages earned. That means the lowest-income and highest-income wage earners in New Jersey pay about the same $100 in annual payroll taxes for temporary disability benefits.
New Jersey is one of three states that imposes payroll taxes on employees in addition to employers.

HEADLINE: Javits Center President Reportedly Tops Pataki's List to Take Over the Port Authority

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
The president of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, Robert E. Boyle, is Gov. George E. Pataki's top choice to become executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, officials said yesterday.
The new executive director will run an agency that both Governors want to continue shifting away from development deals to focus on transportation. The agency's chairman said the changes mean the elimination of 500 jobs this year. 
 Combined with the dismissals, early retirements and job attrition that began in August 1995, that will reduce the number of employees to 7,300, from 9,100. Former executives and senior employees say the downsizing is wrecking one of the nation's blue-chip public service agencies, but Port Authority officials say the changes are long overdue.
"The determination has been made that we are really not a real estate development agency and that our core mission is transportation infrastructure," said Lewis M. Eisenberg, the chairman, who announced the new job cuts in an interview. "I would say it is an agency which is more focused, its purpose and design are more clear, than in the past."
Governor Pataki is expected to announce the new director next week. Mr. Boyle, a friend of the Governor's from his hometown of Peekskill, won the administration's approval for confronting the unions at the Javits Center that the Governor felt were driving up costs.
Mr. Boyle did not return phone calls seeking comment.
Aides to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she would have no reaction until an announcement was made.
Mrs. Whitman was angry two years ago when Governor Pataki announced his decision to appoint George J. Marlin to the post without consulting her. In replacing Mr. Marlin, who will leave April 3, the new executive director will oversee an agency shrinking for the first time in its 75-year history.
Critics of the retrenchment say the once proud guardian of the region's gateways and the developer of the World Trade Center has been brought low by a series of blind swings of the downsizing ax.
They describe an agency so bent on change that it plans to unload valuable real estate without regard to the long-term revenue consequences, so fixed on reducing staff that the employee exodus has left La Guardia Airport bereft of one third of its electricians, and so riven by jealousy between New York and New Jersey that a project to extend the runway at Newark International Airport has yet to be approved two years after its introduction.
Supporters of the new direction counter that the authority was a dinosaur gamboling in the fields of big government, unaware of the realities of the leaner 1990's. The two state administrations have yet to produce a full blueprint of how far the cutbacks should go, but there is no doubt further shrinkage lies ahead.
"The question is what are we going to do to improve the transportation system in the region, the waterway and the harbors, not if we can build an industrial park somewhere," said Charles Gargano, the vice chairman. "It had a reputation for a lot of waste, for not watching out for the interests of New York. They did not have a focus on the core mission of the Port Authority, which was the transportation systems of the region and how they can focus on improving the economy of the region."
The authority still runs major enterprises, including the region's three major airports, the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the PATH commuter rail line. But entire departments within the agency have disappeared, including its export marketing section, its trade library and independent groups that analyzed the environment and economic policy. It sold off the Vista Hotel for $141.5 million and parts of industrial parks in Elizabeth, N.J., andYonkers.
Various privatization options are being considered for the World Trade Center, and the organization wants to sell Piers 1 to 5 in Brooklyn as well as the grain terminal there. A $1 billion international arrival building at Kennedy International Airport will be built and run by a private company, and its 105 employees will not work for the Port Authority. It handed the Passenger Ship Terminal to the city on Dec. 31.
December also witnessed one of the largest departures of senior management and technical staff. The Port Authority said it had yet to compile complete figures, but those leaving said it amounted to roughly 300 of the most experienced employees, including 8 of the 24 electricians at La Guardia Airport and the building crews that helped restore the World Trade Center after it was bombed in 1993. Also, in the last two years, at least 17 of 28 senior department heads have quit or retired.
In interviews, a dozen of the people who have left cited three main reasons. First, they feared the authority would either be eliminated or shrunk to a point where all it did was manage a few bridges and railroads, without generating revenue to finance new prestige projects. Second, they felt the new management no longer welcomed proposals for new ventures. Third, they wanted to get good salaries with private companies before the changes tarnished the authority's reputation.
"There is a high level of angst and uncertainty," said John Collura, who worked for the authority for 26 years and was chief operating officer when he left in March 1996. Much of the uncertainty stemmed from the way the downsizing was handled, the employees said, with little internal discussion or warning.
In seeking to unload important real estate like the World Trade Center or letting a private company build and run Kennedy Airport, the authority risked cutting itself off from the sources of revenue that allowed it to be an independent agency not beholden to local government.
"The Port Authority will wind up more like the Metropolitan Transit Authority or New Jersey Transit by living day to day, putting off maintenance," said Richard C. Leone, a former chairman. By tradition, the governor of New Jersey appoints the chairman and the governor of New York names the executive director, although they are supposed to consult on their choices.
Employees who had departed said the changes had not affected safety and the public would probably not notice, although it often meant postponing preventive maintenance.
"Any time you lose experienced people, some things could possibly take longer to rectify," said Joseph DiPrisco, 52, who took the December buyout after 34 years employment.

HEADLINE: Edgy Market Tumbles for a Third Day as Dow Loses 59.27

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market fell yesterday for the third consecutive session as investors appeared to be growing more concerned about rising interest rates and this year's fast climb to repeated record highs.
The decline ended the busiest week of trading ever on the New York Stock Exchange on volume of 2.8 billion shares. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 59.27 points to close at 6,696.48, capping a late week plunge that left the index up just 3.9 percent for the year.
"You had a 6 1/2 to 7 percent month until the last three days, and that's way too strong," said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Kansas City, Kan. "It was just running too fast; it was running way ahead of the fundamentals."
Although few analysts had an easy explanation for the market's slide, many tied it to rising interest rates in the bond market -- which could lure some cash out of the stock market -- and worries about next week's Employment Cost Index report, a key measure of inflation.
The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.88 percent yesterday, from 6.86 percent on Thursday, and has jumped half a percentage point in less than two months.
The Employment Cost Index, which measures growth in wages, has been singled out by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, as a key barometer of inflationary pressures.
While most analysts are predicting that the Fed will not raise its short-term interest rate target at its policy meeting next month, a rise in the Employment Cost Index could set the stage for an interest rate rise later this year.
"I think the market's starting to come to grips with the reality that the increase in the Employment Cost Index means the Fed may raise rates," said John H. Shaughnessy, an analyst at the Advest Group.
Several analysts argued, though, that the economic outlook remained strong and that all the fundamentals for a strong stock market were still in place, including strong cash flows into mutual funds.
And while some expressed concern about the market's volatility and the defensive posture of many investors who have been buying safer, large capitalization stocks, most analysts said the drop this week was healthy.
"What we are going through is a two- or three-day jolt in the market," said Edward Collins, head of stock trading at Daiwa Securities. "I've been in this business a long time and you don't go straight up. But I still think we have a little more run to go in this one."
While the Dow was down throughout the day, falling as much as 93 points, it recovered some of the loss, ending down 0.88 percent in a volatile session of trading. Du Pont and Eastman Kodak led the Dow's decline. Du Pont dropped 4 7/8, to 102 5/8, and Kodak fell 2 7/8, to 85 5/8.
After an impressive run this year in which the Dow gained more than 435 points, or 6.8 percent, as of Tuesday, the blue-chip index has lost 187.42 points. Early in the week, many analysts said, investors began anticipating a blockbuster month that seemed likely to take the Dow to 7,000. But the retreat has forced them to scale back their ambitions.
"The market has positioned itself in a very defensive way," said Richard Eakle, a market analyst at Eakle Associates in Fair Haven, N.J. "People are moving away from small cap stocks. They don't want to worry about the problem of liquidity. It's a lot easier to sell Eastman Kodak than a small cap."
Broader market indexes were also down. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost 7.04 points to close at 770.52. And the Nasdaq composite index fell 14.54 points, to 1,363.83.
One of the few stocks to escape unscathed was Microsoft, which gained 13/16 , to 9515/16 . However, shares of Cascade Communications, which makes telecommunications equipment, plunged 23 1/8, or 36 percent, to close at 41. Analysts ignored an earnings report that beat their expectations and concentrated on what they saw as future weaknesses.
Yet even though many analysts were concerned about the market's jittery mood, some said that the market had proved its resilience time and again. In July, the Dow lost 254 points over three days, before recovering. And in December it lost 205 points over four days, only to bounce back.
"The fundamental picture can hardly be better," said Robert Stovall of Stovall 21st Advisers. "I don't see any conspiracy out there. All you're seeing is a market that's twitchy and sensitive."
One recent convert to bullishness is Elaine Garzarelli, the former Lehman Brothers market strategist who now runs her own firm, Garzarelli Capital. Ms. Garzarelli, who had been bearish on the stock market since July, switched her stance this week, a fact that was widely reported on Thursday as the Dow dropped 94 points. In an interview yesterday, she conceded she had failed to predict a continued bull market, but that a revised "model" that eliminated "cash flows" from her studies now pointed to a bull market.
"I was trying to find out what happened and it took so long," she said, explaining why it took her half a year to revise her outlook.
Now, she says she is "normally bullish" and is forecasting that the Dow could rise 10 to 15 percent. And she said she was happy she switched just as the market started a correction, which means her clients can get in at a lower price. "We're getting in on a nice correction," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Supermarket Chain to Pay $81.5 Million in Bias Suit
Florida's largest supermarket chain agreed to pay $81.5 million to settle accusations that it systematically denied promotions, raises and preferred assignments to its women employees. The settlement, by Publix Supermarkets, may be the largest workplace discrimination case in terms of the number of people it covers.
The class-action lawsuit covers more than 100,000 women who have worked since 1991 at Publix stores in Florida and other Southern states. [Page 1.]

White House Coffee for Bankers
The Democratic National Committee organized a meeting at the White House last May in which some of the nation's most prominent bankers met to discuss banking regulation with President Clinton, a senior bank regulator, the Treasury Secretary and the top fund-raiser for the party, Administration officials said. The meeting was one of 103 at the White House arranged by the Democratic Party that were attended by the President and other top officials. [1.]
 
Abortion Pill Is Closer to Market
Three years ago, it seemed inevitable that the French abortion pill would soon be sold on the American market. But a dispute between the American group that was given the patent rights to the pill, RU-486, and the businessman the group had chosen to raise money and arrange for the pill's manufacture and distribution kept the pill off the market. Now there is hope that the stalemate is ending. [7.]
 
Bond Prices Fall Sharply
Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply, as investors sold on concern that coming reports on the economy and wages would show faster growth and greater inflationary pressures. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 10/32, to 955/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.88 percent from 6.86 percent on Thursday. [38.]
 
Dollar Rises, Then Slips
The dollar vaulted over the 120-yen barrier for the first time in nearly four years then dropped, hurt by fear that Japan's central bank was selling dollars to defend the yen. The dollar fell against other major currencies on profit taking from the dollar's sharp rise over the last week and on news of higher inflation in Germany. [36.]

Big Bankruptcy in South Korea
The Hanbo Steel Corporation, South Korea's second-largest steel producer and the flagship of one of the country's big industrial conglomerates, is seeking court protection from its creditors, dealing a new blow to an economy already reeling from labor strife and prompting an injection of money into the financial system by the central bank. Hanbo's collapse, one of the biggest in Korean corporate history, was caused largely by a plant expansion that the company could not afford. [38.]
 
More Funds for Food Inspections
President Clinton's 1998 budget will propose spending $43 million for a program to detect outbreaks of food-borne illnesses and to improve food safety. [1.]

Fresh Moves for British Telecom
Fresh from striking Britain's largest corporate acquisition, in which British Telecommunications will buy MCI Communications of the United States for $20 billion, the chief executive of British Telecom is charting additional steps toward turning this once-mundane utility into the world's fourth-largest telecommunications enterprise. Sir Peter Bonfield said his personal experience working in the United States would help BT shift from being just a telephone company into a multiservice, multimedia telecommunications phenomenon. [38.]

Coffee Prices Fall As Strike Ends
Coffee prices tumbled after dock workers in Colombia ended a 10-day strike, allowing thousands of bags of coffee to flow into the world market. The strike at the key Colombian port of Buenaventura ended after union leaders and management reached a wage agreement, port officials said. [36.]

HEADLINE: 10 Abandoned Children Found in Ramshackle Atlantic City House

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 24

 BODY:
With two kerosene heaters for warmth and nothing to eat but canned vegetables, 10 children lived alone for three weeks in an abandoned, crumbling row house in the shadow of the city's shimmering casinos, the authorities here said today.
They survived without electricity, running water or a back door, using buckets as a toilet and scurrying to school each morning for a free breakfast, the officials said. 
 Building inspectors knocked on the door of the house at 633 Baltic Avenue on Thursday after receiving a call from a neighbor who smelled kerosene, said Steven M. Greenwood, a code enforcement officer. When they peered inside, he said, they saw the children and two adults sitting in the dark. Drug paraphernalia was strewn around the squalid apartment, he said, and the acrid-sweet smell of crack cocaine hung in the air.
The children, who range in age from 1 to 16, told officials that they were from Camden and Trenton, but that they had been alone in the house since early January, during some of the winter's most bitter cold. Wendy Patella, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services, would not say how many of the children were boys and how many were girls, nor would she say how many of them were related. As of tonight, the children's parents and relatives had been identified but had not been located.
The two adults, a man and a woman, told the officials that they were not related to the children, Mr. Greenwood said. He said the police questioned them and allowed them to leave.
The children, who were evaluated for health problems at the Atlantic City Medical Center, have been placed with foster families, Ms. Patella said.
Mr. Greenwood, who made the chilling discovery with other building inspectors, police officers and social workers, said the children had at first refused to reveal even their names. One of the boys, an 11-year-old, tried to keep the others from talking, he said. But eventually, he said, they told the inspectors that their parents had dropped them off at the house three weeks ago and never returned.
The building had been without any plumbing since 1994, Mr. Greenwood said, and without electricity or gas since early last year when the building's owner, Alex Michel, vanished.
The children had apparently been surviving by stealing water and sometimes running an electrical cord from another unoccupied house next door. But when inspectors arrived at noon, they said that the house was dark and without any utilities.
Two dogs were roaming the apartment, and the floors were covered with feces and the tools of drug users -- wax paper that had held crack rocks and heating spoons still covered with their residue.
Upstairs, a baby girl lay in a crib sleeping in the cold and appeared unconscious, though 10 minutes of gentle prodding by inspectors finally revived her. The other children appeared healthy, with only slight sniffles and colds, Mr. Greenwood said.
"This place was a shambles," Mr. Greenwood said, adding that dilapidated buildings are far too common in this city of about 38,000 people, just blocks from the hulking rows of casinos that thrive even in the dead of winter. "Sheets were being used as doors, there was garbage everywhere and when my inspector walked into the kitchen, his foot went through the floor."
"While we've got a lot of abandoned buildings here," he added, "we've never had a situation like this where kids were just left to fend for themselves."
Today, the block was quiet except for reporters milling about and children hurrying home from school, many in baggy jeans and carrying boom boxes. The doors and windows of the building were boarded up. A warning sign read, "This structure is unfit for human occupancy."
Neighbors said they had not seen the children until this week, when a few ventured out to sit on the building's stoop or walk to a nearby school. Many spoke bitterly about the deterioration of their city, where the casinos lure many to seek their fortune, but the wealth has never spread past Caesar's Palace, the Trump Taj Mahal or other gambling venues.
A resident, Tony Brown, said he thought the mothers of the abandoned children were two sisters in their late 20's who had moved here from the South, hoping to find good jobs at the casinos. They found work, he said, but quickly squandered their earnings on drugs.
"They had no family to depend on," he said. "They were very good people. They just got a bad deal."
Mr. Brown and others said it was not uncommon here these days to find children fending for themselves in decrepit housing, with only occasional visits from relatives. Affordable housing is harder than ever to find, he added, and drugs can be bought on many street corners.
Child services officials said that 337 children had been abandoned in New Jersey in 1995, the last year for which they have records.
"People are living in these abandoned buildings all over the city, kids and all," Mr. Brown said. "All over the streets you can get the drugs. I've got to blame this on the drugs."
Omar Africa, an unemployed father of five who was walking his son home from school, said it was obvious for a long time that the building had been taken over by drug users. He questioned why city officials and neighbors had not investigated sooner.
"It's been that way for a long time but nobody said a thing," he said, gesturing toward the boarded-up structure. "Whoever finally called should be commended, but I don't think they were the first to notice there was a problem here."
While many neighbors surmised that drugs were at the root of the problem, few were willing to let the children's missing parents off the hook. Many parents in this blighted section of the city were struggling, but would not think of leaving their children, they said.
"They should burn these parents, not lock them up," said Steve Serale, who was visiting a friend on the block. "You don't jeopardize your kids like that for anything or anyone."
Despite the squalid conditions they had endured for the past three weeks, the children remained reluctant to leave and took pains to protect their parents, inspectors said, noting that it took several minutes of cajoling to get them even to tell their names. Mr. Greenwood said that small talk about their dogs -- one whose name was Cheese -- and his offer to tie one child's shoelaces helped win them over.
"They were really shy, bummed out, and we had to push them along," he said. "But they had an idea of what was about to happen. By the end, they seemed pretty enthused about getting out."
The younger children waved goodbye, he said, and smiled from the back of the police cars that rushed them away from their home.

HEADLINE: An AIDS Nursing Home Finds It Is No Longer the Last Stop

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
Deric Dixon had a bout of double pneumonia in December that could have killed him. But it didn't.
Mr. Dixon, a clerical worker who has AIDS, had been taking a new class of drugs, protease inhibitors, that are extending lives. He swallows 30 pills a day, at 9 A.M., 4 P.M. and 9 P.M., since he became a patient at the Rivington House, a nursing home for people with AIDS on the Lower East Side. 
 When Mr. Dixon arrived at the center last summer, his legs looked like tree trunks because they were so bloated from fluids caused by an AIDS-related cancer, Kaposi's Sarcoma. The new drugs kept his immune system from deteriorating further and allowed his body to stabilize in the months before the pneumonia.
"If it wasn't for the drugs, he would be dead," said Steven A. DeMartino, a staff supervisor at Rivington House. "All indications are that he's more resilient. When is the last time you heard somebody say that about the H.I.V. disease? We're not used to talking that way."
When the Rivington House opened two years ago, the 219-bed center was the last stop for many AIDS patients. The length of stay was 12 to 15 days, and the death rate was nearly 50 percent. In recent months, the length of stay has risen to 120 days. More people are feeling healthier and are going home. And the death rate at Rivington House, the nation's largest residential health-care facility for AIDS patients, has fallen 20 percent, which has left the center with about 20 empty beds.
Mr. Dixon's experience and the empty beds at Rivington are part of a new chapter in the AIDS epidemic: Like many people with AIDS who are taking advantage of the new drug therapies, Mr. Dixon is feeling better and thinking that he might be around longer than he expected.
In Washington yesterday, New York City health officials reported that for the first time since 1981, deaths from AIDS declined sharply, falling by 30 percent from 1995 for all racial and ethnic groups. The decline actually began before protease inhibitors were widely available, but experts say that as protease inhibitors become more widely used there should be an even sharper decline in deaths.
Like many residential treatment centers and hospitals in New York, the Rivington House has seen the ripple effects of the advent of a powerful new class of drugs that is bringing many people back from the brink of death.
At the center, new questions are being asked. The big one is: What now? What do the AIDS patients do, now that they have gotten better instead of worse?
For some patients, the new drugs have kindled a fragile kind of hope, adding to the terror, the confusion and the complexities already in their lives.
Mr. Dixon, a slight, bespectacled man in a plaid sweater, said the new drugs have given him a sense that he can look forward to living perhaps 5 or 10 years more rather than 2. Mr. Dixon, who has worked as an administrative assistant at Community Access, an agency that provides housing and other services for people with mental illness, moved to New York from Detroit, where he said his family had rejected him because he is gay. Now, Mr. Dixon, who takes psychotropic drugs for manic depression, is weighing questions he had never dreamed he would have a chance to consider. He talks about his hope to reconcile with his family and other matters of the heart.
"Will I allow myself to love someone again? How will I tell someone I have AIDS?," he said yesterday.
Still, many patients are dying, with or without the new drugs, including a young mother in the room next to Mr. Dixon's, a patient Rivington officials said was within hours of death.
While the new drugs have made many patients stronger, officials at Rivington House and elsewhere see danger in the growing sense of optimism among those who have concluded that the disease is soon to be beaten.
"I don't think we've turned the corner," said Linda A. Domizio, director of professional services at Rivington House. "I think it's too premature to make any projections about what's going to happen in the future. It's a very difficult regimen to adhere to. And we don't know what the long-term effects are going to be."
But the new drugs have given many people with AIDS a glimmer of hope. At the Rivington House, a six-story, red-brick structure that used to be a public school, patients are talking about getting their G.E.D.s, getting jobs, even getting their teeth fixed. The corridor walls are decorated with brightly colored artwork, painted by patients. A golden retriever, named Dinah, nuzzles patients and prowls halls.
But despite the center's welcoming atmosphere, Joseph Breen is eager to leave at the end of the month. Mr. Breen, who has been on protease inhibitors for nearly a year, looks forward to going back to his acting career.
Breen, who is 38, has had side effects including a painful kidney stone attack that sent him weeping to a hospital emergency room. He switched medications.
Mr. Breen, who has three children and a ex-wife in Connecticut, said he used to be a leading man in television soap operas including "Guiding Light," "As the World Turns" and "Loving." At one point, he said, he was making more than $300,000 annually, but three years of unemployment have left him with only Social Security disability benefits.
Mr. Breen will move to a house run by the Actor's Fund of America, for entertainers who have AIDS. Some days he believes he will have a normal life expectancy. But on a recent day, after he experienced a night of discomfort from kidney problems, he asked a staff worker if he would live to see a cure.
"I will never stop taking these AIDS medications until there is a proven cure," he said yesterday. "You can't play around with this disease."

HEADLINE: Stand Firm on Police Pay

 BODY:
For the last two years, the union representing New York City's nearly 38,000 police officers has tried every conceivable tactic to avoid the realities accepted by other municipal employees. The union tried to run around Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and get the Legislature in Albany to arrange for higher wages than the city can afford. Now that the courts have effectively blocked that approach, the union has rejected the Mayor's latest sensible offer and thrown up picket lines at precincts around the city. Mr. Giuliani, whose political reputation rests heavily on his crime-fighting zeal, must stand firm and not be bullied by these police protests.
Though the city's economy has improved recently, the fiscal situation remains imperiled by projections of deficits in the years ahead. Accordingly, in 1995 Mr. Giuliani negotiated five-year contracts with most city unions, calling for a wage freeze in the first two years and an increase of 13.3 percent in the last three years. Now the city has offered the police a two-year freeze followed by an increase of about 15.5 percent over three years, a considerably more generous package, provided the police make concessions on work rules and pension payments to cover the extra cost. City Hall is right to demand that wage increases be funded by improved productivity. 
 Part of the problem is that the police union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, has been ill served by its leadership for years. This week, a Federal grand jury indicted top officials of a sister union representing the transit police on racketeering charges. Among those charged was James J. Lysaght, a lawyer who designed the P.B.A.'s strategy of trying to use political muscle in Albany to circumvent the city. Mr. Lysaght is entitled to the presumption of innocence, of course, but his strategy of trying to muscle the city by going to Albany has been a diversion. Police officers should demand that he step aside in favor of leadership willing to negotiate in good faith with City Hall.
The P.B.A. makes several arguments to support its claim for preferential treatment, all of them fallacious. The union says the police should get credit for the city's decline in crime. But police officers are already reaping a bonanza in overtime from the recent crackdown on drug trafficking in Brooklyn and upper Manhattan, and other actions.
The police also think they should be paid what their fellow officers are paid in Nassau and Suffolk counties. But their wages are comparable to what the police are paid in other big cities, the most meaningful comparison. New York City police get benefits, vacations, sick leave and pensions that are much more generous than those in many suburban communities. If New York City officers want to be compared to their brothers and sisters in the suburbs, they could agree to one-person patrol cars in low-crime areas and other work-rule changes that help cut costs in those places. The union should also work to expedite arrest and arraignment procedures to cut overtime costs.
If the police union insists on rejecting the city offer and going to an arbitration proceeding, Mr. Giuliani should widen his scope and demand the changes in work rules and benefits that the police have resisted for so long. A much better alternative would be for the police to recognize that they are not going to get a better deal from the city or arbitration, no matter how much noise they make.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Joblessness Above U.S. Rate

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate held steady at 6.2 percent in December, nearly a percentage point above the national rate of 5.3 percent, the State Labor Department announced yesterday. The private sector created 5,700 new jobs last month, most of them in retail, but the public sector lost 2,200 jobs.

HEADLINE: Let the Users Pay for New York's Rail Tunnel

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to build a railroad tunnel beneath New York Harbor (news article, Jan. 15): I applaud any effort to return more of the region's freight to the rails. But how will this affect the overall transportation system? Yes, the highways are a mess and the railroads underused, but the massive public expenditures on highways in the 1940's through the 1960's shifted the system to the current status quo.
Major and shortline railroads, steamships and national and local trucking companies are all working in the marketplace delivering goods. A harbor tunnel would shift the system out of balance. For example, Conrail has an exclusive ability to move freight destined for Long Island via the old New York Central Railroad line from Albany. Would the tunnel authorities allow other railways to access Long Island? What if a steamship company decided to start a subsidiary railroad to utilize the tunnel? How would the tunnel affect the contracts between steamships, railroads and trucking companies now moving freight to and from the region? 
 Rather than use public funds to influence the system, City Hall should tell the transportation companies that there is a problem and that they need to fix it. New York City demanded that the New York Central Railroad eliminate steam engines within city limits in 1905 and gave them five years to solve the problem. The railroads have built bridges, tunnels and new track when the economics were favorable, and they would do it again. Offering public funds when private capital exists is poor public policy.
 
THORN MEAD
Marblehead, Mass., Jan. 22, 1997

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Thomas Kerr)

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ANDORRA, by Peter Cameron. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) Comic verve is harnessed to a darker purpose in this novel about a wealthy American who seeks refuge from sorrow in an imaginary, and remarkably polite, Andorra.
 
THE DESTINY OF NATHALIE X AND OTHER STORIES, by William Boyd. (Knopf, $22.) Stories that occupy rich and diverse landscapes both mental and geographical, each with its own catalogue of human woes and weaknesses.
 
DIARIES. Volume 1: 1939-1960, by Christopher Isherwood. (Michael di Capua/HarperCollins, $40.) When Isherwood fled Britain for California in 1939, he set out on this amused, amusing record of the cares and pleasures of exile.
 
FLYING HOME AND OTHER STORIES, by Ralph Ellison. Edited by John F. Callahan. (Random House, $23.) A slim but shining collection, some of its contents showing apprentice connections to "Invisible Man," all of it distinctively Ellison's.
 
FRAGMENTS: Memories of a Wartime Childhood, by Binjamin Wilkomirski. (Schocken, $20.) A Latvian Jew who spent his early childhood in death camps reflects thoughtfully on how that perverted education distorted his life afterward.
 
GUIDED TOURS OF HELL: Novellas, by Francine Prose. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) Two irresistible tales about Americans abroad in pressurized environments that both speed and aggravate the purgation of their inner problems.
 
HINTS OF HIS MORTALITY, by David Borofka. (University of Iowa, $22.95.) An impressive short-story collection, chiefly inhabited by men who have somehow failed to make the grade.
 
THE ISLAND OF THE COLORBLIND: And Cycad Island, by Oliver Sacks. (Knopf, $24.) Once more in search of ingenious adaptations to bizarre conditions, the neurological explorer visits the Pacific in search of populations with runaway frequencies of color-blindness and parkinsonism.
 
ONE MAN'S AMERICA: A Journalist's Search for the Heart of His Country, by Henry Grunwald. (Doubleday, $30.) Anecdote, insight and charm inform this memoir by a onetime refugee who as editor in chief at Time Inc. occupied a fabulous lookout post on the American century.
 
ONE WORLD, READY OR NOT: The Manic Logic of Global Capitalism, by William Greider. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) Reporting that captures the sins of the great economic beast and proposes reasonable reforms, together with some unlikely interpretations and prognostications.
 
THE SPEARS OF TWILIGHT: Life and Death in the Amazon Jungle, by Philippe Descola. (New Press, $25.) Classic (but unclassically self-aware) fieldwork with a close-to-untouched culture in one of the last places on earth such things are found.

HEADLINE: Jewels of the Desert

BYLINE: By KIM WESTERMAN; KIM WESTERMAN, a poet and food writer, lives in northern Tucson.

 BODY:
STANDING in line at Le Cave's Bakery in South Tucson, I found myself in conversation with a Yaqui teen-ager who wore shiny cowboy boots, some of the reddest I'd ever seen. "Stewart Boots -- Just fitted for my 16th birthday," he said self-consciously as he sidled up to the counter and ordered a pumpkin empanada.
The Stewart Boot Manufacturing Company is easy to miss. The ramshackle building looks like all the other small white houses on 28th Street, just off South Sixth Avenue, the commercial hub of South Tucson's Mexican-American community. The front door sticks and the dark, low-ceilinged room is wall-to-wall boots. One of the craftsmen left his sewing machine and greeted my companion, Jane, and me in the small area set aside for sizing. In less than 20 minutes I had ordered a pair of mustard-yellow, square-toed custom boots in kid skin. 
 Ten blocks north of Stewart Boots is el barrio, the neighborhood that, for me, is both the genesis and sustenance of border culture in Arizona. I've gotten to know the barrio well over the last seven years, making frequent visits from my home in the foothills of northern Tucson. The trip is usually an end in itself, but this time we used it as a starting point for a weekend trip across the border.
There is a palpable friction here -- among cultures, languages and values -- but it is a creative friction. The barrio is a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood where Anglos and Mexican Americans live in relative harmony as middle income families buy up old homes in need of repair.
A walk along Convent Avenue and Cushing Street uncovered some beautifully preserved 19th-century adobe homes. Some have corrugated steel roofs, an apparent concession to those who complained that Tucson didn't seem like an "American" town. Fortunately, many settlers were interested in preserving their Hispanic past, including meticulous details like saguaro-rib ceilings, now outlawed since the saguaro cactus is threatened by overdevelopment.
It was October, and the long summer, with its relentless sun and dry, staccato winds, had finally lifted. In fall the young desert light is diffuse and less threatening.
This border zone is in the Sonoran Basin, which extends 60 miles north to the Gila River in Arizona and 200 miles south to Hermosillo, Mexico, the capital of Sonora. Since ours was a brief trip, we traversed only the interior of the basin, from South Tucson down to Magdalena, Sonora, about a hundred miles one way.
Heading south, away from the urban hum, we were in the desert proper within 10 minutes. As deserts go, it is lush, but the eye must be trained to see into the vast expanse partially rimmed by the Santa Rita Mountains.
Flat terrain of wiry ocotillo plants and creosote bushes (sweet-smelling after a rain) is punctuated sparely with saguaro cactuses, whose stature belies their fragility. It's hard not to anthropomorphize these giants in an otherwise lunar landscape.
Like many plants in the basin, saguaros grow nowhere else on earth. Even though they've undergone adaptations that allow them to survive in an extreme climate, their survival counts on a tenuous ecosystem of interdependence. As seedlings, they must be sheltered from the blistering sun in order to develop their complex insulation and water storage systems. Growth is slow: arm buds appear only after 75 years. During monsoon season, when the ground often becomes saturated and winds kick up, these ancients, with their shallow root systems, are in danger of being simply knocked over.
We decided to go for a walk in Madera Canyon, a bird sanctuary and wildlife refuge halfway between South Tucson and the Mexican border. The 19-mile drive out of the desert and up into Coronado National Forest is an almost imperceptible climb, but, indeed, we'd entered another microclimate. At 5,400 feet, the air was crystalline, the landscape populated with evergreen oaks, mesquite, white-limbed sycamores, and my favorite: alligator junipers, named for their scaly bark, which camouflages a variety of lizards.
A half-hour walk on the well-maintained Super Trail deposited us at the base of a waterfall, the mouth of a substantial creek, probably fed by Mount Wrightson (9,453 feet), behind which the sun had just set. Walking back to the car, I spotted a raccoonlike coatimundi scurrying in the last light of the day.
Our destination for the evening was Sonoita, the beginning of Arizona wine country, with some 10 wineries. Sonoita's downtown, an area that has outgrown its truck-stop roots and is emerging as a wild West strip mall, is the unlikely location of Er Pastaro, an Italian restaurant where we had a delightful dinner. The Roman chef, Giovanni Schifano, and his Austrian wife, Karin, close up every summer and return to their home in the Maltese Islands, bringing back enough hand-picked capers to last all year. I had the perfectly al dente spaghetti alla carbonara (with bacon, eggs and cream), and Jane had penne alla Norcia, an Umbrian dish with sausage and mushrooms. We shared a bottle of rough Sicilian red wine, appropriately tannic for the rich food.
We stayed at the Vineyard Bed-and-Breakfast, a 1916 restored hacienda on 20 acres of oaks, grasslands, and vineyards. Our freestanding casita, decorated in southwestern motif, provided views of the grounds in every direction.
Morning brought clouds, but Sonoitans are quick to say they don't indicate rain. Or more precisely, when it does rain, it usually evaporates before it can land, leaving long, dark traces in the sky. The Spanish name for this phenomenon is "nublina," but Jane calls them witches' hairs, lovely all along deserted scenic Highway 82, which we took because we were eager to reach Nogales, the U.S.-Mexico border, by lunch.
We parked on the Arizona side in order to buy the inexpensive car insurance that a sojourn into Mexico necessitates. Then we crossed the border on foot to search for a particular kind of hand-blown water glass I had found years ago at the Lazy Frog, a craft store just off tourist row, and one of the few retail outlets in Nogales in which bargaining is frowned upon.
I didn't find them, but I did pick up some vanilla without coumarin, a common chemical additive. Nearby, I bought Portofidio Single Barrel Anejo (aged) tequila -- smooth, creamy and slightly sweet.
NOGALES is Spanish for walnuts. It is said that when the city was named in 1854, two identical walnut trees mirrored each other on opposite sides of the border. There is no sign of those trees in this burgeoning, but still mostly poor, metropolis.
Ambos Nogales -- "both Nogaleses" -- is economically and spiritually one city, separated, but not divided, by a wire fence. It was here, in 1882, that Mexico was first connected to the United States by rail. Now, because of hotly contested immigration laws, the heavily policed border is ominous, but the folklorist James Griffith documented a practice common in the 1980's: international volleyball games, with the wire fence serving as net.
We picked up the car and crossed into Mexico, where teen-age boys with automatic weapons were guarding the towns of San Ignacio and Imuris. Seventeen roadside shrines and an hour later, we were in the old mission community of Magdalena, looking at the bones of Eusebio Francisco Kino, the Jesuit missionary who died on the church grounds in 1711. Discovered under the chapel by archeologists in 1966, the bones now rest in full view in the center of the plaza under a glass dome.
The Spanish Colonial town is striking in its architectural simplicity. White, hacienda-style structures with tile roofs form a square around the 15-acre plaza. Wide streets that once saw horses and buggies now give passage to pedestrians.
The church of Santa Maria Magdalena de Buquivaba is the locus of a multicultural convergence each October for the feast day of the Roman Catholic St. Francis of Assisi. The pilgrims are Mexican, Mexican-American, Anglo, Yaqui and O'odham. They come to touch and kiss the statue of yet another saint, Francis Xavier, patron of missionaries, whose life-size image lies horizontally, as in death, in the chapel adjoining the main sanctuary. A few try, out of what seems a violent desperation, to lift the statue's head, an ability believed to be granted to those who are right with God.
They also come to purchase beautiful painted glass frames, cuadritos, intended for sacred pictures. I chose a frame bearing the image of a translucent green lizard on a slate background, planning to use the frame itself as the picture. Shopkeepers complained that they wouldn't get much business for the rest of the year; they bring in 80 percent of their yearly income on the feast day.
We wandered through the Plaza Monumental, satisfying in its symmetry, then turned back north toward Nogales, where we stopped for a dinner of Guaymas shrimp at La Roca, an ornate, second-floor restaurant built into the side of an enormous rock. Inside the cavelike space, the rock provides a partial ceiling and the entire east wall. Camarones mojo de ajo (shrimp with butter and garlic) is a house specialty that I can never resist, but the menu listed 10 other shrimp preparations, including batter-fried and grilled.
There is never much traffic crossing the border back into the States after 10 P.M. It is harder, though, to enter the United States than it is to enter Mexico; American border patrol agents take their time questioning each driver and passenger, choosing some, in an elusive logic, to submit to searches. We were waved through.
We had booked a room at Rio Rico Resort, 11 miles north of the border, a sprawling complex high on a mesa with quiet rooms and stunning mountain views. Our third-floor room was large and rather drably appointed in dark blues and browns, with stock landscape prints above the bed. Its nicest feature was a balcony with table and chairs, a perfect spot for room service breakfast.
Seven miles north of Rio Rico, in the Santa Cruz River Valley, is Tumacacori, home of the O'odham. Originally hunter-gatherers, the O'odham were expert in weaving and storytelling. A self-sufficient community when Padre Kino arrived in 1691, they were nonetheless enticed by the gifts he bore: livestock, horses, and seeds for food crops, like wheat, which could be grown throughout winter. He traded them, of course, for souls.
The O'odham invited Padre Kino into their homes, engendering the strange proximity of Catholicism to Native American life, images of which fill so many history books. The mission at Tumacacori was taken up by Franciscans and the church rebuilt after the Jesuits were expelled from New Spain in 1767.
On a rare day when there were no other tourists at the site, now the Tumacacori National Historical Park, we started for the sanctuary as horses whinnied in the near distance and a road runner tried clumsily to hide behind a chaste tree.
Little has been done to renovate the church, but faint friezes of stenciled flowers are still visible near the ceiling. The cemetery out back is surrounded by a whitewashed wall with deep indentations indicating places for the 14 stations of the cross. We stood for a moment inside the round mortuary chapel, whose planned dome roof was never completed. The view is all sky.
Time, like space, is elongated in the desert. Surrounded by 20 or so dead, their graves marked with stones and crosses made of rotting sticks tied together with wire, I was reminded of a Mexican folk saying: Hay mas tiempo que vida. There is more time than life.
 
Finding food and shelter in the desert
 
The Basics
Madera Canyon, accessible off I-19 at Green Valley, is a protected wilderness refuge. Trails are provided for every level of hiker. Picnic facilities and cabin rentals are also available. Information, call (520) 625-8746.
Tumacacori National Historical Park is just off I-19, 18 miles north of the Arizona-Mexico border. Admission is $2. For more information, call the park (520) 398-2341.
Proof of citizenship is required to enter Mexico. Alien residents of the United States must have proof of residency to return to the United States. Mexican car insurance can be purchased at any number of agencies near the border in Nogales, Ariz. Our 1994 Mazda cost $13 a day, plus tax. The country code for Mexico is 52.

Where to Stay
The Vineyard Bed-and-Breakfast, 92 Los Encinos Road, Sonoita, telephone (520) 455-4749. A quaint hacienda with three well-appointed bedrooms, each with private bath, in the main house, and a free-standing casita. Double rates are $75 to $85, including a full breakfast.
Rio Rico Resort and Country Club, 1069 Camino Caralampi, Rio Rico, (800) 288-4746. The location of this rather gaudy Avatar Resort is ideal: just 11 miles north of the Arizona-Mexico border. The rooms are large and quiet, and the mountain views are unparalleled. Rates are $85 to $155. Golf and tennis packages are available.
The Arizona Inn, 2200 East Elm Street, Tucson, (800) 556-8480, fax (520) 881-5830. An historic inn a half-hour drive from Tucson International Airport, it is built in an adobe style. Sitting around the elegant piano bar is a relaxing way to spend the evening. Double rates are $180 to $215.

Restaurants
Among the many traditional restaurants in South Tucson, Taqueria Pico de Gallo, 2618 South 6th Avenue, (520) 623-8775, is fast food heaven. Try the fish tacos on homemade corn tortillas with fresh salsa. They also serve shrimp ceviche and carne asada (grilled flank steak). Horchata, a rice drink flavored with cinnamon, helps put out the fire. $15 for two.
Alfonso's Carnitas Jalisco, 2801 South 6th Avenue, South Tucson, (520) 882-7985, has a large menu, but I've never made it past their house specialty, carnitas: stewed pork, which you can dress up with salsa. $15 for two.
Le Cave's Bakery, 1219 South 6th Avenue, South Tucson, (520) 624-2561, has traditional Mexican sweets, as well as homemade breads and both sweet and savory empanadas.
Er Pastaro, 3084 Highway 82, Sonoita, (520) 455-5821, is a desert anomaly. The specialties are hearty, central Italian pasta dishes, like penne alla Norcia (with sausage) and spaghetti alla carbonara. The chocolate truffle desserts alone are worth the trip. Dinner: $40 for two, not including wine.
La Roca, 91 Calle Elias, Nogales, (631) 2-07-60. An elegant Sonoran restaurant with a traditional menu. Chile rellenos are expertly made and the seafood dishes are fresh and simple. Try camarones mojo de ajo, large Guaymas shrimp in garlic and butter. Be sure to ask for tortillas instead of dinner rolls. Dinner: $40 for two, not including drinks.

Shopping
Stewart Boot Manufacturing Company, 30 West 28th Street, South Tucson, (520) 791-9973, custom designs Western boots for adults. Factory seconds are $150; custom boots start at $375. Closed Sunday.
The Lazy Frog, 57 Campillo Street, Nogales, Sonora, Mexico, (631) 2-23-11, sells handcrafts, pottery and Mexican vanilla. Prices range from $6-$300. Closed Sunday.
El Changarro, 93 Calle Elias, Nogales, (631) 2-05-45, offers a large selection of handcrafted, traditional Mexican style furniture and home accessories. Prices are high (an enormous hardwood armoire is $1,000 to $5,000), but they will ship anywhere in the world. Open daily.
Old Town Artisans, 186 North Meyer Avenue, Tucson, (520) 623-6024, is a cooperative where you can find Kachina dolls, jewelry, pottery and woodcarvings. Prices range from several dollars for children's toys to several hundred dollars for silver jewelry. Open daily.
Santa Cruz Chili and Spice Company, Tumacacori (just south of Tumacacori National Monument), (520) 398-2591, has dried chiles of all kinds, as well as original blends of spices. One room is a museum devoted to western memorabilia. Closed Sunday. K.M.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Edward G. Caputo;
Computer Crunch at the Millennium

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
EDWARD G. CAPUTO is the president of Command Systems Inc. in Farmington, a computer consulting company that has formed a partnership with the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company in Hartford to develop a system that will solve the "Year 2000" problem, also known as Y2K, faced by computer users everywhere.
Mr. Caputo jokes that he is going to be home on New Year's Eve 1999 because he would not want to be on an airplane, or even in a hotel, when the computers start to crash. 
 The basic problem is that computers are programmed to recognize only the last two digits in a year -- 1996 is read as just 96. So at the turn of the century the computers will read 00, meaning malfunctions in the making.
Mr. Caputo graduated summa cum laude with a degree in business administration from the New York Institute of Technology, and has more than 25 years' experience in the insurance, financial and manufacturing industries. Before forming his present company in 1985 he was the founder and president of the Computech Corporation in Glastonbury, which grew to 70 employees and $4 million a year in seven years.
Mr. Caputo discussed Y2K, or the Millenium Bug, during an interview at his office overlooking Batterson Park Pond in Farmington. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
 Q. What caused the Year 2000 problem?
A. It dates back to the beginning of automation, when the first computers were rolled off the factory floor. The cost of the hardware was the most expensive part of the system. This little computer on my desk has more power than a computer the size of the whole building had back in the 1960's. So the major drive was to save on the use of the hardware -- the memory, the disk drives, all of that equipment.
The people in the industry were also trying to save on space. And the most convenient place to save on space is the date area. Everybody uses dates, over and over again. If you can just cut out that "19" you save a lot of space. But it caused a major problem.
Q. So what happens after midnight on Dec. 31, 1999?
A. At all companies that have processing routines -- and today, every company is very dependent on computers and automation -- all calculations that utilize dates will be erroneous unless they go through and fix the date logic and the databases. Insurance companies, banks, Wall Street brokerage firms, utility companies, manufacturing companies, they all will have this problem.
All computer systems are suspect. They'll be paying the wrong interest rates on mortgages or passbook accounts. Insurance companies will calculate the wrong benefits, and so forth.
Q. Why?
A. The way a program works now, if the computer is trying to calculate the difference between today and 1983, the computer takes the 96 from 1996, and subtracts, say, the 83 from 1983, and gets 13. In the year 2000, it's going to take just the 00, and subtract the 83, and come up with minus 83, because it's treating 2000 as if it was 1900. Everything is going to be based on 1900 instead of 2000, and it's going to cause tremendous problem.
What happens when someone applies for Social Security, for instance, on Jan. 15, 2000, it will do the subtraction, and the applicant will have a negative age.
Q. Isn't it too early to get excited about this?
A. No. In fact in many cases, it's too late. Some companies are going to be in big trouble because they didn't start five years ago. You have companies that have 100 million, 150 million lines of code, and it will take many, many years to process all that, and test it, to make sure the changes in the date routines will not cause regression in other areas, and to make sure it all fits together properly.
Q. There isn't going to be some diskette you can pick up at Wal-Mart and fix this problem?
 A. I don't believe there is any silver bullet, either for home PC's, or business, or government. It's a very, very labor-intensive process. There will be tools that will make the process a little bit easier, provide a methodology and a structure.
But it's a very convoluted process because everyone developed programs in their own way, according to their own logic and their own personality, and it's very difficult to correct that with one program or algorithm. It's got to be done one system at a time.
We've converted 5 million lines of code for Phoenix, and put it back into production -- but that's only one-third of what we have to do.
Q. Why hasn't this problem been fixed before now?
 A. Time and expense. Everybody's trying to get the latest and the greatest, and get done the things they need to get done immediately, and this was a postponeable project for a long, long time. Companies have budgets, they have regulations to follow, new products to put out, and this was something they could push off. Unfortunately, they can no longer push it off. We're right up against the wall now.
Q. How much is it going to cost to fix all the computers?
 A. Well, the Gartner Group in Stamford is estimating that it's going to cost $1 trillion worldwide. And, it's going up every month, because of supply and demand. As demand increases and the supply of programmers decreases, the cost is skyrocketing. The price of programming has doubled over the last two years.
A company that has 25 million lines of code, it's costing over $1 a line just to address this problem. And it all likelihood it's going to go up to $2 and $3 a line by the time 1998 and 1999 roll around.
Q. Haven't most businesses starting to address it?
 A. As of right now, probably only 25 percent of companies have an active project.
Q. Are there enough programmers to deal with the issue?
A. I don't think there are enough in the United States, no. We have about 100 openings right now, and we have eight recruiters working. We just invested $100,000 in a system to help us locate people. We have tremendous shortages.
That's one of the reasons we set up a programming operation in India, an area that has a lot of people, people who are mathematically inclined, who are taught from kindergarten computer literacy. And even though we're paying them well by their standards, it's less expensive than doing it over here.
Q. How long have you been working on the problem with Phoenix?
 A. More than two years. In addition to more than 15 million lines of code in their mainframe system, their personal computer systems and support systems number in the thousands. That is going to be a whole other level.
As we started to see how big the problem was for Phoenix, we also realized everyone in financial services was going to face something similar. We decided, why don't we take this out to the rest of the market? That's why we created Command 2000.
Q. If only 25 percent of companies are fixing the problem now, what was the percentage two years ago when Phoenix started?
A. This is a guess, but I would say less than 5 percent. It was very unusual for a company to have that much foresight.
Q. What range of costs going to be, from small to large businesses?
 A. It can go anywhere from a couple of million dollars, to $150 million. It's going to depend on what solution they use.
Q. Are companies ignoring the problem or are they not aware?
 A. There is a lack of awareness out there. One of the steps in our Command 2000 program is management awareness, where we go in and help senior management understand how big a problem this is, and how expensive it is, and how disastrous it's going to be if they don't tackle it.
You take companies that are busy with acquisitions or mergers, that are busy with Federal regulations or growth plans, chances are the board of directors are not going to be worried about the year 2000. It's the squeaky wheel syndrome.
Again using Gartner's statistics, 20 to 25 percent of companies are not going to be ready by the year 2000, and are going to face a serious risk of major lawsuits, bankruptcies, erroneous data coming out of their systems.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Miami's Shaken Image Shakes Its County Too

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
AT a time when Miami's tourism industry has rebounded from the tourist murders of the early 1990's and visitors have been flocking to the area in record numbers, officials here are having a case of the jitters. Miami's image has suffered another black eye, this time from the one-two punch of a $68 million deficit and the threat of a vote to abolish the city itself.
Miami's troubles have made national headlines since last summer, when three top city officials resigned to face Federal corruption charges and it was disclosed that the city was near bankruptcy. Since then, the city's bond rating has dropped to single-b from triple-b and Florida's Governor has appointed an oversight board to help the city tighten its belt and carry out a recovery. 
 "I can see tourists saying, 'They can't even pay the police. Should we even be there?' " said Mayco Villafana, spokesman for the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau.
The irony, of course, is that the city of Miami's troubles have little to do with the 28 other municipalities of Dade County, the "greater Miami" metropolitan area that uses Miami as a brand name. Most of the attractions that draw tourists are scattered around these other cities, including the Art Deco district and the South Beach section in Miami Beach, Miracle Mile in Coral Gables and the beaches of Key Biscayne.
Miami, the city, does not even have a beach, the main lure for domestic and international travelers along with the weather, shopping malls and restaurants.
So in a pre-emptive strike, representatives from other cities and tourism organizations have been dispatched to major tourism markets -- the Northeast and Canada, Europe and South America -- to spread the message that Miami is not Miami. The officials stress that all the main infrastructure a tourist may worry about -- airport and seaport, the bus and rail system, water and sewers and major highways, the tourist-oriented police programs -- are controlled by Dade County, which is financially stable, not any one city. They have also tried to put the recent negative publicity about Miami in perspective.
"The city of Miami represents only 17 percent of the residents of Greater Miami and the Beaches," or 365,000 of more than 2 million, the Visitors Bureau president, Merrett R. Stierheim, wrote in a memo fired off last month to his membership. "The city of Miami accounts for only 35 square miles out of the 2,000 square miles that comprise Greater Miami and the Beaches."
Neighbors like Miami Beach, while optimistic that their sister city will survive, have also tried to distance themselves from the mess. Mayor Seymour Gelber of Miami Beach said he was not as concerned about tourists as he was about investors who may have second thoughts about opening businesses in the area. "Tourists worry about the weather and about safety," he said. "When they go to the beach they don't ask, 'What's your bond rating?' "
Still, when Mr. Gelber was asked recently what the financial relationship was between Miami and his city, Miami Beach, he said: "I quickly explained that we're not related at all."
Miami, the city, does include the popular Cocowalk shopping and entertainment center in Coconut Grove, Bayside Marketplace near the Port of Miami and a downtown shopping district popular with tourists from Brazil and other countries. Some business owners have joined the movement that is calling for a referendum on whether Miami should dissolve itself and merge with Dade County's government, although opposition to such a move is also widespread.
Patty Allen, director of the Downtown Development Authority, the quasi-government agency that represents Miami's downtown business district, said that commercial property owners were split on the abolition issue but that what "people want to see is a restructure of some kind." She said there was a consensus that the city needed a more aggressive economic development plan and should use tax abatements, low interest loans and other incentives. But Ms. Allen said it was business as usual despite the financial crisis. "Investors understand the market is the market and Miami is a great market," she said. "They're looking at the rate of return."
Although tourism has actually risen recently, some tourism officials are still concerned. After the tourist murders of 1993, the impact was not felt until months later when tourism was off by nearly 100,000 visitors in 1994, reversing a trend of growth. The latest tourism figures, for the first nine months of 1996, show that 7.1 million tourists visited Dade County, a 2 percent increase over the same period in 1995.
"I don't think we're going to have any ill effect from this," Rob Snowden, Cocowalk's general manager, said of the fiscal problems.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Nyacks;
Unusual Diversity in A Bedroom Suburb

BYLINE: By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
THE Rockland County community known as the Nyacks -- the hilly riverfront villages of South Nyack, Nyack and Upper Nyack; the rural hamlet of West Nyack and an area west of Nyack known as Central Nyack -- is not a typical New York bedroom suburb.
For the tourists, the draw is Nyack itself, with a melange of about 50 antiques and crafts shops, one-of-a-kind clothing and gourmet shops, galleries and restaurants. 
 For residents, it is an interlocking jigsaw puzzle of races, cultures, religions, socio-economic groups and living styles with 20 houses of worship and 30 different languages or dialects spoken by schoolchildren.
"A lot of people that gravitate to the Nyacks come from Park Slope, Brooklyn Heights, the Upper West Side and the West Village because it has the diversity they're accustomed to and they like the urban flavor of a place where the schools are complicated," said Jo Baer, broker/owner of Baer and McIntosh Real Estate.
The Rev. Richard Gressle of Grace Episcopal Church in Nyack said he had been attracted to the village because the people there "think in ways that have been lost in the places I have lived."
"Like it or not, there are enough liberals left out there whose experience from the 60's and 70's is still their road map," he said. "They're out there in the community and they're determined not to fall into that quiescent numbness that seems to have gripped everyone else."
Eugene Gurlitz, a set designer, said he had moved to West Nyack because "it's a distinctive rural area even though it's close to the city."
"There's no blacktop on my driveway or sidewalks on my street," he said. "This is where I wanted to live, but I relate socially to Nyack more than I do anywhere else."
Residents live in housing as diverse as they are. Nyack and South Nyack have a mixture of less expensive, modest homes on quarter-acre lots interspersed with larger, more expensive Tudors and Victorians.
HOMES in Upper, Central and West Nyack can be good buys because they are in the Town of Clarkstown, which has lower taxes than the other Nyacks, which are in the Town of Orangetown. Upper Nyack has a larger selection than elsewhere in the Nyacks of grander homes on lots of one acre or more, Ms. Baer said. The median price of a house in West Nyack, which has many 1950's development homes on one-acre lots, was $225,000 in 1996, mirroring the median price of a home in South Nyack.
In Central Nyack, the median price of a home last year was $128,000, about 30 percent lower than Nyack's. Two-bedroom apartments in the three co-ops in the Nyacks, with a total of 258 units, go for $119,900 to $175,000. Prices of two- and three-bedroom condominiums at the 101-unit Clermont overlooking the river in Nyack range from $225,000 to $700,000 for the triplex penthouse.
Two-bedroom prices at three other condominiums, with a total of 85 units, range from $89,000 to $220,000.
"There is a bigger demand for rentals here than the supply," Ms. Baer said. The largest rental building is the 162-unit West Shore Towers on the Nyack riverfront, where one-bedroom apartments average $1,120.
The housing market in the Nyacks has been strong over the last five years and with few exceptions, housing prices have appreciated, according to the Rockland County Multiple Listing Service.
The median price of a home in South Nyack appreciated more than the other villages and hamlets in the Nyacks from 1990 to 1996, going to $256,000 from $154,000, to $256,000, according to the M.L.S. During the same period, the median price of a home in West Nyack rose to $220,000 from $205,000 to $220,000.
A MAJOR magnet for home buyers in the Nyacks is its schools. Sally Witte, a psychologist who lives in Nyack with her husband, Michael, a cartoonist, and their three children, said her experience in a private girls' school in the Midwest never caused her to question her values.
"But in this school system, because there are so many kinds of people," she said, "you're sort of always having to question what your values are.
"You're put in a situation where you have to struggle a bit more, but I think you can learn from this heterogeneity." She added: "In many ways, my children's education has been more complete than mine."
Said Roberta Zampolin, superintendent of the 3,000-student Nyack School District, which serves Nyack, Central, South and Upper Nyack, Grandview and Valley Cottage: "It's a constant struggle of how to meet all the needs of the different students, but we do a great job if you look at our statistics."
The district's Math League ranked No. 1 in the state, said Ms. Zampolin, adding that 93 percent of the high school graduates last June went on to higher education.
The district has three elementary schools for kindergarten through fifth grade, a middle school for sixth through eighth grade and Nyack High School. At a time when schools are cutting back classes in the arts, the high school offers electives in photography, media communications, including television and video production.
Students in West Nyack are served by the Clarkstown Central School District, where, said William Heebink, its superintendent, 93 percent of last June's graduates of South High School and North High School went on to college. He added that the schools had begun a $13 million program to update its computer capabilities.
The 8,600-student district, which has 10 elementary schools and a middle school, offers an innovative language program that sends sixth graders through 10 weeks each of Japanese, French, Italian and Spanish to help them choose the language they want to specialize in when they reach seventh or eighth grade.
Among the recent arrivals in the Nyacks is Mary Fisher, a mother, artist and AIDS activist who spoke at the last two Republican National Conventions. She is renovating her house after having moved from Maryland with her two children. "It's a difficult time for me," said Ms. Fisher, who herself has AIDS. "As my children grow, their questions get different and they get harder. I came here because I wanted to be in a strong community, one with the kind of people who would want to know and watch out for my children."
Touch, an acronym for Together Our Unity Can Heal, a nonprofit AIDS support group, has just opened its new quarters at 150 Broadway in South Nyack, where it serves 130 people with AIDS in Rockland County.
THE restaurants that line Broadway and Main Street in Nyack reflect the overall community's diversity. Among them are pubs, like O'Donoghue's Tavern; Italian restaurants, like Heather's Open Cucina; The King and I for Thai food; Ichi Riki for Japanese food; Southern Comfort for Southern home-cooking; Three Broadway and the River Club on the Hudson for fine dining and Strawberry Place for breakfasts with the children.
Children are offered food for thought at the hands-on Hudson Valley Children's Museum, at 21 Burd Street, a short walk from the river. They can play in an orchestra of spoons and coffee cans, fix a car, create crafts from recycled materials and explore a bubble factory. The museum, which is open Tuesdays through Sundays at varying times, charges $4 for admission for all.
For both the young and their elders, there is the Palisades Interstate Park system just north of the Nyacks, where they can hike on Hook Mountain, bike, picnic and swim, and the riverside Memorial Park at the end of Burd Street in Nyack, where there are two basketball and two tennis courts, a playground, boat launch and baseball field. And for $5, residents can work a small plot of land in the Nyack Community Garden.
Julius Petersen's Boatyard, founded in 1898, provides repair services, winter storage and 60 boat slips. The private Nyack Boat Club offers more than 150 moorings to its members.
Named by Dutch settlers for the Indians that first settled there, Nyack grew as a river port through the 19th century. The village prospered from a growth in factories, quarries and shipbuilding.
But by the end of the century, prosperity slowed and the village began to decline. With the opening of the Tappan Zee Bridge in 1955, the Nyacks became more accessible and downtown Nyack showed some signs of revival. But strip malls outside Nyack and, finally, the opening of the 800,000-square-foot Nanuet Mall in 1969, decimated the shopping district. Later, an influx of Federal subsidies and innovative business people began to turn the Nyacks around.
Antiques dealers bought up vacant storefronts and Nyack gained a reputation as an antiques mecca, although one afflicted by what merchants call a severe parking shortage.
"It's difficult to face a situation where people come in mad at you before you've done anything for them because they've been hunting for a parking space for so long," said Hank Hovorka, owner of Heather's Open Cucina. Many in the Nyack business community have voiced apprehension over the impending opening of the first three anchors in the 1.8-million-square-foot Pyramid Mall this spring in West Nyack. But Terry Hekker, Mayor of Nyack, said it could be a boon to the local economy. She said she hoped to open a kiosk at the mall that could promote the Nyacks and carry shoppers back to the villages by jitney.
One attraction that is expected to draw traffic is the 600-seat Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center, which opened last fall with a budget projected at $1 million for its first year. The theater is a renovation and expansion of the former Cinema East.
One of its prime movers is its president, Walter LeCroy who with 12 others contributed $25,000 or more to get the center under way. He moved to Nyack in 1981 because he liked to walk within a little village. "In another village, there wouldn't be a wider group of artists, or a theater to revive," he said.
