LOOK WHO MOVED INTO TOWN: The Nyacks have always been known for their interesting and often famous blend of residents. For one, there's the ghost who is believed to haunt 1 Leveta Place and was the focus of a state appellate court ruling in Manhattan in 1991 that realtors are required to disclose to prospective buyers accounts of the presence of ghosts in a house. Nyack has been home to actors and actresses, such as Ellen Burstyn and the late Helen Hayes; Jonathan Demme, who directed "Silence of the Lambs," and Edward Hopper, the artist, who grew up there. Last year Rosie O'Donnell, the actress and television personality, bought the Nyack home of Ms. Hayes for $770,500.. Ms. Hayes had done extensive renovations, so she called it Pretty Penny. Ms. O'Donnell is expected to do still more.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Rethinking The Meaning Of the Modern

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
AND THE WINNER IS -- MODERN architecture! That's the announcement the Museum of Modern Art would like to make when it finally selects an architect to design its expanded Manhattan campus. No big names. No razzle-dazzle designs in instantly recognizable signature style. No prizes for best song, most congenial contestant, wizard special effects. Rather, museum officials hope that the process of redesigning one of the world's most vital cultural institutions will itself be the lead performer.
Last week, the museum announced an international list of 10 architects invited to compete for the commission, a project that is not simply an addition or expansion but of another order of magnitude. The architects have been encouraged to rethink the configuration of the entire campus, which now includes the Dorset Hotel on West 54th Street, bordering the rear of the sculpture garden, which was acquired last February. 
 The architects are Wiel Arets and Rem Koolhaas of the Netherlands; Toyo Ito and Yoshio Taniguchi of Japan; the French architect Dominique Perrault; the Swiss team of Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron, and four New York firms: Steven Holl, Bernard Tschumi, Rafael Vinoly and the office of Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. By May, three finalists will be chosen. The commission will be awarded by the end of the year.
Speaking on behalf of the Museum of Modern Art's trustees, Glenn D. Lowry, the director, said the selection process itself would help to "conceptualize a modern museum in the context of the future."
The museum convened a three-day conference last October at the Rockefeller estate in Westchester County, to discuss the expansion on a conceptual level. Discussions were held between curators, critics and architects, including several, like Peter Eisenman and Arata Isozaki, who were not included on the final list. Last fall, the museum also sponsored a series of public lectures and symposiums on the expansion project. Another series will take place when the 10 designs are put on view.
The architects on the list are relatively youthful. Most are in their 50's. Some architects who were not invited to compete have expressed surprise, bafflement, even anger, at this emphasis on younger architects -- as if the museum had deliberately chosen to take a slap at more established architects like Norman Foster, Richard Meier and Charles Gwathmey. These architects, a generation older than those on the Modern's list, are the names one expects to find on short lists for prestigious projects.
Actually, the Modern's tilt toward youth makes perfect sense. The architects on the list represent a generation that has felt compelled to reinvent the idea of modernism for itself. The generation preceding theirs includes a number of distinguished architects, like Foster, Meier and Gwathmey, whose work is strongly rooted in the values of the modern movement. Still, at a pivotal moment, the work of these designers was less influential than that of Robert Venturi, Charles Moore, Michael Graves and others of their contemporaries who chose to promote the the post-modern cause.
Younger architects, especially in the United States, grew up having to reckon with the repudiation by their elders of 20th-century history. They were educated in a climate that subjected modernism to constant criticism and ridicule. The sterility of modern architecture. The anti-urbanism of modern architecture. The indifference of modern architects to popular needs and tastes.
The Museum of Modern Art, meanwhile, was undergoing its own crisis of identity. In the 1970's and 80's, the museum stood at a crossroad. How could a modern museum survive in what was widely labeled a post-modern world? Had modernism become a closed historical chapter? Should the museum simply devote itself to filling out the record in a story that had reached the end? Or did modernism represent a set of values that could feed into the future?
The Modern itself had helped to precipitate this crisis. In 1966, the museum published Robert Venturi's "Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture," a book that instantly became the bible of post-modernism, the text that encouraged architects to repudiate the esthetic values on which the museum had been founded. Later, Philip Johnson, who was a founding director of the museum's architecture and design department as well as a prominent museum trustee, further complicated matters when he began crusading against the modern movement he had once championed.
Arthur Drexler, the museum's longtime architecture curator, didn't help matters much by basically sitting on his hands throughout this period, committing his department to what seemed like an endless recycling of shows on the great modern masters. In 1984, Drexler commented to me that the only contemporary designed objects he judged adequate to the museum's esthetic standards were pieces of military hardware, like the Stealth bomber. As one contemplated the Bell helicopter that still hovers at the entrance to the design galleries, one imagined Drexler as an embattled figure sitting atop a stockpile of weapons, manning the barricades against post-modern incursions.
The 1985 expansion by Cesar Pelli, is an enduring symbol of that crisis. Here the museum entrusted its redesign to an architect whose adherence to modern principle, never particularly firm, soon lapsed into a purely commercial practice dedicated to producing decorative building skins. Pelli was the perfect architect for a moment when the museum hoped to insure its future not by esthetic but economic means, erecting a profit-making condominium tower on its property and refashioning the museum itself in the image of a suburban mall.
SINCE THEN THERE HAS BEEN a changing of the guard: a new president, a new director, new curators, a rejuvenated department of architecture and design. This new group, mostly under age 50, is of a generation that regards the modern, and the Modern, from quite a different perspective. Born well after the pioneering days of the modern movement, this generation accepts as a matter of course that the "modern movement" and the polemical struggles of that movement are a matter of history. But they also perceive modernism as an ongoing way of relating to the present.
John Summerson, the British critic and historian, was referring to the modern movement when he wrote in 1947 of the need to "sort out those aging ideas that get encrusted round past creative achievement and clog the proper working of the imagination in changing times." For Summerson, in other words, modernism had already grown stale 50 years ago, a decade before the Seagram Building went up. But for many architects today, especially the generation represented by the list, the sorting out of aging ideas could serve as an excellent definition of modernism itself. The definition evokes no particular style or philosophy. It merely proposes that time moves on, that the imagination can be stifled, that creativity is, in part, an act of mental hygiene.
The museum's trustees are wise to view the process of selecting an architect as a creative venture in its own right. It's an opportunity for the museum to sort out some aging ideas that got encrusted round the institution itself. Like the idea that there is some inherent conflict between the traditional and the modern: the second grew organically out of the first. Or that historically there was only one correct, canonical "modernism" rather than Futurism, Constructivism, Bauhaus, de Stijl, Expressionism and many other modernisms.
We value the Modern as a place where this sorting-out goes on, where modernism is presented within a framework of changing awareness. Many of the architects on the museum's list have embraced that framework as the essence of contemporary architecture. Pioneer modernists spoke of transforming entire cities, of remaking the world. Modern architects today are more likely to speak of heightening our consciousness of the modern world. The function they see for architecture is much like the museum's own historical goal.
I hope they won't forget that it's also one of the world's great spots for dating.

The 10 architects invited to compete for the commission have been encouraged to reconfigure the use of the entire campus to create a modern museum for the future. HEADLINE: NEW MATH, SAME STORY

 BODY:
Paul R. Krugman did a good job of describing income inequality in his article "New Math, Same Story" (Jan. 5).
I offer a view from the production floor that may explain one cause of the problem. 
 1. Management encourages workers to improve productivity. Workers are promised that any improvements they make will not result in loss of jobs.
2. Workers organize in "quality circles," make productivity improvements, are commended at company meetings and have their pictures displayed on posters in the hallway.
3. Demand for the product slumps. Management shuts down several production lines. Some workers are "temporarily" laid off.
4. Demand increases. More efficient production rates allow production lines to remain shut down. Workers who were laid off are forced to take lower-paying jobs in the service sector.
So much for promises.
 
ARTHUR D. SIEGEL
Cheshire, Conn.

HEADLINE: NEW MATH, SAME STORY

 BODY:
Krugman correctly points out that statistical changes in the Consumer Price Index will not change the fact that inequality has widened in recent decades. But the story is even sadder than he suggests. 
 The consumer goods that have held steady or dropped in cost have been, disproportionately, luxury items (computers, audio equipment, cars and long-distance phone calls). The things that have increased in cost have been those essential to low-income and young families (new homes, college tuition, medical care, public transportation and basic telephone service).

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Sales and Service Operations;
As Industry Changes, Networks Feel a Ripple Effect

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
AS corporate America downsizes and looks for outside suppliers for non-core operations like property management, the real estate industry is reorganizing itself as well, consolidating into fewer, but bigger, companies that can take over the jettisoned corporate departments.
This is having an impact on real estate networks, those far-flung associations of usually independent companies that seek to have a means of referring to affiliates in other regions on a fee-splitting basis. 
 It is also leading to the development of new types of organizations, including at least one group that emphasizes offering a broad variety of services, rather than the traditional referrals.
Local real estate sales and service operations have long sought to broaden their ability to hold on to clients and increase revenues by affiliating in some fashion with companies in other cities.
Some, such as Cushman & Wakefield, Grubb & Ellis and CB Commercial, have done so by acquiring or establishing corporately owned offices in major cities. Cushman & Wakefield, for instance, employs over 1,500 people in 40 offices nationally.
But others say this is an overly expensive approach that does not guarantee a uniform level of quality, despite having the same brand name over the door. These companies have joined with others in a variety of networks, which range from licensing operations with a central corporate staff to voluntary associations governed by membership boards.
With these national -- and increasingly international -- affiliations, a company that handles a corporation's business in New York can maintain the relationship, even if the corporation wants to expand to California, Georgia or Hong Kong.
"It is important to provide one-stop shopping," said James D. Kuhn, the president of Newmark & Company Real Estate. "If I have a client in New York who wants space in Hong Kong, I'd go there with him, meet with an affiliate and do the transaction."
Without this ability to provide service in remote markets, real estate executives say, they may put their New York business at risk if a client decides to shifts all its activities to another agency.
Recently, networking was in the news as Newmark cut its 10-year relationship with the New America Network and announced it would be joining The Commercial Network. And executives of the old Edward S. Gordon Company, now Insignia/ESG, said they planned to acquire real estate companies in other cities, despite being a founder of Oncor International, a membership oprganization.
Mr. Kuhn said Newmark made the shift from New America, which is a privately owned company that supplies services to brokers, to T.C.N. for two major reasons: to gain access to more international markets and to gain a greater measure of control of its own operations.
"It is extremely important to be represented internationally today and T.C.N. is in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Beijing and all over Europe," Mr. Kuhn said. "The other thing is that New America is owned by Gerry and Jeff Finn and we think it is important that we control our own destiny. We don't want outside individuals making decisions that affect our business."
T.C.N., he noted, is owned by its member firms.
Jeffrey M. Finn, the president and chief operating officer of New America, said the purpose of his company was to provide research, communications and other services to brokers, many of them in smaller markets. "We have a staff of over 50 people to provide services, including sophisticated technology to link over 200 offices in North America," he said.
John Powers, an executive managing director at Insignia/ESG, acknowledged that a company on the prowl for acquisitions may not fit comfortably with the collegial style of Oncor. The network was founded in 1977 at least partially to offset the growing influence of corporate real estate service providers.
"There was a feeling among members that there was still a place for strong regional firms," Mr. Powers said. He said the members referred business to each other and discussed mutual problems. "We could discuss things in a nonthreatening way," he said. "You were dealing with a colleague, not a competitor."
BUT now, he said, many companies are reducing the size of their internal real estate operations and looking to outside contractors to provide these services. Many corporate real estate managers prefer dealing with a structure that looks like their own, he said, with a strong central command and widespread subsidiaries under apparently tight control.
"The problem is that networks have not been as successful as national firms in forging strategic alliances with corporations," he said. "There really is not much difference, because all companies have brokers who are independent contractors. But reality is perception."
He said Insignia/ESG's relations with the other companies in Oncor would depend in large part on where Insignia makes acquisitions, turning colleagues into competitors. Nevertheless, he said "we have a high regard for the firms in Oncor and we will find a way of continuing to work with them."
Networks can continue to be viable in the current economic environment, but they have to adopt a more corporate appearance, said Patrick Moultrip, the president of T.C.N. "For the last three years I have been recruiting people who know how to talk to corporate America, because that's their background," he said. "For example, I'm out of Sun Microsystems."
He said the network has about 15 people on staff now, in addition to the staffs of the network's members. "We can put together a SWAT team overnight to help a company that is downsizing and outsourcing and we will do it for as fixed fee," he said. "And if tomorrow they don't need us, we're not there."
Ownership, rather than alliances, produces a more consistent, higher quality service, argues David Gialanella, a senior managing director of Cushman & Wakefield. "When you are representing a client nationally, they are looking for quality, consistency and control," he said.
"There is a fundamental restructuring of the real estate business and industry is looking a real estate companies as service providers, not just deal doers. That is hard to do in a nonstructured environment."
He said that Cushman & Wakefield, in addition to its domestic array of offices, has formed partnerships with companies overseas so it can work with corporations operating global businesses. "Companies are recognizing that international real estate is as important as domestic," Mr. Gialanella said. Cushman & Wakefield covers Europe through Healey & Baker in London, Asia through Marlin Land in Hong Kong, South America through two affiliates in Sao Paulo and Canada through Royal LePage in Toronto.
"A network is a body without a head," said David Binswanger, president of Binswanger Inc., a Philadelphia-based firm, that owns all 18 of its domestic offices and has alliances with a British and a German company to handle international assignments.
"A client like Kodak would deal with the same person regardless of whether the job was in Italy, Mexico or Brazil," he said. "We would take advantage of local expertise, but the deal would be handled centrally to maintain quality."
THE real estate industry will evolve into different forms as it consolidates , said Stewart Forbes, president of Colliers International Property Consultants in Boston. "It similar to what happened in the securities industry after fixed commissions were abolished," he said. "You ended up with fewer but larger firms. That's what's going on in real estate now. You are going to end up with a few firms dominating the industry nationally and some niche players locally. It is going to be very difficult to be in between."
Robert L. Billingsley, executive vice president of Colliers ABR, Inc., the New York affiliate of the Colliers system, describes it as a "federation of stockholders." He said participation in the Colliers system gives the firm access to services, such as the work of a 12-person research department, that a purely local firm could not support, and influential contacts in far away places.
"Colliers Jardine handles East Asia," he said, referring to an alliance with the noted trading company. "It's interesting to watch the eyes of corporate officials bulge out when they realize that your local partner is Jardines."
While most networks and national real estate companies emphasize their geographic reach, one New York-based grouping of companies focuses on the breadth of services offered. The Arete Group (pronounced are-TAY after a Greek word for excellence) has brought together real estate brokers and planners, a law firm specializing in tax incentives, construction and project managers and financiers in one loosely affiliated organization.
"Arete is a federation, not a network, and it is transaction driven, not referral driven," said James Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a member of the group specializing in office space. "We are not all sales people. We have attorneys, architects and developers. The business is moving away from the old-line brokerages."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We think it is important that we control our own destiny," says James D. Kuhn, president of Newmak & Company Real Estate. "We don't want outside companies making decisions that affect our business." (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
What's Next for Riverfront Bayonne Military Base?

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE land juts out like a shelf from the edge of Bayonne two miles into the Hudson River, where it spills into Upper New York Bay. And from one spot at the eastern tip of the 437-acre site, the Statue of Liberty, the Manhattan skyline and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge come into view.
It is here where the 62,000 residents of this old industrial city are preparing to confront their future. Sixteen months ago the Pentagon ordered the shutdown of the Military Ocean Terminal by 2001, ending this man-made peninsula's more than 50 years as a military base and leaving it one of the last prime parcels of real estate available along the Hudson River shoreline. 
 Some 110 bases nationwide have been closed or reconfigured since 1988, according to the Washington-based National Association of Installation Developers, a nonprofit group that works with communities to re-use bases. Bayonne's base, from which cargo was sent to battlefields around the world, is the largest in New Jersey set to close.
Since the announcement, the city has shaken off the shock of the closing of the base, its largest employer, which will mean the loss of 1,924 civilian jobs, half of them held by local and county residents. But the challenge for this Hudson County community is how to shape what will be the most significant redevelopment in 40 years in Bayonne.
To counter the economic blow of the closing, the city is negotiating with the Federal Government, the landowner, to acquire the site, a maze of warehouses, barracks and docks. It would then be subdivided, with some parcels sold or leased to developers and others kept for public uses like schools.
The city is reviewing its options for the site, which must undergo an environmental cleanup, to be paid for by the Government. At this early stage -- a master plan is to be completed in October -- the direction is toward a mixed-use development focused on industrial uses, from light manufacturing to warehousing.
Other possible uses include television and film production, a community college and a cruise-line terminal.
"No option has been foreclosed," Mayor Leonard P. Kiczek said. He is also chairman of the 11-member Base Re-use Commission set up to look into uses for the old site.
Meanwhile, the city is working with developers to turn 120 adjacent waterfront acres, once partly a landfill, into a golf course. And retail projects, including two shopping centers, are to rise along nearby Route 169 by this spring.
"The site may have potential, but over 25 years," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "Bayonne has to be sure not to compete with the unused waterfront in other cities, which have the advantage because they have a base on which to build."
Mayor Kiczek is upbeat. "The emphasis will be on producing jobs and tax revenue, creating a new generation of prosperity for the city," he said of the site, which makes up a fifth of Bayonne's land. While he did not preclude the possibility that a "fragment of the former base could be used for residential development," he said he wanted to make sure that his city's residents would not be overburdened with taxes.
The city watched its tax base slip when industries left. It was bypassed by the mid-80's boom because of a lack of transportation links, together with sewage and environmental problems.
Frank P. Perrucci, 56, like many other residents is hoping that the base's re-use will bring property tax relief to the area, where homeowners bear a heavy tax burden. "It is what's needed to help keep oldsters -- and youngsters -- in Bayonne," he said.
Edward J. Kaczka, a 48-year-old resident who owns a local insurance brokerage concern, added: "As long as what goes on there brings in services, it sounds good to me. What I don't want is something that will become a separate part of Bayonne."
FOR others, the concern is that nothing will get built.
Mayor Kiczek, who as a teen-ager delivered fast-food chicken to soldiers at the base, said the city for decades had most of its commerce along its eastern shoreline and most of its residential areas further west. "We have learned the lesson that this layout of our community works best," he said.
He says a redeveloped base area could replace twice the number of jobs lost, increase the city's revenue from property taxes and open the waterfront to the public. The Government pays no real estate taxes on the site, which except for special times, like Armed Forces Day, has essentially been cordoned off from the community's tight neighborhoods of neat houses.
"We want to see new jobs growing before the base closes," said Brig. Gen. Gilbert Harper, the installation commander.
The decision on how best to use the site is largely up to the community and the re-use commission. Final approval, however, rests with the Government.
Suitors have been drawn to the base like miners in search of gold. Some of the plans are grand, including one to build a $1.5 billion world trade center. The project, called Gateway USA, was conceived by Gordon Bishop, a former columnist for The Newark Star-Ledger, and Marwan M. Sadat, president of Sadat Associates, an environmental engineering and science firm in Princeton. Designed by Michael Graves of Princeton, it would have six trade pavilions on 150 acres. Plans for the rest of the site include hotels, cruise ships and education-entertainment centers.
Another, by World City Corporation of Manhattan, would make Bayonne the summer home of the world's largest ocean liner, which the company wants to build.
The 6,200-passenger floating hotel, a quarter mile long and 21 stories high, would also be the catalyst around which the base would be developed with, among other uses, offices, movie theaters, a community college and parkland, its sponsor says.
Knut Ulstein Kloster, the founder of Norwegian Cruise Lines, conceived the concept of the floating hotel, which would be called America World City, and put up $34 million for its design. World City still needs a Federal loan guarantee for most of the ship's $1.2 billion cost.
Other plans include building a recycling plant and blowing up some warehouses for a movie. The longshoremen's union wants to lease part of it for a bulk freight port and the U.S.S. Battleship New Jersey Commission wants to tow the ship from the West Coast to her namesake state and berth it in Bayonne, where it would be maintained as a museum. And some groups, including the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, are hoping to put in a container port similar to those in Elizabeth and Newark.
But Bayonne has committed itself to only two uses so far. About 100 Coast Guard personnel will move into 25 acres of the former base next June as part of its deployment off of Governors Island.
And 18 more acres will be for park-and-ride lots to serve the state's 20.5-mile light rail system along the Hudson River, the southern half of which, to be completed by 1999, starts in Bayonne. There are also discussions to extend the line into the site and eventually to a hoped-for fleet of ferries to Manhattan.
OF the other proposals, Mayor Kiczek said, "As the plans evolve and commitments become more serious, they can be incorporated into the re-use plan." He said the trade center concept could work at the site and bring something new to the riverfront.
There are challenges ahead, including the cost and time to improve and clean up the site. "There are areas of concern on the site, but they are not widespread or insurmountable," said James Monkowski, chairman of the environmental subcommittee on the base re-use commission.
It can take years to redevelop some bases. So towns must "manage their expectations and be flexible" to meet the market, said Ellen Baer, a principal at Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler, a Manhattan-based consulting firm that has worked on base re-use plans.
Plus, the redevelopment must navigate through a layer of military bureaucracy. "What makes the process succeed are community consensus and political leadership," Ms. Baer said. "Otherwise, you have a ship with no captain that floats out to sea."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Leonard P. Kiczek, at the Bayonne Military Ocean Terminal, says "no option has been foreclosed" on redeveloping it. The base, which is to close by 2001, gets a Coast Guard contingent in June. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Grant Advances Bay Shore's Downtown Revival

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: BAY SHORE

 BODY:
THE announcement last month that the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York had allocated $520,000 in grant money toward the construction of 78 units of below-market-rate housing has given this South Shore community another leg up on its efforts to revitalize its downtown.
"A lot of work has been done by the town to put together an economic development plan for Bay Shore," said Thomas A. Isles, Planning Commissioner for the Town of Islip, of which Bay Shore is an unincorporated area. 
 "Housing is another method of encouraging redevelopment, and the project announced three weeks ago is going into that direction," he said.
The housing, which still needs more than $2 million in state funds before work can proceed, is only one component of what is planned downtown. Two major projects, an aquarium and a new home for Touro College's School of Health Sciences, offering bachelor's degrees in such things as physical and occupational therapy and a master's in biomedical sciences, have also been proposed, along with other redevelopment.
Many of the Main Street storefronts carry "For Rent" or "For Sale" signs because of limited demand for the hamlet's 350,000 square feet of retail space. Most of the Main Street buildings were constructed 40 years ago when Bay Shore became Suffolk County's regional retail center.
An overall economic development plan completed by Town of Islip last year, which focused largely on Bay Shore, called for the hamlet's business district to "reinvent" itself.
One proposed direction was to find new uses for some of the surplus retail space, by converting it to offices, for example. Live/-work space for artists and housing above stores were other proposals.
Medical office space is in demand because of the 451-bed Southside Hospital at the east end of Main Street. But retail can remain the major activity because distinctive "niche" stores like Bay Shore Lighting and Home at 143 West Main Street and Bay Shore Furs at 12 East Main Street still attract "destination" shoppers to the downtown and do well, Mr. Isles said.
The development plan also proposes that Bay Shore capitalize on its location as a gateway to Fire Island by promoting tourism. About 400,000 ferry riders pass through the community each year.
State and Federal grants will be used to pay for street improvements that will include new lighting and paving and landscaped walkways linking municipal parking lots to Main Street. A building on the south side of Main Street just north of Watchogue Creek will be demolished to open up the view to the waterfront.
"With our long-range plan we hope to make Bay Shore the thriving community it once was," said Pete McGowan, the Islip Town Supervisor.
AMONG potential tourist attractions is the proposed $60 million Long Island Aquarium. The project, which would be privately financed, has received a $750,000 grant from the New York State Urban Development Corporation for a feasibility study and for preliminary designs.
The 2.5-acre aquarium site, on Park Avenue north of Main Street, is owned by Islip's Community Development Agency and leased to the aquarium's promoters for a nominal fee. When construction starts, it is to be sold to the group, called The Long Island Aquarium, for its appraised value.
A campaign to raise $12 million from private contributors is about to start and a $48 million public tax-exempt bond offering is expected to be issued in September, said Artie Dromerhauser, the Long Island Aquarium's executive director.
The preliminary design is for a 97,000-square-foot educational and entertainment complex with a three-level, 1-million-gallon aquarium and a 400-seat theater. Cambridge Seven of Cambridge, Mass., designers of the National Aquarium in Baltimore, among others, are the architects.
The proposed school is the Touro School of Health Sciences, a division of Touro College, which is negotiating to purchase a county-owned 83,000-square-foot office building on Union Boulevard. The school, which has 600 students and a faculty of 150, is currently located in Dix Hills.
The town was able to obtain $3 million in Federal grants and loans for the school to enable it to purchase and renovate the building. Some county functions, such as a health clinic, would stay.
"If you are looking for a way to have a dramatic impact on a community that's seen better times, this is certainly one way to do it," said Edwin W. Finder, the former executive director of the Bay Shore Business Improvement District, a business group, and now its consultant.
The 78-unit housing project proposed for the downtown would replace dilapidated residential structures on Smith Avenue north of Main Street. The town already owns some of the properties. The rest will be acquired through negotiation or condemnation.
The land would be turned over to the Long Island Housing Development Fund Company, the development arm of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit housing group based in Hauppauge. The entity will construct the new units which will include a mix of for-sale housing and rental apartments.
Under the plan, there will be 52 three-bedroom attached and semi-attached houses, expected to sell for $74,000 to $85,000. Of the 26 rental apartments, which will be owned and managed by the Town of Islip Housing Authority, 10 will be for families and 16 for the elderly. To qualify for the houses, purchasers can make no more than 80 percent of the area's median income of $66,000, and the income of renters cannot exceed 50 percent of the area's median.
Owners of the existing houses will receive relocation assistance from the town, or they will be able to purchase one of the new houses. Tenants will receive similar assistance, or they will be able to elect to move into one of the new rental units.
EAB, a Uniondale bank, would provide a $4.335 million construction loan for the 52 for-sale units, as well as end loans for purchasers.
That commitment and the $520,000 Federal Home Loan Bank grant that Representative Rick A. Lazio, Republican of Babylon and Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato helped secure, are "critical" in helping the $12.3 million project get the $2.2 million in state funds that it still needs, said Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership.
"It indicates that the private sector looks at the project as a good business deal," he said, "and one of the state's requirements is that there be a leveraging with private sector money."
The project's impact would be far greater than 78 new housing units, said Robert J. Klein, a vice president of the EAB Community Development Corporation, a subsidiary of EAB. "Once private developers see this happen, they will put up market-rate housing," he said.
Private investment is, in fact, already flowing into the downtown. Louis J. Modica, a local developer, recently acquired a 14,000-square-foot vacant office structure at 85 West Main Street. He is fixing it up to rent to a medical group.
THE building, known as the Omni, was started in the 1980's but was never completed and had become a symbol of the community's failure, said Mr. Isles, the town planner.
Steven H. Bankin of Bay Shore is renovating an 18,000-square- foot building at Main Street and Fourth Avenue as new retail space on the ground level with nine apartments ranging in size from a 750-square-foot studio to a 1,400-square-foot two-bedroom unit to occupy the upper two floors. Rents will range from $750 to $1,400 a month, he said.
"There are a lot of things that are about to happen," said Susan Barbash, a local resident and developer, and also the co- chair of the Bay Shore-Brightwaters Summit Council.
The organization was started in 1994 by the Bay Shore Board of Education and its school superintendant, Evelyn Holman. As an umbrella group for local organizations it has become an influential voice on behalf of residents, holding an annual open meeting for the discussion of problems and ideas.
"Touro to a great extent was attracted to Bay Shore because we have been able to demonstrate that this is a community that is coming back," Ms. Barbash said.

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Justifying Government Jobs

 BODY:
James Treffinger, the Essex County executive, recently asked all county employees to write letters justifying their jobs. What would you say?

The Wrong Targets 
 The idea of the exercise -- self-justification -- is obnoxious. It is bullying by the boss. Let the boss justify himself or herself and manage the work force intelligently and properly.
 
DONALD SINGLETON
Jersey City
 
The Wrong Emphasis
I work for the state (not New Jersey) in social services. The politically correct response would be pushing how much money I save the taxpayers. But the real focus should be how much good I can do for the taxpayers, and non-taxpayers, in my state. I realize in days of privatization this may not be the proper response. Doing the minimum for the minimum seems to be the current goal. While it is not the response that budget crunchers are looking for, service is why we are there.

BILL REVILL
Meriden, Conn.
 
Justifying Justification
Corporations justify their existence in a free market every day with every exchange of goods or services. If people don't like a corporation or its product, they can boycott it with little repercussion; try boycotting the payment of your taxes.
 
CHRIS TOTO
Lawrenceville
 
A Necessary Job
As a government worker in New Jersey, my job is necessary, as I work for the Division of Unemployment. When other people are out of work, it is the responsibility of my agency to make sure the eligible people get their money and the ineligible people don't.
 
ROBIN BUTEN
Lawrenceville
 
Another Necessary Job
I don't need to justify my job in the Government: I'm in the Navy. I've gone to sea to keep this country free.
 
TERRY BRYANT
Groton, Conn.
 
Employees Are Maligned
I work in the private industrial sector, and my feeling is that government employees are unnecessarily maligned. They don't have the cushy gigs that the public would like to believe. The pay isn't all that great; the security is not what it once was, and longevity toward a retirement is getting tougher to achieve with each passing year. Still, I have to justify both my job and (hopefully) a small increase each year to my employer at review time. I also have to tell them what I plan to accomplish for them so that I can keep receiving my employment.
 
STEVE MARTINI
Wanaque

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The American Dream, In One Form or Another

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY; Brett Pulley reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Karen Tarver, a native of this hardscrabble city and a single mother, moved away to Plainfield more than 15 years ago, and as she said the other day, she "never planned to come back."
But a couple of months ago, while searching the newspaper for a new apartment for herself and her 12-year-old daughter, Joice, Ms. Tarver came across an advertisement seeking first-time home buyers. As a modestly compensated employee of a public utility company, Ms. Tarver had assumed that she could not afford to purchase a home. But that was before the advertisement led her to Orange Hecker Gardens, a development of affordable town homes in the Central Ward neighborhood of Newark. On Feb. 14, she is scheduled to become the owner of her very own, newly constructed, three-bedroom town house -- a $94,500 revival of the American dream, built on urban land once left for dead. 
 For Governor Whitman, Ms. Tarver is a shining example of how government should help build and rehabilitate affordable housing as a means of restoring decaying cities. By working with private banks, the state has provided low-rate construction loans and subsidies for projects like Orange Hecker, helping developers to build quality homes that can be sold to people like Ms. Tarver at a price they can afford.
Governor Whitman, in her recent annual address to the State Legislature, boasted of the success of her urban housing initiatives and pledged to pull together $100 million more from various entities (none of them being her own budget) to expand the program. "We are expanding people's opportunity to claim a part of the American dream," the Governor said in her speech. A few days later, the Governor joined Ms. Tarver for a ribbon-cutting ceremony in front of Ms. Tarver's new home.
But housing advocates and community development leaders contend that Mrs. Whitman's focus on ownership does not address the need for rental housing in the state's cities. The 2,250 new homes that Governor Whitman plans to build through her Urban Home Ownership Recovery Program will create more owners like Ms. Tarver, but many people simply cannot purchase their own homes, they have insisted.
"Ownership is good for people who are able to buy their own homes," said Diane Sterner, the executive director of Affordable Housing Network of New Jersey, an association of housing and community development groups. "But there's a terrible lack of resources for affordable rental housing."
Last year, Ms. Sterner's organization drafted legislation calling for a $290 million housing bond that would have attacked the problem at its foundation by providing money for affordable housing, job creation and rental assistance. The legislation, however, has languished in committee since Mrs. Whitman tucked it away there last June. "We're not overly optimistic at this point," Ms. Sterner admitted.
Instead of a huge general obligation bond like the one housing advocates have called for, much of the money going toward Governor Whitman's effort is coming from banks that already offer products like low-interest construction loans and mortgages. What the state has essentially done is helped to pull private lenders and their services together and sweetened the pot with a small amount in subsidies.
"With the pipeline that we're creating, we're demonstrating a need and a market to purchase houses in New Jersey," said Timothy J. Touhey, the executive director of the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, the quasi-independent agency that has created partnerships with 11 private banks and is also providing the subsidies.
Even if it cannot fully address the needs of those who cannot afford to purchase a home, the Governor's plan must at least reach the people like Ms. Tarver who can qualify to become homeowners but don't know it. Hubert Graham, the real estate broker responsible for selling the Orange Hecker project, said that although there is an obvious need for housing in the area, many people simply don't know that they can afford to buy a home for a monthly cost that is sometimes less than they are paying in rent.
"Many people can do what Ms. Tarver is doing, but they don't know that they can," he said. "What's required is an all-out effort to educate them."
Her chance to become a homeowner "just kind of came along," Ms. Tarver said. She is excited and optimistic, she added, about moving back to her native city to invest and share in its revitalization efforts. "This is just a great opportunity for me to become an owner," she said. Looking down the street at the older homes on the block, she said, "I can already see other people doing things to fix up their homes too."

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 15; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 802 words

HEADLINE: Instead of a New Bridge, Why Not Mass Transit?

 BODY:
"Still Needed: A Cross-Island Bridge" is akin to Lazarus rising from the dead. Unfortunately what is "scarce and in imbalance" is an understanding of the longtime resolved issues of his suggestion, even after 35 years of its repeated defeats.
Since 1965, when Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller killed an Oyster Bay location for a bridge, through 1973, when the Legislature repealed bridge legislation, since no Suffolk County crossing to the northeast would be able "to pay for itself," and in 1980, when Gov. Hugh L. Carey rejected a bridge crossing, since it would cost close to $2 billion, a Long Island Sound bridge crossing has been shown to be ill conceived. 
 Governor Carey did, however, establish an Action Committee for Long Island, which looked at all the transportation and economic factors associated with the construction of a new Long Island Sound bridge and after one year of intensive study rejected it overwhelmingly due to the main fact that commercial and industrial productivity on Long Island would not be changed with a new crossing
In my five years as a bridge administrator with the Coast Guard reviewing bridge-construction permits and environmental-impact assessments for bridges in six New England states, having reviewed some of the original planned Long Island Sound bridge-crossing proposals and over my last 20 years as an ecologist with the National Park Service, I have heard made every possible argument for the construction of a "new L.I. Sound bridge crossing."
Nothing has changed the fact that any new bridge crossing the Long Island Sound would have significant negative impacts on all Long Islanders. To name just a few:
(1) A new bridge crossing would cost an estimated $1.9 billion, with a $3 million to $4 million annual maintenance cost -- and that is in 1988 dollars.
(2) Bridges draw more traffic! They accommodate existing traffic levels, since they are planned for a "projected use," which ultimately becomes obsolete once a bridge is placed, due to increased use from the development, which is spurred on after the bridge is completed. Just look at Staten Island and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
(3) Bridge tolls in the past have slowed vehicles down, contributing to increased concentrations of air pollutants. Even with the E-Z Pass implementation, the volume of air-polluting vehicles, especially trucks, does not get less. Regional air-and noise-pollution impacts dramatically increase after a bridge is constructed. No bridge ever built reduced air-pollution or noise-pollution levels in its corridor.
(4) Bridge right-of-ways divide communities, due to property acquisition for bridge approaches, ramps and maintenance facilities. The new bridge will attract more trucks, especially since it would be an interstate connection, thus more pollution concerns.
(5) Bridges have significant impacts on waterways from hydrocarbon runoff, to paint and solvent discharges during maintenance to loss of wetlands from construction to potential dredging to maintain water navigation. The Long Island Sound Study does not include a bridge in its considerations for the restoration of the Sound.
(6) Bridge construction produces "short-term" jobs, which would need to be shared between two states. Stable long-term jobs are derived from mass transit and its ridership.
Mr. Waldman identifies a host of factors contributing to the Long Island transportation peritonitis, and that this blockage can only be cured by his radical cure, a new bridge across Long Island Sound.
Many sites have been suggested for this crossing. Yet all have been defeated, not as Mr. Waldman would have you believe "by a few bistate groups in local opposition," but rather by a diligent cadre of professional environmentalists who through experience know that any Long Island Sound bridge would be a pariah, not a panacea.
These solutions are suggested to Mr. Waldman to place his future efforts:
(1) Establish additional ferry services across Long Island Sound. They are less expensive and generate more revenues.
(2) Put the same heart-felt enthusiastic fervor into petitioning greater expenditures and subsidization of the Long Island Rail Road. Improving mass transit has repeatedly increased ridership. Look at the progress made in the City of New York over the last 10 years.
(3) With the merger of Brooklyn Union Gas with Lilco, there should be a movement to provide the incentives for greater reliance on gas-powered buses and minivan transportation links to help reduce our future demand on fossil fuels.
Mr. Waldman's "radical change" is not so radical at all. It is moribund and uninformed and would lead Long Islanders to another dead end.
 
JOHN T. TANACREDI
Valley Stream
Ecologist, National Park Service
Adjunct Professor, Polytechnic U.

HEADLINE: Park Your Car; Save Your Planet

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Joe Sharkey's Jersey column "Speak Up If H.O.V. Lanes Were Your Idea" (Jan. 19) reads like the provocation of a talk-show host. 
 He misses the most important reason for H.O.V. lanes: since driving is contributing to the ruining of the environment, it needs to be reduced.
Mr. Sharkey mentions several possible reasons for the decrease in car pooling from 1980 to 1990 (shifting work patterns and inadequate public transportation). He omits the most likely reasons: the number of freeway lane-miles is increasing, and the inflation-adjusted price of gas (per mile driven) is about the lowest it has been since 1950.
I can't take credit for the idea of H.O.V. lanes, but I think we need them to save the planet. Instead of one-lane H.O.V.'s, we should limit the number of non-H.O.V.'s to one lane.
 
DR. ROBERT BUDNY
Principal Research Physicist
Princeton University

HEADLINE: Five Acres, a Tax Break and a Bushel of Opinions About Farmland Law;
He Has 13 Acres And an Explanation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article "Five Acres, and a Tax Break?" creates a misleading and destructive impression. Most readers would reach the conclusion that homeowners with farmland assessment do not pay their fair share of taxes. This is not the case. 
 Our 13-acre farm is a typical case. We pay full residential property tax on our house and on our first two acres. (We live in a two-acre zoned area.) The farmland assessment applies only on the other 11 acres. Therefore, we pay at least as much tax as any other property owner with a similarly valued home. We pay our full share of our town's tax bill.
Since farmed (or undeveloped) land places no demand on the community for such services as school, police and fire protection, there is no logical reason why it should be taxed to pay for these services. The question is not why farms should get a "tax break." The question is why, in an allegedly fair and rational system, land without homes on it should be taxed, farmed or unfarmed.
An accompanying article, "How Tax Bills Stack Up Against a Flock of Sheep," further reinforces the misimpression by quoting statistics that 23 percent of the land in Mendham classified as farm produces one-fifth of 1 percent of tax revenue.
While a reader might conclude that homeowners in Mendham who also have property assessed as farmland pay only one fifth of 1 percent of Mendham's taxes, this is not the case. Such a homeowner with a $300,000 home pays as much property tax as any other resident of Mendham with a $300,000 home.
However, the taxes on the house fall under the category of "residential property," which the article says produces "83 percent of this years tax revenue." Therefore, the perceived tax shifting is an illusion.
The same situation exists for the corporations as well. While your article leads off with the eyebrow-raising fact that the peach orchard BMW maintains by its headquarters rates just $373.52 tax for its 20 acres, the reader must search through the body of the article to find that BMW pays $215,000 in taxes on its adjacent 21-acre headquarters. BMW receives no "tax break" on the commercially valuable office building. But would it be fair to tax BMW $215,000 a year for owning a peach orchard? And is it really likely that BMW or other corporations would continue to maintain a peach orchard if they had to pay $215,000 a year in taxes for the privilege? Would the critics prefer the likely outcome of eliminating the farm assessment: sale of the orchard, and the construction of homes or offices?
The article repeatedly refers to the owners of property assessed as farmland as wealthy and reinforces this impression by citing a few wealthy individuals who farm in New Jersey. But it should be obvious that thousands of small parcels in hundreds of communities in the state cannot possibly be all, or even mostly, owned by wealthy people. One of the law's great strengths is the low-acreage requirement that makes it possible for the middle class to own undeveloped land and to farm. The higher acreage requirements and greater sales requirements imposed by some states would exclude a majority of landowners who now get the farmland assessment, while the wealthy would still qualify.
When I speak to other New Jerseyans, regardless of their age or occupation, I find that there is one subject on which there is virtually unanimous consensus. People feel that the state is losing its natural beauty and that the day is not far off when this will no longer be a nice place to live. They mourn the loss of woods and fields; they object to noise and crowding, and they find the roads increasingly impassable. But most people see no way out: they feel the economic forces pushing us to overdevelopment are too strong to resist.
The Farmland Assessment Act has proved it is possible to resist the trend, at least to a degree. Before readers jump to conclusions about who benefits from the Farmland Assessment Act, they should consider the implications for all of us of increasing pressure for development.
Far from restricting the Farmland Assessment Act, a wise policy would expand it to an Open Space Act, rolling back taxes on woodlands, meadows and other natural space without requiring the owner to farm. The purpose of the act was not to help "farmers who make a living in farming"; it was to preserve what little is left of New Jersey's desperately needed open space.
 
JAMES MILLBAUER
Chester

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;
Pizza Job Sustained a Dream

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
Eleven A.M. on a Monday, at Ray's Pizza on Third Avenue and St. Marks Place, seemed like an odd place and an odd time for a celebration.
But that's what it was. Zoran Bandovic, a dark-eyed 40-year-old with an unruly graying brush cut, was sipping a Sam Adams. Danilo, 7 1/2, and Ivan, 4, were happily eating chocolate cake. Their mother, Jela, was drinking juice. 
 They had just come from the downtown offices of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, where they had been given approval for green cards. Mr. Bandovic pulled out his passport to show it, proudly.
There was even a good reason to celebrate at that very spot -- a generally unremarkable coffee, pizza and bagel place awash in East Village anonymity.
"I came to this country like a parachute," he said, dropping his right hand through the air onto the table. His wife and sons came later. "When I came, three years ago, my first job was at this pizzeria. I wanted to show them where I started." A flash of humor crossed his face. "I was a doctor from Yugoslavia."
He made a few friends. One, he said, told him not to stay in the East Village. Too strange. "But I find it very interesting," he said. "The people are friendly, open. The people are nice."
Jela interrupted with a wifely jab: "Nice girls!" He grinned.
After two weeks at Ray's, he said, he heard about Veselka, the Ukrainian diner on Second Avenue. "I went to work there, making sandwiches behind the counter. We were four doctors working over there, three from Poland!"
And he began volunteering at St. Luke's Hospital, to get closer to the world he left. In four months, he was offered a job in the pathology department. Now, he commutes from Astoria and studies for the grueling exam he will take in June to earn the right to be a doctor in America.
He left Belgrade, the Serbian capital, he said, mainly for economic reasons. He and his wife were both doctors, at a top university hospital, but at the time, 1994, inflation was so high that his salary effectively shrank to less than $10 a month.
But he did not leave until after he got word that he was being drafted. "I'm a Serb," he said. "She's Croatian, from Herzegovina," pointing to Jela. "Because of the war in Bosnia, I had been mobilized. Or, there was an attempt to moblize me. I was being sent to kill her parents, or have them kill me!"
He forgot his beer as he reminisced. Danilo and Ivan continued eating cake. Jela was quiet.
"The last day I was in Belgrade, they came to pick me up," he said. "But I was out taking the kids for a walk. So I was absent. God helped." ANDREA KANNAPELL

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Battle of the Braid Brigade

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
AT Walton High School in the Bronx, Andrean Russell was the student her peers went to when they wanted their hair braided.
Over the years, her clientele grew, along with her reputation as a skilled braider. Relatives and friends have sat patiently at Ms. Russell's knee for hours while she weaved African-inspired braids into hair once styled with straightening chemicals. 
 Last year, Ms. Russell began seriously thinking about turning her weekend passion into a career. "I began doing research to see what I needed to obtain a license to braid hair professionally," said Ms. Russell, 23, who is a legal secretary and part-time student at Bronx Community College.
The answer was not what she expected: a course of study at a cost of thousands of dollars and 900 hours.
"Nine hundred hours!" Ms. Russell said with a trace of indignation in her voice. "I don't see the need for all those hours of training when all I want to do is braid hair. Something I've done since I was a teen-ager."
Under a 1992 state law, natural hair stylists must complete a 900-hour cosmetology curriculum covering everything from chemical hair treatments and pedicures to shaving to receive a state license. The law has been sharply criticized by prospective hair braiders like Ms. Russell, who wonder why they should be subject to hundreds of classroom hours devoted to hot pressing and curling, or haircutting and shaping, disciplines that do not apply to braiding.
Ms. Russell says the requirements are excessive to the point that the state is depriving her of a civil right -- to pursue the occupation of her choice. She and Bonnie Best, a 30-year-old part-time braider in Cambria Heights, Queens, have filed a lawsuit that seeks to revise the licensing rules.
"Of the 900 hours required by the state, only 250 are devoted to braiding techniques," said Mark W. Smith, the lawyer who took on the case after conversations with Carla Brown, a professional braider who teaches a braiding course at York College in Jamaica, Queens. "But here's the catch. The cosmetology schools aren't offering the courses, and those who are qualified to teach it, like Ms. Brown, haven't been certified by the state to do so."
The lawsuit is likely to draw considerable interest in a bustling cottage industry of stylists catering to the growing popularity of African-inspired braids among black women. Braiding shops seem to have cropped up overnight along 125th Street in Harlem and Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. They are supplemented by the braiders, from high-school students to unemployed women to working professionals, who run informal styling operations in their homes, bartering their services for everything from cash to clothing.
In many cases, the stylists are African or Caribbean immigrants who use skills learned in their homelands to eke out a living in America. In other cases, they are young women who, like Ms. Russell, styled hair for friends and expanded to take on other clients. Many may be unaware of the licensing requirements. But Mr. Smith noted that even for those who want to satisfy the state requirements, it is impossible, because no privately run cosmetology school in New York offers a program or course of study that includes the required 900-hour curriculum.
"In fact, no person has ever completed the 900-hour curriculum," Mr. Smith said. "The only individuals who possess natural hair styling licenses are those who were grandfathered into the law when it was first created four years ago."
Gwen Lee, a spokeswoman for the New York Secretary of State, Alexander F. Treadwell, who is named as a defendant in the case, said she could not comment on matters under litigation. The Secretary of State's office oversees and controls the New York Division of Licensing, which issues natural hair styling licenses and created the requirements and curriculum for licensing. State officials had 30 days to respond to the complaint, which was filed on Jan. 6.
The case is but one of several involving hair braiders in more than half a dozen states. They are using legal weapons and political pressure to challenge laws that require anyone offering natural hair-care services to the public to complete lengthy and expensive programs at certified cosmetology schools.
In the last two years, Tennessee, Texas, Florida and the District of Columbia have created separate braiders' licenses, according to Taalib-Din Uqdah, the executive director of the American Hairbraiders and Natural Hair Care Association. Several other states, including Louisiana, Michigan and Illinois, are said to be considering similar laws. Although licensing laws for braiders vary from state to state, all require some basic hair-care training, from 16 hours in Florida to 1,500 hours in California.
Most braiders agree that training is necessary, especially courses devoted to recognizing scalp disorders and other health-related issues. But many question the government's right to sanction their craft, which has traditionally been learned from friends or relatives.
Government officials argue that the proliferation of braiding salons raises questions about sanitary practices and professional accountability; oversight is necessary, they argue, to protect dissatisfied customers. Partly with those concerns in mind, the State Legislature wrote language into the cosmetology law in 1992 that specifically requires braiders to be licensed, as are barbers and other hair stylists.
A "grandfather clause" in the law exempted licensed cosmetologists and hair salons that existed before 1992.
Members of the cosmetology industry, which had lobbied for tighter controls on braiders, applauded the new measures.
"If we have to take a minimum of 1,200 curriculum hours and pay up to $10,000 to learn our trade, why shouldn't braiders?" said Barbara G., a black cosmetologist who asked that her full name not be used, expressing concern that her comments might create tension in the mid-town Manhattan salon where she works alongside braiders.
The number of individuals practicing African-style braiding in New York is unknown. But Mr. Smith and others say the current law has had the perverse effect of driving more braiding services into the "underground" economy, where government lacks the opportunity or ability to reasonably regulate the industry.
"Ms. Russell and Ms. Best are taking this action because they don't want to hide or braid hair undercover," Mr. Smith said. "They also don't want to break the law.
"By bringing suit we hope to force the state to create reasonable regulations that take into account the safety of the community without taking away economic opportunity for braiders."
Ms. Best, who has a bachelor of arts degree in engineering, didn't know how to braid until she enrolled in Ms. Brown's braiding class last year. Now, she would like to supplement her income as a braider, but says she cannot afford to spend the $6,000 to $10,000 it costs to enroll in cosmetology school.
"And I wouldn't dream of operating without a license," Ms. Best said. "I don't want to have to hide from the authorities or do it undercover."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1146 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Secretaries Go From 'Take a Letter' to Taking Charge

BYLINE: By MARTHA NOLAN McKENZIE 

 BODY:
MOVE over, Miss Moneypenny. Clear out your desk, Jane Hathaway. Your days as the quintessential secretaries have passed.
No longer just helpers who keep the boss's calendar straight and take dictation, career secretaries and administrative assistants have, in the last decade, increasingly taken on the duties of middle managers. 
 The reasons are varied. Because of downsizing, there are fewer middle managers around, and companies have given many of the unfilled responsibilities to secretaries. And with executives typing memos on their laptops and checking their own voice mail, secretaries have been relieved of some of their time-consuming clerical duties and are available to tackle other tasks.
"The de-layering of organizations largely meant the layoff of middle managers," said Elizabeth Fried, president of N. E. Fried & Associates, a human resources consulting firm in Dublin, Ohio. "But their work remained, and it had to go somewhere."
In most cases, however, the authority given to secretaries has lagged behind that of the former managers whose duties they are assuming. So have their salary levels: the average pay of secretaries is about $8,000 a year less than the average pay for white-collar workers in private industry. But over the last five years, the gap has closed slightly. From 1992 to 1996, the national average for secretarial salaries rose 14 percent, to $24,200, according to Watson Wyatt & Company, a human resources consulting firm based in New York, while white-collar wages as a whole climbed 11 percent, to $32,100, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"Often what happens is the boss calls the secretary in and says, 'Handle this for me,' " said Florence Stone, editor of The Take-Charge Assistant, a publication of the American Management Association in New York. "It's not added to her job description and she's still listed as a secretary in the personnel files, so her salary is not adjusted. All these new responsibilities are being given very cavalierly.
"In the marketing department, the secretary may be doing the market research. In purchasing, she may be responsible for all the purchasing orders. She may be supervising staff, doing performance appraisals and running team meetings."
Ellen Napier, administrative assistant to the president at Ocean Spray Cranberries in Lakeville, Mass., has taken on some budgeting responsibilities and organizes special meetings of Ocean Spray's board. At the Paul Revere Insurance Group in Worcester, Mass., Chris Jackel, assistant to the president, compiles data from members of her department, organizes meetings and committees and handles customer service calls. Lisa McClain, a secretary with an investment banking firm in Manhattan, coordinates group events at conferences and is the liaison between management and other secretaries.
Such responsibilities would have been unthinkable for a secretary 18 years ago, when Marion Gehl joined the Milwaukee office of the firm now known as Deloitte & Touche as an administrative assistant. "Like the other assistants and secretaries, I spent my time typing, filing and taking messages," Ms. Gehl said.
Now, as administrative assistant to the partner in charge of audit operations, Ms. Gehl, 45, pours through stacks of reports, gathering figures to compile monthly summaries of billings and collections of each partner in her office. She then writes a synopsis, highlighted with charts, to give her boss a concise picture of monthly operations. She has also taken on the role of marketing director, handling media relations, planning meetings and researching prospective clients.
A 1995 survey by Professional Secretaries International, a trade association in Kansas City, Mo., found Ms. Gehl in the majority. More than 70 percent of the respondents said they were handling management tasks. Nearly half were responsible for training other workers, one-third supervised others and four out of five were involved in purchasing.
The survey also showed that most of these secretaries were not trained before taking on their new duties. "There was a real lag between the time secretaries had to demonstrate skills they didn't necessarily have and the time managers realized they needed to provide some training," said Susan Fenner, the manager of education and professional development for Professional Secretaries International. "I think that is starting to change, but slowly."
LAST spring, Sprint brought consultants to its Mansfield, Ohio, headquarters for north-central operations to work with secretaries and their managers on adapting to the changing relationships and roles. The consultants helped the company define the new duties for the secretaries and asked the secretaries what support and equipment they needed.
But the most important thing the consultants did, said Carolyn Turner, 49, the executive administrative assistant to the president of the north-central operations, was to "help the managers get out of their old habits of thinking of a secretary as a secretary," she said. "They helped show the managers we can help them more and they can trust us to make decisions."
Many secretaries are turning to night classes and seminars for training. Sandy Chismark, an administrative secretary with Southwest Gas in Phoenix, is two-thirds of the way through the credits she needs for her bachelor's degree in business management at the University of Phoenix. Attending classes in the evening, she has already taken courses in financial management, statistics, labor law and ethics.
"I'm taking these classes for my own benefit, to help me handle my current responsibilities and hopefully to advance in the future," said Ms. Chismark, 45.
The traditional secretarial schools are also responding to the changes in the secretarial field. The Katharine Gibbs Schools in New York, for example, began changing its curriculum in 1994 to offer more business courses, like economics and statistics.
"We recognized the school was behind what the industry's needs were," said William Kalaboke, the president of the Katharine Gibbs Schools. "Employers are looking for more than someone who can merely translate words onto paper. So we revamped our curriculum accordingly."
Secretaries say they need one thing even more than training: authority. Too often managers give their secretaries the responsibility for a job or project without giving them the authority they need to accomplish it. Ms. Gehl has faced that frustration. "If someone doesn't get their numbers to me on time, I can't go rattle any cages," she said.
It is a mistake made by too many companies, said Steven Frohman, the president of Applied Synergistics, a consulting firm in Milwaukee. "Businesses are focusing 100 percent on developing the technical skills in their secretarial staff, but the issue of authority is much more critical."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marion Gehl of Deloitte & Touche is part of a new variety of administrative assistant. (Chris Corsmeier for The New York Times)
 
Graph: "Up From the Typing Pool"
The change is hard to notice, but the average national salary for secretaries in private industry has been edging closer to that for white-collar workers. (Sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics; Watson Wyatt & Co.)

HEADLINE: On the Mexico Bailout

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your Jan. 18 editorial "Vindication of the Mexican Bailout," you trumpet the accomplishments of President Clinton for saving Mexico, and arguably the United States, from an economic crisis. You write that "Mexico's early repayment of loans made by the United States in 1994 puts the finishing touch on a public-policy success." 
 But you did not note that the International Monetary Fund has been pressured into lending the Mexican Government yet more money so that we could get back ours.
Under those circumstances, Mr. Clinton's "public-policy success" is neither public policy nor success. When the International Monetary Fund has been repaid, you can give the Clinton Administration a pat on the back for a job well done. Until then, the jury is out.
We should be thankful that we did not have a currency crisis when the Treasury's currency intervention fund was tapped to lend Mexico more than $13 billion and the yen and the dollar almost spun out of control.
 
ANDREW FURMAN
Maplewood, N.J., Jan. 18, 1997

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
A Setback for Mortgage Brokers' Bonuses

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

 BODY:
A FEDERAL court has called illegal a practice in the mortgage industry that costs consumers millions of dollars in extra payments.
A judge for the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, in rejecting a motion to dismiss a lawsuit against two lenders, said this month that Federal law prohibited lenders from paying independent mortgage brokers a premium for writing loans with interest rates higher than normal. 
 The payments, called yield spread premiums, have not been forbidden by the Department of Housing and Urban Development or the Justice Department, but consumer groups say they are kickbacks.
 Consumers have been suing over the practice, arguing that brokers, who offer loans from a variety of sources, have a fiduciary duty to find the best deal for borrowers. Not telling customers about extra percentage points tacked onto a home loan amounts to fraud, the plaintiffs say. Their cases have generally been settled out of court.
The Ford Consumer Finance Company, a mortgage subsidiary of Ford Motor, settled such a suit last August, agreeing to pay 70,000 to 80,000 borrowers a total that could reach $20 million.
A yield spread premium often works like this: If a lender is offering a 30-year mortgage for 8 percent, but a mortgage broker gets a consumer to accept a 9 percent rate, the broker gets an additional fee from the lender for writing the loan at the higher rate.
Lawyers said the Federal judge's action, while not a final decision in the case, was the first time a Federal court had said that paying yield spread premiums to brokers was illegal.
Daniel A. Ragland, an Atlanta lawyer representing the plaintiffs in the case, said the ruling would undoubtedly be used by other lawyers in fighting the fees. "I think this is the best order out there," he said. The case is expected to go to trial this summer.
Separately, H.U.D. said last week that it was looking at the issue and might issue a regulation about the practice in the spring.
The judge's ruling advances a lawsuit filed last year by two Maryland couples against Saxon Mortgage and Crestar Mortgage, both of Richmond. The couples contend that the companies charged them higher-than-normal interest rates on mortgages. Crestar had asked that the suit be dismissed, arguing that the practice was not illegal under the Federal Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act and was recognized by H.U.D. as a legitimate form of broker compensation.
Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. disagreed. First, he said, "H.U.D. has never expressly permitted or prohibited such payments." But he continued that the payments were prohibited under the settlement procedures act. "Quite simply," he said, "the premium rewards the broker for referring the above-par loan." He added that the court "is unable to see what service is provided" to consumers, "unless it is the provision of a bad deal."
Lawyers for Saxon and Crestar refused to comment on the judge's ruling.
William Cumberland, general counsel for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said he believed that it was not illegal for banks to pay yield spread premiums to independent brokers, but that the judge's interpretation could be picked up by others.
"We all know if one district judge has spoken on an issue the others will follow," he said. "It's going to have a significant psychological impact on people involved in these issues."
