SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1108 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Doing Homework on Taxes Before Lending to a Child

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
YOUR son wants to buy a house, but doesn't have enough money for the down payment. So, loving parents that you are, you lend him $30,000 and tell him to pay you back when he can. You don't even charge him interest.
Lending money to your children seems simple. They need the money and you happen to have it. As Richard J. Daley, the late Chicago mayor, once said when criticized for using his influence to help his sons, "If a man can't put his arms around his sons, then what kind of a world are we living in?" But the I.R.S. rules governing all no-interest loans are anything but simple, and if the loans are set up incorrectly, you may be creating a tax burden for yourself. Set up properly, however, they can be used to lend your child, or anyone else, up to $100,000 free of Federal taxes. 
 "It could be a good way of allowing a younger generation to use $100,000 worth of assets that otherwise they would have to borrow at market rates," said James DeJesus, a partner in the Manhattan office of the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche.
 But as Lawrence F. Montague, a partner with Deloitte & Touche in Stamford, Conn., said, "This is one of the more convoluted parts of the tax code."
No kidding. The first rule to remember is that the amount of any no-interest loan should be no more than $100,000. Lend more and the Internal Revenue Service will compute what it believes to be market-rate interest on the loan. So even though you are receiving no interest payments from your child, the I.R.S. will tax you as if you did. This is called imputed interest. (Gift taxes may also apply if the imputed interest plus any gifts made by the lender to the borrower surpasses $10,000 in a calendar year.)
Second, the I.R.S. will also impute interest -- using the A.F.R., or applicable Federal rate -- if the loan is more than $10,000 when the recipient has more than $1,000 in net investment income, which is defined as interest, dividends and, in some cases, capital gains. For income tax purposes, the I.R.S. sets an interest rate every July. Last year, it was set at 5.77 percent.
Confused? Well, say you made a three-year, $100,000 no-interest loan to your son and an identical loan to your daughter. Your son has $900 in net investment income; your daughter has $5,000. The loan to your son generates no imputed interest because the loan is not above $100,000 and your son has less than $1,000 of investment income. Your daughter is over that limit, and thus you must pay taxes on imputed interest.
The imputed annual interest on her loan is $5,770 (5.77 percent of $100,000), but there is another twist. The I.R.S. limits the interest to the amount of the borrower's investment income. So you would pay taxes on $5,000.
In theory, you can make as many of these loans as you want, as long as none are for more than $100,000 and the I.R.S. does not think you are trying to avoid taxes. If the imputed interest is above $10,000, you would have to file a gift tax return.
Married couples cannot, however, double the amount they lend to an individual free of Federal and gift taxes. Parents can make tax-free gifts, though, while these loans are outstanding; the gifts are limited to $20,000 a couple each year, minus imputed interest reported on loans made to the recipient.
Although the loans can last decades, they cannot be used to transfer wealth permanently. The debts remain assets in the lender's estate, and after the lender dies the unpaid balances are subject to estate taxes.
Of course, many loans that parents make to children are never repaid. The parents either forgive the loan or the child does not make paying it back a high priority. Financial planners urge parents who expect the money back to make the loan terms clear at the outset so the child understands that the money is not just a gift.
Paul Richards, president for education with the National Center for Financial Education in San Diego, urges parents to charge interest or take an equity position in any business or home for which the loan is used. "If statistics were kept, you would probably find that there were more defaults on these type of loans than any other," he said. "My own personal view is that you should never loan money you can't afford to give away."
If the loan is never repaid, and a good-faith effort has been made to seek repayment, the parents can at least get a bit of a tax break.
The I.R.S. allows parents to take a deduction for the bad debt. The write-off would be treated as a short-term capital loss that could be used to offset capital gains. The losses could also be deducted from other income in $3,000 increments in future years.
ROBERT GOULD of San Diego borrowed about $100,000 from his mother, Margaret, to open an advertising agency and makes payments several times a year. "It's the Bank of Mom," he said.
Mrs. Gould charged her son interest, as much as 10 percent, required collateral and fully documented the loans. They are not subject to imputed interest and she pays taxes on her son's interest payments. "This is a much better way to go," Mr. Gould said. "When it is done informally, there is too much of an opportunity to let human nature come into play and go, 'Well, it's Mom.' "
Proper paperwork is also proof to the I.R.S. that the transfer was a loan, not a gift. It can help, too, when a borrower is using the loan as a down payment on a house. (The Federal Housing Administration recently did away with a rule stating that money from family members for a down payment had to be a gift, not a loan. That means parents can hold second mortgages on the homes they help their children buy.)
Making a loan to your children may provide them with more than just your money: they could get a tax deduction. If they use the loan to make a taxable investment, like buying stocks, they can deduct the interest, whether actual or imputed, as an investment expense up to the amount of their investment income. They also can take a deduction if the loan helps them buy a home.
If, for example, the loan is subject to imputed interest of $5,000, your child can take the home mortgage deduction on his Federal tax return, if the home secures the debt. This creates a curious set of phantom transactions: You would be paying income taxes on $5,000 that you never received, but which the I.R.S. says you should have charged, while your son is taking a tax deduction on $5,000 that he never had to pay in interest, but the I.R.S. figures he would have paid if you had asked. Sounds like an Abbott and Costello routine.
"The rules can be pretty daunting," Mr. DeJesus said, "even for a sophisticated taxpayer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Gould is making payments, with interest, on $100,000 he borrowed from his mother, Margaret, to open an advertising agency. "It's the Bank of Mom," he said. (Alan Decker for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: January 26, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3025 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
We Like You. We Care About You. Now Pay Up.

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL

 BODY:
AH, the Super Bowl. The camaraderie of family and friends gathered around the TV set, the roar of the crowds, the cold beer, the call from the bill collector.
Sound farfetched? It's not. Debt collection has become a science of catching debtors off guard, and its practitioners have discovered that even the most evasive deadbeats will answer the phone on Super Bowl Sunday, thinking that their buddies are calling to gab about the game. 
 "The Super Bowl is definitely a good day, so we target people with higher balances and people we haven't been able to reach at other times," said Dan Peters, the manager of the vast computerized dialing system at I.C. System, a large collection agency here.
Unlike some other agencies, I.C. System sends its employees home right before kickoff so they can watch the game. Even so, Mr. Peters said, the company planned to be near its peak capacity, with 200 collectors calling debtors across the country until then.
The football gambit is just one manifestation of a quiet revolution that has transformed the debt-collection industry over the last few years. Collectors are using new technology to home in earlier on potential deadbeats and are getting better at tracking them down where they live, work and play. To many, it feels like there is no escape.
Yet, with more people falling behind on their payments and a record one million households filing for personal bankruptcy last year, collectors have found that tough-guy threats and endless dunning notices have lost their punch. They have discovered that it is more effective to assume the role of a friendly financial adviser.
"Ten years ago we simply called up and asked for the money; now we say, 'How can we help you?' " said Lee J. Robinson, the senior vice president for collections at the Crestar Bank in Richmond. Often, he said, sweet talk is the best way to a debtor's limited dollars. "Collecting is basically selling, and what we are selling is a payment plan," he said. "Most people are past due on four or five debts and the debts are much bigger than before, so now we need to sell them on the idea of paying us first."
To Robin Taylor, who fell behind on her credit card bills last year, the deluge of calls from collectors was a mix of sweet and sour.
"J. C. Penney was wonderful; they treated you like you were a human being trying to do your best," said Ms. Taylor, a newspaper circulation manager in Manchester, Conn. "To Bank of Boston, you are nothing but a liar or a deadbeat. All the guy said was if you just made your payments like you said you would we wouldn't be calling you." She said the bank had also called her at work and harassed her 14-year-old son.
But Ms. Taylor got a bit of revenge: The money she had to pay off her bills went to Penney, not Bank of Boston, she said.
A spokeswoman for Bank of Boston said the bank's policy is to treat customers "with dignity and respect."
Because more debtors have to choose which lenders to pay, collectors are moving away from the traditional technique they call "grinding," in which they ignore debtors' excuses and simply repeat that they have to pay up now -- or else.
"When most debtors were blue-collar workers, you would demean and embarrass them," said Roger Willis, a leading collection consultant in San Francisco. "That worked, because that is the way most of those folks were treated anyway."
But times have changed, Mr. Willis said, and friendly persuasion has replaced bombast. "Generation X is focused on escaping any kind of pain or responsibility," he said. "You have to sell them on the benefit of taking responsibility and the explicit consequences if they don't."
And, however cloaked in nurturing language, the collectors also make threats: People who don't pay will get a black mark on their credit bureau file, hurting their ability not only to borrow money but also to get a job or rent an apartment. And lawsuits to garnish the debtors' wages might be filed in states that allow the practice.
But debt collectors have to be careful about what they say. Many debtors may not know it, but they have legal protection against once-rampant abuses. The 1977 Fair Debt Collection Practices Act forbids collection agencies from threatening to file suit if they have no intention of doing so.
In addition, the law bans certain harassing practices, like calling after 9 P.M. Debtors, in fact, have the right to demand that a collection agency not call them at work or, for that matter, at home. Such ostrich-like behavior, however, won't keep the unpaid bills from showing up on credit reports.
Debtors also have what amounts to the ultimate weapon -- they can wipe away most of their debts by filing for bankruptcy. (The lenders' revenge, of course, is to deny home and car loans to those who have filed for bankruptcy or to charge them near-usurious interest rates.)
Before the 1960's, the collection industry mainly used the mail to pry dollars out of debtors, sending them increasingly stern letters. Like many other agencies, I.C. System, founded in the 1930's, initially served retailers and professionals like doctors and dentists. In the last 30 years, the focus of collections has shifted to the telephone, with increasingly assertive tactics.
Recently, I.C. System, now the 30th-largest collection agency in the country, has been hired by lenders to call some customers after they miss just one payment. This nip-it-in-the-bud practice is known as an early-out program.
ON a recent rainy afternoon, Jennifer Toepper worked the phone in her beige cubicle at the three-story brick headquarters of I.C. System off a rural highway here. Unlike the back-alley hangouts of popular lore, the building is a cheerful place, with three stories of cubicles surrounding a sculpture-filled atrium.
But Ms. Toepper, who is 20, has no time to admire the view. She is making early-out calls to people who are one month behind on payments to a big appliance company.
In the hectic pace set by the computerized dialer, she has just seconds from the first ring of her phone to glance at the computer screen and figure out who is on the line and what she wants from the conversation.
Ms. Toepper determines that she is speaking to a woman who has missed a $105 payment on a $2,631 projection television. The customer, it turns out, misunderstood the terms of a sales promotion, and quickly agrees to give Ms. Toepper her checking account number so I.C. System can electronically transfer the money.
A note pad on Ms. Toepper's desk bears the inscription, "Get those WUPP's." The acronym stands for Western Union Phone Pay, a service that electronically deducts funds from a debtor's checking account. Such transfers are the quickest and surest way for the agency to get paid.
Not every newly minted debtor is as innocent as the TV buyer. "There are a lot of 'I forgot's,' " said Nicole Neis, who sits next to Ms. Toepper. Late in the year, she said, people plead that "Christmas is coming up and I need the money." But she doesn't buy that excuse. After all, she said, "These are appliances and computers that are a 'want' debt, not a 'need' debt."
Lenders organize collections into "buckets" of accounts, based on how late the payments are. One bucket is for people who are one month late, another for those two months late, and so on. Each bucket calls for progressively tougher tactics, typically with a different group of collectors. "Back end" collectors, who handle the most delinquent accounts, are often the industry's highest-paid stars.
One reason is that they don't get ruffled. Across the atrium from Ms. Toepper's cubicle, Cindy Olson's computer flashes details of a doctor's bill, unpaid since October 1992.
"Is Christine there, please?" Ms. Olson asks. No, but Christine's husband is.
"Do you want to settle this right away before it goes further into collection?" Ms. Olson asks him. "We have the option of recommending the account be placed with an attorney."
The debtor argues the bill is inaccurate.
"We already sent you an itemized bill in October," Ms. Olson responds coolly after looking at the computer screen. Then, barely flinching under a barrage of obscenities, she asks politely, "Do you want to discuss payment today or do I have to disconnect?"
With just too firm a click, Ms. Olson turns off her phone headset and types "vulgar, rude" in the computer log. Without missing a beat, she moves to the next call.
The wall of her cubicle displays a chart of her current bonus plan. If she can get $42,000 in payments in this month, she will receive an extra $1,625 in her paycheck. The average collector at I.C. System earns between $9 and $11 an hour, plus bonuses.
Ms. Olson likes collecting because she can work part time and fit her schedule around taking care of her children. On this day, for example, she is working from 1 to 8 P.M.
Prime times for collections are 7 to 9 A.M. and 4 to 9 P.M. weekdays, when people are most likely to be home. Even better are Saturday mornings and Sunday evenings.
And collectors are always looking for the extra opportunity. "When there was the big snowstorm in Ohio, we targeted Cleveland during the day," said Dan Peters, manager of the I.C. System dialing machines.
IN 1995, lenders placed $100 billion of consumer debt with the nation's 6,300 collection agencies, up 37 percent from 1990, according to the Nilson Report, a newsletter in Oxnard, Calif.. The agencies recouped roughly $16 billion, though their success rates varied wildly, depending on the type of bill, the age of the account and the credit standards of the lender. They kept just under $1 for every $3 they retrieved, making debt collection a $5 billion industry in annual revenue.
But the revenue figure understates the true size of debt-collection activity in the United States because it includes only debt that is placed with agencies after it has been charged off. It does not include the rising "early out" programs, both by the lenders themselves and by collection agencies under contract, that call debtors who are just a month or two late. And it doesn't include collection of business debt, or the collections by the rising number of law firms that work for lenders.
Although the business is still dominated by small outfits, some bigger companies have been buying up the little guys. The largest credit agency is Nationwide Credit, a subsidiary of the First Data Corporation, the credit card processing conglomerate. Currently, no large independent collection agencies are publicly traded.
Of all the economic sectors dominated by small businesses, the category of debt collection and credit reporting is the fastest growing, by the reckoning of the Small Business Administration. The agency estimates that employment in the industry will surge 68 percent by 2004, to nearly 3 million, from 1.7 million in 1994. One reason for that growth: governments at all levels are using the private sector to help in tax collection.
Moreover, the industry seems immune to the automation that has shrunk the work forces of other industries. "Unfortunately, we haven't come up with a substitute for a live person," said Jeffrey L. Dodge, senior vice president of the Equifax Financial Services, the large credit reporting bureau. "Robots don't work. Tape recordings don't work. If you get a phone call and it's a computerized voice, you have more important things to do."
One technology that does seem to work is the videocassette. Norwest Card Services, the credit card unit of the big Minneapolis bank, sends a five-minute tape filled with soothing reassurances to people it can't track down by phone. "We work to make your calls to us a positive experience," a smiling Norwest representative intones. "You'll see that we're ready to listen and offer solutions to your specific situation." Almost one-third of those receiving the video make at least one payment.
Another effective weapon is the computerized dialing machines, which place hundreds of calls simultaneously to offices and homes. With this tool, collection agencies are able to calculate, through trial and error, the daily schedules of the people they are trying to reach, and are programming their computers to factor in special events, like snowstorms and sports extravaganzas, that keep people at home and close to their phones.
For example, the automated dialers at I.C. System have nearly 500 phone lines, which typically make more than 100,000 calls a day, one-third of which actually reach human beings.
A dialer monitors the human collectors, placing new calls when it calculates that they should be finishing up on their old calls. Sometimes the dialer is early, and the recipient hears a recording that instructs him to "hold for an important call."
THE machine can tell live voices from answering machines. In busy times, the dialer will hang up on answering machines or play a taped message asking the debtor to call back. In slow times -- or with more recalcitrant debtors -- it will switch to an operator to leave a personalized message.
Some lenders are moving into a new technological frontier, developing computer models that decide which late payers to pounce on first.
After one missed payment, the Crestar Bank places phone calls right away if customers are near their credit limits or if they routinely pay the minimum each month. People who have bounced checks or have missed payments in the past get immediate calls, too. But someone who doesn't flash such warning signs of financial stress may get no more than a late fee on his next bill.
If people fall further behind, other computer models are used to determine how tough a stance to take. Norwest, for example, has developed a system that looks at late-paying customers' other debts from credit bureau files.
"If the person has opened up 13 other cards in two weeks, I figure no good can come of this," said Brian J. O'Hare, president of Norwest's credit card unit. "I want to close the account and get him to pay me from the other cards. If there is someone who has diminished capacity to pay but no diminished willingness, I want to work with that person."
What sort of personality is attracted to making the phone calls that most people rate up there with dog bites and parking tickets as guaranteed ways to ruin a day?
"Kids don't grow up saying, 'I want to be a bill collector,' " said Marci Martin, the training superviser at I.C. System. "But for some people, it's their niche."
In her case, it was an escape from a job at a hotel front desk that required her to put on a cheerful face at all times, no matter how grumpy she felt. "Here, I don't have to be nice," she said. "I'm my own boss. If I want to be tough, I can tell you you have to pay all the money today. If I want to be lenient, I can be lenient."
Others like the human contact, no matter how hostile it can become. Daniel Alejandro spent 12 years as a Baptist minister, but when his wife was transferred to Minnesota for a computer job, he gave up the collection plate for the collection call. "I felt it was time to change," said Mr. Alejandro, who now works for I.C. System. "I have the people skills, and it is good money." He acknowledged, though, that the job "gets a bit tedious" at times.
"The ministry is perceived very differently from collections," he said. "But the similarity is that you call people to responsibility," in one case spiritual, in the other, financial.
"I'm still helping people solve their problems," he added. "But, this time, it's for a profit."
Managers who hire collectors say they look for people with sales backgrounds, assertive personalities and a dash of cynicism. "Collecting is an exquisite art form," said Mr. O'Hare of Norwest. "You have to be empathetic but be absolutely firm. You have to be an attentive listener but willing to challenge the individual. You have to be a good salesman and be able to deal with a lot of rejection. All the good collectors I've ever seen enjoy a good head game."
One of the more challenging specialties in collecting is called skip tracing, or finding the master deadbeats who slip off their creditors' radar screens by changing their phone numbers, their addresses and, in rare cases, their names.
Skip tracers use computer phone directories, including reverse directories that link phone numbers to street addresses, allowing collectors to call neighbors and ask for a debtor's new phone number, or to leave a message to pass along. Finally, there are credit bureau files where fugitive debtors, unable to shake their borrowing habits, often make a reappearance.
FOR all the efforts of the collection agencies, most of the debtors they dun just don't pay. And, as a rule of thumb, any debt under $2,000 is generally deemed too piddling to justify sending to a lawyer. But with the silence of computers, I.C. System is getting its revenge: Every month the company sends negative reports on 480,000 people to credit bureaus, reflecting $167 million in bad debt.
Sometimes -- on average, two and a half years later -- the debtors call I.C. System in a panic. They have tried to get a job or obtain a mortgage, but have been blocked because of a stained credit file.
"I just got called all kinds of names," said Beth Zeug, an I.C. System manager who helps answer 1,200 calls a day from disgruntled debtors. The caller was apparently furious when she rejected his offer of payola. "He said he will pay us money to take the debt off his credit file but he won't pay the $500 vet bill," she said.
"I had one guy who didn't pay because his cat jumped out of the car window on the way home from the vet and got run over by a car," she said.
Ms. Martin, who trains new collectors, advises them to numb themselves to sob stories like those, just as emergency-room nurses must steel themselves to blood and broken bones.
"The collectors who feel sorry for people don't work out," she said. "Someone tells me a sad story -- the kid went to drug rehab, the dog ran out, Dad lost his job -- any sad story you've ever heard. I say, 'The bottom line is, you still owe the money.' "

HEADLINE: The World;
Oil Imports Are Up. Fretting About It Is Down.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN his second inaugural address last week, Bill Clinton made promises on the usual problems, like race relations, education and health. But another hardy perennial, the nation's dependence on imported oil, went unmentioned. Not gone but forgotten, this problem is larger than ever.
Imports have risen to record levels -- above 50 percent of consumption, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Needing cash last year, the Government sold off about 25 million barrels from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the equivalent of almost three weeks of imports from Saudi Arabia. That hoard might have been precious in a crisis. 
 But there will not be another crisis quite like the oil shortages of 1973 to 1974 and 1979 to 1980, experts say, and there are reasons that might justify America's profligate course. Last year, domestic production decreased, but the oil companies delivered 2.8 percent more fuel to their customers. As a result, imports, which are relatively cheap, increased 6 percent, the institute said.
The contrast between the bad old days and today is stunning. When imports were 40 percent of consumption, Jimmy Carter, donning a cardigan, said that America should cut imports by nearly a third by 1985 and declared "the moral equivalent of war." As President Carter's energy czar, James R. Schlesinger, put it last week, Americans now have evolved to "indifference without moralizing."
Efforts to find substitute fuels for vehicles continue, along with programs to pump more domestic oil and conserve use. But dependence on foreign sources will grow anyway, the General Accounting Office said last month, because rising demand will outstrip all these efforts as the economy grows. Even without a population increase or new factories to consume more energy, new Chevy Astros, Mercury Villagers and other vans are roaring out of showrooms as old fuel-efficient Chevy Chevettes and Honda Civics head for the scrap heap. That means more fuel per mile.
Combined with declining domestic production, imports could rise to 60 percent of consumption by 2015, the G.A.O. said.
Hazel R. O'Leary, whose job as Energy Secretary ended with Mr. Clinton's swearing-in, said in an interview just before her departure that the American people needed to get the message, but delivering it was beyond the ability of an Energy Secretary. She said it would take another oil shock.
And that appears about as certain as another hurricane in Florida or earthquake in California. The only question is when. Many of the elements are already in place; Larry Goldstein, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said that idle production capacity is only about three million barrels a day, all of it in the Persian Gulf. "If you were to have a disruption in Kuwait or Saudi Arabia, " he said, "the ability of the world to make it up is zero. And nobody would honestly say the Middle East is more secure today than it was a decade ago."
But Mr. Goldstein and other experts say oil is no longer at the top of America's problem list for a number of reasons.
For one, interruptions in supply from the Persian Gulf are possible, but there is no enemy superpower poised to march in. "When the Soviet Union was still around, it had six airborne divisions seemingly ready to fly into the gulf," said Mr. Schlesinger, who also did a turn as Secretary of Defense. OPEC has lost power too, he said.
In fact, the so-called North-South confrontation of the 1970's, with rich oil-consuming nations facing off against poor energy-producing ones, is mostly gone. Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, pointed out that in the 1970's and 1980's, oil-producing countries nationalized their industries, but now they are privatizing them and asking for Western investment. "It's back to a high degree of interdependence," he said. "Everybody wants to be on the same team now."
And America itself has changed. The amount of goods and services that 20 years ago required five barrels of oil to make now takes only three. Not only have utilities switched to coal and natural gas, but the output of the American economy has also shifted away from products using vast amounts of energy, like heavy manufactured goods, to those that use hardly any, like movies and computer software.
The price of oil is down, too. In 1980, oil sales were about 8.5 to 9 percent of gross domestic product. "Today, it's a little over 3 percent," Mr. Goldstein said.
Mr. Goldstein also distinguishes between dependency and vulnerability. If this country cut its dependency by several million barrels a day, it would still be just as vulnerable to price shock, he said, because in a free international market, "a disruption anywhere is a price shock everywhere." Making a similar point last month, the G.A.O. gave the example of Britain after the fall of the Shah of Iran and the subsequent price shock. That country was nearly self-sufficient in oil at the time, but when the price rose, the economic dislocation was severe. The G.A.O. report found that "vulnerability is linked to dependence on oil, not merely to dependence on imported oil."
Cheap oil is still a boon to the American economy. The G.A.O. put the benefits of cheap oil at hundreds of billions of dollars annually. Its analysis explicitly excluded the cost of human life in sending American soldiers back into Mideastern oil fields -- or the limits that import dependency may impose on American foreign policy. In the current political climate, though, those costs do not seem to be high on anybody's list.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

I.B.M. STOCK
Good News, Go Away
I.B.M. stock, it may seem, is the stock market in miniature -- both just kept heading gleefully higher, taunting the naysayers. And last week, both fell in tandem. Here's a huge difference, though: the haughty Dow would laugh if anyone compared it to the 2,700-point weakling it was before the '87 crash, but I.B.M., even after quadrupling since '93, has yet to see its precrash high. It edged close last week -- $168, versus $175 in August 1987 -- but then came the bad news. What? You say an 18 percent rise in quarterly earnings, even better than analysts had expected, doesn't sound like bad news? Shows how much you know. I.B.M. shares plunged 10 points in a day, 6 the next and TK the next, leading the whole market in what is politely known as a "correction."
 
JOURNALISM
The 'Gotcha!' That Backfired
It's become a staple of TV news: the Gotcha! stories, in which reporters insinuate themselves into the belly of some beast and discover something, well, simply shocking. But do the news hounds go too far? Have they crossed the line from protecting the public interest to getting flashy scoops for the sake of the flash? That was the issue when reporters for ABC's "Primetime Live" finagled their way into Food Lion stores for a report that accused Food Lion of selling spoiled meat. And last week a North Carolina jury said resoundingly that ABC had gone too far, awarding Food Lion more than $5.5 million in punitive damages. Food Lion never disputed the show's findings, just the methods -- like having producers submit fake resumes to get jobs. "I don't have anything against undercover investigations," one juror said. "Just do them legal." But "trivial" complaints, one media expert said, should not obscure a "noble journalistic goal."
 
SPORT UTILITY VEHICLES
ove Over, Explorer
You can almost hear the conversations in Detroit a decade or so ago: "So, everyone's buying imports. What'll we do?" "Let 'em drive trucks," a passing messenger boy pipes in. "Nah," a guy in a suit says. "It'll never work." "Hmmm," said another. "Let's give it a try. Can't hurt -- nothing else is working." And so was born the unlikely American craze for big, gas-guzzling "sport utility vehicles" (even the name is clunky). Foreign car makers mainly sat it out, seeing it as a crazy idea. So Detroit practically had the field to itself and racked up huge profits. Well, the party may be over: the Japanese and Europeans are getting in on the madness, with at least 17 new foreign sport models due in the next four years. And guess what: they don't cost a fortune. Watch your back, Detroit.
 
INDEXED BONDS
Inflation? Then You Win
You thought you were insured against every calamity? Not a chance. Starting on Wednesday, you can also insure yourself against inflation -- by buying inflation-indexed Treasury bonds. Say you buy a $1,000 bond and it pays 3 percent. You'll get $30 the first year, and the $1,000 will grow by the inflation rate -- if it's 4 percent, add $40 (which you don't see yet). Trouble is, you'll pay tax on the whole $70, so unless the bonds are in a tax-deferred account, you'll get little cash in your pocket. In fact, if demon inflation does return, your tax could more than wipe out your income. Then again, these bonds are a gamble -- and if inflation does rise, you win the bigger gamble. It's just that it won't look that way till the game's over -- when the bonds mature in 10 years.
 
PHILANTHROPY
Enough Money? What an Idea
It was a shocking statement. Downright un-American, really. "I simply decided I had enough money," Charles Feeney said. What? Enough money? Doesn't he know, as a New Yorker cartoon once made clear, that "money is life's report card"? Clearly not, because for 15 years Mr. Feeney has given most of his money away. And since he'd made a fortune in airport duty-free shops, the sums were staggering -- a total of $600 million. But the truly amazing thing was that it was all anonymous -- he didn't even get any gold stars on his report card. Mr. Feeney, who's 65, came clean last week, though. He had to: his company had just been sold, and his secret would come out. His share of the proceeds, some $3.5 billion, went straight to his charitable foundations, leaving him perhaps $5 million. As he said, though, "nobody can wear two pairs of shoes at one time."
 
AND MORE PHILANTHROPY
Billable Heiress
Doris Duke also wanted her fortune -- $1.2 billion -- to go to charity, and if she'd just written a check before she died, it would have. Instead, she kept rewriting her will in her final years, with control of the vast estate flitting from daughter to diet doctor to accountant to butler. She was, in other words, writing an engraved invitation to the legal profession saying: Come and get it. And, of course, the lawyers have come. They fly across country to meetings, billing perhaps $450 an hour en route; they pore over the same papers, billing as they read; they descend, en redundant masse, into courtrooms, billing as they jostle. The total: $10 million and counting (counting fast). One person described it as a "feeding frenzy" -- and that was a lawyer! Decency forbids printing nonlawyers' opinions.
 
EXECUTIVE DIVORCE
What's Yours Is Ours
"First Wives Club" has come to the courtroom -- with a vengeance. In a Connecticut divorce case, Lorna Wendt is asking what is normally considered reasonable: half. The case stands out, though, because of the sums involved: she says Gary Wendt, a top General Electric executive, is worth $100 million, and 50-50 splits are rare at these levels. He offered $10 million; she declined. If the 31-year marriage was a partnership -- if it was their career, not his -- why, she asked, should he get the bulk of it? And multimillionaires throughout the midlife-crisis set await the outcome nervously. One wrinkle: Mr. Wendt says he's worth just $25 million, and his experts back him up. How could there be such a disparity? Simple. It's all those newfangled ways companies have of paying people -- stock options, deferred compensation, pension goodies, you name it. It adds up to a lot more than it seems, Mrs. Wendts' experts say. (Don't feel bad: with that kind of money, you, too, could have experts.)
 
NUTRITION
Oatmeal, Miracle Cure?
Americans, bless their sound-bite-clogged hearts, love a quick fix -- whether it's a diet pill or a miracle pain-killer -- and they're suckers for official-sounding health claims. Makers of oat cereals know this, and have long lobbied to be able to say, on their labels, that whole-oat fiber is good for the heart. Last week, they got their wish from the F.D.A., with one condition: that labels say the oats must be part of a diet low in saturated fat and cholesterol. The industry practically danced a jig at the news, with full-page ads appearing within a day trumpeting the wonders of Quaker Oats and Cheerios. But wait a second, said Bonnie Liebman of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, "you have to eat up to four servings a day, every day," to get enough of that magic fiber. The real answer, she said, is a diet rich in fruits and vegetables. Otherwise, you'd better really love oatmeal.
 
TELEVISION
What Price 'Seinfeld'?
Would there be intelligent life in a world without "Seinfeld"? No, much too cosmic a question. How about this one: Would there be profitable life on a network without "Seinfeld"? NBC is scared to death that the answer might be no -- in fact, there are fears that if this show ever vanishes, it will be network TV's last gasp, letting cable's marauders take over. Just look at the show's power: with stupefied viewers unable to push the "off" button, a hit show, of course, makes whatever follows it a hit, too. But "Seinfeld" creates such a force field that it even helps the show that comes before -- "Seinfeld" fever, apparently, takes hold before the dishes are even cleared. Do the show's stars know their power? Of course, and they reportedly want $1 million each to come back next season. That's per episode, by the way, or $22 million a year, putting Elaine, George and Kramer -- the man who's turned entering a room into an art form -- up there with Jim Carrey and the mega-stars. Pricy, but consider the alternative.

HEADLINE: Deaths in the Workplace: Looking Beyond the Numbers

 BODY:
"One Day's Death Toll on the Job" (Dec. 22), by Jon Nordheimer, examined the deaths of 13 American workers on a single day last fall. The toll was smaller than usual -- on a typical day, 17 people die in the United States because of the work they do. These were among the responses to the article from readers:

To the Editor: 
 Undeniably, as measured by fatalities, the workplace is becoming safer. Fatality rates have declined by about 2.7 percent a year since the end of World War II. But the work of the Labor Department and OSHA doesn't seem be a leading driver of the trend.
Our research suggests that there are three main reasons for the decline in fatalities: the changing nature of employment, with a movement away from heavy manufacturing to a service economy; the fluctuations of the business cycle, and, most interesting, the changes in the country's workers' compensation insurance systems.
Workers' compensation affects safety and fatality rates in three ways. Like unemployment insurance, workers' compensation is "experience rated," in that larger employers pay insurance premiums, based in part on their safety experience. Over the last 10 to 15 years, many states have changed the rating formula so that more employers qualify for the program and that even more of their premiums are determined by their own safety. A result is a much stronger economic incentive to provide a safer workplace and control workers' compensation insurance premiums, which have generally risen dramatically since the 1970's.
Second, workers' compensation premiums are determined for more than 600 classes of employment. To the extent that insurance costs are higher for one class of employment than another (say, for construction work versus office work), employers will have incentives to substitute capital for the relatively higher labor costs and thus move employment away from the riskier occupations.
Finally, in the last several years, there has been tremendous growth in programs that allow employers to self-insure a portion of their insurance liabilities, providing a much stronger economic incentive to have a safer workplace. In some industries, with workers' compensation premiums approaching 50 percent of payroll costs, employers have embraced workplace safety as a means of economic survival.
 
DAVID DURBIN and RICHARD J. BUTLER
Hoboken, N.J., Dec. 23
 
Mr. Durbin is vice president and director of research at the National Council on Compensation Insurance in Hoboken. Mr. Butler is Williams Professor of Insurance at the University of Minnesota.

HEADLINE: Kiss Kiss;
Bipartisanship And Other White Lies

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was one of those rare times in American politics last week when, however briefly, hostile partisanship gave way to Emily Post. With a soothing assurance of bipartisan bonhomie, President Clinton set the tone in his inauguration speech: "The American people returned to office a President of one party and a Congress of another. Surely they did not do this to advance the politics of petty bickering and extreme partisanship they plainly deplore."
Speaker Newt Gingrich sounded downright giddy after the ceremony, proclaiming that there was "a sense of bipartisanship" in the air. Madeleine K. Albright, unanimously confirmed as Secretary of State, welcomed "a new era of bipartisan foreign policy." On Friday, Mr. Clinton announced that he and George Bush and other former Presidents would hold a summit meeting on community service. 
 But as much as voters may complain about legislative gridlock, the fashionable notion among politicians that Americans are demanding comity and compromise above all else may be more an illusion of statistics than a political reality. In fact, in the last two elections, voters did not reward split-the-difference coalition builders but chose more hard-edged ideologues in both parties, leaving a gaping hole in the center of Congress.
"When it comes to actually casting a vote, people are not necessarily looking for the peacemaker or diplomat," said Leonard Williams, a professor of political science at Manchester College in Indiana. "They're looking for someone who is clear about what they stand for. Someone who wants commitment. The remarkable thing is that we found an electoral advantage to being an extremist."
Mr. Williams and a colleague, Neil Wollman, analyzed the re-election races of House incumbents in the last two elections and concluded that the Republican sweep of 1994 did not wipe out the ranks of the liberals in Congress, and that the voters last year did not reject the sharp conservatism associated with Mr. Gingrich and his fellow Republicans. Their study shows, for example, that conservatives won 95 percent of their races in 1996.
Nor is there much to the notion that people intentionally opted for divided Government last November in the hope that the executive and legislative branches could function in moderate bliss. To the contrary, 84 percent of those who backed Mr. Clinton, advertising himself as a centrist, also voted for a Democrat for the House.
This may underscore another example of voters (the same people who want their taxes cut and the Federal budget balanced) trying to have it both ways. In November, voters rewarded a Congress that ended on a note of bipartisan accomplishment by sending back most incumbents. Yet while people tell pollsters they are disgusted with partisan bickering, they also contend that they want their leaders to act out of principle, to stand for something.
 
 
 
Healing, No
 If the voters are confused, so are the politicians. They know that if they produce they will be more popular come election time. Yet, there is great risk, too, in cozying up to the other party.
"For politicians, not only does their gut tell them not to trust the other side, but the people they represent don't really trust the other side either," said Eric M. Uslaner, a professor of government at the University of Maryland and author of "The Decline of Comity in Congress" (University of Michigan Press, 1993). "Everyone wants to see what they can do. But looming beneath everything is the fact that both parties represent very different groups of people -- and for almost the last 20 years have been at each other's throats."
Steve Bell, a Republican political consultant and a former Congressional aide, said there is no way even the appearance of cooperation will last -- certainly not through the elections of 1998. "It will not be, 'Let's come together and heal' -- that's not how you get elected in this country," Mr. Bell said. "You'll see people running on the death penalty, abortion, school prayer. You get elected by exciting your folks. You show them where you stand on certain code issues. And you turn them out."
Indeed, behind the facade of conciliation, there is a growing insistence in both parties that unless they more aggressively stake their claims on issues, they will lose their identities even further.
 
 
 
Egged On
 The Wall Street Journal's editorial page recently called on its constituency of Republicans to celebrate their party's ideological fervor. "Rank partisanship can indeed corrode the system," the editorial said, "but the Beltway now seems instinctively to dump on acts of partisanship that flow from ideology." And consider, in another conservative journal, The Weekly Standard, this hardly delicate headline on a recent essay: "Stick It to the Democrats."
The Democrats, thus far, are not so blatant; if the Republicans see bipartisanship as the strategy of losers, the Democrats, having indeed lost their majority, have to appeal to bipartisanship if they are to accomplish much of anything.
But they, too, seem to be spoiling for confrontation. There is, for example, this collision course on Capitol Hill: Republicans in Congress are pressing for a balanced budget amendment as their top priority, while the Democrats' No. 1 goal -- reforming the campaign finance system -- is not even on the Republicans' agenda.
"I don't think the foundation for bipartisanship was set in the 1996 elections," said Bob Carolla, communications director for the liberal organization Americans for Democratic Action. "The general election was the usual vituperative attack on way-out liberals or unpatriotic liberals. How is Newt Gingrich supposed to sit down with David Bonior or, better yet, Barney Frank, and talk about common ground?" Primed for the next battle, he added, "We're getting ready to fight like hell on the balanced budget amendment."
 
 
 
Sign My Bill
 The parties also show evidence of using the shroud of bipartisanship to obscure very partisan intentions. For example, in the name of bipartisanship Mr. Clinton last week called on Republicans to sign off on his party's plan to rewrite the campaign finance laws. But the appeal for harmony was as much a strategy by Democrats to turn attention away from their party's crisis over more than $1 million in questionable contributions, many from foreign sources. In fact, some party officials gloated that the President's announcement was cleverly timed to coincide with -- and draw a contrast to -- the House vote to reprimand Mr. Gingrich for ethics violations.
Just the same, many Senate Republicans, who want to keep the campaign finance system that helped them win control of Congress, insist that the remedy is not to overhaul it but to punish the Democrats who took advantage of it.
Efforts to bring civility and accommodation into politics are not new, and have never been particularly successful. In 1939, for example, Franklin D. Roosevelt called for "cooperation -- without trace of partisanship."
Harry Truman took a harder look. "There was never a nonpartisan in politics," he declared. "A man cannot be a nonpartisan and be effective in a political party."
One politician inclined to Roosevelt's point of view is Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, a Republican who calls himself a social liberal and economic conservative. "People do want bipartisanship," he said. "People are sick to death of finger pointing."
Then why, if people were so eager for comity, did Massachusetts voters defeat Mr. Weld in his race for Senate last year? Rather than go with a moderate who had pledged to work both sides of the aisle, they settled on a liberal Democrat, Senator John F. Kerry.
 
 
 
Still Drinking
 All the same, when Mr. Weld called Mr. Kerry to congratulate him after the election, he also invited the Senator to join him for a beer at the saloon favored by Boston politicians.
And even in Congress, lip service to the notion of working together is still being paid. In what may be a delicious coincidence, Republicans and Democrats plan to gather in early March in Hershey, Pa., the city known for producing chocolate kisses. It is billed as the "Congressional Bipartisan Retreat."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Pilots Just Want a Little R-E-S-P-E-C-T

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
CONSIDERING the record profits that airlines are generating these days, pilots should be happy. After all, the industry is more stable now than it has been since its deregulation in 1978. That means greater security for pilots, whose jobs are still among the best-paying in the nation.
But pilots are complaining. Union leaders say it is their members' hard work that has bolstered earnings, and they are demanding raises to make up for wage cuts during years of steep losses. At American, pilots are warning they may strike. At United, the employee-owner pilots are publicly criticizing the tight-fistedness of the managers they hired. At Continental and Northwest, the tune is the same: it's pay-back time. 
 Not everyone is sympathetic, though. Piloting has been called the best part-time job in America, allowing many pilots to have second careers. And although they start off with low salaries (around $30,000), a pilot currently at American, United or Delta will earn an average of $125,000 a year (in 1996 dollars) over a 30-year career. Many other employees at American, worried about the effects of a possible strike, started wearing buttons last week bearing the acronym SPOILED, for Spoiled Pilots' Objective Is Leaving Employees Destitute.

More Than Money
But the pilots' restiveness is about more than wages. Broad changes have occurred in the nature of the profession and the makeup of the pilot ranks, and those shifts help explain some of the current saber-rattling.
Pilots, for example, do not command the respect they once did when air travel was glamorous and only for the well heeled. Back then, airplanes were less refined, and jut-jawed captains stared down the dangers and calmed nervous passengers with Chuck Yeager drawls.
Today, pilots have in many ways become systems managers, monitoring computers that can largely fly planes on their own. There is a joke that the cockpit of the future will have one seat for a pilot and one for a dog -- the dog is there to bite the pilot's hand if he touches anything; the pilot's job is to feed the dog.
And as more people board increasingly crowded flights that serve fewer meals and offer no legroom, comparisons to flying buses -- and their drivers -- are inevitable, particularly after Greyhound Air started flying in Canada last year.
While society's opinion of pilots may have slipped half a notch over the years, pilot self-image appears to be as healthy as ever. One reason is that the military is training fewer pilots, so more civilians, who were not steeped in a culture where chain of command is everything, are flying for major carriers. They do not automatically respect their airline's chief executive, particularly since fewer chief executives are pilots themselves or founding fathers of the company.
Pilots are the C.E.O.'s of their planes, with the lives of passengers entrusted to them and up to $1 billion in insurance riding on their flight. Pilots like to say that they can earn their yearly salary 10 times over in just two critical seconds, and that if something goes wrong beyond their control, well, they are always first to the accident scene.
Because no C.E.O. carries such responsibility on a daily basis or faces such risks, pilots naturally chafe when airline managers see them simply as a stubbornly high cost of doing business. The employee buyout of United Airlines in 1994 was motivated in part by pilots seeking more respect from management.
Individual pilots may want more respect, but union leaders say their current demands are based on simple economics. Many airline managers, after exhausting cash and credit in the 1980's through a host of strategic errors, turned to employees for wage cuts and work-rule changes.
J. Randolph Babbitt, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, said his members had little choice but to become, in effect, investors of last resort in these troubled carriers -- pilot skills are not transferable to other industries, and if pilots leave one airline for another, they start at the bottom of the wage and seniority ladder.
Pilots are not asking so much for a raise but to get back to where they used to be, Mr. Babbitt said. "They made an investment of their wages, and they are simply looking to get a return."
According to one former Eastern Airlines captain, though, most pilots at major airlines were paid too much before, and most of them are paid too much now.
"What pilots get and what they do does not correspond," said Robert W. Iverson, who was a pilot with Eastern for 18 years. Along with other pilots, he founded Kiwi Airlines in 1992 but left in 1995 amid disputes over how to run the airline. Pilots' pay, Mr. Iverson said, is actually more a reflection of their power to cripple the company if they go on strike.
 
Easy Living
Mr. Iverson, who was a Kiwi pilot in addition to chief executive of the airline, also ran two construction companies while flying for Eastern. Pilots are actually flying only 60 to 80 hours a month, although they are working away from home, on average, 160 nights a year.
But Mr. Iverson scoffed at suggestions that pilots' schedules can be exhausting. "It's not intellectually difficult, it's not physically difficult," he said. "It's probably the easiest way to make a living ever invented."
Pilots can laugh at this (although they tend to laugh harder when there are only pilots in the room).
Here is one joke making the rounds: After the pilots at United led their employee buyout in 1994, they all gathered to discuss how their jobs would change now that they had more say in running the airline. The airline's chairman, Gerald Greenwald, announces their new schedule -- each United pilot would now have six days off each week, and would fly only on Wednesdays.
A minute later, one pilot raises his hand and asks, "Every Wednesday?"

HEADLINE: Small Loans May Be Key To Helping Third World

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 24

 BODY:
A global campaign to help poor people by encouraging them to start small businesses is expected to be endorsed by the Clinton Administration, several foreign leaders and leading development agencies at a meeting in Washington early next month.
Private anti-poverty groups have drawn up a plan that calls for $21.6 billion to be advanced to nearly 100 million poor people over the next eight years. The money would be in the form of small loans to finance entrepreneurial activities like small-scale farming or trade. 
 Among the plan's backers are major international aid agencies, banks, corporations and foundations. They believe such small loans -- often no more than a few hundred dollars -- offer the best way to help the roughly 2.5 billion people now living in abject poverty. Nearly two-thirds of those people are women and children.
Hillary Rodham Clinton will be co-chairwoman of the meeting, scheduled for Feb. 2 to 4, with Queen Sofia of Spain and Tsutomu Hata, a former Prime Minister of Japan. Speakers are to include the heads of the World Bank and the United Nations Development Program.
"We want to reallocate existing aid to microcredit schemes," said Nancy Barry of Women's World Banking, an organization promoting credit for poor women and one of the meeting's backers. "They are more efficient than public-sector spending because once the poor have incomes they can look after themselves."
No one doubts that giving the poor small credits, normally secured by no more than a collective pledge from neighbors that they will be repaid, can be an important tool to reduce poverty. Such credit plans, which had about a million clients in 1985, now have about 10 million.
The Grameen Bank in Bangladesh, the best-known institution offering such plans, has lent $1 billion to two million poor women and seen 97 percent of its loans repaid, which suggests that its clients are growing more prosperous.
But critics contend that the meeting's backers are making exaggerated claims that raise unrealistic expectations.
They say "microcredit," as such small loans are known, appeals to politicians by promising to reduce poverty without the pain of big aid budgets. Most microcredit organizations are financially nonviable and require subsidies, they say. And they fear that the ground swell of interest in microcredit will divert scarce aid funds from more mundane development goals like health and education improvement.
"They are evangelists who think they have discovered the Holy Grail of poverty reduction," says Ben Rogaly, a development expert at the University of East Anglia in Britain. "All the evidence suggests credit for self-employment benefits the better-off poor over the destitute," he said. "There is no stand-alone answer to poverty."
The decision to call the meeting next month reflects the support given to this approach by the United Nations. The meeting was organized by the Results Educational Fund, a Washington group that tries to mobilize support to fight hunger and poverty.
But only some 2 percent of the roughly $60 billion that donors spend on development assistance annually goes to microcredit plans, which reach only a tiny fraction of the world's poor. The United States provides about $130 million for such plans.
The meeting organizers hope to change this. Their goal is to raise the number of poor people with access to credit to 100 million by the year 2005 at an estimated cost of $21.6 billion.
About $7 billion would come from aid-giving countries and international organizations. Countries in the developing world would be asked for $1.6 billion and private corporations and anti-poverty groups for another $2.5 billion.
Microcredit organizations hope to raise an additional $2 billion in new deposits from their clients and to borrow another $8 billion commercially as they become viable.

HEADLINE: In the Two Koreas' Icy Rivalry, Signs of a Thaw

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Just last month, diplomacy on the Korean peninsula seemed a permafrost of enmity and distrust, with relations between North and South Korea as chilly and bleak as a rice paddy in winter.
Now there are signs of a thaw. No one knows whether it will get very far and nobody has ever made money betting on conciliation in Korea, but diplomats and scholars say that forces are at work to create far-reaching opportunities to reduce tensions on the Korean Peninsula over the next few years. 
 One opportunity will come this Wednesday, when officials from the United States and South Korea sit down in New York with senior diplomats from North Korea to discuss a proposal for talks that could lead to a formal end to the Korean War. The fighting was suspended in 1953 with a simple armistice, rather than a real peace treaty, and the border that gashes across the middle of Korea remains the site of the greatest massing of enemy troops on the globe.
"This is just one small step, but it's still a significant one," a senior South Korean official said of the coming week's talks. "It's like a baby taking its first step."
The meeting on Wednesday will be simply talks about talks, for North Korea has agreed only to accept a briefing about what the four-party talks -- involving the United States, China and the two Koreas -- would be about. But officials note that a handful of other efforts are also under way to ease tensions.
"I don't see peace breaking out this year, but I do see some significant progress in that direction," said Michael Breen, the head of a consulting firm here for businesses involved in North Korea.
Many people expect the United States and North Korea to open liaison offices in each other's capitals later this year, a step toward the eventual establishment of diplomatic relations. The United States may also ease its sanctions against North Korea and, together with Japan, send some food assistance.
North Korea is expected to approve further visits by American experts who would search for the remains of soldiers killed in the Korean War, and American and North Korean officials will also discuss the spread of missiles. Some diplomats think that North Korea could be induced to give up its entire ballistic missile program if the price were right.
And then, the ground-breaking is expected this spring on a project to build two new light-water nuclear reactors for North Korea, in exchange for its giving up its suspected nuclear weapons program. South Koreans would then be based at the construction site in North Korea.
More broadly, some see the virtual economic collapse in North Korea as creating new hopes for change. The notion is that the North may be so desperate that it will accept distasteful steps -- such as discussions with the South -- in exchange for vast amounts of assistance that the Government in Seoul is holding out as a lure.
"Further and expanded aid to the North depends on its attitude," said Kim Suk Woo, the Deputy Minister of National Unification.
"If North Korea is prepared to admit its economic difficulties and reach out and cooperate with South Korea," he added, "then a breakthrough could happen."
Mr. Kim said that among the steps that the South could take would be allowing tourists to go to the North, assisting the North's agricultural base, repairing flood damage, and authorizing South Korean companies to invest in the North. Collectively, such moves would amount to a revolution in relations between the two Koreas.
In a more modest step, the South Korean Government today authorized seven domestic companies to do business in the North, in such sectors as manufacturing textiles and bottling mineral water. South Korea has also agreed to send the North 300 tons of flour, a small amount but a hint of what the South could provide.
Some analysts say that one excellent omen was North Korea's willingness to express regret last month for having sent a submarine full of commandos into South Korean waters. That incursion last September had poisoned relations between the two Koreas and halted all plans for cooperation.
The statement of regret put America's policy of engaging North Korea back on track, but for now North Korea is still rejecting any discussions with the South.
"Frankly, it is highly unlikely that four-party talks will take place," said Kim Myong Chol, an unofficial spokesman for North Korea in Tokyo.
Mr. Kim said that North Korea was attending the briefing next Wednesday out of courtesy to President Clinton, rather than because of any real interest.
"North Korea has every reason to be polite to President Clinton, but we have no reason to listen to South Korea," Mr. Kim said. "So we don't foresee any improvement in relations between North and South Korea."
One reason for skepticism about the prospects for major improvement is simply the force of personalities, especially that of the South Korean President, Kim Young Sam. President Kim says that his mother was killed by North Korean commandos in 1960, and he clearly harbors a visceral hostility for North Korea -- which it reciprocates.
To be sure, Some officials say that President Kim is hoping to arrange a summit meeting in the latter half of this year with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il. But North Koreans may prefer to wait until Kim Young Sam leaves office early next year and hold a summit meeting with his successor.
Still, whether discussions come this year or next, most believe it is on the horizon. One reason is that North Korea is expected to name Kim Jong Il President and Communist Party leader this summer, after a three-year period of mourning to honor his father, the former North Korean leader Kim Il Sung.
Diplomats say that the prospect of North Korea again having a formal leader creates new possibilities, especially because Kim Jong Il is expected to try to raise funds so that he can celebrate his inauguration by bestowing gifts on the population.
North Korea has just reached a tentative deal with Taiwan to accept and store up to 200,000 barrels of low-level Taiwanese nuclear waste, in exchange for an initial payment of $75 million and more later on. That may pay for some of the festivities, but the most obvious way for North Korea to raise large sums in a hurry would be to talk peace with the South.

HEADLINE: Despite Agreements, Cleanups Are Slow to Come to the Border

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: CALEXICO, Calif.

 BODY:
Taking no chances, a team of state water quality engineers suited up like astronauts on a poisonous planet to take samples from the stinking, foaming stream that ripples through this dusty border town.
Wearing plastic face masks, coveralls and a double layer of gloves, they dipped bottles into the murky New River to measure the prodigious amounts of bacteria and other contaminants carried from Mexicali, Mexico, across a tattered fence. 
 Modest improvements over the last year to the Mexicali sewage system have given residents here hope that the river will eventually flow cleanly past the housing tracts and farmland in this town, 100 miles east of San Diego. But like much of the pollution cleanup along the border promised before the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect three years ago, major progress has yet to come.
After removing his gear and rinsing his hands, one water engineer, Charles Springer, sat near the riverbank and described the brackish water as somewhat cleaner than it was a few years ago, but still 2,000 times more polluted than the level considered safe for swimming.
"I've heard stories of people who've splashed themselves and had to go to the hospital," Mr. Springer said. "The water is definitely something you don't want to touch."
A report last year by the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, part of the Federal Department of Health and Human Services, showed that a witch's brew of contaminants from Mexico -- including sewage, chemicals from factories and pesticides from agricultural runoff -- feed into the river.
The sewage treatment plants in Mexicali, which cannot cope with the expanding population of one million, pour millions of gallons of raw and partly treated effluent into the stream each day.
Small enough to be called a creek almost anywhere but in the Mojave Desert, the New River runs through urban slums and past a slaughterhouse and a gantlet of oozing pipes before flowing into Calexico.
It then meanders north for 50 miles through Imperial Valley farmland until it empties into the Salton Sea, a landlocked lake that is polluted in its own right, primarily from agricultural sources in California.
Though the New River is lush with reeds, turtles and occasional wintering egrets, its problems are unmistakable. In some spots, the river is covered with soap foam and lacks the oxygen to support fish. When pollution is at its worst, the usually green algae-filled water runs black.
The Imperial County Health Department says the river carries micro-organisms capable of transmitting cholera, polio, tuberculosis and typhus. Signs in English and Spanish warn people to avoid contact with the water.
For Suod Rashid, who owns Jerusalem Sportswear in a shopping center, the nearby river is more an esthetic problem. Standing behind his cash register, he told of hours without customers on hot days, when the stench from the water is especially strong. The smell, he said, has led a nearby chiropractor to move.
"Sometimes when I open the store in the morning, I have to spray air freshener and get the air-conditioning going because it smells so bad," Mr. Rashid said.
After nearly 50 years of promising improvements, the United States and Mexican Governments are spending $5 million on "quick fixes" to improve the sewage system in Mexicali. Construction on a $70 million treatment plant, with possible financing from both countries, could begin in a few years.
The environmental side accords to Nafta were signed to insure that increased industrialization and population growth would be regulated and that existing pollution problems would be cleaned up. But since the accord went into effect in January 1994, it has become apparent to experts that the cleanups will take longer than expected.
"The problems are quite severe on the border," said Alan Hecht, principal international administrator at the United States Environmental Protection Agency, which released a five-year border-cleanup plan last month. "It's not something you'll fix quickly."
Hampered by its economic crisis, Mexico has allocated $100 million to $200 million in the last two years to clean up pollution in border towns. The amount is far short of predictions issued in the Nafta debate.
"Both Governments rushed to address the symbolism of border pollution," said Daniel Seligman, the director of international trade for the Sierra Club. "But once the free-trade deal was signed and delivered, they failed to carry through."
Officials of both countries hope to obtain a loan from the North American Development Bank, created by the Nafta side accords, to finance the treatment plant in Mexicali. The bank has approved four small projects, totaling $5 million to $8 million, that are unrelated to the Mexicali-Calexico problems. But it has not distributed the money.
In the meantime, irate residents in this bustling community of 19,000 have proposed damming the river at the border or piping it to the outskirts of town. But not much has come of that except frustration.
An Imperial County supervisor, Wayne Van De Graaff, is optimistic that the river's transformation is near. Though five American and Mexican presidents have visited the region over the years with promises to clean up the river, he said, official resolve these days is more serious. "Everybody wants to see this cleaned up," Mr. Van De Graaff said. "It's a stigma to the county."

HEADLINE: OPTIMISM GROWING THAT BUDGET DEAL CAN BE NEGOTIATED

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Two years ago, the Republicans proposed cutting $270 billion from the growth of Medicare spending over seven years, setting off a bitter political battle that has poisoned efforts to balance the Federal budget ever since.
But as the Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership in Congress prepare for yet another effort to eliminate the deficit by 2002, their differences on Medicare -- and on a number of other contentious issues -- have narrowed sufficiently so that both sides for the first time are expressing cautious optimism that they can reach a deal on a balanced budget this year. 
 "The groundwork has been laid pretty well," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, said in a television interview on Thursday.
President Clinton said on Wednesday that the odds of getting an agreement were "quite high." On Friday, the Democratic leader in the Senate, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said Congress and the White House "can agree by spring on a plan to end nearly three decades of red ink."
The remaining differences, over ideological approaches to the role of Government, as well as over spending levels, are big enough that neither side is taking a deal for granted, and neither is likely to eschew partisan rhetoric as it maneuvers for a negotiating advantage. Mr. Clinton is to send his budget proposals to Congress on Feb. 6, and the Republicans will flesh out their own proposals over the next month.
"I don't think the differences have narrowed as much as it might appear on the surface," said a Democratic Congressional aide involved in the budget process. "We're still in a honeymoon phase, and no one wants to appear not to be cooperative. But as we move forward, positions will harden."
On all the major issues, though, Democrats and Republicans have ground each others' positions down enough over the past two years that they start off within shouting distance of one another.
On Medicare, the Administration said last week that its budget proposal would call for $138 billion in spending reductions over six years, just $20 billion less than a comparable Republican proposal last year.
The gap could widen when the Republicans complete their new plan. But already, the focus of the debate over Medicare has shifted from the scale of the spending cuts to narrower issues, such as whether the Administration's plan fairly compensates health maintenance organizations and whether it relies too much on accounting gimmicks.
Mr. Clinton has said he would keep an open mind about a proposal from some Republicans to increase Medicare premiums for wealthy retirees. But after the political battering they took over Medicare last year, some Republicans said they were reluctant to push for such an increase.
The Republicans have consistently insisted on far larger tax cuts than the Democrats have been willing to accept. But the Administration's own tax-cutting proposals expanded during the Presidential campaign, and Mr. Clinton said this week that he could "envision being more flexible" on Republican demands for a reduction in the tax on capital gains, the issue that has most clearly divided the two sides. Republicans, in turn, have promised to consider Mr. Clinton's proposals for tax deductions and credits for college tuition.
Senate Republicans last week proposed a tax-cut package of $193 billion over five years. The Administration's tax-cutting proposal in its coming budget is expected to be valued at $100 billion to $130 billion.
Mr. Clinton has already said he would call for increases in spending on education, welfare and other domestic programs, and this weekend he proposed an expansion of the Federal food safety program. Republicans are certain to fight all or most of his proposals.
But the Republicans are no longer putting much firepower behind their calls to eliminate or scale back the Education, Commerce and Energy Departments, and after cutting overall discretionary spending on domestic programs in 1995 by more than $20 billion, to $490 billion, the Republicans voted to increase it last year to $503 billion.
After squabbling over the accuracy of the economic and technical assumptions underlying their competing budget plans, the White House and the Republicans in Congress have edged closer together, particularly in their estimates of the size of the deficit they must eliminate to balance the budget by 2002.
The Administration foresees needing to close a deficit of about $100 billion in 2002. The Congressional Budget Office's estimate is about $150 billion.
"If you simply look at the numbers, at the size of the problem and at the progress they made in 1995 and 1996, you'd have to say the stars are in alignment," said Van Doorn Ooms, a former policy director at the House Budget Committee.
"The objective conditions for a deal are very good," said Mr. Ooms, now a research director at the Committee for Economic Development, a business-financed research organization. "Having said that, one must always be aware of how many little things can go wrong in the process."
Indeed, for all the praise that Mr. Clinton's new Medicare proposals won from Republicans early last week, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, later excoriated one component of the plan that would shift spending on home health care from one Medicare account to another as part of a short-term fix for Medicare's financial problems.
"The President ought to be ashamed," Mr. Gramm said. "This is a proposal that says, 'I am content to deceive the American people.' "
But whether it is Medicare or some other budget category, neither side has been willing to embrace the deep, sustained cuts that would yield long-term fiscal stability, or to cancel or delay tax cuts to make eliminating the deficit easier.
So to some degree, the success of the budget negotiations will hinge on the White House and the Republican leadership finding mutually acceptable ways of avoiding or postponing difficult spending cuts.
For example, the Republicans have called for an increase in military spending in the next few years, and then a decline as 2002 draws nearer.
Similarly, the White House budget last year called for increases in domestic spending in the early years, and deep cuts in the years after President Clinton has left office. The plan also included a series of sketchy proposals that the Administration contended would bring in $30 billion in 2002, said Robert D. Reischauer, a former head of the Congressional Budget Office who is now a fellow at the Brookings Institution.
Martha Phillips, the executive director of the Concord Coalition, a fiscal watchdog group, said: "Any agreement they reach will not, at the end of the day, be a beautiful creature to behold. Both sides will claim to have solved the problem, but we will find out in a year or two that there's more work to be done."
