HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
America's Latest Export: A Stressed-Out World

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. SHWEDER; Richard A. Shweder, a cultural anthropologist, is Chairman of the Committee on Human Development at the University of Chicago.

 BODY:
ALONG with Coke, CNN and Visa, stress is rapidly spreading throughout the world. Or at least the word for it is.
In Tokyo, "stress" is enunciated in the midst of a stream of Japanese: "Shujin wa stress ga tamaru to okorippoku naru," a Japanese housewife complains to a friend. ("My husband becomes irritable when stress builds up.") On the streets of Moscow, the term suddenly pops up in the middle of this sentence: "V sostoyanii stress u menya vsyo valitsya iz ruk." ("In this state of stress I can't do anything right.") The English syllable is articulated by Hindi speakers in New Delhi, by Chinese speakers in Taiwan, by Spanish speakers in Seville. "Stress" seems to be on loan to most of the major languages of the world. 
 The history or epidemiology of the spread of the English word "stress" has yet to be documented, although it is a foreign entry -- a borrowed term -- in etymological lexicons for Russian, Polish and Bulgarian and in Kenkyusha's New Japanese-English Dictionary. The word has even propagated among Anglophobic French speakers in Paris, where it can be found in common usage (etat de stress, syndrome de stress) as well as in the "Dictionnaire des Anglicismes: Les Mots Anglais et Americains en Francais."
From tongue to tongue there are, of course, variations in the voicing and stressing of "stress." In Spanish it is pronounced "ess-TRESS." In Russian "STRESS-a." In Japanese "su-tor-es-u." Nevertheless, "stress," the Anglophonic sounding sound, is quickly becoming an Esperanto answer to all questions about spiritual, mental and physical well-being. How are you? Etat de stress. Esstress. Stressed out.
No one knows exactly how to explain the global success of the word, although it is safe to assume that the contemporary idea of stress was manufactured, patented and labeled in the English-speaking world in the latter half of the 20th century. And it is just as useful as a Visa card and as satisfying as a Coke. But what makes it so useful and satisfying? Why has it been so easy to export in the expanding free market for ideas?
One theory is that although stress may have been discovered here, it is a universal fact, a medically proven hazard in Manhattan, Tierra del Fuego or Katmandu. Thanks to American scientists, the rest of the world is finally catching on to the evils of stress and to the health benefits of a leisure society.
The word "stress" has old roots in a Low Latin word, "strictus," and ancient meanings like "afflict," "punish" and "pull asunder." Soon after World War II, though, the medical establishment began packaging a new concept of stress, the notion that the trials and tribulations of life trigger a physiological "stress response," resulting in measurable physical and mental illness. In 1950, Dr. Hans Selye, an outspoken physician also trained as an organic chemist, proposed that stress consists of physical changes in the endocrine system, including gastric ulceration and an overdevelopment of the adrenal cortex.
In later years, scientists championed other secretions and juices of the body (an increase in catecholamine, a fall in testosterone) as potential signs of a "stress syndrome." (In a similar enterprise, numerous English speaking pop psychologists have tried to translate the existentially laden words we once borrowed from Europe, "Angst," "ennui" and "Weltschmerz," into medical discourse.)
Unfortunately, there may be somewhat less to the medical image of a universal malignant "stress syndrome" than initially meets the eye. Some of the hormonal changes attributed to the "stress response" turn out to be associated with pleasant and health-promoting experiences as well, like sex and sports. And no one has yet traced or verified a true causal connection between secretions of catecholamine (or whatever) and actual human diseases of any kind.
The real rub, however, for the theory that "stress" is popular because it is a prevalent malady is that human beings are amazingly resilient. Only a small minority of those exposed to the fiery ordeals of life, like divorce or unemployment, develop a psychiatric disorder or become sick as a consequence. The most recent comprehensive review of stress, "The Effects of Stressful Life Events on Depression," published in the 1997 Annual Review of Psychology by Ronald Kessler of the Harvard Medical School, begins this way: "Despite ample theories of psychopathology and many associated empirical studies, it is uncertain whether stressful life events promote psychiatric disorders."
Fortunately, there is an alternative theory to explain the international embrace of "stress." The idea, popular among linguists and ironists, is that the word is exquisitely vague and elusive, unlike, say, "Angst," which points to the psyche or "Weltschmerz," which points to the world. When someone says, "I am stressed out," it isn't clear whether the source of suffering is inside or outside, subjective or objective, mental or physical. The cause of stress may be a harrowing event, a tormented mental state, a physiological impairment or just some chronic sense of cosmic uneasiness. No one knows.
 
 
 
Keep the Peace
 Imprecise and evasive language may be a disaster for science but it is a boon in everyday life. "I am stressed out" is non-accusatory, apolitical and detached. It is a good way to keep the peace and, at the same time, a low-cost way to complain.
It was not so long ago in the history of the world that pronouncements of suffering were occasions for making accusations and assigning responsibility. Personal misery was explained by pointing a finger at others or at oneself. This created conflict, guilt and ill will, and it often took time, effort and other scarce resources to make amends.
To say, "I am stressed out," though, is a no-fault verbal gambit. It is far less costly than claiming a nervous breakdown (which places the blame quite literally on one's mental processing system), less costly than Weltschmerz, or disenchantment with the world (which might require political action or even revolution), less costly than making accusations about being ripped off or put down (which might require legal action), less costly than confessing one's sins (which may require religious faith).
That is what makes the expression a ready-made and noncommittal (and indeed noncommittable) response to a variety of unavoidable questions, including "How are you?" "How are things going?" and, by the way, "Why are you behaving that way?"
"Stress" keeps a reputation intact. With a declaration of stress, no one is blamed and the sufferer is viewed as someone who actively copes with the strains and pressures of modern cosmopolitan living -- the kind of person who drinks Coke, watches CNN and carries a Visa card.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Transplant Surgery As a Kind of Contest

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"The Man With the Golden Hands" touches on the touchy matter of how the public, the press and the profession put pressure on doctors to try, or to hold back from trying, new and risky operations. But the program, the first of four about transplant surgery under the title "Knife to the Heart," doesn't cut very deep.
The focus tonight is on Dr. Christiaan Barnard, the South African surgeon who was turned into a celebrity in 1967 when he did the first human heart transplant. As this beat-by-beat account reminds us, the procedure was successful, but the patient died soon afterward. And that remained pretty much the situation in the next two years as surgeons around the world hastened to try their hands, not all golden, at it. One doctor attributes their race to egoism and nationalism. 
 In tonight's episode, the British producers, who go in for some dramatizing and other news-magazine techniques, give particular attention to Dr. Barnard's romantic exertions. (That's Gina Lollobrigida, fans.) His wife recalls deciding, "I must get rid of this guy." Dr. Barnard, interviewed at length, is frank about his medical and domestic missteps. More significantly, the program reports on progress in finding organs and preventing their rejection by the body. You can also hear cliche-clogged interviews with the widows and nurses of heart recipients. And that person dressed up like a surgeon who appears at the start and end of the hour is the narrator, Connie Chung. Next week, kidneys.

'The American Experience'
'Hawaii's Last Queen'
 PBS, tonight at 9
 (Channel 13 in New York)
Lydia Kamakaeha Liliuokalani may not be a household name in American history, but as tonight's offering from "The American Experience" tells the story, she played a prominent if passing role in the United States annexation of the Hawaiian Islands at the turn of the century.
Liliuokalani was Queen for something more than a day (about two years), but by the time she inherited the throne from her brother, King Kalakaua, in 1891, it had become clear that in Hawaii sugar ruled. With the arrival of cane-field workers from Japan and China (some carrying smallpox), the Hawaiians had become a minority in their own land. Economic and political power was closely held by white plantation owners, many of them the children of missionaries who had converted much of the country to Christianity and outlawed the hula. God and mammon seemed to be in cahoots.
Vintage pictures evoke the years of America's exercise in colonialism. Liliuokalani, who abdicated when faced with a company of marines, wrote in her diary, "May heaven look down on these missionaries and punish them for their deeds." Kalakaua, who reigned much longer, was a far more colorful figure, given to high living even as he tried to defend Hawaiian independence and traditions against overwhelming pressures. He is remembered for bringing back the hula.
As for "Hawaii's Last Queen," no one tonight has an unkind word to say about her, except perhaps that she wrote "Aloha Oe," the song we've had to listen to in every movie ever made about Hawaii.

HEADLINE: In America;
A Loss of Nerve

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"What a century it has been!" said President Clinton at his inauguration last week. "America became the world's mightiest industrial power, saved the world from tyranny in two world wars and a long cold war, and time and again reached across the globe to millions who longed for the blessings of liberty.
"Along the way, Americans produced the great middle class and security in old age, built unrivaled centers of learning and opened public schools to all, split the atom and explored the heavens, invented the computer and the microchip, and deepened the wellspring of justice by making a revolution in civil rights for African-Americans and all minorities and extending the circle of citizenship, opportunity and dignity to women." 
 It was the greatest, cockiest run in the history of the world. But why are we at such loose ends now? For most of the century the United States had the energy and exuberance and impertinence of youth. We didn't just fight and win wars, we invented Hollywood and rock 'n' roll, and made jazz one of the great art forms of the world. We hit home runs and stole bases and hollered at the umpires. We drove fast, played hard and laughed long into the night. We had nerve.
What happened?
You got no sense from Mr. Clinton's speech that we are in for a similar run across the 21st century. For the moment, at least, we seem exhausted, rudderless, disoriented. Our great dreams have given way to a corrosive apprehension. The descendants of the soldiers who got in Hitler's face are afraid to ask their bosses for a raise.
Mr. Clinton did not address this in his speech, but Robert Reich, in his last major address as Labor Secretary, hit the matter head on. As America continues to prosper, there is less and less of a sense that everybody has a stake in what is going on. More and more Americans are being left out. The folks at the top are doing breathtakingly well. But the large mass in the middle has been forced to work harder and harder (two jobs, three jobs, four) just to stay in place. Those at the bottom are falling out of sight.
(Recent very modest wage increases are filling the elites with fears of inflation. But at the same time, the inequality in earnings continues to widen.)
"The remarkable thing about the first three decades after World War II," said Mr. Reich, "is that prosperity was widely shared. Most people in the top fifth of the income ladder saw their real incomes double and so did most people in the bottom fifth. Broadly shared prosperity -- the assumption that we were all in this together -- highlighted and fortified something about the character of America that was the envy of the rest of the world."
That is now the stuff of nostalgia. Broadly shared prosperity is gone. What is left is great uncertainty and a sense of faintheartedness.
In an appendix to his speech, Mr. Reich wrote: "From the 1950's through most of the 1970's the income of the poorest fifth of Americans grew faster than the income of the top fifth. Between 1950 and 1978 the inflation-adjusted family income of the bottom quintile grew by 138 percent, while the real income of the richest 20 percent of families grew by 99 percent."
But between 1980 and 1995, he noted, the inflation-adjusted earnings of adults in the highest brackets rose by 10.7 percent while the median worker's wages fell 3.6 percent and those in the lowest brackets saw their wages decline by 9.6 percent.
Mr. Reich wrote: "Wealth is even more unevenly distributed than income. Not only does the richest 20 percent of the United States hold the bulk of the total wealth, but over the period from 1983 to 1992, this group received some 99 percent of the total gain in wealth."
You cannot sustain the American dream with those kinds of numbers. And the greatness of America is inextricably linked to the maintenance of the dream. The House Democratic leader, Richard Gephardt, in a speech Friday before the Economic Policy Institute, referred to the widening gap between working families and the well off as the nation's "one unacceptable problem."
America's great challenge as we move into the endgame of the Clinton-Gingrich era is to find new leadership that will point the way to honest solutions.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Democrats Search for Life Of Their Party

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
NIBBLING on chunks of cheese, waiting for the speeches to begin, the lobbyists traded stories. One told of how he had received a personal phone call from the party chairwoman, imploring him to attend. Another reported that he had bargained the ticket price down from $500 to $250.
"I probably could have gotten in for $50," he said, laughing ruefully at the thought. 
 On a recent chill evening, the New York State Democratic Committee held a fund-raiser in the Grand Salon of Manhattan's Essex House hotel. Even the dim lighting and the faux drawing-room elegance of the "salon" could not conceal the fact that this was a decidedly modest affair. About 75 people were in attendance, and of those, several were elected officials attending for free.
When the state's highest-ranking Democrat, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, addressed the group in his funereal baritone, the best he could muster on the state of affairs was: "This party is afloat."
Others use terms more like "adrift." New York's Democratic Party may finally be free from debt, but it is still very much a party on the outs -- outspent, out of power, and by the account of some of its own members, out of ideas. And even though registered Democrats in the state continue to outnumber Republicans by a margin of 3 to 2 -- in New York City, it's a margin of 5 to 1 -- Democrats speak openly about how difficult it will be to win back Gracie Mansion this fall, or the Governor's Mansion next year.
Fred Siegel, a professor of history at Cooper Union who describes himself as a "Democrat with frayed allegiances," put the party's problems this way: "It's not so much the Republicans have risen, as the Democrats have collapsed."
THINGS have looked pretty bleak for the Democratic Party for more than two years now, ever since then-Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was defeated byGeorge E. Pataki.
For 12 years, Mr. Cuomo had run the state's Democratic Party as a personal fief, installing his own operatives in its offices and doing little, many in the party muttered, to help candidates other than himself. When he went down, he left the party without much in the way of infrastructure as well as more than half a million dollars in debt.
"Those years," the party's current chairwoman, Judith Hope, said delicately, "were not used well in terms of strengthening the party at the local level."
Over the last two trying years, the party has managed to pay off its creditors and gradually to build up a war chest. It has also staved off further declines, a good sign, according to its leaders: since the Democrats didn't lose ground in races last fall, they are really making progress.
And if the party still lacks executive power, they say, it is busy laying the groundwork for future glory, doing the kind of local organizing that was too long neglected.
"This is the new Democratic Party," Mr. Silver declared at the recent fund-raiser. "It comes from the grass roots."
In light of the glaring problems facing New York Democrats these days, it is, however, easy to be skeptical of these arguments, which sound suspiciously like a new version of an old routine:
The party isn't dead. It's just resting.
THE most obvious problem for Democrats in New York right now is, awkwardly enough, the state's relative sense of well-being. The crime rate is down; key economic indicators are up. And as former Senator Bob Dole can attest, it's tough to make a case against an incumbent, even a not terribly popular one, when voters feel they are better off than they were four years ago.
But that's not the only problem. To the extent that Democrats have come up with a critique of Republican rule in New York, the critique often has a defensive, even ad hoc quality to it, sounding as if it were opposition for opposition's sake. Cut government services less, Democrats say. Or cut different services. Or don't lower taxes so much. Or lower different taxes.
Nor does one get the sense, listening to many of the state's most prominent Democrats, that they have really grappled with the underlying causes of their losses.
"The problem for the Democratic Party is people have turned away from government," Mr. Siegel observed. "And New York's Democratic Party, particularly in the city, remains first and foremost a party of government."
At the Essex House fund-raiser, Assembly Speaker Silver described the Democratic agenda for the coming months as fighting budget cuts proposed by Governor Pataki.
"The Governor has brought a lot of us together again," he said, looking out over the lobbyists around the cheese table.
After he spoke, one longtime Democratic operative predicted that by the end of the legislative session, the Governor's popularity probably would have declined. But so, too, he added, would the Democrats'.

LENGTH: 1254 words

HEADLINE: Fueled by Anger, Headed for the Border

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Dean Noble may live in Connecticut, but he no longer buys gasoline there. On a recent trip into Manhattan, Mr. Noble waited until White Plains to fill his tank.
"I feel so strongly about this, I'll risk running out of gas just to come to New York to buy it," Mr. Noble, a 37-year-old film director, said, estimating that he saved $3 with each out-of-state fill-up. 
 Mr. Noble is part of a growing exodus of drivers who cross state lines to buy their gas and avoid paying Connecticut's gasoline taxes, at 43 cents per gallon the nation's highest and 13 cents a gallon higher than New York's.
As recently as 1990 the gas taxes here were lower than in New York, but sharp, regular increases pushed the Connecticut taxes ahead of New York's in 1992, and a 1993 law set more increases, including four penny-a-gallon increases last year and another one this Jan. 1.
This rat-a-tat-tat of increases, the informal boycott and a campaign by service station owners have led officials here to talk of a gas tax revolt and to make reducing the taxes the top priority of the new legislative session.
Taxes aside, the price of gas has been higher than at any time in years, adding more pressure to reduce the state's gas taxes, which include a 39-cent excise tax and a 4-cent gross receipts tax.
Connecticut's gas prices are surpassed in this country only by Hawaii's, according to a survey releases this month by the American Automobile Association.
"People are outraged by this tax," said State Representative Carl J. Schiessl, a Windsor Locks Democrat who is co-chairman of the Legislature's tax policy committee. "The question is no longer whether we cut the gas tax, but how we're going to do it."
Connecticut is not alone in its concern that taxes may send residents flocking to neighboring states. Last week, New York had a temporary moratorium on its sales tax in a bid to stop people from crossing the Hudson River to shop in New Jersey, where there is no sales tax on clothing.
The growth of Connecticut's gas taxes can be traced to 1983, when the Mianus River Bridge in Greenwich collapsed, killing three people. The following year, the state established a special transportation fund to address problems with bridges and roads, and the gas tax was designated its primary revenue source.
Since then, the state has spent more than $13 billion on roads and bridges, and as the program has grown, the gas tax has grown with it.
A report last month by a nonpartisan think tank, the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, chronicled the path of the excise tax on gas: it was 14 cents in 1984, 22 cents in 1990, and is now 39 cents.
The New York gasoline taxes of about 30 cents have increased by a nickel since 1990. New Jersey's taxes of 14.5 cents have remained virtually unchanged for seven years.
Michael Meotti, the Connecticut council's president, listed two reasons for Connecticut's increase. One was the cumulative growth of the debt from the 20-year bonds used to finance the state's road repair program. The other was the state's budget problems in the late 1980's and early 1990's. At that time, the Legislature increased the gas tax to pay for things like fringe benefits for Transportation Department employees and the operating budget for the state police, Mr. Meotti said.
Given the increases, the movement to reduce gasoline taxes was "probably inevitable," the council's report concluded.
The aversion to Connecticut gas prices can be seen starkly at service stations near the borders.
One recent morning, Robert Springer, a retired teacher, picked up his car from Arcouette Auto Center in Enfield, where it had been repaired, but he declined an offer to fill the tank. "I try to plan my trips so that I buy my gas over there," he said, gesturing to the Massachusetts state line less than a mile away.
Tim Arcouette, whose family owns the station, was sympathetic. "I don't blame you," he said, admitting that his brother had recently bought fuel for their tow truck in Massachusetts.
Over the next hour, only one car pulled in for gas. Mr. Arcouette's father, Ed, 70, the business's founder, said that five years ago there would have been a steady stream of cars at the pumps.
"Even our most devoted customers are starting to go by the wayside," he said. "They've all gone down the road."
Seven-tenths of a mile down Maple Road, 20 feet over the border in Longmeadow, Mass., eight cars with Connecticut plates were lined up for gas at Mimi's Mobil. A gallon of regular unleaded cost $1.35, a dime less than at Arcouette's.
The taxes, which are estimated to cost the average driver about $200 a year, are much heavier than in other Northeastern states.
Connecticut's gas taxes of 43 cents per gallon compares with 29 cents in Rhode Island; 21 cents in Massachusetts, and 30 cents in New York, the economic policy council said.
The automobile association's January report showed that the average price for a gallon of unleaded was $1.50 in Connecticut, $1.40 in New York, $1.37 in Rhode Island, $1.34 in Massachusetts and $1.23 in New Jersey.
A lawyer in one Hartford suburb, who had just returned from a visit to New York City, said she was shocked to discover that her neighborhood gas station charged more for gas than a full-service station in midtown Manhattan.
While proposals to cut the tax foundered last year, five bills to reduce it have already been offered this year, two weeks after the session opened. The Senate Democrats, who a few years ago approved the tax increases that recently took effect, now favor cutting it.
And Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, who was largely silent on the gas tax in his first two legislative sessions, began this one by decrying it as "highway robbery."
This turnabout in the political climate is partly a result of the lobbying campaign orchestrated by service station owners. They have organized town meetings with elected officials, called radio shows and posted fliers on gas pumps across the state.
The taxes are not a large part of the state budget. Last year, they raised $460 million, a little less than 5 percent of state revenue. With the state projected to have its sixth straight surplus this year, lawmakers said there should be adequate resources to cover a reduction.
Still, some lawmakers think that cutting the gas taxes does not make sense. State Representative David H. Pudlin, a Democrat of New Britain, said the proposed reductions would probably be so small as to have no real impact on people's pocketbooks and offer little benefit to the economy.
"Gas prices go up and down a few cents every day," he said. "A cut in the gas tax is not necessarily something that people will notice."
Mr. Meotti noted that money from the gas taxes had had a clear impact. The Federal Government in 1994 studies ranked Connecticut's roads and bridges as being in better condition than elsewhere in the Northeast, he said. Thirty-one percent of Connecticut's bridges were found to be deficient, compared with 46 percent in New Jersey and 63 percent in New York.
Many Connecticut drivers have restructured their lives to avoid buying gas in the state. While buying fuel at a Mobil Station on the Hutchinson River Parkway in White Plains, Felix Benitez, who lives in Bethel, Conn., and works as a doorman in Larchmont, N.Y., explained, "When I leave for work in the morning, I only put the littlest amount in -- only what I need to get to the New York border. Then I come here to fill up the rest of the tank."

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises sales of bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction a new 10-year inflation-indexed note.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.01 percent and on the six-month bill, 5.11 percent. In when-issued trading, the new 10-year inflation index note was offered at a price to yield 3.49 percent.

HEADLINE: Voice of Britain, First Thing Each Day

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
It is hard to imagine a more convincing example of one broadcast's impact on its own culture than the one that recently emerged about Britain's leading news program.
In a new book on postwar politics, the historian Peter Hennessy reported that he had discovered the procedure that the commander of a Royal Navy submarine somewhere in the depths of the North Atlantic was officially counseled to follow to find out whether Britain would have survived a nuclear strike. 
 As the final step before opening sealed orders on retaliation, the skipper was to tune in to the BBC and listen for the network's "Today" program. "If the Trident commander could not pick up 'Today,' that would be that," Professor Hennessy wrote.
"He would then have to decide whether to launch the missiles or go off to New Zealand. He would know that there was no point in going back to base."
Many Britons -- at least those four million who tune in to the program each morning -- would not quarrel with that definition of the show's indispensability to British life.
More than any other news program, it sets the agenda for public discussion in a country with a particular appetite and talent for debate. The Evening Standard recently called the program "the unacknowledged legislator of 1990's Britain," while its most famous host over 40 years, Brian Redhead, called it the best way of "dropping a word in the ear of the nation."
The current hosts of "Today," the nimble John Humphrys, Sue MacGregor and James Naughtie, are as well known here as the anchors of network newscasts are in the United States, and they labor under at least two disadvantages in that comparison: They are on radio, not television, and their program is broadcast at 6:30 A.M.
The major figures in public life clamor for the chance to appear on the program, even though it means a bracing encounter with aggressive interrogators and a ride across London to the Broadcast House studios in the predawn hours or a remote feed truck parked in their driveways in the middle of the night.
Contrary to prevailing trends on radio and television, "Today" has made its content increasingly serious in recent years, and manages to be contentious without descending to "Crossfire"-type slugging matches.
Politicians from Britain's two biggest parties have smarted from the sharper-edged questions, and, in a series of attention-getting episodes, set out to discredit their tormenters, though always unsuccessfully.
"They've learned that when you lose your temper that early in the morning, you lose," said Justin Everard, a spokesman for "Today."
"Grown-up politicians like a tough interview," said Mr. Humphrys, who is the most prosecutorial in style of the three hosts -- known in this country as presenters. Last month, when Prime Minister John Major wanted to address his falling fortunes in a BBC interview from his home, he requested that Mr. Humphrys be the questioner. Margaret Thatcher, Mr. Major's predecessor, used to call in to the show, and she judged the mettle of her ministers by how well they held their own against the combative "Today" presenters.
"Of course we get letters saying you were hard on so-and-so," Mr. Humphrys noted. "You got it wrong and all that kind of thing. But when it comes to our attitude to the politicians -- especially the politicians -- the message overwhelmingly is, 'Don't let the bastards get you down; stick it to them.' In fact, we want you to be tougher."
Seated around the kidney-shaped table in Studio 4B, their early-morning cockpit, his two colleagues nodded in agreement. "The audience expects it of us, much more than Americans do," Ms. MacGregor said.
Americans might see their methods as verging on hectoring, but "the British would feel betrayed if we didn't ask tough questions," Mr. Naughtie said.
And while an abortive attempt was made some years ago to transform "Today" into a television program, the hosts have resisted the idea.
"There's a kind of radio culture of discussion and journalistic sharpness with words that we've kept going," Mr. Naughtie said. "There's a huge tradition in this country of listening to speech radio."
"It has a directness," he added, "that makes bluffing quite difficult."
The three hosts rotate through the six-day-a-week schedule so that two of them are on every morning. They have a jocular camaraderie on the air, but also consider themselves surrogates for their no-nonsense-please listeners, the people who fill letters-to-the editor columns with laments signed "Disgusted of Cheltenham" and the like.
On a recent morning, the program had a typical mixture of subjects: business and sports reports, the reviews of the morning papers and the interviews -- a Labor Party victory in an off-year election, proposed new restrictions on combat knives, a tuition increase at the London School of Economics, a meeting of European leaders in Dublin, overcrowding in British prisons, the effects of the embargo on Iraq and the newspaper-circulation war between The Times and The Daily Telegraph.
The interviewing is civil, articulate and often contrarian. When Peter Stothard, editor of The Times, took his seat prepared to argue that his paper's increased circulation stemmed from its improving quality, Ms. MacGregor began the questioning by saying, "Now it's really the price cuts, isn't it?" The hosts cannot abide wordy responses, and will not hesitate to cut off a windy guest.
"The most exasperating thing for us and for the listeners," Mr. Humphrys said, "is to allow the interviewee to ramble and obfuscate." When a harried Cabinet member accused him of having interrupted 32 times in 10 minutes, Mr. Humphrys rushed to correct him. It was only five minutes, he said.
Each of the interviewers will let listeners know when they find an assertion far-fetched, which is often. Sometimes, it's a particularly skeptical tone of voice, other times it can be a times-up declaration.
"Oh, come on," is one of Mr. Naughtie's favored phrases.
This particular morning, Mr. Humphrys was wrapping up an interview with Graham Barton, managing director of Battle Orders, a mail-order source for combat knives.
Mr. Humphrys: "All right, here's a suggestion for you. How about stopping selling them?"
Mr. Barton responded: "I'd happily stop," he said, "if there was any link that could be put forward to say that one of the knives that I have sold over the course of the last 20 years has been used in an incident."
Mr. Humphrys: "Oh, that is preposterous, you have no way of knowing whether they've been used or not, have you? Do you know every single person who has ever bought a knife from you ?"
Mr. Barton: "Neither does anybody else selling knives, John."
Mr. Humphrys: "Well, I've already suggested you could stop selling them altogether, but there we are, Graham Barton. Thank you very much."
Mr. Humphrys was a local newspaperman in Wales before joining the BBC in 1966. He covered Northern Ireland and had a series of overseas assignments before becoming, in 1971, the network's first full-time television correspondent in the United States. He later went to South Africa and returned to London in the 1980's as a broadcast host.
Ms. MacGregor, lately from England, was raised in South Africa. She has spent her entire career in broadcasting, serving as host for 15 years of a BBC program called "Woman's Hour." Though her questioning can be persistent, her timber is soothing and her diction exacting, and those traits have earned her a nickname she abhors, Nanny to the Nation.
Mr. Naughtie -- the "gh" is pronounced like a "k" -- is from Scotland, something that is immediately apparent when he speaks. He has never met an "r" he couldn't roll and has a love for gripping consonants. After his studies at Aberdeen University and journalism courses at Syracuse University, he became a newspaperman in Scotland, moving to London in 1977 to cover politics for The Scotsman and then The Guardian. He joined the BBC in 1988.
The "Today" program coexists with some charming BBC anachronisms. Half an hour before the show, listeners are treated to the Radio 4 medley, a sprightly orchestral collection of "Early One Morning," "Men of Harlech" "Danny Boy" "Scotland the Brave" and, with drums rolling, "Rule Britannia." There is an agricultural report, a feast of regional accents from all over the British Isles, and a shipping forecast from some of the most poetically named spots on earth -- Ronaldsway, Malin Head, Baily, Rockall, Cromarty, Forth, Tyne, Dogger, German Bight, Humber, Finisterre, Sole.
During the two and a half hour program, there are pauses for a prayer for the day and a thought for the day. Birthdays of the Queen and her immediate family are noted with best wishes and happy returns.
The show is criticized for its preoccupation with politics and its relative lack of interest in literature, science, technology and the world of ideas. Like the British press in general, it is London-centric and pays scant attention to concerns outside this area. There are periodic suggestions of changing the mix, but at the BBC, formulas, particularly those perceived to be working, stay fixed.
Professor Hennessy, in reporting his discovery of the "Today" program's role in Britain's military planning, called it "a final if macabre tribute to a broadcasting service sans pareil."
He also noted that one of the voices a commander was to listen for in particular was the regionally idiosyncratic one of Mr. Naughtie. It was left to The Daily Mail the next morning to write a fitting epitaph. "When Naughtie falls silent," the paper said, "the end is nigh."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Near a program's end, Sue MacGregor and John Humphrys, seated, take a call, and James Naughtie observes. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 469 words

HEADLINE: Block Legalization of Casinos

 BODY:
Legalizing casino gambling is a lot like betting against the house. Promises of windfall riches are seductive to states. But by the time the risks are revealed, there will be no way to dismantle the gambling trade or pay for the social and economic costs gambling imposes on weakened communities.
The New York Legislature is poised to vote a second time on a state constitutional amendment to legalize gambling. The Legislature approved the measure last year. If it does so again this year, a statewide referendum on the issue will be placed before voters on the November ballot. 
 The Senate is expected to vote on the question tomorrow, with the Assembly considering the issue in February. It is not clear that the amendment has sufficient support to pass either house. But lobbying efforts by business interests in areas where casino gambling would be allowed -- Niagara Falls, the Catskills, Buffalo and Lake George -- have been intense. Though few legislators are gambling boosters, many may yet be convinced by spurious arguments that New York should snatch gambling dollars from New Jersey and Connecticut, or that casinos on Indian lands justify expanding gambling elsewhere.
The actual costs and benefits of legalized gambling are hard to quantify. Experiences in states such as Illinois, Indiana and South Dakota suggest that gambling does little for economic development, but creates costs for law enforcement and social services that outweigh economic benefits from the casinos. New York cannot afford to take a gamble that has paid off in very few places, if any.
The argument that the existence of casinos on Indian lands should open the gates to non-Indian casinos is equally wrong. The only Indian-run casino in New York, Turning Stone, was created by a compact drawn between the state and the Oneida tribe under the Federal Indian Gaming Act of 1988. Turning Stone does not have slot machines -- considered by many experts to be the most addictive form of gambling -- and it does not serve alcohol. The constitutional amendment would allow slot machines, and would not prohibit alcohol at the new casinos. Future expansion of Indian-run establishments may be limited by a Supreme Court ruling on Indian gaming rights delivered last year.
Some legislators now say they will approve the measure solely to get the issue to the voters in November. That is an abdication of legislative duty. Legislators are paid to deal with the merits of legislation, not to pass the buck to voters. It would be absurd to unleash a massive campaign by the pro-gambling forces to influence voters if these lawmakers believe that gambling is bad for New York. Legislators who vote for this measure will give gambling their approval, regardless of their twisted efforts to squirm out of that position.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Syria And Israel

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The head of Syria's delegation in the peace talks with Israel says that Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin made a commitment to withdraw from all of the Golan Heights as part of a peace agreement -- and that his successor, Shimon Peres, reaffirmed the commitment.
Walid al-Moualem, the Syrian Ambassador to the United States, made that among many points about the negotiations in an interview just published in the Journal of Palestine Studies. His comments are an unusually detailed statement of the Syrian view. 
 The Ambassador said that in January 1996 the talks with Israel were going so well that the two sides set a deadline of June "to close the remaining gaps," with the expectation that "by September the final document would be ready." Then Mr. Peres called early elections, terrorist bombs struck Israel and the Syrian-Israeli negotiations were suspended.
The interviewer, Linda Butler, managing editor of the Journal, asked Mr. al-Moualem "through what medium" Mr. Rabin had conveyed his withdrawal offer. He replied, "I prefer not to say." But he said the offer was repeated in the negotiating room at the Wye Plantation in Maryland. "And I told Dennis Ross [the American facilitator in the talks]: 'Please register what the Israeli side said.' "
Because the aim was "a comprehensive agreement," Mr. al-Moualem said, the parties did not sign points agreed but deposited them with the Americans until all the issues had been resolved. The main matters to be negotiated apart from the Syrian demand for total withdrawal from the Golan were security arrangements and normalization of relations.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israeli Ambassador in Washington played a significant part in the talks, took a very different view of what happened when I telephoned him. He has returned to a professorship in history at the University of Tel Aviv.
"There was no agreement" on withdrawal, he said; "there was no commitment, there was no promise." If Mr. al-Moualem heard something from someone on the Israeli side, Mr. Rabinovich said, "it was not deposited with the Americans." As for finishing an agreement by September if the talks had continued, he said: "I don't think this would have happened."
What really occurred, Mr. Rabinovich said, was that Mr. Ross and other American participants, seeking to bridge the gap, were given to understand by the Israelis that full withdrawal "was in the realm of the possible" -- but only if Syria met Israel's needs on security and normalization. And "the Israeli conditions were never met."
Ambassador Rabinovich called the al-Moualem interview "a very interesting document, the most explicit and detailed Syrian comment on these negotiations."
Mr. al-Moualem said Prime Ministers Rabin and Peres both "wanted to achieve a settlement with Syria, but each had his own speed and conditions. Rabin was reluctant, suspicious, very cautious. He moved very slowly, inch by inch. When Peres became Prime Minister, he was in a hurry." Mr. Rabinovich said he agreed that "Rabin was too slow and Peres too quick."
On security issues, Mr. al-Moualem underlined Syrian rejection of Israel's proposal for a ground station in the Golan after withdrawal. "We would refuse," he said, "even if it would be manned by Americans."
On normalization, he said totally open economic relations would not work when Syria had a per capita income of $900 a year and Israel $15,000. He said the parties had discussed "a transitional period during which we could raise our economy to the level where there can be competition without undue hardship on our society."
The interview makes clear how bleak the prospect is now for the Israeli-Syrian talks. Mr. al-Moualem said Syria was ready to resume them if the new Israeli Government of Benjamin Netanyahu recognized "the commitments made by the previous Governments." Mr. Netanyahu, who has opposed withdrawal, said only last week that the Golan was "critical to the defense of the state of Israel."
"Nothing can compensate the Syrian people for losing one inch of the Golan," Mr. al-Moualem said. "Not even the moon. It is a sacred cause. . . .
"That is where we stand. The American efforts are now focused on the Palestinian track. We don't mind. We are not in a hurry."

HEADLINE: Aid Cuts Put College Beyond Reach of Poorest Students

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
As state governments keep whittling away their support for higher education, tuition at public institutions is likely to continue rising as financial aid shrinks, moving college further beyond the reach of poor students, education experts say.
"There has been a redistribution of educational opportunity," said Thomas G. Mortenson, a higher education policy analyst in Iowa City and a senior scholar at the National Council of Educational Opportunity Associations in Washington. 
 To some experts, New York State is a case in point. Earlier this month, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed to increase tuition at New York's public universities by $400 a year and reduce state aid for the state's neediest students. Tuition at both the State University colleges and City University would rise to $3,600 a year at CUNY's four-year colleges and $3,800 a year at SUNY's.
Governor Pataki's proposals are not certain to be adopted; the Legislature rejected similar cuts last year. But experts say that higher tuition and reduced aid are inevitable.
"It's not this 400 bucks that Governor Pataki is proposing, it's the general pattern," said Arthur Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University.
At the City University of New York, which charged no tuition until 1976, tuition now accounts for 43 percent of the four-year college's budget, up from 19 percent seven years ago, CUNY's current budget proposal shows. Students there say any increases strain their stretched personal budgets.
"If tuition goes up, I don't think I will have to drop out, but it will not be pleasant," said Michelle Whitfield, a 34-year-old Harlem resident who is a voice student at Brooklyn College's Conservatory of Music.
She works 30 hours a week as a temporary worker doing word processing on Wall Street to pay for college and to support herself and her elderly mother. She earns too much to qualify for financial aid, she said, but had to withdraw from college last spring when she ran out of money. Although she is back in school, she said she might have to sit out future semesters if costs rise.
Higher-income and middle-income students have been going to college in ever-greater numbers as college becomes an increasingly important factor in earning a decent salary. But lower-income students are going in about the same proportions that they did in the 1970's.
For decades, public universities have remained an important source of higher education for those who cannot afford private institutions. Today, more than 80 percent of America's college students study at public universities.
But while these universities are still considerably less expensive than most private colleges, they, too, are increasingly pricing themselves beyond the means of the poorest Americans, experts say.
Morton Owen Schapiro, dean at the University of Southern California and a specialist in the economics of higher education, said that tuition at public colleges and universities had risen by an annual average of 4 percent to 4.5 percent after inflation since the late 1970's, well ahead of the growth in financial aid.
"That is going to hurt a lot of people," he said, adding that while some private colleges offer generous financial aid to needy students, most of them go to public institutions.
He and Michael S. McPherson, president of Macalester College in St. Paul, have found that public subsidies to higher education have shrunk from 45 percent of higher education's revenues in 1980 to 35 percent today -- most of it to public universities.
Compounding the financial problems of many students are continuing cuts in financial aid. Federal Pell grants, aimed at helping the nation's neediest students pay expenses other than tuition, now amount to a maximum of $2,700 for students at public four-year colleges. Mr. Mortenson calculates that had they kept pace with inflation, they would amount to more than $5,500 today.
For many students, state tuition support has declined, too. For 20 years, New York's Tuition Assistance Program -- available to students with incomes below a certain level -- had always covered tuition at the public universities for students who qualified. But in 1995, New York reduced the maximum award for public university students to 90 percent of tuition.
And now Governor Pataki has again proposed that students who receive Pell grants as well as state tuition assistance should receive less from the state program.
To some extent, the impact of these financial pressures has been camouflaged by the steady growth in college attendance by more affluent students and by older people. But students from poor families have increasingly been left behind.
Mr. Mortenson has found that the proportion of students earning college degrees by age 24 from families in the richest quarter of the population (in 1994, those with incomes above $65,000) has jumped sharply, to 79 percent in 1994 from 31 percent in 1979. But the rate among students from families in the poorest population (with 1994 incomes below $22,000) stayed flat over the same years, at about 8 percent.
Looking at the trend another way, affluent students were nearly four times as likely as the poorest ones to graduate from college by age 24 in 1979, but nearly 10 times as likely in 1994. "We have greater inequality of educational attainment by age 24 than at any time in the last 25 years," Mr. Mortenson said. "Lower income kids are having a terrible time in higher education."
In 1995, City University surveyed 545 CUNY students who had left the university system even though they were in good academic standing. Thirty-four percent cited lack of money or the need to work as the reason. When the City University raised tuition by $750 in 1995 and New York State cut financial aid, the university saw a sudden drop in undergraduates: 138,000 students enrolled at its four-year colleges, 4,500 fewer than the previous year and about 6,500 fewer than projected.
"I am convinced that the reason was simply financial," said the university's Chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds. "Students needed to have much more cash on the barrel. I am convinced that we are denying opportunity for poor students to go to college."
City University, the nation's largest urban university system, has the highest percentage of students in poverty: about 40 percent of the 139,000 undergraduates at its four-year colleges come from households with incomes of less than $20,000. More than half of all undergraduates -- 85,000 -- qualify for Pell grants, and 72,000 get tuition assistance from New York State.
Still, more than half of the students also work: 27 percent hold full-time jobs and 32 percent work part time -- many to support their own families, because 29 percent have children.
Even with multiple sources of support, many City University students encounter financial problems, which are reflected in their frequent moves in and out of school and the longer time they take to graduate.
Abdul Khan, a 36-year-old immigrant from Pakistan and an engineering major at City College, has been forced to skip semesters because his full-time job at a newsstand -- which pays $13,000 a year -- leaves little extra money after living expenses. If costs rise further, he said, "maybe I can take one semester every year."
Mr. Mortenson, the analyst of higher education, said that if financial aid is not increased, one answer for students like Mr. Khan may be to take out more loans -- an often unpalatable option for those unsure they will be able to finish college.
David Torres, a 35-year-old psychology major at Brooklyn College who lives in Ozone Park, Queens, said he had weighed taking out a loan, now that he has exhausted his state tuition assistance.
"But loans terrify me," he said. "What if I don't finish and can't pay it off? It's scary."
Mr. Mortenson has an answer for students like Mr. Torres.
"What I tell kids," he said, "is that as scary as paying for college is, you have to go. The only thing more expensive than going to college is not going to college."

HEADLINE: MEDIA: ENTERTAINMENT;
At Sundance, disappointment over the latest independent films.

BYLINE: By Bernard Weinraub 

DATELINE: PARK CITY, Utah

 BODY:
AT a panel discussion the other morning on the economic state of the independent film business, Jonathan Dana, a veteran producer and movie company executive, opened the session on a Dickensian note: "It was the best of times; it was the worst of times." The crowd of independent film producers, writers and aspiring film makers laughed -- but knew exactly what Mr. Dana meant.
Although the 13th annual Sundance Film Festival in the Wasatch mountains of Utah has been marked by high-profile film acquisitions made by such companies as Miramax, Gramercy, Fine Line, Sony Classics and Fox Searchlight, the reality of the festival is that the bulk of the 127 films shown here may never see the light of day. (And the more than 1,200 feature films actually submitted to the festival will certainly struggle to find a distributor). 
 "It's basically Darwinian -- survival of the fittest," said Tom Bernard, co-president of Sony Pictures Classics.
Russell Schwartz, president of Gramercy Pictures, remarked: "It never ceases to amaze me. Where do all these films come from? Unfortunately, a lot of them are not audience friendly."
Mr. Dana observed, "Last year there was an astounding group of films -- you had 'Shine,' for example; you had 'Big Night.' This year it's not quite as voluminous in terms of quality. There's a sense of disappointment. How do you get all these films into the marketplace? You don't. It's rougher now than it's ever been. The stakes are higher."
Independent films are characterized as those movies not made by studios. Smaller independent films -- costing $25,000 to $200,000 -- are usually financed by credit cards, personal savings, family money and rich uncles.
Films in the million-dollar-plus range are financed by companies like Miramax, Fine Line, Gramercy and Fox Searchlight (which are owned by entertainment giants like Disney, Warner Brothers, Polygram and the News Corporation.) as well as by video and pay-television outlets and private investors. European, Australian and Japanese companies -- whose representatives were prowling the snowy streets of Park City -- were also in evidence.
Financially, Sundance's fare divides into two categories: those movies that have already been picked up for distribution by companies like Miramax and Fine Line, and those -- the vast majority -- still looking for distributors.
Last year, the most widely discussed film at the festival, "Shine," directed by Scott Hicks about the Australian pianist David Helfgott, was sold to Fine Line for domestic rights for more than $2 million. So far, it has returned about $12 million at the box office in the United States.
But the "Shine" sale came after a dispute between Miramax, Fine Line and the producer selling the film that almost led to a fist-fight at a restaurant here. (The average purchase price of films here hovers between $400,000 and $800,000).
The most amazing sale last year -- and one that is still talked about -- was the purchase by Castle Rock of a modest drama, "The Spitfire Grill," for $10 million. (It has grossed about $12.5 million.)
No film shown at Sundance had ever fetched such a price, and it is widely believed that Castle Rock could have probably bought the movie for far less. Owned then by Ted Turner and now by Warner Brothers, Castle Rock was flush with money but poorly advised. Chastened, Castle Rock was not a very visible buyer this time around.
So far several films have been sold in the $2 million to $3 million range, but there has been a general sense of disappointment among buyers, in part because this crop of movies focused heavily on so much teen-age angst and tortuous twentysomething relationships.
Among the big sales: Miramax's purchase of Mark Waters's "The House of Yes," a black comedy about incest; Fox Searchlight bought Miguel Arteta's "Star Maps," a drama about a Mexican teen-ager in Los Angeles who sells maps to the homes of movie stars; Gramercy bought Mark Pellington's "Going All the Way," based on the Dan Wakefield coming-of-age drama about two Korean War veterans in the 1950's; Trimark purchased Tom DeCillo's comedy, "Box of Moonlight," in which John Turturro plays a man at odds with his family and co-workers.
"The deals this year are less dramatic in nature and less contentious," said Mark Ordesky, executive vice president of acquisitions for New Line and Fine Line. "Let's face it -- people aren't slugging it out."
Amir Malin, a partner in October Films, the New York-based company which released "Secrets and Lies" and "Breaking the Waves," put it more bluntly. "This has been an off-Sundance," he said. "Some films have been acquired in an almost knee-jerk way for all the wrong reasons -- to fill a distributor's pipeline. It's going to be very difficult to attract box office on many of these films."
Some of the films that don't open in theaters will appear on cable or pay TV; others will go directly into video stores. But even those independent films that find distributors and wind up at theaters are often doomed. Last year, for example, the majority of Sundance films that reached theaters proved disappointing at the box office.
What originally transformed Sundance -- and made investors and studios realize the financial potential for independent films -- was the unexpected success of Steven Soderbergh's dark 1989 comedy, "sex, lies and videotape," grossing more than $24 million. More recently, two independent films, "Four Weddings and a Funeral," released by Gramercy and grossing $250 milliion around the world, and Miramax's "Pulp Fiction," which took in at least $200 million worldwide, raised expectations to an unrealistic level.
But independent films are increasingly risky in the marketplace despite the fact that they made up the bulk of last year's most acclaimed films -- among them, "The English Patient," "Shine," "Secrets and Lies," "Fargo." The mantra of distributors at Sundance was that profit margins were diminishing, marketing costs were increasing and the glut of films was hitting independent films especially hard.
"There's a blockbuster mentality now for independent films, too," observed John Schmidt, a partner in October Films with Mr. Malin and Bingham Roy. "If you don't do well quickly you're out of theaters."
Amy Israel, vice president of acquisitions at Miramax, cited one recent film, "Walking and Talking," about teen-agers, which was a big success at last year's Sundance Festival but never quite made it at the box office. "I loved it," Ms. Israel said. "It just never had time to sit in the theaters. It's a shame that smaller films can't take their time at the marketplace."

HEADLINE: As Casino Vote Nears, Opponents Wage Vigorous Campaign

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 26

 BODY:
With the State Legislature preparing to cast its deciding vote on a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling, the ever-present throb of lobbying here has risen to a dull roar.
Lobbyists, lawyers, ministers, business leaders and regular citizens have buttonholed legislators and pressed them with memos and glossy brochures. They have opened phone banks to inundate lawmakers with imploring calls. And they have deluged communities with postcards urging voters to call or write their representatives. 
 Although frenetic lobbying was widely expected on such a contentious and money-driven issue, many lawmakers say they have been astonished by the size and aggressiveness of the opposition, who have made the bill's supporters seem muted by comparison.
"They're like bees on honey," said Assemblyman Robert G. Prentiss, a Saratoga County Republican and an opponent of the amendment, whose passage remains very much in doubt. The Senate is expected to vote on Tuesday and the Assembly sometime the following week. If approved, the amendment would go before voters in a statewide referendum this November. If it fails, legislative leaders say it will not be considered again this year.
The bill's opponents, a diverse group whose interests on other issues often collide, include Roman Catholic, mainstream Protestant and evangelical church leaders, environmentalists, officials in the thoroughbred horse racing industry and Donald J. Trump. Mr. Trump, who owns three Atlantic City casinos, has invested more than $1 million in the last year to fight the amendment, saying it would drain money from the city's economy, reducing the value of his vast real estate empire.
The measure's supporters are mainly mayors and business owners from regions that would stand to gain casinos and, they say, economic growth from the measure: Buffalo, Niagara Falls, the Catskills and Warren County near Lake George. A fifth area that would be eligible for a casino, Saratoga County, has had a groundswell of opposition against the amendment.
The amendment would authorize one casino each in Buffalo, Niagara Falls and either Warren or Saratoga County. It would allow an unlimited number in the Catskills. And it would authorize slot machines and video poker at harness racetracks and at the Saratoga Race Track.
Legislators say they are particularly surprised that, except for Mr. Trump, executives of major casino companies apparently have not joined the fray, either for or against the measure. Many opponents had expected casino investors from around the country to make large campaign contributions and hire top-drawer lobbyists to pressure the Legislature to approve the amendment, on the theory that New York State would provide a lucrative new source of business.
Many opponents say they fear that casino interests are waging a campaign for the amendment that is so subtle that it cannot be traced through campaign or lobbying records. "I haven't seen anything, and that scares me to death," said a well-known lobbyist for Mr. Trump, speaking on condition of anonymity.
But in interviews last week, several casino executives said their companies, though very interested in expanding into New York if the amendment passes, have stayed on the sidelines because they did not want to create the appearance of meddling in the Legislature. They suggested, however, that their companies might promote the amendment if it goes to a referendum.
Gary L. Burhop, vice president of corporate communications for Harrah's Entertainment, said that many industry officials no longer believe that outsiders can influence the Legislature simply "by hiring a bunch of lobbyists," as was done by casino operators in their recent battles in other states.
Mr. Trump is the one casino owner who has been anything but subtle in his opposition to the amendment. In 1996, he spent $855,750 on a team of four lobbyists and three public relations firms to fight the amendment, and has signed contracts to spend at least as much in 1997. Two of the four lobbyists are former top aides to the Senate's Democratic minority, where about 15 undecided members hold the key to the amendment's fate.
Mr. Trump and his wife, Marla Maples, have also made at least $350,000 in campaign contributions in 1996 to both parties, making them among the largest contributors in state politics.
Many gambling analysts say the legalization of casinos in New York State will cut into Mr. Trump's profits in Atlantic City. But in an interview last week, Mr. Trump said that was not why he opposed the bill.
"I'd have a very big casino in New York, which would more than compensate me for losses to Atlantic City," he said. "But I will tell you, if gambling happens in New York, it will be very detrimental to my holdings."
Another casino company that has been lobbying against the amendment is London Clubs International, which wants to build a private, dockside floating casino adjacent to the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan. The current amendment would not allow casinos in New York City, so lobbyists for London Clubs, which runs elite private gambling clubs in London, Beirut and Cairo, are urging legislators to reject the current measure and rewrite it to include the city. That version would then have to be reapproved by the Legislature in 1999 before it could go to a referendum.
James McMahon, a lobbyist for London Clubs, said the amendment should be revised because many communities want casinos. "It's the reverse of Nimby," he said. "It's 'Yes in My Backyard.' "
Mr. McMahon's arguments echo those of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has said that he will urge city voters to reject the amendment because it does nothing for their economy, and the Hotel Association of New York City, which contends that casinos in the Catskills will hurt its businesses. Mr. Giuliani and members of the hotel association, who were both in Albany last week making their cases, said they would support the amendment if it included the city.
Their views clash with the position taken by their putative allies: a broad coalition of religious leaders who say that casinos are immoral and will increase a host of social ills from divorce to crime to child abuse. That coalition has been successful in cajoling its parishioners to write and call legislators to register opposition.
Other opponents include environmentalists like Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who contends that casinos will spur development in ecologically sensitive areas of the Adirondacks and Catskills. The thoroughbred horse racing industry and several Off Track Betting Corporations also assert that casinos will drain money from their industries.
But while the opponents have little in common, they have cooperated with each other informally, sharing information and lobbying tips in the hallways as well as appearing together in news conferences. A recent event presented this unlikely scene: Mr. Kennedy sandwiched between the executive directors of the State Conservative Party and the state's Christian Coalition.
The support for the amendment has been headed for several years by a group of Catskills resort owners and their influential lobbyist, Lester Shulklapper, who has helped draft the amendment and devise strategies for passing it.
More recently, coalitions of business owners, real estate developers and mayors have formed in Buffalo, Niagara Falls and the Lake George area to push for the amendment. Though late in getting started, the groups' leaders have been traveling regularly to Albany. Their main message: Neighboring casinos in Canada and on Indian reservations are killing their tourism businesses.
"We need to level the playing field," said Sergio Fornasiero, a retired developer from Buffalo and head of the city's pro-casino coalition.
