HEADLINE: A Once-Hidden Faith Leaps Into the Open;
After Years of Secrecy, Santeria Is Suddenly Much More Popular. And Public.

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

 BODY:
The recreation room is thick with cigar smoke by late afternoon. Three drummers frantically pound sacred drums, enticing worshipers to crowd around and step to the pulse. A singer chants insults in an African language, hoping to anger the santos, or deities, into appearing.
Suddenly, a woman draped in white shudders violently. Her eyes glaze, then roll back into her head. She reaches for her forehead as if to soothe it, all the while twirling low to the ground, round and round, massaging the intricate rhythms of the drums. Yemaya, the deity who symbolizes the sea and masquerades as the Virgin Mary, has finally come into the room. Yemaya has possessed her. 
 But it was not Yemaya's earthly arrival in the Marble Hill section of the Bronx on a bitterly cold Saturday that was most remarkable. Instead, it was her presence in so visible a place: the recreation room of a high-rise apartment building, a place typically reserved for children's birthday parties and community meetings.
Santeria, a religion created several centuries ago by West Africans enslaved in colonial Cuba and imported to New York City more than 40 years ago, is going public.
For decades, Santeria has operated in a muted underground here, its rites confined to basements and living rooms far from the condemning eyes of outsiders who labeled it hoodoo. Recently, however, the religion has jumped out of the shadows. It has burst onto the Internet. It has smitten musicians like David Byrne and Paul Simon, and will hit Broadway next fall in a musical. And it has slowly seeped into city life through its African and Cuban culture, its houses of worship and the innumerable botanicas, shops frequented mostly by Santeria devotees -- santeros and santeras -- who buy needed herbs and religious objects.
"The religion is absolutely more public and more popular and more secular now," said Emilio Barreto, a Santeria priest and singer who helped beckon Yemaya that Saturday afternoon and has recorded a compact disk of Santeria music called "Santisimo."
"People are more willing to talk about some of the things that go on. There are more initiates every day and more people coming to the celebrations to witness what they are about. People are spreading the word and people are showing up."
For thousands of New Yorkers, such a "toque" (pronounced TOE-kay), or performance for the saints, is now no more unusual -- or secret -- than attending shul or kneeling to Allah. Once dismissed as a ghetto religion practiced only by the Caribbean poor and uneducated, Santeria has a growing following among middle-class professionals, including white, black and Asian Americans. There are police officers in New York who pray to Obatala, the father of all deities, or orishas, before they slip on their gun belts. There are lawyers and professors, civil servants and musicians whose homes are filled with altars laden with flowers, rum, cake and cigars to keep the gods happy and helpful. Many dress in white to symbolize purity.
"This isn't the bush here," said Anthony Cabrera Mondesire, a Santeria priest and a former regional transportation planner who lives in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. "We are not hicks and peasants."

A Focus on Nature And Extended Family
Because the religion is not centralized and has a history of profound secrecy, it is still difficult to know just how many people practice it.
Scholars and priests estimate that there are hundreds of thousands of santeros and casual Santeria believers from New York to Boston. And it is clear, they say, that the religion is attracting growing numbers of people from Florida to Seattle to Canada, despite the continuing controversy over the sacrificing of animals and initiation costs than can reach thousands of dollars -- for clothing, food, implements, fees and livestock.
They are drawn to Santeria, sometimes called Lukumi, for a host of reasons. The religion emphasizes the here and now rather than the afterlife, and it focuses on natural forces. Each deity represents an aspect of nature, like thunder, and a human characteristic, like power.
Like many religions, Santeria also offers community. Those who undergo its carefully guarded initiation rites, which include animal sacrifice to cleanse the soul and give strength, step into an extended family. They have godparents -- the priests and priestesses who bring them into the religion -- as well as people designated as uncles and aunts. They also belong to a house, or temple, which doubles as the priest's home.
People who feel that they live on the margins of society, including new immigrants, often say Santeria makes them feel welcome.
"You are part of a group," said Mercedes Sandoval, who teaches anthropology at Miami-Dade Community College in Florida and has studied Santeria for decades. "It's an emotional and economic support system. It's a fictive extended family in a post-industrial society."
Houses are growing -- one Brooklyn priest has more than 200 godchildren -- and multiplying. Also increasing, say scholars and priests, is the number of people seeking counsel from the gods on matters of love, health, work and finance. "Five years ago, I did 200 readings in a year," said Ade Ifaleri Olayinka, a high priest in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. "Last year I did 700."

For Some, Sacrifice; For Others, Sacrilege
If there is any one aspect of Santeria that has upset and repulsed nonbelievers, it is the ritual sacrifice of animals, usually fowl and goats.
For years, the Association for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals stopped ceremonies, rescued chickens, goats and lambs, and had santeros arrested. People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals has also waged a high-profile campaign against the slaughter. Santeros kill animals, usually by slicing their carotid arteries, in rituals for major events like birth, death, marriage and the initiation of priests. The blood is used as an offering to the orishas and in most cases, the sacrificed animals are cooked and eaten.
But in 1993, the United States Supreme Court recognized animal sacrifice as a religious sacrament and decided that it was protected by the Constitution's guarantee of religious freedom. That has complicated the mission of animal rights activists.
"We'd like to challenge the ruling," said Mark MacDonald, a special investigator for the A.S.P.C.A. "But then it becomes very political. It's very hard."
Hollywood has further blemished the religion's reputation by routinely portraying santeros as satanists. And in New York City, Santeria is frequently blamed for any incident hinting of the occult.
Even Mr. MacDonald, who wishes he could end the slaughter of animals by santeros, said the religion has been much maligned by people who believe the exaggerated, and often untrue, stereotypes.
"I think they get a bogeyman rap because people don't understand," Mr. MacDonald said, adding that he has developed a respect for Santeria. "People think because they dress funny, they are right away slaughtering animals in there."
As the religion grows, so have the number of animal sacrifices, but the A.S.P.C.A. reports receiving fewer complaints, only about one a month, down from about six a month several years ago.
Part of the reason is that Santeria is no longer a rarity in so many predominantly minority communities. Emboldened by santeros in Miami, who have not shied from openly practicing their religion, and the Supreme Court ruling, many New York santeros are easing into public view.
Nothing so proved the point as the sign affixed to a fence outside the Bronx high rise where Yemaya came to earth. In bold, handwritten letters for all to see, it read: This Way To Toque.
"There is more exposure to it," said Alton Rogers, a retired police detective. "And not so much in a negative way as it has been in the past." Santeros used to be afraid that being open about their faith would lead to ostracism or reprisals, he said. "You don't feel that kind of pressure."

Age-Old Powers Cloaked in Saints' Robes
Santeria was born among the West African Yoruban people who were taken to Cuba as slaves from the 16th to the 19th century. It reached New York City in the late 1940's with the arrival of the first Cuban santero, Pancho Mora.
Forced to conceal their religious traditions, the santeros cloaked their faith in Roman Catholic imagery. Chango, god of thunder and lightning, for example, was worshiped in the image of Saint Barbara, whose father was struck by lightning as he beheaded her for her faith. This melding became known as Santeria, the worship of saints. It is not uncommon to find santeros lining the pews of a Roman Catholic church or a devout Catholic dropping in on a Santeria priest for advice. Nor is it unusual to find santeros who worship the orishas in their pure form, without the presence of saints.
Santeros believe in a supreme being, Oloddumare, and a pantheon of orishas who can be asked for help in everyday life. Priests interpret the orishas' counsel through divination. Sometimes the orishas speak directly to them by taking possession of worshipers, santeros say.
Soon after Mr. Mora's arrival, large botanicas started springing up in El Barrio and the South Bronx, selling medicinal herbs as well as statues of St. Francis of Assisi and other Catholic icons. Now there are two dozen botanicas listed in the Bronx phone book, far more than stores selling other religious items, and the competition is fierce.
In the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, Deyanira Rodriguez has pushed the botanica concept one imaginative step forward. On one side of her beauty parlor, Deya's Unisex, customers buy oils and potions to lure back their men. The other side offers a more practical allure: a quick wash, cut and dry. "The idea has worked out pretty well," she said. "The other botanicas are jealous. They want to get me out of here."
In many stores in Latino neighborhoods, the statue of a saint stands guard, surrounded by candles and bowls of coconut or molasses. In parts of the Bronx and upper Manhattan, flower shops stock extra blossoms on particular days, like red carnations on Chango's feast day, and bakeries carry extra cakes and pastries when when a god like Ochun, who likes sweets, is being celebrated.
English-language books on Santeria, once nearly impossible to find, are now abundant, as is information on the Internet. Search the Web for Santeria and nearly 1,800 sites come up. Marta Vega, a santera and professor who heads the Caribbean Cultural Center in Manhattan, remembers putting on the center's first Santeria-related exhibitions 20 years ago, when few people had heard of the religion. Now, the concerts, lectures and art exhibits are standing room only.
And this year, Santeria is crossing over to Broadway in a Paul Simon musical, "The Capeman," about a legendary East Harlem murderer turned poet. In the play, santeros have been cast to sing and drum their prayers to the orishas.
Music has always served as a point of introduction to the religion. Tito Puente, La India, Eddie Palmieri, Conrad Herwig, David Byrne and Paul Simon have incorporated the music of Santeria into their recordings. Celia Cruz has sung of deities like Chango. (This is not entirely new: When Desi Arnaz, as Ricky Ricardo, belted out "Babalu" on the "I Love Lucy" show, he was referring to the orisha Babalu-aye.) Percussionist Milton Cardona, a santero who plays the sacred bata drums, has recorded with almost all the top names in Latin music.
But there is a downside to all this newfound popularity: fraud. Increasingly, men and women with limited knowledge are passing themselves off as Santeria priests and charging customers for services rendered.
Santeros say they regularly come across people who paid hundreds of dollars to be initiated, then realized that the dishonest priest did not follow the dictates of the religion. Or santeros learn of priests who espouse only the religion's dark side, luring people with promises of hexes and supernatural power, all of which serves to further sully Santeria's fragile reputation.
So santeros in New York are pushing their religion to another level: they have begun seeking secular legitimization. One local priest incorporated his temple. Several have been certified through churches in Miami and Nigeria. They have also formed a few priestly societies.
"We need to get together," said Ted Holliday, one of New York's first black Santeria priests. "If we don't, it will degenerate into 'magic voodoo' again."

Charts: "AT A GLANCE: Inside Santeria"
 
IN THE BEGINNING -- Oloddumare, the supreme being, created the universe and sent the orishas, or deities, to create life out of the elements. There are two master orishas: Obatala, who created human life and consciousness out of the substance of the earth, and Orumila, who governs an individual's destiny.
 
THE MEANING OF LIFE -- The world is a place for the soul to evolve. Santeros strive to be of service to others, to develop good character and to keep a cool head. There are two other types of people: bystanders and those who are destructive. All humans go to heaven -- ikole orun -- when they die, but destructive people live in hell on earth and suffer in heaven.
 
GOOD AND EVIL -- The terms are too subjective, since what can be good for one person can be evil for another. Instead, forces in the universe are either constructive or destructive for humanity. In either case, they are controlled by orishas.
 
AFFECTING FATE -- With the help of priests, who can divine the past, present and future, individuals can appeal to the orishas through prayers, music, proper behavior and offerings of food, flowers or other items and, in initiations or dire straits, animal blood.
 
PRIESTHOOD -- Women can become priests, but only men can become high priests. Priests are the only ones who can interpret the laws expressed in the 256 symbols of the Ifa Corpus, a codification of Santeria tradition. Each priest receives an individualized set of taboos, which can include prohibitions on alcohol use, promiscuity or illegal activities, for example.
 
(Source: Anthony Cabrera Mondesire, Santeria priest and author) (pg. B3)

 IN HIDING -- In the 1950's, who knew that the Babalu in the Ricky Ricardo song was a Santeria deity?

HEADLINE: For Whitman, More Temporary Solutions

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
When Christine Todd Whitman was running for governor four years ago, she stood next to a life-size cartoon of Gov. Jim Florio holding bags of cash to help draw attention to her pledge that she would end the state's longstanding practice of spending more than it takes in each year.
Governor Whitman has kept other campaign promises, like cutting income and business taxes by $2.8 billion so far. But she has depended on almost $4.2 billion in temporary measures during her first term to help balance the state's budget. 
 And on Wednesday, in her new $16 billion budget, she will propose another $800 million more in so-called one-shots, or sources of money that the state cannot depend on in future years.
Critics say the Whitman administration's practices, particularly changes in the state's public-employee pension system, have heightened the risk of increasing the burden on New Jersey taxpayers.
But Brian W. Clymer, the State Treasurer, insists that the Whitman administration's budget maneuvers have been fiscally prudent, and he notes that the state has maintained a high credit rating.
Although the Whitman administration has taken steps to curb government spending in the last three budgets, most notably by reaching a four-year pact with state employees that includes a two-year wage freeze, much of the reduction in state government spending in Governor Whitman's first term has come from one source: reducing the state's contribution to the public employee pension system by almost $3.5 billion.
The Governor is able to do this because in 1994 she made several changes to the pension system, including raising the assumptions about how much the system would earn on investments. But fiscal monitors warn that the state may have to increase its contributions to the system in future years.
In Mrs. Whitman's new state budget, the pension system would once again help, this time providing $623 million in immediate, but temporary, budgetary savings.
The Whitman administration proposes to borrow $3.4 billion through bonds, which analysts call the biggest borrowing by a state in history. That money would be used to help pay off the pension system's $4.2 billion unfunded liability account, which is used to help cover cost-of-living increases for retirees.
The maneuver would enable the state to save $113 million in debt service on the bonds this year and and $510 million from the pension system's surplus.
Although Mr. Clymer has projected moderate but steady economic growth for the coming fiscal year, including a $264 million increase in tax revenues, the addition of $823 million in one-shots would help Governor Whitman, a Republican, avoid some unpopular cuts during her re-election campaign, as well as help pay for the $270 million new school financing plan approved by the State Legislature last month.
Steven H. Hochman, assistant director of state ratings at Moody's Investors Service, one of two major bond rating agencies, said there has been a troubling trend in New Jersey of depending on temporary measures to balance the state budget.
"We have been noticing that as the state has implemented its multiyear tax cut program it has been relying on a variety of nonrecurring measures, or temporary measures to accommodate the tax cut," Mr. Hochman said. "That is a continuing concern."
Mr. Hochman added that the proposal involving the pension obligation bonds "appears to be part of that pattern. That kind of pattern continues to raise the question of how the state will be able to accommodate with the reduced revenue stream over the longer term."
In addition to saving $623 million through the pension system maneuver, the Whitman administration is counting on $200 million in one-shot revenues from the proposed sale of the State Disability Benefits Fund, which distributes annual payments up to 26 weeks to New Jersey workers who are temporarily disabled due to injury or sickness unrelated to their job.
This is the second time that Mr. Clymer has turned to the disability fund for budgetary savings. Last year, he took $250 million out of the fund's surplus to help balance the budget. He has also taken millions of dollars from other state funds designated for specific purposes.
"Things started happening during the later part of Governor Florio's first term because there was a fervor to cut taxes," said State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hudson County, who is a member of the State Legislature's Appropriations Committee. "If we keep doing these things, and get away from conservative fiscal policy, these things add up, and we are in danger of becoming irresponsible."
Critics also say the Whitman administration has failed to wrestle with several looming problems that could lead to fiscal trouble ahead.
Over the objections of both organized labor and business, the state is using money from the Unemployment Compensation Trust Fund to pay for the state's charity care program, which reimburses hospitals for treating low-income, uninsured patients.
"We are concerned about some trends that the state does not appear to be confronting," said Donald Linky, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, a nonpartisan public policy research organization founded in 1930.
"The projections for school construction will put considerable pressure on local government budgets, and the property tax over the next several years," Mr. Linky said. "And we don't see any real plan on how the state is going to fund the expansion of school capacity, and additional teachers that will be needed."
Governor Whitman herself acknowledges that she has more to do before the state is on strong fiscal footing. If elected, she said she will work even harder to insure that the state's structural deficit -- the difference between what is collected and what is spent -- is closed.
"We have been able to balance the budget every year, and we have been able to and we will continue to control spending," Governor Whitman said in a recent interview. "I want to be able to continue to live in this state. I would like my kids to want to live in this state, so I want to make darn sure that I leave this state on a good solid footing so we don't have to worry about spikes in taxes, or all of our services going south on us, that we have built something that is meaningful."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strike Over Labor Pact Idles G.M. Plant in Ohio
Close to 4,100 workers went on strike against General Motors at a huge plant in Moraine, Ohio, where sport utility vehicles are assembled. The International Union of Electronics Workers ordered the strike after workers voted against ratification of a new labor agreement. 
 The pact was rejected in part because it included a new program intended to penalize workers with high rates of absenteeism. The strike is the fourth large one against G.M. in less than a year. [Page B8.]
 
Tiny Sensors With Big Powers
At Xerox's research center in Palo Alto, Calif., three miles from the San Andreas Fault, scientists are working on technology that might one day enable buildings or highway overpasses to adjust instantly so that they could dance in harmony with an earthquake, rather than crumble under its tectonic force. The technology, called micro-electro-mechanical systems, uses Lilliputian sensors, motors, nozzles, valves or other mechanical systems to gauge heat, light, motion and sound -- and respond. And nimble buildings are just one application being envisioned. [A1.]
 
Toward Quantum Leap in Computing
A team of scientists plans to announce the discovery of a material that may become the foundation of a new approach to computing, making possible machines thousands of times faster than today's supercomputers. The researchers, from Xerox and several universities, expect to announce the creation of a microscopic magnet, one molecule in size, that could be used to pack data more densely and to quicken operations. [D2.]

PC Shipments Rise 18%
The personal computer industry continued its strong global growth in 1996, as shipments expanded by almost 18 percent, though expansion slowed in the consumer market, according to Dataquest, a market research organization. The PC industry shipped 70.9 million machines in 1996, up 17.8 percent from shipments of 60.2 million in 1995. [D2.]
 
States More Hesitant to Spend
Five years of economic growth has left state governments flush with money. But instead of spending it, they are generally building rainy-day funds and letting a little trickle back to residents through rebates and tax cuts. The trend is a break from what usually happened in boom times, when states often used increased tax revenues to make up for spending cuts or enacted programs that had been postponed by an earlier recession. [A10.]
 
Reading the Subtitles at Sundance
Though the Sundance Film Festival has been marked by high-profile film acquisitions by such companies as Miramax, Gramercy, Fine Line, Sony Classics and Fox Searchlight, the reality is that the bulk of the films shown there may never see the light of day. Bernard Weinraub: Entertainment. [D10.]
 
While Resolutions Remain Fresh
Companies trying to cash in on New Year's resolutions are advertising heavily to try to persuade consumers that their diet or fitness center will help them achieve their goals. The marketer of Nicorette gum, for instance, has introduced an ad telling consumers how to keep resolutions "from going up in smoke." Advertising. [D12.]
 
Royal Appliance Manufacturing was among the advertisers during the Super Bowl that showed themselves to be deft at special effects. In a series of commercials that earned high marks for artistic expression of a day spent cleaning, Fred Astaire sashayed across the screen with a Dirt Devil vacuum cleaner, made by Royal, in hand. [D10.]
 
A Ratings Battle in Australia
As in other countries, television news in Australia has become a battleground, with millions of dollars in revenue as the spoils of victory. Networks owned at least in part by the billionaires Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer are among the competitors tangling to get that exclusive scoop that will turn the ratings tide. [D10.]
 
May the Web Be With You
As 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment prepares to re-release the film "Star Wars," stargazers can look to the World Wide Web for background. New sites devoted to the "Star Wars" trilogy abound, as do countless others started earlier by fans and maintained faithfully ever since. Taking In the Sites. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Ed Wilson, 71, a Sculptor and Art Teacher

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
It has been two months since Ed Wilson died at his home in Vestal, N.Y., and if the event has not been widely noticed beyond the Binghamton area, where he had been a working sculptor and art teacher, it may be because, like his art, Mr. Wilson's life did not always get the scrutiny it deserved.
Mr. Wilson, whose family said he died of congestive heart failure on Nov. 26, was 71 and had been well known in Binghamton since 1964, when he became chairman of the department of art and art history at the State University of New York. 
 For all his influence on students, what brought Mr. Wilson to local attention was a series of his sculptures, among them a memorial to John F. Kennedy and a piece titled "Falling Man."
Mr. Wilson produced some two dozen sculptures, working variously in bronze, aluminum and red hickory, but the very aspect of his work that made him a prized local artist in Binghamton helped keep him from receiving serious critical notice.
That's because Mr. Wilson worked primarily on civic commissions, and as a result his sculptures were generally not displayed in galleries or museums, but in public spaces -- parks, schoolyards and college campuses -- where they rarely receive more than a passing glance or are such a part of the landscape that they are really not seen at all by those who pass them very day.
Those who did take a second look at Mr. Wilson's work were generally impressed. In their book, "A History of African-American Artists" (Random House, 1992), Romare Bearden and Harry Henderson devoted a chapter to Mr. Wilson, ranking him as a significant artist and citing works like "Second Genesis" and "Jazz Musicians," both at schools in Baltimore, where he was born.
Whatever his critical standing, that Mr. Wilson became an artist at all represented a certain triumph of will. For a black youngster in the 1920's and 30's, Mr. Wilson, whose mother was a teacher and whose father was a college administrator, grew up in unusually comfortable circumstances.
His interest in art and his talent emerged when he was kept out of school with rheumatic fever and whiled away his time at home making detailed cardboard models of towns. When he returned to school full time his teachers encouraged his art, but his father, concerned about the economic prospects of a black artist, persuaded him to study architecture and civil engineering.
During a wartime stint in the Army, however, Mr. Wilson experienced such extreme prejudice he decided a black architect would face such obstacles that he might as well make a life for himself as an artist.
Switching to art when he returned to school, he soon abandoned painting for sculpture, and after obtaining a master's in 1953, he taught at North Carolina College in Durham until he went to Binghamton, where he worked until his retirement in 1992.
Mr. Wilson had been deeply involved in the civil rights struggle in North Carolina, and the experience influenced his art. Many of his works also reflected his early interest in painting. For all their varied shapes, the focal points of a Wilson sculpture are often small-scale images on a sometimes hidden surface.
At Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, for example, the message of Mr. Wilson's "Middle Passage," ostensibly three gently curving slabs of concrete nestled together outside the school, does not become apparent until one takes a second, closer look, squeezing between the slabs to examine narrow bands of bronze depicting the horrors of a slave ship.
It was perhaps partly because Mr. Wilson's work did not always receive such scrutiny that his own death was largely overlooked, so much so that even Mr. Henderson, the co-author of the book on black artists, did not learn about it until Saturday, two weeks, he said, after he had tried to call Mr. Wilson to discuss a major publisher's plan to include an image of one of his works in an art book.
That a black artist could have a prolific career at once so public and so obscure should not be especially surprising, certainly not to Mr. Wilson. One of his most original works stands in an Oklahoma City park, a memorial to Ralph Ellison, the author of "The Invisible Man."
Mr. Wilson, who was divorced, is survived by a son, Craig, of Troy, N.Y.; a daughter, Julie Shiver of Baltimore; a sister, Frances Lee of Baltimore, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: As Serb and Croat Leaders Weaken, U.S. Alters Policy

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
A year after the signing of the accord that ended the war in Bosnia, the Clinton Administration has concluded that the days of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia are numbered.
While that number is a mystery, Washington has begun altering its policy, supporting the protests of Mr. Milosevic's opponents, looking past Mr. Tudjman to identify a new generation of leaders and seriously considering plans for commandos to capture some of the roughly 70 people indicted on charges of war crimes. 
 Only a year ago, the Administration looked upon Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Tudjman as guarantors of stability in Bosnia. The two men, both authoritarian and both with clear responsibility for the war, had nonetheless committed themselves to ending it by signing the Dayton accord in December 1995.
Thousands of American and other NATO troops were sent to Bosnia to separate the combatants and prevent a recurrence of bloodshed. To protect those troops, the Clinton Administration said, the United States and its allies chose not to hunt down accused criminals.
Today, the earth has shifted in the former Yugoslavia, with Mr. Milosevic holding on to power in the face of protests and Mr. Tudjman gravely ill with prostate cancer.
The Clinton Administration has concluded that Mr. Milosevic is unwilling to do much more to support the peace plan, and that a stable Bosnia requires a more democratic Serbia and Croatia. While the new Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, has spoken vigorously of the need for democracy in the region, the Administration has not decided how to promote it.
On Friday, asked about Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Tudjman at a news conference, Ms. Albright said that policies cannot be based "on any one individual." The peace accord "is supported by more than just two leaders," she said, and American policy remains the effort "to develop institutions" that "can support an evolution toward democracy and capital markets."
A senior American official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Washington is not trying to push Mr. Milosevic out of power or "calling for his demise." But, the official added, "his aura is broken."
With the Serbian Orthodox Church against him, the economy in trouble, the police and the army saying they will not shoot protesters and even the Bosnian Serb Government supporting the opposition, Mr. Milosevic's rule is not likely to last more than a year, American officials say. "Now it's a matter of when his era ends, not if, and how it does," the official said. "Even if he survives, he won't be able to exercise the same unbridled one- or two-person rule, with his wife. The rules have changed."
American and European officials say they cannot predict who might succeed Mr. Milosevic, where the current opposition might take the country if he fell suddenly, or what impact a change could have in Bosnia. While the students who are marching daily in protest espouse democratic aims, some opposition leaders have been militantly nationalist in the past and supported the war in Bosnia.
Such uncertainties help explain why America's allies are even less eager to push for serious political change in the Balkans, senior American officials and some senior European diplomats say. They have always cared less about creating a democratic and unified Bosnia than about stopping the war.
With troops of their own in Bosnia and worried about a new flow of refugees, the prime interest of European countries remains stability. Far from acting to undermine Mr. Milosevic, the Europeans and Russia are not willing to go even as far as Washington has gone to isolate him.
"Washington has increased its rhetoric over Serbia and is putting great pressure on Serbia, but has not really made the decision to say that the sooner Milosevic goes the better," said Morton I. Abramowitz, president of the Carnegie Endowment and a former American diplomat. "But the alliance is totally divided on how to deal with this guy, and that's the problem. A lot of people want to work something out between Milosevic and the opposition, and there is no agreement within the alliance on what pressures to bring on him."
Unlike its European allies, Washington has withheld full diplomatic recognition from Mr. Milosevic's Government and has prevented the World Bank and International Monetary Fund from operating there. Those measures have failed to induce Mr. Milosevic to free up the press, talk to the opposition, respect human rights and open up to foreign investment, United States officials acknowledge.
American officials succeeded in pressing for a common front within the so-called Bosnian contact group -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia -- to urge Mr. Milosevic to recognize and reinstate the original results of the Nov. 17 municipal elections. The opposition won victories in 14 of the 18 largest cities, including Belgrade. Mr. Milosevic's Government canceled the elections over "irregularities" and attempted to hold new ones, and the coalition, together with university students, have held daily protests ever since.
Mr. Milosevic accepted an investigation, proposed by the Americans, from the Organization for Cooperation and Security in Europe. Its report backed the opposition, "thus internationalizing the opposition and giving it real credibility," an American official said.
But the protests have not spread very far beyond Belgrade. And Mr. Milosevic continues to play for time, first accepting some opposition victories, but then backtracking. American officials acknowledge that the Contact Group will not agree to put further pressure on Serbia by lifting recognition or restoring harsher sanctions originally imposed by the United Nations.
Mr. Tudjman, the Croatian President, is hardly less of an authoritarian than Mr. Milosevic on issues of democracy and media freedom, American officials agree, but he has been treated differently, with full diplomatic recognition and international help for economic reform. Croatia did not start the war and did not suffer United Nations sanctions, and Germany led the West in treating Mr. Tudjman as more benign than Mr. Milosevic.
Croatia has manipulated its own elections and cracked down on the media and international organizations promoting human rights, American officials acknowledge, and it has also been moving to absorb the ethnic Croat part of Bosnia bordering on Croatia. The Croats have also resisted allowing refugees to return to the Krajina region of Croatia and make it hard for ethnic Serbs to remain in the Eastern Slavonia region.
But American officials regard Mr. Tudjman, 74, as an "old-fashioned nationalist" formed in the period of World War II, and believe that after his death or retirement -- there will be presidential elections in the second half of 1997 -- the era of one-man rule there will be over. But in Croatia, there is also no obvious heir apparent.
In Croatia, too, there is a budding opposition movement. American officials note that 100,000 people turned out to protest Mr. Tudjman's effort to shut down an independent radio station -- which was granted a license only on Friday -- and they say they have stressed issues of democratization with Mr. Tudjman.
On the issue of accused war criminals, senior American officials say there is new seriousness in Washington, with military and intelligence officials preparing detailed plans for how commando forces could capture indicted suspects and transport them to stand trial before the war crimes tribunal at The Hague. Otherwise, they say, the tribunal may wither and the promises of justice and ethnic reconciliation will die.
But the officials say that no decisions have been made by Mr. Clinton, and that the main inter-agency battle has yet to be fought. The commandos would operate under the authority of the tribunal. But as usual, European countries do not want to take part in such a risky venture without Americans alongside.

HEADLINE: RUSSIA IS FUMBLING ITS CONTRIBUTION TO SPACE STATION

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Problems with Russia's space program have delayed its main contribution to the proposed international space station, endangering the entire project, some experts say.
The Russian module is a centerpiece of the orbiting outpost, which involves 15 nations and is expected to cost at least $50 billion and be the size of a football field. The station is meant to symbolize, and help foster, a new era of East-West accord and is an important part of the Clinton Administration's Russia policy. It is also NASA's biggest and most politically complex project. 
 But the cash-poor Russians have now fallen nearly a year behind schedule in building a module that is vital to the station's success.
So in an emergency move, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration decided early this month to build a stopgap module in the United States that will enable the station plans to go forward, even though the date for astronauts to move into the station would be pushed back. NASA is racing to contain the political damage while redoing the station plan.
"The danger of its unraveling is great," F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican who recently became chairman of the House Science Committee, said in an interview.
The plan calls for the orbiting outpost to be built in stages by 15 nations, replacing cold war hostilities with a new kind of global teamwork. That work is to begin late this year.
The first two modules, financed by the United States, are to be sent aloft in November and December. In the original plan, a module financed by Russia was to have been flown into space in April 1998, followed by numerous other components until the end of construction in 2002. The delayed Russian module is meant to provide life support for astronauts as well as stability and propulsion for the orbital complex, keeping it from tumbling out of control or falling back to Earth.
Incensed at the delay, Mr. Sensenbrenner said that if Russia was still withholding the payments for its space program at the end of February, the station team should ask the Russians to leave as full partners, letting them serve only as subcontractors paid to do specific jobs. "If Russia continues to fail to fulfill its obligations," he said, "it will shake the political and financial underpinnings of the station."
The issue is high on the agenda of Vice President Al Gore and the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who are to meet early next month in Washington. Mr. Sensenbrenner said he planned to hold hearings on the station's fate right after that meeting.
While NASA officials concede that there has been considerable turmoil, they insist that the basic East-West partnership is sound, if frayed, and that the project is nowhere near collapse. The sprawling outpost can be built on budget and on time and can include Russia, they say.
NASA itself can ride out violent political storms because the agency, as an important source of funds for aerospace contractors, has many powerful allies in Congress.
"From the day we started with the Russians, it has been the perils of Pauline," Daniel S. Goldin, the NASA Administrator, said in an interview, noting that previous problems had been solved and saying that would be the case again. "I feel we're going to build it with them," he said. "I feel it in my bones."
Despite that, NASA is preparing for the worst. It is studying a second makeshift component, or a modification of the first one, that would give the station long-term stability, even if the Russian module never shows up.
In a bold step, the first stopgap piece for NASA is to be made out of military spy gear, which would apparently be the first such diversion to a civilian program. That means that orbital equipment built to help Americans spy on Russia will now aid the Russians as they struggle to get their technological house in order.
The station's current troubles are part of a pattern of new stresses between the United States and Russia, including friction over issues like NATO's expansion and nuclear disarmament. To some degree, the project's fate is a hostage to wider political currents.
Even so, American shuttles and the Russian Mir space station have succeeded in linking up flawlessly in a series of warm-up missions in the past two years. The fourth American astronaut to stay on the Mir is now aboard the Russian outpost for a four-month visit.
The recent problems might delay the first permanent habitation of the international space station by a half-year or so, pushing back that milestone from May 1998 to December 1998 and perhaps to early 1999, when the Russian module might make it into space. That 43-foot-long, 23-ton cylinder, or something like it, is essential if astronauts are to live and work in orbit.
John E. Pike, head of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington, said the prospect of Russia's dropping out of the program was "a distinct possibility in terms of the general drift of Russian-American relations."
But he predicted that the station project would survive a Russian departure because thousands of jobs, contracts and political deals depended on it around the world.
"It's going to be the biggest construction program since the pyramids," Mr. Pike said.
The push for a big Western space station began more than a decade ago during the cold war as the Reagan Administration sought to outdo Russia's feats in orbit, envisioning an outpost that was bigger and better. By 1990, the American station was seen as a staggering 508 feet long -- nearly the size of the Capitol in Washington. It was expected to cost up to $120 billion over 30 years.
After the cold war, and after Bill Clinton was elected President in 1992, the White House ordered NASA to work with the Russians to design a smaller and cheaper outpost.
Mr. Goldin brokered a deal among Congressional leaders and international partners to have Russia join the team, helping to transform the decade-old dream (on which American taxpayers had already spent $8 billion) into a top Clinton initiative.
Now the partnership includes Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Russia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the United States. Russia and America are the dominant players.
It will take more than 40 launchings from Asia and America to get all the station pieces into orbit. By 2002, the international space station -- which will weigh 470 tons and be 290 feet long and 356 feet wide -- is to house up to seven astronauts at a time. The station will be used to study the heavens and Earth and things like human physiology in orbit, all while moving through space at more than 17,000 miles an hour.
One goal of the Clinton Administration is to engage Russia in constructive space work in return for its ending such practices as the export of advanced rocket gear to developing countries.
The original pact with Russia sweetened a $400 million contract for space hardware and launching services. The United States saw that money as strengthening Russia's shaky space program as the Russians moved toward a market economy.
This priming of the pump is now resulting in the production of the first station component, a 21-ton, 41-foot-long core module known as the Functional Cargo Block. On schedule to be launched in November atop a Russian Proton rocket, it is primarily for storage and experiments and has no ability to provide astronauts with life support.
The second module is known as Node 1, a 18-foot-long cylinder built by the Boeing Company that will serve as a connecting link to the future American side of the station. An American space shuttle is to take it aloft in December.
It is the third element, known as the Service Module, that is in trouble. Being built by Krunichev, a Russian company, it was to have been launched by a Russian Proton rocket in April 1998 to provide the station's basic living quarters and propulsion.
But it is so far behind schedule that little more than its outer shell is complete, said Wilbur C. Trafton, NASA's associate administrator for space flight, who was in Russia last week for talks.
In an interview from Moscow, Mr. Trafton said NASA had decided in early January, after much debate, to switch to an Interim Control Module, which has rocket engines for station propulsion and will be made by the Naval Research Laboratory from a rocket-booster system meant to deploy spy satellites.
The new control system will cost less than $100 million, Mr. Trafton said. But it will also require a space shuttle flight into orbit, which will cost $500 million or so. He said the new unit might be ready to go by the spring or fall of 1998.
The switch to the Navy design is reported in the Jan. 20 issue of Aviation Week & Space Technology, an industry journal.
Since the Interim Control Module, as currently envisioned, could position and stabilize the new station for only a year or so, until its fuel ran out, NASA is also studying other options, including a more costly supplementary vehicle it calls the Propulsion Module, which would be fully refuelable. Under current plans, neither module could provide life support services for astronauts.
In theory, an international space station with a Propulsion Module , and with added life-support gear, could be refueled by a modified space shuttle and be free of any dependence on Russian gear.
"We can't bet on the Service Module," Mr. Trafton said. But he added, as did Mr. Goldin, the NASA Administrator, that he still believed that the Russians would eventually succeed in getting the delayed component into orbit.
Yuri N. Koptev, the director of the Russian Space Agency, said last week in Moscow that he hoped the Russian Government would soon allocate funds for the station work.
"If the appropriations are delayed again," Mr. Koptev told the Itar-Tass news agency, "foreign partners might raise the question of excluding Russia from the project."

HEADLINE: Indians' Cruel Winter of Aid Cuts and Cold

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: FORT YATES, N.D., Jan. 21

 BODY:
Arctic winds swirled around Asa Lester's flimsy house, piling drifts to the roof and making it feel like 60 below zero. As his propane supply sputtered to an end, his furnace shut down, leaving Mr. Lester, a wiry Sioux, to face days wrapped in blankets, huddled around a glowing hot plate.
Across this wind-whipped reservation today, propane trucks followed Air Force snowplows, delivering heating fuel to Sioux families isolated on prairie expanses by the worst winter blizzards in memory. 
 For much of the Northern Plains, this has been the cruelest winter. Although Mr. Lester survived, eight people have died in North Dakota in the last three weeks as a result of the weather, a toll that surpasses the state's annual murder rate. With 15,000 dead cows around the state lying frozen on the prairie ground, President Clinton last week declared North Dakota a disaster area.
For the Sioux and other Indians whose remote settlements have been buried under snowdrifts, the harsh weather could not have come at a worse time. Across the nation the Federal Government has cut money to help Indians improve and weatherize their housing.
More than any other group, the two million Indians in the United States, including the one million on the reservations, depend on Federal aid. But annual spending by the Department of Housing and Urban Development has dropped, to $500 million from $650 million three years ago.
Here at the Standing Rock Reservation, where thin walls, balky furnaces and plastic sheeting on windows make for chilly days and nights in Government housing, the Federal repair budget has dropped one-third since 1995, hitting $1.4 million.
"It makes me wonder if Congress wants to cut out Indian housing altogether," said Phyllis A. Young, who has been on the housing board at Standing Rock for 20 years. Referring to a 1950's strategy for withdrawing legal recognition of tribes, she asked, "Are we on the road to termination by appropriation?"
In Sioux County, where half the 9,000 members of the tribe live in Federal housing, dependency on Washington stretches from a frigid day in December 1890, when the reservation police near this Army post killed 12 Sioux, including Sitting Bull.
A century of Federal education failed to teach the Standing Rock Sioux how to make money on their own, or how to join the increasingly prosperous settler economy that was growing up around them.
While North Dakota now has the nation's lowest unemployment rate -- 1.9 percent -- unemployment on the reservation hovers around 75 percent. Instead of jobs, the welfare economy provides a minimal safety net in a county that ranked in 1990 as the sixth poorest in the nation. With a per-capita income of $9,000, Sioux County receives $8,000 in per-capita Federal spending every year. The national average is about $5,200.
In 1960, a Federal dam project increased dependency on Government handouts, and on Government housing. By damming the Missouri River for electric power and flood control, Federal engineers flooded 5,000 acres of the reservation's most fertile cropland.
Floodwaters covered almost 200 Sioux houses built in sheltered river lowlands. Families were forced to move into "650's," Government houses built for $650 each on the wind-scoured plains.
"When I was 10 years old, my home was destroyed and my family was removed from the river bottom," Mrs. Young recalled. "We went from building our own homes, having our own food, having our own property, to relying on the Government for welfare."
Over the next 10 years, officials expect private mortgage lending to start seeping into reservations because of two developments, tribal foreclosure ordinances and changes in Indian housing legislation.
But, for now, the Government remains the largest source of shelter for the Standing Rock Sioux and many other Plains tribes. Federal money is paying to build 220 houses here and it is to help pay for the move here of 100 used houses from the Grand Forks Air Force Base.
Today, when a winter disaster hits this community, the telephone that rings the most insistently belongs to Irma Walking Elk.
"We've been getting 100 applications a day," said Mrs. Walking Elk, who runs the local federally financed program to help pay for home heating. Referring to the 700 households on the reservation that receive fuel aid, she said, "Most of them exhausted their benefits by January."
Since November, rural North Dakota has been hammered by twin forces, snow accumulations up to five time normal levels and a near tripling in prices of propane heating fuel, far faster than the increases in heating oil and gasoline this winter.
With propane prices jumping, to $1.30 a gallon from 50 cents in three months, the effects are clear.
"They are taking money out of food budgets," Mrs. Walking Elk said about the people in the assistance program. "In this weather, 100 gallons barely heats a house for a week. Furnaces go out. Pipes break, and people go to live with relatives."
Facing three more months of winter, the tribe is diverting profits from its modest casino to pay for home deliveries of propane.
Standing in the tribal office today, Jerome Otter Robe recalled how his extended family survived last week after their furnace had shut down in the blizzard. "We turned on the electric stove," he said, "and went to bed with our clothes on. The bathroom froze up and started to reek."
As part of Federal disaster relief, Standing Rock has received an emergency fuel appropriation of $300 for each eligible household.
"We have two or three families living in one house," Jesse Taken Alive, local chairman for the Sioux, who prefer to call themselves Lakota, said before hurrying off to a meeting for emergency managers. "If it weren't for the extended family and kinship that is alive and well among Lakota people, we would have the homeless problem of the city."
In the below-zero weather, Mr. Taken Alive went on the tribal radio and threatened to have the police impound any cars that ventured onto the snowbound roads.
The single fatality on the reservation has been Darlene Cadotte, a worker at the casino who tried to race a blizzard home, where her seven children were waiting. The blizzard buried her car, killing her.
"I know people who left their houses and just drove around in their cars to keep warm," said Darren Pleets, a propane deliverer.
Inside the warm cab of the delivery truck, Jim Kraft, the driver, said on Tuesday that he had just about worked to the end of a list of 300 backlogged orders.
"We were stormed in for three days -- couldn't move a wheel," Mr. Kraft, who has delivered the gas for 35 years, said as he expertly maneuvered his truck through a narrow cut in a snowdrift. "This is a winter I won't forget for a long time."

A1); On Ken Tischmak's North Dakota ranch, a dozen cows were among 15,000 around the state that froze to death in this winter's blizzards. (Associated Press) (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: States Control Spending Despite the Tax Windfalls

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Five years of economic growth has left state governments flush with money. But instead of spending it, they are generally building rainy day funds and letting a little trickle back to residents through rebates and tax cuts.
The trend is a break from what usually happened when the economy boomed, when states often used increased tax revenues to make up for spending cuts or enacted programs postponed by an earlier recession. 
The states' new restraint on spending, and the trimming of tax rates, show both the response of elected officials to anti-tax sentiments and efforts to avoid a painful mix of spending cuts and tax increases in the next business decline, say officials who study state finances. The states are also wary about future financial aid from the Federal Government, the experts say.
Last year, the states on average held spending increases to 4 percent, not much above inflation, while their revenues grew at more than 6 percent. Over all, states count on personal income taxes for 31 percent of their revenues, while general sales taxes bring in one-third of the total. Most of the rest comes from taxes on corporations, tobacco, alcohol.
Nine states expect their revenues to be 10 percent above the figures projected in their budgets. Texas, Michigan, Minnesota and Indiana expect to pile up surpluses of more than $1 billion each.
This year, tax cuts or rebates will take effect in 27 states. In the last two years, tax reductions had been enacted by 32 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
"When you have had this surge in revenue growth in the past, the states spent a good share of it," said Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the National Governors Association, who is a former deputy director of the Congressional Budget Office.
While more than half the nation's governors are busy honing images as tax cutters, many of the reductions have been tiny. More than half of the total dollar reductions were in New York and New Jersey, both led by Republican governors. Tax-rate cuts have reduced revenues by $4.2 billion in New York since George E. Pataki became Governor in 1995 and by $2.8 billion in New Jersey since Christine Todd Whitman became Governor in 1994.
State tax cuts in the last three years amounted to less than 1 percent of state government revenues nationwide, according to the Center for the Study of the States in Albany.
The big tax cuts in New York and New Jersey have been the exception to rebates and holding onto surplus revenues. The two states' aggressive tax reductions may put them in sharply contrasting positions to the rest of the country the next time the economy falters and tax revenues weaken.
One state with a conservative approach is Michigan, which had a surplus of nearly $1 billion, but did not cut taxes last year. Budget officials in several states said one reason to build surpluses before cutting tax rates was uncertainty about how to pay for jobless and welfare benefits for people who would be thrown out of work in the next recession.
Minnesota anticipates a $1.4 billion surplus in the current fiscal year and Gov. Arne H. Carlson, a Republican, is proposing to return $261 million in a one-time tax rebate that would be paid just before Christmas, and to cut the tax-rates to bring a $240 million yearly reduction in revenues.
Iowa, with just 2.8 million residents, has $440 million set aside, and is expected to add another $334 million this year. Gov. Terry E. Branstad, a Republican, has proposed a cut in the tax rate that would reduce income tax revenue by $200 million a year, which means the state's surpluses should increase next year if the economy continues to expand.
The states collected 6.2 percent more in tax revenues in the second quarter of 1996 than in the comparable period a year earlier, the Center for the Study of the States said in an analysis of the latest available detailed revenue data.
Donald J. Boyd, director of the center, said that in that quarter, state income taxes withheld from paychecks grew at 10 percent or more in nine states -- California, Colorado, Georgia, Kentucky, Minnesota, Oregon, Utah, West Virginia, and Wisconsin. And, if not for cuts in income tax rates, these tax receipts would have grown by double digits in three more states, Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.
Taxes withheld from pay checks are considered relatively stable revenues. But in some states, including New York and New Jersey, even faster growth is taking place in tax payments on estimated income, which tend to be made by people with higher incomes who get much of it from bonuses and from the sale of stock and other assets. Stock prices are up currently but if they should fall, tax revenues from capital gains could diminish rapidly.
In New York and New Jersey, whose state income tax revenues are highly dependent on earnings of people in the financial services industry in Manhattan, bonuses also appear to be generating extra tax dollars. New York counts on the income tax for half of its revenues, a higher level than most states.
H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, has criticized the tax cuts backed by Governor Pataki. "He has cut taxes without a plan to get the revenue to make up for the cuts," Mr. McCall said. "The Governor's budget assumes that the boom on Wall Street will continue, but if that doesn't happen New York will be facing a serious problem."
The state expects a $1 billion surplus this year, which Governor Pataki wants to use for further tax cuts, putting aside $65 million in a rainy day fund, the maximum allowed by law. Mr. McCall said more of the surplus should be used to pay down debts or prepay expenses.
New Jersey also relies heavily on Wall Street bonuses for income tax revenues.
Connecticut, where a $200 million state income tax cut takes effect this year, is not as vulnerable to the economic ups and downs as it is to what Richard Netzer, a professor at New York University, calls "a long-term problem because of its enormous dependence on the rapidly contracting defense industries."
Tax revenues are coming in below projections only in Hawaii, where tourism has been flat; Idaho, where corporate income taxes are 37 percent below projections, and Tennessee, where overall revenues are 2 percent below projections.
No state is considering raising income, sales or business taxes, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.
But eight states are considering higher excise taxes, according to the conference. Higher gasoline taxes are being considered in Pennsylvania, Utah and Wisconsin and higher cigarette taxes have been proposed in Alaska, Florida, Maryland, Oregon and New Hampshire. The Alaska proposal would raise the current 29-cents-a-pack levy by a dollar.
Georgia is phasing out one of the most regressive taxes in the country, a sales tax on groceries. Arkansas, Louisiana and Missouri are considering reducing sales taxes on food.
Some state budget officials say that surpluses may invite Washington to avoid helping the states.
"The Federal Government is talking seriously about balancing its budget," said Carl Koch, Iowa Deputy Treasurer, "and if the Federal Government realizes that the states have huge surpluses they are going to look to the states to solve some of Washington's problems."

HEADLINE: States Resisting Urge To Use Tax Revenue

 BODY:
Five years of economic growth has left state governments flush with money. But instead of spending it, most are building rainy day funds and letting a little trickle back to residents through rebates and tax cuts. The restraint are efforts to avoid a painful mix of spending cuts and tax increases in the next business decline. 
 Last year, the states on average held spending increases to 4 percent, while revenues grew more than 6 percent. This year, 27 states are cutting taxes. In the last two years, 32 did so, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Article, page A10.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Russia Falls Well Behind In Its Part of Space Station
Russia has fallen nearly a year behind schedule in building a module that is to be the centerpiece of an international space station. NASA will build a stopgap module to allow the station to go forward if economic troubles in Russia continue to affect its space program. A1
 
Chechens Prepare to Vote
After 21 months of brutal war with Russia, Chechens were preparing themselves and their scorched republic for presidential and parliamentary elections today. In the hope that the world will recognize the vote as fair, they have invited more than 100 foreign observers. The elections are seen by Chechens as the first step toward creating an independent republic. And that is precisely the Kremlin's worst fear. A1 

U.S. Shifts Balkan Strategy
Only a year ago, after the accord that ended the war in Bosnia was signed, the Clinton Administration viewed the Balkans' authoritarian leaders as the guarantors of the peace. Now, it has concluded that the days of Presidents Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia (above) and Franjo Tudjman of Croatia are numbered. It has quietly begun supporting their opponents and searching for a new generation of leaders. And it is seriously considering plans for commandos to capture some of the roughly 70 people indicted for war crimes. A3
 
Unrest Spreads in Albania
Violent protests by tens of thousands of people demanding money back from failed pyramid schemes spread across Albania in what may be the biggest challenge to the Government since the country threw off Stalinist rule five years ago. Legislators held an emergency session to give President Sali Berisha special powers to deal with the unrest, as some 35,000 protesters battled riot policemen in the capital. A3
 
Israeli Cabinet Investigated
The Israeli police began an investigation of a report that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's appointment of a new attorney general this month was part of a deal to win a plea bargain for a political ally on trial for bribery. According to the report, the deal was also intended to gain critical support from the Shas party for the troop withdrawal from most of Hebron. Mr. Netanyahu has denied the charges, but some Cabinet ministers warned that the allegations, if proven, could bring down the Government. A8
 
U.S. Said to Chide Germany
The United States has decided to increase its criticism of Germany for its restrictions on the Church of Scientology, The Washington Post reported. The Post quoted an Administration official as saying the State Department's annual survey of human rights around the world would criticize Germany for "a campaign of harassment and intimidation" against the church. Senior American officials said they were unaware of any major increase in criticism of Germany over the issue. A4
 
NATIONAL A10-15, B8-9
 
G.O.P. Promises of Access Attracted Biggest Donors
Republican fund-raisers have focused on large corporations and individuals with interests pending on Capitol Hill, making explicit promises of special rewards for big donors. Offering their biggest givers special access to lawmakers helped them increase the size of their largest contributions and the number of those big donations. Those who give more than $250,000 can have a party staff member help them with problems in Washington. A1
 
Harsh New Reality for Indians
The bitter winter weather that is plaguing tribes on the Northern Plains has highlighted the difficulties American Indians are having with Federal assistance. More than any other group in the United States, Indians depend on Federal aid. But the Government has cut money to help improve and weatherize their housing. A1
 
States Show Fiscal Restraint
Instead of spending the tax revenues that have flowed in during five years of economic growth, most states have been saving them. In previous good times, those governments have restored money to programs that were affected by earlier budget cuts or have offered tax rebates. But state leaders are trying to avoid tax increases or spending cuts in future downturns. They are also unsure of Federal aid. A10
 
Arena of Faith and Healing
America's religious landscape is increasingly a place of mass movements. Often, they speak in familiar terms, but these movements are developing outside the control of traditional denominations and religious leaders. Experts say the phenomenon -- exemplified by a new group, Women of Faith, that drew nearly 15,000 people to a rally in Cincinnati -- reflects the spirit of the age, a time of widespread longing for meaning and deep public distrust of established authority, whether secular or ecclesiastical. A10
 
New Hope for AIDS Treatment
A major AIDS meeting in Washington ended with the hope that experimental drugs will ease the burden of patients who now must undergo difficult drug regimens. Experts also hope that the new drugs can help those for whom existing medication is failing. A10
 
Rain Spares California, a Bit
A weekend round of storms did not deliver as much rain as flood-weary Californians feared, sparing the state's weakened levees and exhausted emergency personnel. Still, the rains unleashed mud and debris that closed the main road between San Francisco and Lake Tahoe. A12
 
Strike at G.M. Factory in Ohio
Almost 4,100 workers went on strike against General Motors at an Ohio plant that makes sport utility vehicles. A union official said the workers struck because of a backlog of grievances. The company's board was expected to raise dividends today, but now that is less likely. B8
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Legislators in Albany To Vote on Gambling
As the New York State Legislature prepares to cast its deciding vote on a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling, a frenetic lobbying drive has erupted in Albany. Many lawmakers say they have been astonished by the size and aggressiveness of the opposition, a diverse group that includes Roman Catholic, mainstream Protestant and evangelical church leaders, environmentalists, officials in the thoroughbred horse racing industry and Donald J. Trump. The measure's supporters are mainly mayors and business owners from regions that would stand to gain casinos. B1
 
A Gasoline Tax Revolt?
At 43 cents a gallon, Connecticut's gasoline taxes are the nation's highest -- 13 cents a gallon higher than New York's. A growing number of the state's drivers are refusing to pay them, instead crossing state lines to fill their tanks. As recently as 1990 Connecticut's gas taxes were lower than in New York, but sharp, regular increases pushed them ahead in 1992, and a 1993 law set more increases. This rat-a-tat-tat of increases, the informal boycott and a campaign by service station owners have led officials in Hartford to talk of a gas tax revolt and to make reducing the taxes the top priority of the new legislative session. B4
 
Questions on Trenton Budget
Governor Whitman has depended on almost $4.2 billion in temporary measures during her first term to help balance New Jersey's budget. And in her new $16 billion budget, she will propose on Wednesday another $800 million more in so-called one-shots, which are sources of money that the state cannot necessarily depend on in future years. Critics say the Whitman administration's practices, particularly changes to the state's public employee pension system, have heightened the risk that taxpayers may have to pay more later. But Brian W. Clymer, the State Treasurer, insists that the Whitman administration's budget maneuvers have been fiscally prudent. B4
 
Budget Cuts Drive Tuitions Up
As state governments keep whittling away their support for higher education, tuition at public institutions is likely to continue rising as financial aid shrinks, moving college further beyond the reach of poor students, education experts say. To some experts, New York State is a case in point. B1
 
Street Repairs Continue
Repairs to the Manhattan streets that buckled after a water main break on Friday are taking longer than expected. Only two of the lanes on Seventh Avenue between 15th and 17th Streets will be open today, and city officials said it could be sometime Tuesday, or even early Wednesday, before all lanes of Seventh Avenue are open to traffic. They acknowledged that even such a small problem area could clog southbound traffic on Seventh Avenue all the way up to Central Park South, where the avenue begins. B3
 
SPORTSMONDAY C1-11
 
Packers Win It, Confidently
Playing with the confidence and, in some areas, the dominance of the teams Vince Lombardi put together in the late 1960's, the Green Bay Packers won the Super Bowl by 35-21 over the New England Patriots. It was the team's first championship in 29 years, and came with several record-setting performances, including Desmond Howard's 99-yard kickoff return for a touchdown, the longest ever in the post-season. C1

The top honor for a dramatic film at the Sundance Film Festival went to Jonathan Nossiter's "Sunday," a quiet tale of two people who meet oddly and go on to weave a web of shared illusions. C15

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXXI;
On a Day for Mouthing Off, Desmond Howard's Gallops Speak Loudest for Packers

BYLINE: By MIKE FREEMAN 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Kick returner Desmond Howard is about 180 pounds, which makes him a pipsqueak in football. But there he was after his explosive 31-yard punt return to open the first series for the Green Bay Packers tonight, sticking his face in a group of New England Patriots players and talking trash. One of those players was a 300-pound offensive lineman, Bruce Armstrong. Not exactly a smart thing for Howard to do.
But this was the Super Bowl and Howard's juices were flowing, his family was watching, and he was not going to show restraint. Fear was not a factor. And Howard wasn't exactly happy with the Patriots, especially after his college teammate at the University of Michigan, safety Corwin Brown, had said last week that he was going to "smash" Howard during the game and then strike a Heisman pose over his body. 
 "There was a lot of mouthing going on," Howard said about his confrontation with nearly half the Patriots' bench. "There were some expletives in there."
Howard would have the last word. Maybe it was just fate, but what followed Howard's return was big play after big play for the Packers in their 35-21 victory over the Patriots in Super Bowl XXXI.
Howard had one of the most explosive days for a return specialist in Super Bowl history. His kickoff return in the second half for 99 yards and a touchdown was the longest in Super Bowl history. He finished the game with 4 kick returns for 154 yards and 6 punt returns for 90 yards. The 244 total return yards matched the Super Bowl record set by San Diego's Andre Coleman in 1995. Coleman's 8 kickoff returns included a 98-yard touchdown run.
So impressive was Howard that he was named the game's most valuable player, an unprecedented award for a special-teams player.
"I really didn't expect them to kick me the ball that much," Howard said. "But as I've said before, you can roll the dice and kick it to me if you want. But if you keep doing it, you're going to get burned eventually."
The big plays came pouring in for the Packers. In addition to Howard, Brett Favre had two long pass plays for touchdowns, one to Andre Rison on the second play of that first series for 54 yards and the other an 81-yard pass to Antonio Freeman, a Super Bowl record for the longest pass play.
Despite the big plays on offense, the defense of the Packers should not be overlooked. Coming into the game, there were expectations that Patriots Coach Bill Parcells would find a way to put a kink in the offensive game plan of Mike Holmgren, the Packers' coach. But it was the Packers' defensive coordinator, Fritz Shurmur, who came up huge.
With the Patriots leading by 14-10 in the second quarter and facing a third-and-10 on their own 42, a corner blitz by Doug Evans put a nasty hit on quarterback Drew Bledsoe that sent the ball spiraling incomplete. If New England had scored on that drive, the game might have turned out differently.
Then, later in the quarter, the Packers' LeRoy Butler had a 9-yard sack on a safety blitz, and later put pressure on Bledsoe in another blitz that caused him to throw the ball earlier than he wanted. It skipped on the ground incomplete.
The most spectacular plays by far came from Howard, who came to Green Bay with his Heisman Trophy in need of some good polishing. A castoff from the Washington Redskins, he was criticized there for his lack of energy bursting off the line of scrimmage and a lack of overall toughness -- not to mention his falling asleep in meetings. After he was put on the expansion list by Washington, claimed by Jacksonville and then released, the Packers took a chance on him.
"Obviously, I never quit on myself," Howard said after the game, "or I wouldn't be standing here."
Sometimes all a player needs is a change of scene -- and a stage.
The biggest play of the game came after the Patriots had cut a 13-point Green Bay lead to 27-21 with 3 minutes 27 seconds left in the third quarter. The Patriots had been kicking to Howard all evening, and Patriots punter Tom Tupa again kicked the ball right down the middle of the field to him. That's a no-no.
The seams opened just at the right time and just in the right places, and at about the 40-yard line, Howard broke loose. He followed Don Beebe up the middle and bolted by Tupa as if Tupa were a planted turnip. Howard then jetted into the end zone.
This time, there was no trash talking because no Patriots were in sight. That made the score 35-21.
"Obviously it was a backbreaker," Howard said. "They had just scored, they had the momentum. Then we have my return, and that was basically the game."
Of all the pre-game hype, in all of the news conferences, in all of the prognostications, few people expected Howard would be the one to break the hearts of the Patriots.
Or be the one to get a phone call from President Clinton, who had watched on television. He told Howard he would see him in Washington, since the Packers were invited to the White House. Howard has come a long way, from the unemployment line to talking football with the President.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shaking off a Patriots tackler, Packers kick returner Desmond Howard set a Super Bowl record with his 99-yard touchdown run. He finished the game with four kick returns and six punt returns for a total of 244 yards. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Latin Arms Sales Help Stabilize the Region;
A Bad-Neighbor Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In proposing that the United States resume the sale of advanced weapon systems to Latin America, the outgoing Secretaries of State and Defense, Warren Christopher and William J. Perry, fell prey to bureaucracies with little sense of history. 
 You also criticize this recommendation (editorial, Jan. 20).
In earlier days, uncontrolled United States arms sales contributed to bloodshed and economic distress in the region. The Carter Administration halted this. And in one of the cold war's hottest periods, the Reagan Administration hardly wavered in the effort to prevent the proliferation of advanced weapons in Latin America.
President Clinton, who has enjoyed several major policy successes in the region, would put the future (and American lives) at risk by fostering a costly arms race for the sake of short-term exports.
A remilitarization of Latin America would mean diversion of resources for development, a more troubled region that is more open to drug cartels, and less healthy democracies.
The President should now direct Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen to work with Latin America to construct a regional regime for conventional arms limitations that is focused on advanced weaponry. Under a regional regime, the United States -- and Russia and France, for example -- could sell weapons, including aircraft, only if they fit the region's criteria, guaranteeing that a Pandora's box of regional rivalries would not be reopened by unrestrained purchases of advanced weapons.
A decision by the President simply to lift the ban on advanced weapons to Latin America would be seen by many Latin Americans as a bad-neighbor policy, not the stuff for a place in history.
 
FRANK MCNEIL
Boca Raton, Fla., Jan. 23, 1997
The writer was Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Latin American affairs, 1977-78.
