HEADLINE: Riding Wall St. on Autopilot: Indexed Funds Draw Investors

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Time was when most American investors chose their own stocks, one at a time. More recently they asked mutual fund managers to do the picking for them.
Now cocky, as the longest bull market in history continues without a substantial decline, many are deciding that they no longer need an expert to find the best investments. Instead, they are investing in mutual funds whose sole purpose is to mimic the performance of the stock market. 
 Known as index funds, these funds simply hold shares in all the companies that make up a popular stock market index -- for example, the 500 stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, which, after the Dow Jones industrial average, is the most widely followed market barometer. In essence, these funds run on autopilot, giving up the chance to do any better than the market average but also guaranteeing that except for the nominal cost of running the fund, they will do no worse.
The ascendancy of index funds has come as many Americans, exuberant over the winning performance of the stock market, are convinced that all that is required to make money is to be in the market -- period.
"Everybody remembers that the market went up 23 percent last year and 37 percent the year before that," said John J. Brennan, president of the Vanguard Group, the nation's second-largest mutual fund company. "When the market goes down 100 points in a day, it's quickly forgotten."
But even the people who sell index funds say that many investors appear to be full of misconceptions about the relative safety of their investment. Most notably, some novices have apparently mistaken the certainty that an index fund will match the market average for an assurance that it is an almost risk-free investment. In doing so, they have confused the diversification of their assets across a large number of stocks with the safer approach of spreading money among stocks, bonds and cash.
Index funds have been growing in popularity far faster than the mutual fund business as a whole. In the last decade, the amount of mutual fund money invested in the most widely held stock index funds has risen more than a hundredfold, to $65 billion -- a growth rate 18 times that of the overall fund industry. And much of that money found its way to index funds in just the last two years.
Indeed, the largest index fund, the Vanguard Index 500 fund, is gaining rapidly on the largest of all mutual funds, Fidelity Magellan. And now even mutual fund giants like Fidelity Investments and Merrill Lynch, which have long boasted of the stock-picking prowess of their money managers, have moved to offer investors more index funds of their own.
With their typically low costs, index funds are indeed one of the best ways to invest in the broad stock market, which has historically outperformed nearly all other investments. But what has caught the attention of recent investors is not just the long-run potential of index funds, but their short-term payoff. Over the last three years, index funds that track the S.& P. 500 performed better for their shareholders than did 93 percent of the 2,400 mutual funds that rely on money managers to pick and choose among a broad array of American stocks. (While index funds have done well recently, that has not always been the case: there have been long periods in which most of the actively managed stock funds outperformed the indexes).
Mr. Brennan of Vanguard, which is the largest seller of index funds, said he had heard an abundance of callers describe index funds as "safe options" earlier this month when he spent parts of several days answering calls from individual investors on the company's toll-free sales line. "That sends up all kinds of red flags for us," he said.
Partly, that misunderstanding is a function of ignorance, but it also reflects the fact that most recent investors have never experienced a bear market. More than 60 percent of the money in stock mutual funds, and 85 percent of that in index funds, has come into those funds since 1990, a period in which the major stock market indexes have never fallen more than 10 percent.
What will happen when the overall stock market goes down, of course, is that an index fund will fall just as much, perhaps even more. Unlike a general stock fund, an index fund cannot hold cash or other instruments to protect itself against a market decline. Moreover, the index funds, like the indexes themselves, are weighted by a company's market value. Therefore, movements in the price of the biggest stocks like General Electric, Coca-Cola and Exxon, have an outsized effect on the performance of the index. And it is those big stocks that have been the most successful in the recent market run-up. In a downturn, they might well fall farther than stocks that have not risen so much.
"If the market goes down, there's a good chance those stocks will lead the way down as well," said Melissa Brown, a quantitative analyst at Prudential Securities.
The growth of index funds has created a broader challenge for the mutual fund industry as a whole. Index funds, by their very nature, undermine the central tenet of the mutual fund business -- that individual investors who do not have the time to manage their own money should put their trust in a financial professional trading on their behalf.
But if index funds, which are much less profitable for the industry than traditional mutual funds, can consistently outperform professional stock pickers, investors are likely to demand better results to justify the higher fees that most mutual funds charge. Indeed, it is not clear that the industry's giants will be able to maintain the elaborate marketing and management structure they have built up if much of what they do is put on automatic pilot.
The rise in popularity of index funds also holds implications for investors generally, including those who have never used index funds. The last time index investing rose in popularity, in the late 1980's, pension funds and other so-called institutional investors were the driving force. This time, the trend has been driven by individual investors.
If the market turns down, and these less-seasoned investors become disenchanted, they might not just turn more cautious, as institutional investors tend to do in a bear market. They might also pull out of stocks altogether.
Investors are clearly pouring more and more money into index funds. A decade ago, index funds that tracked the S.& P. 500 had only $556 million in assets, less than half of 1 percent of the $146 billion in United States equity funds. Last year, though, assets in those funds topped $65 billion, or 4.4 percent of the $1.5 trillion in domestic equity funds. And of the $165 billion in new cash that flowed into American stock funds in the first 11 months of last year, index funds took in $15.2 billion, or more than 9 percent -- triple the portion of just two years before, according to Lipper Analytical Services.
Institutions, too, have been increasing the portion of their portfolios they devote to indexing. According to Greenwich Associates, a Connecticut investment research company, American pension funds last year devoted nearly 16 percent of their total assets, a larger portion than ever before, to stock index funds. Those assets accounted for one-third of the funds' holdings of American stocks.
The Oklahoma Teachers' Retirement System is putting $700 million -- more than one-third of its equity holdings -- into a fund indexed to the S.& P. 500, said Jo Witt, secretary- treasurer of the system. That will increase by more than five times the amount of the pension fund's assets indexed to the stock market.
"It's been difficult for active managers to even match the S.& P. 500 returns," Ms. Witt said. "And it will cost us a lot less to have index managers than active managers."
But the very factors that have made indexing so attractive could lead to its downfall. The growth in indexing among both individuals and institutions means that a greater portion of the stocks in the S.& P. 500 are being bought and tucked away in funds that hold them for a very long time. With less of those stocks in general circulation, buyers of individual stocks in the S.& P. 500 have to pay more for them.
Henry Kaufman, a Wall Street economist, explains that when more financial resources are indexed, active managers have a greater impact on asset prices. Therefore, he said, "what makes sense for an individual -- to avoid the risk of underperformance by settling for the average return of a market index -- collectively increases the probability that market values will lurch from one extreme to another."
Now, the amount of stock held in mutual funds and pension funds tied to the S.& P. 500 is at its highest level ever -- more than $500 billion, estimates Gus Sauter, who oversees the Vanguard Index 500 fund. That is equal to about 10 percent of the value of all of the stocks in the S.& P. 500.
The eventual result of an indexing boom, said Ms. Brown, the Prudential analyst, is that the stocks in the index could become overvalued when measured against traditional yardsticks like earnings and book value. "Those valuations have nothing to do with anything except that a stock is in the index," she said.
In a rational market, that imbalance would correct itself in the normal course of business. But sometimes the correction can be unnerving, as in 1990, when indexing last was in vogue. In the third quarter of that year, the S.& P. 500 fell nearly 14 percent.
Few individual investors probably realize just how concentrated in a few issues the performance of the S.& P. 500 has been, said Brian Hersey, director of investment manager research at Towers Perrin, a pension fund consultant. Last year, just the 25 largest stocks in the S.& P. 500, which account for one-third of the value of the index, rose 37 percent, accounting for more than the entire gain of 23 percent in the index. Over all, the other 475 stocks collectively dragged the index down. The same situation occurred in 1995 and 1994, Mr. Hersey said. And the S.& P. 500 itself represents only a fraction of the more than 9,000 regularly traded stocks.
While novices in the market may have misconceptions, certainly most investors understand that if the stock market as a whole goes down, so will their index fund. And some of them vow to keep on investing through the inevitable bumps in the road.
Loren Schwiebert, an assistant professor of computer engineering at Wayne State University in Detroit, said he regarded indexing as the best option for him. "I'm 32," he said. "I think it would be hard to find an actively managed fund that will do better than the index for the next 35 years -- or even 25 or 20. In that sense, indexing is a more conservative option."
But few neophyte fund investors recall a period like the five years that ended in 1982, when more than 80 percent of actively managed portfolios performed better than the S.& P. 500. That was clear to Mr. Brennan of Vanguard this month. After he spent a few days hearing comments from callers to Vanguard, he ordered that a special article be prepared for this month's newletter for investors.
Under the headline "Remarkable returns may raise unrealistic expectations," the article also warned, "Indexing isn't invulnerable."


GRAPHIC: An index mutual fund aims to match the performance of a popular stock market barometer, like the Standard & Poor's 500 index. That is most easily achieved by holding all of the index's 500 stocks. But overhead expenses dictate that most index funds will deviate somewhat from the performance of the theoretical index. Therefore, some funds buy only the stocks which, because of their size, account for the largest portion of the index's performance, and others use futures contracts or similar derivatives to try to edge closer to the index's performance.

HEADLINE: Tax-Free Savings Plans Urged in Albany for College Tuition

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
As college costs soar out of the reach of some families, legislators in Albany are considering plans to allow parents to start tax-exempt savings accounts for tuition while their children are still in diapers, or to pay tuition in advance at today's prices.
Twelve states have such systems in place, and as many as 30 more, including New Jersey and Connecticut, are weighing versions of the proposals. In Albany, the idea has the support of the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer, and of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat. 
 But several different versions are under consideration, and none of them is assured passage. Gov. George E. Pataki has expressed interest in the concept but has not taken a position. And Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan, made clear yesterday that he would use the popularity of the concept as leverage in his effort to stave off further cuts to higher education in New York.
"I don't want this to cloud the main issue, which is cuts to higher education," Mr. Silver said. But he added that he would study the proposals.
Under the College Choices plan proposed yesterday by Mr. Bruno and Kenneth P. LaValle, Republican of Port Jefferson and chairman of the Senate Higher Education Committee, New Yorkers would be allowed to put up to $5,000 a year per child into a savings account for college without having to pay state taxes on the money or the earnings that it accrued.
Under Federal law, Federal taxes are also deferred on the interest or dividends such accounts earn until the money is withdrawn, though the initial contribution is not deductible.
Modeled after Individual Retirement Accounts, the Family College Account could be used for tuition, books and other supplies, but not for room or board. The money could be used at any college in the state, public or private. But a family would have to pay a penalty, to be determined, if the child went to college in another state or if the money were used for another purpose.
If a family ended up with more money in the account than needed to pay for college, it would be returned without penalty and taxed at the child's rate, or it could be rolled over into another child's education account.
A separate proposal by Mr. Bruno and Mr. LaValle would create Prepaid Tuition Accounts. They would apply only to the public universities, the State University and the City University. Parents concerned about rising tuition costs would lock in existing tuition rates by paying that amount immediately -- $3,400 a year at SUNY or $3,200 at CUNY -- or by signing up and paying over a period of time.
A private investment manager selected by a state-appointed oversight board would invest the money, and the earnings would be put in the account. If there were more money than needed when the child went to college, the excess would be returned, although taxes would be due.
But in case of shortages, the state would make up the difference.
As with the savings account, the money in the tuition account would be subject to a penalty if not used for the intended purpose.
"All of us know what is happening to college costs here in this state and throughout the country," Mr. Bruno said. "They're escalating beyond the reach of many families."
Mr. Bruno said he hoped that it would be possible to reach a compromise with Democrats who have offered similar measures and to pass the bill this year and make it effective on Jan. 1. "I think the chances are very good," he added.
Such tuition savings plans have been widely promoted as inexpensive ways to help many families, particularly in the middle class, shoulder the growing burden of college costs.
With tuitions averaging more than $3,000 a year at public universities and more than $20,000 a year at some private colleges, higher education is often the second-largest expenditure a family makes, after buying a house.
"This is the wave of the future," said Brian Fitzgerald, staff director for the Advisory Committee on Student Financial Assistance in Washington.
For more than 20 years, tuitions for public and private colleges have risen faster than the rate of inflation, making college educations less affordable to many students. At the same time, state legislatures have cut financial aid to students and raised tuitions at public universities, which tends to hurt lower-income students the most.
This month, Mr. Pataki proposed a $400 tuition increase at the State University and the City University, as well as cuts in state tuition aid for students who also receive Federal support from Pell grants.
Many students have turned to loan programs to help pay for college. But concern is growing over the heavy debt that many students have taken on. And lower-income families are less likely to take out loans for college.
Not everyone, however, sees the new-style aid programs as a good idea. Edward C. Sullivan, Democrat of Manhattan and chairman of the Assembly Higher Education Committee, expressed concern over the potential costs to the state.
"It's a potential ripoff," Mr. Sullivan said. "No one knows what tuition is going to be in 18 years, and this is a commitment of money for future legislatures. Talk about passing the buck."
More affluent people, he said, are in the best position to take advantage of tax-free savings plans. "Is this really what we are going to do with taxpayer money, give Donald Trump a subsidy?" Mr. Sullivan asked.
Although the proposals would rely heavily on individual savings, the programs would cost the state money. Mr. Bruno estimated that by 2003, the two plans would cost $61 million a year.

HEADLINE: Syrians Struggle to Decipher Assad Clan's Dirty Laundry

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Syrian capital can seem a nest of riddles, and what has befallen the Orchid restaurant may be merely where the puzzle starts. A committee descended on the elegant French spot one day in November to shut it down, and it has remained so ever since, with a dangling door-tag signed "Corruption-fighting section, Ministry of Supply."
What most intrigues its patrons is that the restaurant is owned by a nephew of Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad. People who have begun to piece together other developments of recent weeks have begun to wonder what is going on. 
 One of Mr. Assad's brothers, Jemil, has departed abruptly for Paris, where another brother, Rifaat, spent part of a long exile. Rifaat al-Assad, now back in Damascus and officially still a Vice President, is reported by foreign diplomats and prominent Syrians to be under heavy internal surveillance.
The owner of the star-crossed restaurant was one of Rifaat al-Assad's sons, yet he was just the first among the relatives of top Syrian officials whose business activities have been unceremoniously reined in. At the same time, Bashar al-Assad, 31, the President's eldest surviving son, has been newly christened on posters that have emerged around the capital as "our hope" for Syria's future.
When asked, Syrian officials have said that Jemil al-Assad is undergoing medical treatment, that Rifaat al-Assad may move about as he likes, and that the Orchid and other shuttered enterprises were guilty of unspecified irregularities. But diplomats and some prominent Syrians say they believe that something else may be in the works.
With President Assad now 66 years old and recovering from prostate surgery, they say, he may be trying both to clean house and to clear the way for a successor. Those people say it is probably no coincidence that Bashar al-Assad, who was trained in Britain to be an ophthalmologist and who had apparently given no thought to a political future until an elder brother was killed in an automobile accident three years ago, has been portrayed recently in the Syrian press as something of a Mr. Clean.
"The President has had it with his brothers and their sons, and he's trying to do something about it," a prominent Syrian said, presenting a view that is widely held within the diplomatic and business community.
Jemil al-Assad, 64, who grew rich by extracting commissions on business activity in the northern cities of Tartous and Latakia, spawned so much resentment there that he has harmed the family's stature, the diplomats and prominent Syrians say.
They say that Rifaat al-Assad, 59, who assembled squadrons of tanks in Damascus in an attempt to overthrow his brother in 1983, is suspected of trying to renew his ties to upper echelons of the Syrian military. As for the Orchid, which opened last April in the capital's exclusive Maalki district, it had emerged as a visible sign of the dominance exerted by the sons of top officials over lucrative enterprises.
Jemil al-Assad's departure for Paris late last month has not been reported in the official Syrian media. Damascus-based diplomats said they have been able to confirm it only within the last 10 days. But together with a bomb that exploded in a Syrian bus on New Year's Eve, killing 11 people but not announced by the Syrian media until two days later, and the fact that President Assad has not been seen in public since his surgery on Jan. 7, the signs of maneuvering within the upper ranks of the Government have created a mood of unease.
"Things feel very fragile," said one diplomat. He and others said they were struck by the fact that while Mr. Assad was reported to have attended a Jan. 21 wreath-laying ceremony on the third anniversary of the death of his son Basel, the President was the only senior official present whose photograph was not published.
Syrian officials say he was probably not pictured at his son's grave because it was a personal family moment.
Mr. Assad has a history of heart trouble and diabetes, but there is no evidence that he is suffering from anything more serious now than the aftereffects of surgery.
It has been more than 26 years since Mr. Assad seized power, however, and people have begun to wonder whether the latest moves might be related to the question of who will succeed him.
Under the Syrian constitution, the leader of Parliament takes temporary charge upon the death of the President, to await the governing Baath Party's nomination of a candidate to be presented to the Parliament and to voters for ratification. Mr. Assad has said that he does not have an opinion about who should take his place.
Until his death at age 33 in 1994, however, Mr. Assad's son Basel had been widely mentioned as a potential successor.
An engineer, army major and the leader of the Presidential Guards, he was a popular figure whose picture was a fixture along with his father's in shops, on storefronts and in taxis around the country.
Bashar al-Assad, the second of Mr. Assad's four sons, had shown no interest in politics or in the military, the historic route to power in Syria.
But immediately after his brother's death, he cut short his medical studies to return to Syria and enroll in the military staff college, from which he is to graduate this April.
Basel al-Assad, bearded and wearing sunglasses, remains the far more visible figure on posters around Syria, where he is regarded as a national martyr. Since late last year, however, the image of Bashar al-Assad, with his dark mustache, has emerged to claim a place among a trinity that includes his father and brother and carries the caption "our leader, our ideal, our hope."
Even more conspicuously, Government newspapers have published glowing articles in which a high-level official has described the younger Mr. Assad as "the hope for continuity of Assad's way."
People who have met Bashar al-Assad describe him as a thoughtful, modern-oriented man who is interested in setting the Syrian economy on a firmer course. His areas of responsibility now include oversight of an information technology committee weighing whether to permit Syrians easy access to the Internet. And like his brother before him, the younger Mr. Assad has been prominently photographed meeting with officials in Lebanon, where Syria maintains 35,000 troops.
Some diplomats question whether Bahsar al-Assad has the will and tenacity to wage a battle for power within his own country, if that becomes necessary. On the broader question of peace in the region, however, there has been no suggestion that he might be a closet dove, and after nearly 30 years in which Syrian officials have steadfastly insisted that Israel surrender every inch of the occupied Golan Heights, it would be difficult if not impossible for any successor to Mr. Assad to forsake that course.
Still, the inner affairs of the Syrian Government remain murky enough that diplomats here sometimes liken their work to the Kremlinology of the old Soviet Union.
And the diplomats and prominent Syrians, who all spoke on condition of anonymity, say it is impossible to judge to what extent the recent crackdowns might have been intended to eliminate possible rivals to the succession and to what extent they were intended to rid the administration of a widening taint of official corruption.
Among those said to have been disciplined, only Rifaat al-Assad, the one-time leader of the Presidential Guard, is regarded as someone who might still aspire to take control. He was exiled to Western Europe after the tense military standoff on the streets in which he tried seize power from his brother.
With the President's permission, Rifaat al-Assad returned to Syria in 1992 after the death of their mother, and the younger Mr. Assad has never been stripped of his vice-presidential title.
He has wielded little power since his return, and diplomats here say that beginning in late December he all but dropped from sight. They say it was believed at the highest levels of Syria's military and intelligence establishment that he had tried to establish ties with key officers among the country's current military leaders.
Jemil al-Assad, who has focused his energies on commerce, was never seen as having political ambitions, but his Mafia-style control over business in and around the country's two main ports has made him an increasing embarrassment.
Among those who complained about his activities, prominent Syrians say, were not only the Sunni Muslims who make up the majority of Syria's population but also members of the far smaller Alawite sect to which Mr. Assad and his family belong.
"All indications are that President Assad finally came to see him as a liability to the regime," a Damascus-based diplomat said.
Similarly, neither Somar al-Assad, the owner of the Orchid restaurant, nor other sons of top Syrian officials whose business dealings have reportedly been restricted are regarded by people in Syria as rivals for ultimate power.
But the plainclothes intelligence agents around the shuttered restaurant and its Italian twin, La Dolce Vita, along with the reticence of local shopkeepers to talk about what happened, suggests that the young entrepreneurs took their quest for material gain a step too far.
In recent years, President Assad has conferred increased responsibilities on one Vice President, Abdel Halim Khaddam.
Because the Syrian Constitution requires that a President be at least 40 years old, many people believe that for the short-term, Mr. Khaddam remains his most likely successor. People who have tried to detect patterns in what has happened this winter, however, say that they believe that Mr. Assad has someone else in mind.
"Hafez al-Assad clearly wants to be succeeded by his son," one leading Damascus-based diplomat said. "And if you ask me whether all this is about securing the future or polishing the present, I would say that it is probably both."

HEADLINE: Budget Office Forecasts Rise In U.S. Deficit As New Trend

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
After declining for the last four years to $107 billion, the Federal budget deficit will begin rising again this year and will reach at least $158 billion in 2002, the Congressional Budget Office predicted today.
The estimates, which already assume that Congress and the White House will make progress toward a balanced budget, pose the scale of the problem they face as they prepare for negotiations on their tax and spending plans. The projections are in line with preliminary estimates circulated by the Congressional Budget Office last month, and are more than 25 percent lower than comparable estimates made by the budget office last spring. 
 Although the Congressional Budget Office is nonpartisan, the Republican leaders in the House and Senate have adopted its figures as a benchmark for developing their budget proposals.
The White House uses somewhat more optimistic assumptions about economic growth and spending, and the budget proposals it will send to Congress next week are expected to predict that the deficit will rise somewhat in coming years and then decline to about $100 billion in 2002.
President Clinton is scheduled to send his budget to Capitol Hill on Feb. 6, two days after delivering the State of the Union Message. Seeking to build public support for his proposals and fend off Republican calls for deeper cuts, Mr. Clinton has been unveiling selected parts of his spending plans in the last week.
On Tuesday, at his first news conference of the second term, he is expected to highlight his plans for college tuition grants and scholarships.
In part because it expects domestic spending to increase, the budget office concluded that the deficit this year would rise to $124 billion.
The budget office supplied its analysis to House and Senate committees today, and its director, June E. O'Neill, plans to speak about its findings on Tuesday, before the Senate Budget Committee.
The budget office's prediction of a $158 billion deficit in 2002 assumes that the White House and Congress can enact a plan that keeps the Government on a steady path toward eliminating the deficit in the years leading up to 2002. Without the economic lift that a balanced budget plan would create, the budget office estimated that the deficit in 2002 would be $188 billion.
Last spring, the budget office projected that the deficit would be $212 billion in 2002, assuming that policies to balance the budget had been put in place.
Much of the improvement stemmed from higher-than-expected economic growth and tax revenues and a reduction in health care costs.
In testimony prepared for Tuesday's hearing, Mrs. O'Neill said the deficit projections were subject to considerable uncertainty and would depend to a large extent on the pace of growth in the economy and in Federal programs like Medicare.
By factoring into its model a recession beginning in late 2000, the budget office estimated a deficit that was $100 billion higher than its $158 billion estimate, and by factoring in a booming economy in the next few years it estimated a deficit that was $100 billion lower, she said.
Even if Congress and the White House can balance the budget by 2002, "the situation will start to deteriorate rapidly only a few years later with the retirement of the first of the baby boomers and the continued growth in per-person health care costs," she said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 29, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the Congressional Budget Office's projections for the Federal deficit misstated the office's estimate for 2002. Assuming continued progress in balancing the budget, the office estimated that in that year Congress and the Administration would need to close a gap of $154 billion, not $158 billion.

HEADLINE: Atlantic City Casino Industry Is Facing a Chancier Future

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
At the start of 1996, casino operators here were making money so fast that they audaciously began to suggest that this city was on its way to becoming the country's gambling capital.
"We're outpacing Las Vegas," Donald J. Trump gushed then, as he pointed out that the total gross revenue for Atlantic City's 12 casinos in 1995 was more than that for the 18 largest casinos in Las Vegas. 
 With unbridled enthusiasm, developers rushed in, announcing expansion projects aimed at taking the city's casinos beyond their dependence on the region's day-trip gamblers and transforming them into Las Vegas-style entertainment attractions that would draw overnight guests from around the country.
A year later, the atmosphere is distinctly cooler. Revenues are stagnant, and legislators in Albany are about to vote on a proposal to legalize casinos in New York State. Although the large number of gamblers in the region still lures developers to Atlantic City and the city is doing its part by building a new convention center, improving the airport and expanding highways, casino operators have become more cautious about their plans to invest in this city.
Much of the excitement about Atlantic City started when Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Mirage Resorts, announced in late 1995 that he would build a $2 billion casino and resort on a former landfill, but extended negotiations have now delayed those plans.
Harrah's has said that it will delay a $325 million expansion of its casino near the Marina District. And Mr. Trump recently put on hold a $350 million expansion of Trump Castle. Since June, the stock price of Trump Hotel and Casino Resorts Inc., which operates Trump Castle and two other casinos, has fallen to $10.25, from $35.50.
There could be consolidation ahead, too, as gambling and hotel companies merge and focus attention on other markets. Hilton Hotels, which owns the Atlantic City Hilton and Ballys Park Place, has made an unsolicited $6.5 billion offer for ITT, which owns Caesars Atlantic City Casino Hotel.
In December, the Claridge, one of the smaller casinos in town, filed for bankruptcy, weakened by a recent drop in profits.
"The bloom has come off the rose in the Atlantic City market from a year ago," Timothy Wilmott, president and general manager of Harrah's Atlantic City casino, said. "There's a little more hesitation."
Then, there is the larger question of how many casinos can be built in one region before all start to suffer. Competition has increased recently, with these ventures in the Northeast:
*In Uncasville, Conn., the Mohegan Indian tribe opened the third-largest casino in the nation; since its opening in October, the casino has attracted huge crowds.
*In Delaware, slot machines were installed at horse tracks in 1996, and track owners in other states are pushing to be allowed to do the same.
*In New York City, a gambling boat is boarding passengers at Sheepshead Bay and taking them three miles out into waters where local restrictions against gambling do not apply.
*In Niagara Falls, a new casino opened in December across the border in Canada.
But the most ominous threat to the Atlantic City casino market is the vote in the Albany Legislature. The Senate is to vote Jan. 28 on a constitutional amendment that would legalize casinos in the Catskills, Niagara Falls and a few other upstate locations. The outcome is in doubt, and any amendment would have to be approved in a statewide voter referendum in 1997, but casino and industry analysts are watching closely.
"If gaming comes to New York State, it's going to have a very devastating impact on the growth and development of the Atlantic City market," said Marvin Roffman, a gambling analyst based in Philadelphia. He estimated that about 40 percent of Atlantic City's nearly $4 billion in annual gross casino winnings would go to New York.
So far, Mr. Roffman said, most industry officials do not believe that casino gambling will be approved in New York. But if it does, he said, "every gaming company that makes a commitment in Atlantic City is going to think that thing out very carefully."
Although some industry officials expressed concern that the regional market could become saturated, most contend that the demand for gambling around the country still exceeds the supply, citing the case of the Mohegan Sun in Connecticut.
When it opened in 1996, visitors to the nearby Foxwoods Casino, Connecticut's first and the country's largest casino, had to wait in line to get to slot machines and gambling tables. Since the Sun opened 10 miles away, the entire local market has grown by more than 25 percent, industry analysts said.
"I don't know if this is a great thing for the country or the world, but more people are gambling," Mr. Trump said in a recent interview. When a new casino opens in the region, he said, it eventually causes the Atlantic City market to grow. "Initially, these people might go to the Foxwoods, but then they want diversification, so they go to Atlantic City."
Indeed, Atlantic City, and its 40,000 casino industry jobs, is hardly in danger of dying. In fact, the city itself is in the middle of a period of enormous growth. A new $254 million convention center is nearing completion, the airport has been refurbished and a $120 million city beautification project is also under way. Some of the casino expansion plans are in the design stages and do not appear to be facing any significant problems, and plans for new restaurants and theaters are also in the works.
"Atlantic City is on the threshold of big change," Mr. Roffman said. "And it could go either way."
An important factor is Atlantic City's effort to revive its old status as a tourist and convention destination, which was based on the appeal of its beaches, instead of maintaining its current status as a gambling site that just happens to be on the ocean.
"It all will come down to what is built and what these places look like," Alan Feldman, a spokesman at Mirage Resorts, said. "The fastest way to get to saturation is to just keep building gambling joints." Mirage's plans call for a 2,000-room hotel and tourist attraction intended to draw people from around the world.
Engineering studies are under way on a highway and tunnel that would serve the Mirage development, and although one lawsuit filed by a group of community residents against the project was recently tossed out of court, other groups have threatened to file suit.
Sol Kerzner, a South African known for developing elaborate tourism and gambling resorts like the Lost City at Sun City in South Africa and the Atlantis in the Bahamas, agreed that Atlantic City's future would not be dependent on the surrounding region. Mr. Kerzner, chairman of Sun International and a managing partner in the Mohegan Sun in Connecticut, said that he believed that Atlantic City's future would be distinct from the gambling markets elsewhere in the Northeast. "We don't see this market competing with Connecticut," he said. "This market is broader."
As if economic forces were not daunting enough, casino owners here have also allowed their own internal bickering to continue. The industry's local lobbying arm, the Casino Association of New Jersey, abruptly disbanded in 1996, after members disagreed about over whether Mr. Wynn's Mirage project should receive tax breaks and other financial incentives. "Unfortunately, we couldn't work together on the issues," said Mr. Wilmott, of Harrah's, which in September became the first casino to withdraw from the association.
Other association members followed suit, dropping out and complaining that Mr. Trump -- with his three casinos -- wielded too much influence within the association. So instead of bracing themselves together against the market forces washing in around their highly regulated, billion dollar industry, each of the city's casinos is now left swimming alone, at a most uncertain time.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 30, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the economic prospects for Atlantic City casinos misstated the financial situation of the Claridge Hotel and Casino, and an article yesterday about the industry's reaction to a New York State Senate vote against casino gambling repeated the error. The company announced in December that it was seeking to negotiate a restructuring of its debt with corporate bondholders; it did not file for bankruptcy protection.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Good U.S. Data And Lack of Action by Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar passed 121 Japanese yen yesterday and also touched another two-and-a-half-year high against the German mark, spurred by evidence of American economic vitality and no sign of Japanese central bank intervention.
The dollar was also helped by sharp, if temporary, surges in the United States stock and bond markets, on economic data that depicted inflation as benign and put consumer confidence at a seven-year high. 
 Though stocks and bonds surrendered their gains yesterday afternoon, the dollar remained strong. Currency traders who had been expecting a pullback became buyers of the dollar instead, expecting it to test the 125-yen level.
"I think yen weakness will continue, and as long as that happens the dollar will move higher," Kisoo Park, a senior currency dealer at the Bank of Boston, said. "A lot of people fear they didn't catch this dollar move and want to buy on any dips."
The dollar touched an intraday high of 121.77 yen before settling in New York at 121.15 yen, up from 119.47 on Monday and up more than 3 yen in the last week.
Against the mark, the dollar's gains were more muted, partly because the German currency also strengthened in relation to the yen. The dollar climbed as high as 1.6515 marks, the strongest since June 1994, before settling in New York at 1.6485 marks, up from 1.6461 on Monday. The British pound declined to $1.6179, from $1.6231. The dollar was higher in most other currency dealings.
In the last four weeks, it has risen 4.5 percent against the yen and nearly 7 percent against the mark in a rally driven largely by stable interest rates and healthy growth in the United States, coupled with economic weakness and lower rates in Japan and Germany.
Beyond that, there was a notable absence yesterday of any sign that the Bank of Japan might enter the market to sell dollars to defend the yen. On the contrary, some senior Japanese officials suggested that the yen's decline was not worrisome.
The dollar derived further strength from a Labor Department report that employment costs rose only modestly in 1996 and a Conference Board survey showing the highest level of consumer confidence since October 1989.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Step Right Up

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
In the hype before the Super Bowl, The A.P. ran an article about "crazy betting." Las Vegas was not only giving odds on whether Green Bay would beat New England but whether Shaquille O'Neal would grab more rebounds that day than the Patriots would score points, or whether Brett Favre in the Super Bowl would have more passing yards than Tiger Woods would have strokes in the Phoenix Open. Now that the Super Bowl is behind us, Las Vegas will surely be looking for even crazier bets. I say bring foreign policy to Vegas. Ladies and gentlemen, place your bets:
Which will end first, the designated hitter rule in the American League or the American embargo on Cuba? Take the embargo. American League owners are even more pig-headed than Fidel Castro. 
Who will have to give back more money this year, the Democratic National Committee or Dennis Rodman? This will be close. They are both around $1.2 million already. But go with the D.N.C. It has even more weird stuff in its closet than Rodman.
Will President Hafez al-Assad of Syria lecture the new Secretary of State, Madeleine Albright, about the history of Syria at their first meeting in Damascus longer than the longest Major League Baseball game on record? Take Assad. The longest game is 8 hours 6 minutes, but Assad's season-average lecture is 9 hours 38 minutes.
Michael Jordan will average more points per game this season (He's currently at 30) than Bill Clinton will have votes in the Senate in favor of NATO expansion. Take Jordan. Even in an off year he'll outscore NATO.
The Jamaican bobsled team will win an Olympic gold medal before Japan will deregulate its economy. A no-brainer -- take the Jamaicans.
The U.S. will send troops to intervene in more new hot spots this year than N.F.L. owners will move their franchises to new cities during this off-season. Take the N.F.L. owners. They're greedy, Clinton's cautious.
Bibi Netanyahu will call Yasir Arafat either "my friend" or "my partner" more times this year than the number of times Sandy Koufax pitched on Yom Kippur. This bet's interesting. Koufax never pitched on Yom Kippur, so even one endearment from Bibi to Yasir wins a jackpot.
Which will be greater: the number of foreign-policy initiatives in the State of the Union speech or the number of American League pitchers who will win 20 games this year? A tough one. The answer on the State of the Union is likely to be zero or one, at best, but only two A.L. pitchers got 20 wins last season. Take the pitchers.
Which will happen first: Bobby Jones will win another Grand Slam golf tournament, or France will get its wish to take over NATO's crucial Southern Command? Bet on Bobby Jones. He's been dead 25 years, but he'll still beat the French.
Which will end first: the honeymoon between George Steinbrenner and Joe Torre or the one between Jesse Helms and Madeleine Albright? Since he won a World Series, Torre's probably good until the Fourth of July. Jesse's not that patient. Pick Albright and Helms.
A trifecta: The L.A. Dodgers pitcher Hideo Nomo will have a lower E.R.A. this year than double the German mark-U.S. dollar exchange rate, he will record more strikeouts than double the yen-dollar exchange rate and he will give up fewer walks per game than Japan's deficit-to-G.D.P. ratio. This one's too close to call. Nomo's E.R.A. last year was 3.19 and the double mark is now 3.28; he struck out 234 batters and the double yen is now 238, and he gave up 2.6 walks per game and Japan's G.D.P. ratio is projected to be exactly 2.6 percent this year.
Dennis Rodman will un-dye his hair, remove his nose ring and become spokesman for the Boy Scouts of America before Japan will deregulate its economy. Take Rodman.
Whose playing career will last longer: Cal Ripken's or Saddam Hussein's? Take Saddam, even if you have to give some points.
U.S. troops will still be in Bosnia after Toni Kukoc (a Croat) and Vlade Divac (a Serb) have both retired from the N.B.A. and returned home to the former Yugoslavia. Bet on U.S. troops still in Bosnia.
Hillary Rodham Clinton will make a three-point basket from center court at an Arkansas game -- blindfolded -- before Japan will deregulate its economy. Take Hillary.

HEADLINE: Auto-Seat Plants Hit by Strike

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Roughly 500 workers went on strike today at two auto parts factories, in Ohio and Michigan, to demand higher wages and better benefits, another sign of rising wage pressures in the Midwest.
At least 300 workers walked out at a seat factory in Plymouth, Mich., and 200 more went on strike at a seat factory in Oberlin, Ohio. Johnson Controls Inc. owns both factories. 
 Johnson Controls said this morning that it would try to continue production at the plants and was ready to bring in replacement workers to do so. But the Ford Motor Company, which has the best relations with the U.A.W. of any auto maker, said this afternoon that it would not accept any seats made with nonunion labor.
The highly popular and very profitable Ford Expedition sport utility vehicle, which went on sale last autumn, uses seats from the Michigan factory while the Ford Econoline full-size van uses seats from the Ohio plant.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.M. Says Profits Fell Throughout 1996

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Weighed down by some of the heaviest strike-related losses ever suffered by an American company, the General Motors Corporation announced today that its profits fell in the fourth quarter and for all of 1996 from a year earlier.
G.M. said that two strikes last October had reduced its after-tax income in the fourth quarter by $700 million, while another strike last March in Dayton, Ohio, reduced the company's 1996 after-tax income by another $500 million. Several industrial relations experts said that the total of $1.2 billion in strike-related, after-tax losses appeared to be a record before adjusting for inflation. 
 But after adjusting for inflation, a 10-week national strike at G.M. in 1970 was even more costly. Many economists cite that strike as making worse a recession that year.
The auto maker reported today that it earned $786 million, or 92 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, down from $1.6 billion, or $1.95 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. For all of 1996, G.M.'s profits fell to $4.96 billion, or $6.06 a share, from $6.88 billion, or $7.21 a share, in 1995.
Excluding five one-time charges and gains, the company earned 55 cents a share, or better than analysts had been predicting after General Motors encouraged them in December to cut their forecasts in half, to 49 cents. Excluding the strikes, G.M.'s operating results from North American automotive operations, foreign automotive subsidiaries, financing activities and the Hughes Electronics Corporation were all slightly better than a year earlier.
Wall Street analysts generally welcomed the results. "The fourth quarter is just a clear sign that their North American operations continue to improve and international continues to outperform in an environment that's getting difficult," Jack Kirnan, an auto analyst at Salomon Brothers, said.
But G.M.'s stock fell another $1.125 today to close at $60.75, as investors remained disappointed that the company only increased its quarterly dividend by 10 cents on Monday, to 50 cents. Many investors had hoped for a larger increase.
G.M. had one positive piece of labor news today as it reached a tentative pact to settle a three-day strike by 4,100 workers at its sport utility vehicle factory in Moraine, Ohio. The factory is the only G.M. assembly plant represented by the International Union of Electronic Workers.
G.M.'s share of the United States market fell to 30.2 percent in the fourth quarter from 33.5 percent a year earlier. J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, attributed the drop partly to lost production during the strikes, and predicted that the company would do better this year.
Some Wall Street analysts have suggested that with the dollar soaring in currency markets, foreign auto makers would be able to cut prices or offer greater rebates so as to hold on to the market share they have won in recent months. But Mr. Losh said that G.M.'s new models, lower production losses from strikes and a continuing expansion of its capacity to build popular light trucks would allow the American auto maker to sell more vehicles.
"We expect to improve both our share and our profitability in North America," Mr. Losh said.
While the rising dollar has hurt G.M. over all, other shifts in currency markets helped the auto maker slightly in the fourth quarter, particularly changes in exchange rates between some European currencies, he added.
The cost of rebates and other incentives was up sharply in North America and in Europe during the fourth quarter from a year earlier, although down slightly from the third quarter. Mr. Losh said that the increase reflected increased competition, partly because the dollar's strength has already allowed foreign auto makers to stop raising prices.
G.M. had three one-time gains in the fourth quarter of last year: a 9- cent-a-share gain from the sale of its stake in Avis Rent-a-Car, a 45-cent-a-share gain from various tax changes and a 26-cent-a-share gain from a reduction in the company's plant closing fund. The two one-time losses included 21 cents a share from the sale of four auto parts factories in Michigan and Ontario and 22 cents a share in extra pension costs associated with a new labor contract reached with the United Automobile Workers union last autumn. The auto maker also had numerous one-time gains and losses in the fourth quarter of 1995.
G.M. initially estimated the cost of a 17-day strike last March in Dayton, Ohio at $900 million, but reduced that figure today to $500 million. Mr. Losh said that G.M. had been able to make up part of the lost production during subsequent quarters.
The auto maker should be able to make up a portion of the $700 million lost in the fourth quarter, but the reduction in the strike's cost would probably not be as sharp as for the Dayton strike, Mr. Losh said. That is because the Dayton strike took place at the end of a quarter, while the two strikes in October came at the beginning of a quarter and part of the production was made up before the end of the quarter, before calculating the $700 million figure.
Any extra sales and profits during the first and second quarter of this year that may be linked to the October strikes will be credited to these quarters, and will not be used to restate last year's results, Mr. Losh said.
Profits at the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, which makes car loans, rose during the fourth quarter to $274 million from $263 million a year earlier. Hughes Electronics reported on Monday that it earned $281 million in the last quarter, which was down from $326 million a year earlier. But excluding a $45 million loss related to the strikes, Hughes's profits rose slightly.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: More Spanish Accents, But Fewer Are Cuban;
New Latin Faces in a Corner of Queens That Once Seemed More Like Havana

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
From the glass door of his Junction Boulevard barbershop, Rafael L. Fiallo, Cuban immigrant and Queens resident for 28 years, peers into the street where his American dream has come true and, suspending scissors and comb in midair, wonders out loud, "Where has everybody gone?"
The neighborhood has changed, he declares. Not long ago, this stretch of Junction Boulevard and Roosevelt Avenue, the line that both separates and connects Elmhurst, Corona and Jackson Heights, was dotted with Cuban businesses and familiar faces. Now, the old restaurant that served authentic Cuban dishes across the street is owned by a Mexican and tortillas are the main fare. The beauty parlor is a grocery store. And Mario's Jewelry, where Mr. Fiallo used to buy birthday presents for his wife and children, is a Peruvian-owned party-goods store. 
 Mr. Fiallo does not recognize the faces anymore; he cannot even identify the different Spanish accents that flow in and out of his barbershop. And, perhaps what matters most to him, nobody knows who he is, either.
"I used to stand outside and people would walk by and wave, 'Hey, barbero,' people who didn't know my name but knew who I was," Mr. Fiallo, 65, said. "Now, I go outside and nobody calls out."
The neighbors who used to greet Mr. Fiallo were Cuban immigrants who settled in New York in the early 1960's as the Irish and the Germans were moving out, and who have in turn moved to the suburbs or to Miami. With their departure, other immigrants, from Bangladesh to Ecuador, have moved in.
But because New York is such a magnet for Hispanic immigrants, for the most part Latino has replaced Latino in this corner of Queens, both changing and reviving the neighborhood, creating a mix that is no longer Cuban or Colombian. Nor is it just Dominican, Peruvian or Mexican.
Instead, the new immigrants have formed a pan-American neighborhood where each immigrant group takes from the others as much as it gives. But because they have retained a strong sense of national pride and origin, they do not jump in the proverbial melting pot. Their American experience is more like a salad bowl, where ingredients lie side by side, mixing but somehow retaining their particular look and flavor.
"They are creating a true American culture, with ingredients from everywhere in Latin America and a large dose of elements from the United States," said Jose Prince, a professor of sociology at La Guardia Community College. "They have shed some of their national quirks to come together under a Hispanic banner."
It is, in part, a practical decision, since there are not enough members of one nationality to prevail, and because, they say, it is the best way to coexist in harmony and to succeed in business.
"You either adapt or you perish," Jose Vizcaino said, donning a bloody butcher's apron behind the meat counter of his tiny Elmhurst supermarket, El Mundo. "As a businessman, you have to adapt."
Mr. Vizcaino, a Cuban immigrant, remembers a time when he did not have to work too hard to please his customers' whims. He knew Cubans liked a lean boliche (round-eye beef) and big palomilla steaks (top sirloin). But a few years ago, he had to learn that what Cubans call boliche is muchacho for Colombians and colita de cuadril for Argentinians.
"The first time someone asked me for a muchacho, I blanked out," said Mr. Vizcaino, who has since added to the shelves of his supermarket an array of products from Peru, Ecuador and Mexico. "I don't know what they are, but the customers ask for them, I write down the orders, get them, and they buy them."
Even Mr. Fiallo, who claims to miss the old neighborhood, has adapted. Through the years, he has hired several non-Cuban employees and has learned how to decipher his customer's orders -- what Cubans call a hair cut, pelado, is in Colombia a slang word for adolescent boys.
In Rincon Criollo, a Cuban restaurant on the Corona side of Junction Boulevard, Cuban coffee is no longer made the traditional way, in which sugar is mixed with the coffee as soon as the first drops seep out of the percolator. It is, admits the owner, Rodovaldo Acosta, a concession to patrons who may have less of a sweet tooth than Cubans do.
In another bow to their international clientele, they have hung wooden maps of all the countries in the Americas, right above the black and white pictures from their old restaurant on the outskirts of Havana.
In El Yumuri, the bakery next door to Rincon Criollo, the Cuban owner, Manuel de las Cuevas, is raving about his new addition to the menu: tres leches, a Central America delicacy made with three types of milk. And across the street, next to El Mundo, the flower shop owner Luis Molina is well aware that Colombians prefer orchids. But Mr. Molina, who is Cuban, keeps red roses on hand for the few Cubans who still patronize his shop, D'Gardenia.
There is a private side too to this intermingling of nationalities and tastes. Neighbors have become friends, who dance at the same salsa club Saturday night and pray at the same church Sunday morning. And more and more these days, neighbors marry.
Javier Arenas, a retired handyman from Medellin, Colombia, says his Colombian friends tease him because he speaks with a Cuban accent. He cannot help it, he says, since most of his friends are Cubans. He plans to return to his native city, but when he does, he will take with him his cherished recipe for Cuban moros, a traditional rice dish, and his newly acquired taste for Mexican tortillas.
And Maria de los Angeles Macias, who arrived from Mexico just two years ago, says she is already addicted to Cumbia, a Colombian dance, and merengue, a Dominican rhythm.
Emilio, Fausto and Jose Heredia, three Cuban brothers who own Emilio III Cocktail Lounge, in Elmhurst, are married to non-Cuban women. Emilio married a Peruvian; Fausto, a Colombian, and Jose, a Salvadoran.
Fausto Heredia, who speaks with a Colombian accent, says his wife's accent has prevailed not only with him but also with their two children. But, he says with a smile, he has prevailed in the kitchen, where his wife has learned to cook Cuban foods. In the bar, he employs bartenders from Colombia, the Dominican Republic and Peru.
Both decisions, whom to marry and whom to hire, were influenced by the fact that it has become difficult to find Cubans in Queens, Mr. Heredia says. Cubans are the only Hispanic group whose numbers decreased in Queens in the decade between the 1980 and 1990 censuses.
"I don't remember the last time a Cuban client came through that door," he said, pointing to the wooden door of the family's dark, working-class bar on the Elmhurst side of Junction Boulevard. "But I do keep bottles of rum in hand, just in case."
To be sure, this Queens salad bowl is not without its sour ingredients. Some shop owners who publicly say they want to please their new clients as well as people who claim to love the diversity in their buildings, privately complain of the "quality" of some of the new immigrants, who are poorer, younger and more transient than the established, older immigrants.
But even some of those who criticize the newer immigrants acknowledge that their presence has made these neighborhoods a true Hispanic enclave, where food and products from every country in the Americas are available everywhere, and where the sheer size of the Hispanic population has forced establishments and institutions to offer services in Spanish.
In the stores that line Junction Boulevard, employees and shop owners speak Spanish, though they may not know how to speak English. Muti Shuaib, the Palestinian owner of a furniture store that occupies the spot where a popular Cuban bodega once was, communicates in Spanish with his mostly Dominican and Colombian clients. And in St. Joan of Arc, a Roman Catholic church in Jackson Heights, two Spanish-language services have been added to accommodate the needs of an ever-growing congregation. Three years ago, there was only one.
Mr. Prince, who left Cuba in 1964 and has lived in Queens since 1970, says the new immigrants have injected new blood and vibrancy to an area that just a few years ago began to show signs of decay. The continuing revival of the area may bring some of its former dwellers back, he says.
He is encouraged by the early signs. Lately, he has begun to notice that the children of the Cubans who once fled New York in search of the sun are returning to the city of their childhood in search of jobs, the same magnet that pulled their parents here over three decades ago.
"They may not speak Spanish, but when they hear me speak English with my Cuban accent, their ears perk up," Mr. Prince says. "And many times, they remember Queens."

Map: "Changes On the Street"
 Once largely Cuban-American, the stretch of Junction Boulevard from Roosevelt Avenue to 43d Avenue in Queens has changed in recent years. Asian entrepreneurs now own a pharmacy and a photo shop where once was La Fuente Espanola, a Cuban restaurant and bar. A Mexican owns what used to be Cuban restaurant across the street. These and other changes are shaded on the map. (pg. B1)
